reviews.review: Must in Shibuya. This is to me the 1st thing to do in Shibuya, nice temple in the middle of Yoyogi Park. Free entrance

Beautiful Nature In The Middle Of Tokyo. A very beautiful with a beautiful Shrine. It's a great for a walk and see some Japanese culture. There is trees from all over Japan planted there. Definitely worth a visit and free.

Love it. I went there every time I had a visitor coming. It is a wonderful place. The entrance is magical, the path is unique (you step from one world to another). There are many festivals happening there which makes it even more exciting! Scrolling around at any time of the year is an experience in itself anyway! I don't want to say anything about.... Between Harajuku and yoyogi park (to be seen for both on a Sunday) don't miss it out (even if you are not a "temple person")

The Meiji Jingu Shrine. THE MEIJI JINGU SHRINEMeiji Jingu is a Shinto shrine in honour of the devine souls of former Emperor Meiji and his Empress Shoken. Emperor Meiji (1852 to 1912) the great great grandfather of Japan’s present Emperor, had ascended the throne in 1867, and the Meiji Restoration had followed in 1868. After more than two centuries of isolation during the Edo era, Japan had opened up to the outside world through the initiative of Emperor Meiji. That had led to enormous cultural and social changes in Japan, and may have changed the course of its history. The shrine was set up in November 1920, and is almost a century old. It is a “shrine for national peace and prosperity”. Its serenity makes it a “place of calm” in the heart of the bustling and vibrant city of Tokyo. Out of respect for Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken (who had passed away in 1914), the Japanese people had donated trees from all over Japan as well as from abroad, to set up a forest in which their souls could dwell in peace. That currently forms the Outer Garden of 74 acres. The gate of the Grand Shrine is made of a 1,500 year old Japanese Cypress, and is 12 ft high. The Inner Garden is of 173 acres, and is a natural forest that has graced that site for long. The main shrine is constructed entirely of wood, and has large thick pillars. It has a Japanese-style roof covered with green tiles. The interior is not open to the public and no photography is permitted. Japanese people who go to that shrine to offer their prayers, drop coins, clap their hands twice, bow twice, and clap their hands once again.There is a Treasure Museum on these grounds that displays the personnel effects of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. Among these is a horse-drawn carriage they had used. The beautiful Iris Garden had been designed by the Emperor himself. There is also a large pond, well stocked with coloured carp fish. Visitors can drop them peanuts, and watch them rush to get their share. Floral plants like Azaleas, cherry blossoms and dandelions add to the serenity and beauty of Meiji Jingu.Hormuz P. Mama(373 words)
restful place. the true spirit of Japan in here. you feel so small in front of it: I can't describe how beautiful it is. loved it! hope next time to come back in spring.

Peaceful place to walk. I enjoyed spending a couple of hours coming here as a peaceful respite. There are lovely wooded paths, not crowded, plus the shrine itself. The south gate area was under repair, but there are still nice photo opportunities. I saw a wedding taking place. The wish tablets are very moving. I also was struck by the sakes and Burgundy wines along the pathway. Definitely worth a visit if you are looking for a nice walk!

Serene beauty in lovely park and interesting Wall of Wine and Sake Barrels. Set in a tranquil park, it is a majestic and tasteful Shinto shrine dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shōken (and quite different than the colorful Asakusa Temple also worth a visit). Very interesting to observe the cleansing and praying rituals, and pleasant walk through the park. Also very interesting, is the wall of French Wine barrels lining the entrance road (or exit for us since we entered north) to Shrine which were gifts to the Emperor from wineries in Bourgogne, France and is set right opposite from a wall of Sake barrels. From what I learnt, the emperor took the lead by promoting modernization, started wearing Western clothes, sheared his topknot and began eating Western food...and particularly enjoyed wine with his meals. Well worth it as part of our exploration of Shinjuku, walking from Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building and its free observatory from which you can see Mount Fuji on a cloudless day (view from south tower is better), northwest of the park, and exiting south east of park into Harajuku area. Quite an interesting contrast going from such a serene temple and park to Harajuku hip youth and its fashion statements--fun to observe--and later on the local version of Times Square that is Shibuya crossing. As I found myself carrying unnecessary burden, keep in mind that there are no outdoor garbage cans in Tokyo as it is customary to take one's garbage home; you can find garbage can in subway restrooms. It it is also quite impolite to drink or eat on the street or on subway, and is not done.
Must visit. A must-see for first-timers. It would be advisable to have a tour guide so you will learn more about the history and culture of Japan.

Meiji Jingu Shrine in Repair. The shrine and gardens are amazing, the walks some of the best in Tokyo, unfortunately we visited during an upgrade to the central ground, but I know a small thing amazing spiders and webs in the trees, I wish we had time to walk all the paths, some of the most amazing history, the link to French wine and Japanese Sake unbelievable, I am truly Honoured to have gone

Was a nice breezy walk. Not a fantastic park but definately rich in culture. The biggest difference between other parks and Meiji Shrine is you instantly feel you are in Japan due to their trees. Lovely, breezy but thats about it.

Tranquility in Tokyo. I took a walk along the shopping area from Omote-Sando station to the shrine and back again. It's quite contrasting. The shrine is set back its peaceful and beautiful. The trip took me about 3-4 hours at a leisurely pace. I had a morning to kill on a business trip when my schedule changed. I really felt like I'd been in Japan!

Visit everytime I'm in Tokyo. Other than the main shrine, it has a garden and a forest walking up to the main shrine. As it is one of the famous shrines in Japan, it is always crowded with locals and tourists. Some locals choose to have their wedding ceremony there too, if you are lucky you may get to see one (but please stay respectful, it is a private wedding ceremony and not a show). Its close to Harajuku, so definitely worth going

Sanctuary in a bustling city.. Meiji Jingu Shrine is nestled amongst a tranquil green forest, right next to Harajuku station. The main complex is a good 10 minute walk from the station and is popular with bus loads of tour groups. You can buy votives and amulets as souvenirs, or a copper roof shingle (3000 yen) you write your name and a wish which will then be affixed to the roof which I thought was an interesting idea. We were lucky to see a Japanese bride and groom wjen we visited as it is a working shrine.

Meiji jingu. The entrance to the shrine is just behind the exit of the JR Harajuku station... from the entrance is about 10 mins walk to the main shrine building you can Pay respect and make a wish. Overall there's nothing much to see... All can be done in less than an hour.

New Year's Eve midnight worship is not to be missed.. The worship is actually not the main thing, which involves waiting in line to enter the temple in freezing temperature. That said, after the worship, there are plenty of street stores set up in a clearing near the exit, hot food are served to warm you up. Eating there is the real event, in my opinion.

Worth the time for a visit. The Meiji Shrine is much more crowded on the weekends so if you don't like crowds visit during the week. BUT, if you want to see something special ... maybe a wedding or a festival ... then get ready to deal with the crowds on a weekend. It's easy to get to on the JR system and is right next to Harajuku if you want to do some people watching.

The most visited shrine in Japan. This shrine is the most visited in Japan, it has a steady stream of people coming and going the whole time and is definitely worth the time.It's near the fashion Harajuku area which is also definitely worth seeing, especially at night, grab a famous Harajuku crepe and walk down the street shopping and taking in all the colourful and amazing fashion.The walk to the shrine is a pretty one along a wooded pathway with towering trees overhead, it's a longer walk than I expected it to be and we felt sorry for the couple of tourists with suitcases who obviously thought they'd make a quick stop.When you get to the shrine you will see the gifts (hundreds and hundreds of dolls and stuffed toys) placed there along with a tree with wooden plaques where you can write your wishes down and have the priest pray for them/ you each morning once pinned upon the tree.I enjoyed looking around this shrine, but if it's a peaceful, restful place you're looking to come to, to pray than personally this wouldn't be my choice.

A Must See In Tokyo. The Meiji Jingo Shrine is one of the largest and probably the most visited Shinto shrines in Tokyo. it is an impressive place . The walk from Harajuku station through the Yoyogi Park is also a very pleasant experience. Take the Yamanote Line (green and silver) and exit at Harajuku and it is all well signed.

Beautiful shinto shrine. Meiji Shrine is one of Tokyo's most beautiful shrines. It is located close to the Harajuku station. In order to get to the main shrine you walk through a forest-like park, which we really enjoyed. The shrine itself is also lovely, of course. Even though there are many visitors it exudes a calm and peaceful atmosphere.

A gorgeous Park. Meiji Park gets mobbed on New Year's eve. It is a great place to put on your visit itinerary, its entrance at the trendy Harajuku shopping area, a young people's town. If you are coming with kids, note that Meiji Park has an all-year round ice-skating rink and a baseball batting range. You can stroll for square kilometers in this park.

Not my favorite shrine, but lovely setting. I've seen prettier or more impressive shrines but this one was set in a forest, with a long, peaceful forest walk to get there from the main torii, so I have to give it 4 stars. Plus it's free, so you can't go wrong there!
Wasn't that impressed frankly. You can't wander around too much, there was some sort of ceremony going on today so that was kind of neat to see, but other than that there wasn't much.

Man-Made Forest in the Heart of Tokyo. This is a great place to enjoy a quiet walk and relax in the shades of trees, especially if you get tired of the busy streets of Harajuku. It's surprising to know that the forest is man-made, and only about 100 years old.There's also a good chance that you'll be able to see a traditional Japanese style wedding if you go there during the weekends.

Come again...and agsin. Having been to both top shrine's in Tokyo - both are wonderful but this has the edge. Beautiful, serene walk through the trees. I saw a wedding and I think that they do tea ceremonies too. Worth it just to get out of the hustle of Tokyo. Once out head straight back into a fab row of shops and also head to the amazing gyoza place near by...

A nice excursion inside Tokyo to see a great shrine!. Meiji Shrine is a must see in Tokyo! It is worth getting there. You get transported in time and space and you get to find yourself in a great park and palace! We were lucky to see a wedding taking place, too.

Shinto shrine. Came here as a part of a day tour of the city. Not really knowledgeable about the Shinto religion, and still not after this visit. The setting was great, in a wooded area amongst the hustle and bustle of the city. Due to the language barrier, could not comprehend much of the ideology of the religion and so the shrine was somewhat lost on me. Were allowed to take part in the rituals of cleansing our hands and making a wish to the Shinto gods, but felt like a bit of a fraud as I was clueless to it all....It was obviously a big shrine and those with a religious interest would love it. Still haven't understood the 100s of colourful Sake barrels lining one of the entrance roads....

Lovely trees and traditional wedding. The shrine itself was nothing special. Loved the forest and the walk to the shrine. Lots of trees and fresh air.Saw a wedding during our visit which was a great experience. Walked through the garden area which was lovely.
Lovely green spot in city. Despite all the people, this is a lovely green space in the middle of all the bustle, easy walk around. Would be nice if there were places to sit and rest or contemplate...

Meh-ji Shrine. This is probably a very nice shrine to visit if you've not already been to other shines/temples in Japan. We live in the area, so there was nothing new for us here - though it is a very beautiful area. I suggest a good walk thru Yoyogi Park as a better alternative.

Fantastic shrine especially if you get to see wedding processions. . This is a shrine well worth visiting. It is a pleasant walk through the forest to the shrine and we saw three different wedding processions which were wonderful.
I expected more. aybe by the time I went, I did not find anything surprising. The gardens were with carelessness. The good thing was that we see a traditional wedding with spectacular costumes.

Quite, serene shrine. Right in the middle of busy city is this nice place to escape in solitude and reflection. Lots of Shinto structures.
Have to walk on gravel with some cemented sidewalk before reaching the purifying water and then the huge square where the temples are.

Scenic and serene but long walk. It's a long walk to the main temple, but it's also a sanctuary of peace and quiet from the hustle and bustle of the city. It's hard to imagine that this tranquil oasis is right in the middle of Tokyo. The temple itself is ok....but as I had just came from Kyoto, I wasn't really moved by it. Rather, I enjoyed the shaded and relaxing stroll to the temple more.
Beautiful & Peaceful Shrine. Yoyogi Park and the Meiji Shrine do not disappoint! Great, quiet walk in the park to the Shrine, where you can cleanse your soul before entering the shrine.
Relaxing afternoon. Away from the hustle of the city this is a great destination if you want to relax. Very serene and wonderful walks particularly mid week to avoid the crowds.

Beautiful and serene. Along with those paying their respects, there are hundreds of tourists visiting this shrine...and for good reason. It is absolutely beautiful and serene. After a 10 minute walk to the shrine from the gate, there is an area to purify yourself by washing your hands with water before going to the main shrine area. Once on the main grounds, you will see a courtyard area. We were lucky enough to see a woman in full kimono taking photos in front of the shrine. Whether you purchase a token of your respect or take photos, it is worth the visit.Allow yourself 40-60 minutes to fully wander around on the shrine grounds. I would love to return.

My favourite place in Tokyo. Fantastic place to visit! There is a lovely walk through the park to the shrine and you really feel you have left the city behind. The shrine area itself has stunning trees and a real sense of tranquillity and spirituality, whatever your beliefs. I'd highly recommend the garden you can pay to visit. There are fish and turtles in the pond and when I was there a local man had a tame bird on his finger. The teahouse is a historic building rather than a working teahouse (much to my disappointment). The only letdown was that the Treasure House was unexpectedly shut when I visited.A special place, yet so close to the bustle and shops. Not to be missed!

Nothing special . We visited this temple as recommended by many sites but found it greatly disappointing. The temple is not as old as the site. When you approach the temple you are asked to give money before paying your respects, which we found very offensive. The walk up to it was nice as you don't see these size trees in every city. Trip was worth it for seeing a wedding taking place, but that was sheer coincidence.
sacred place. beautiful shrine in Tokyo. a massive Torii looked impressive. not easy to get to the main shrine though.

Oasis In Tokyo. What a peaceful and enchanting place... The gates are awesome and we were lucky to see a wedding procession at the shrine... Gorgeous costumes included. I wish we had more time to just take in the atmosphere and visit more of Yoyogi. Beware the shrine closes quite early at 5pm, so don't do Harajuku first as time there just flies. It is No1 for a reason DO NOT MISS.Even better: FREE

Shrine visit. Even the air was better. So many people were visiting. The 10 minute walk to the shrine was probably better then being there. It is currently under refurbishment. Still very nice to visit.

Peaceful and Respectful in every way.... Exquisite and revered in every possible way.Waking on the path to the shrine, you are surrounded by beautiful trees and it is so peaceful.There are a few shrines but the main one, you can scoop some water to wash your hands, buy some good luck fortune of different kinds, write some wish or blessings to hang up and also do the traditional pray.You don't need more than an hour to venture there but its definitely the best hour spent in our stay at Tokyo.
Beautiful but not a must. Beautiful and calm shrine inside the busy city, but not a must, if you are limited by time you can skip it.The bath to the shrine is very beautiful.

A bit of a walk to the Shrine, but nice walking grounds and a good way to spend a couple of hours of your day.. The Meiji Jingu Shrine entrance is the coolest way to enter any site. The barrels of Sake was fun to see on the walk to the shrine.

Nice stop within Yoyogi Park. Hard a great walk in the park, and a very interesting visit tot he Meiji Jingu Shrine. Its a bit touristy, but provides a chance to see traditional Japanese culture without traveling outside of Tokyo.

Decent shrine but enjoy the path and walk there . The Meiji Jingu shrine is a short 15 minutes walk from the Shibuya crossing. The entrance and surrounding area of the Meiji Jingu is better than the actual shrine itself. Most of the shrine is currently under construction. We came here on October 7th 2016

Most Revered Shrine in all of Tokyo. The Meiji Shrine was a nice stop on an overcast day. It is usually thronged with tourist groups, though that speaks to how revered and visited it is. I recommend that you get there the earlier the better. There are alot of trees, so there should be shade on a sunny day day. It has a wide open plaza at its center, great for taking in the whole of the structure. When my wife and I visited, we were very fortunate to observe a Shinto wedding. Also, feel free to purchase a tablet to hang on a sacred tree dedicated to Emperor Meiji and his wife. There are very interesting reading from travelers all over the world.

Peaceful visit on a rainy day. Visited the Shrine mid morning on a Saturday. It was very busy even though it was raining. It is a beautiful wooded setting that you would not expect to find in the middle of a busy city. There was not very much information about the shrine itself so taking a guided tour is not a bad idea if you are interested in the history of the shrine.
Relaxing time. We went to visit different cultural and traditional places around Shibuya. We went to a park and found this great place. Not a must see tho!

Beautiful. This shrine is in the middle of a park in Tokyo. It's a really nice walk where you are surrounded by nature and it's actually peaceful and quiet (which you wouldn't think since Tokyo is huge with so many ppl)

Very nice shrine in a calm and beautiful area. The shrine itself is very nice, but of course there are many tourists. The roads in this area are soothing and there are some places were you can have a picnic and rewind from Tokyo's more lively parts. The big leaf trees are especially beautiful during spring time.

Rainy Day provided lots of atmosphere!. A misty and cloudy day provided a surreal quality to the walk through the deep forest. Really enjoyed the ravens making lots of noise drowning out the sounds of the people. The Shrine was very good. We were lucky enough to see the departure of a wedding group, featuring a very lovely bride in Kimono. We were leaving at dusk, so all the lanterns were turned on, felt like I was part of a Hayao Miyazaki movie, maybe Spirited Away?

So spiritual. I was totally amazed with this Shrine. Buried within a great forest it stands so great with an historical architecture. I saw lots of people bringing their babies there and they are dressed very formal. I beleive there is a ceremony they carry out for these babies (something like baptising maybe). Shrine totally reflects their culture. It is a must see place from the time of Meiji who in fact first opened Japan to foreign world.
Lovely shrine.. One of the oldest. Very busy. The day we visited there was a wedding going on and lotts of tourists visiting.

Heck of a shrine!. We visited Meiji Jinsu Shrine on a rainy day. The rain had moistened the pathway, making it harder than usual for worshipers and travelers. On the way to the shrine, clouds gathered again and the intermittent rain resumed. The inclement weather stopped no one from marching forward to the world heritage. Here we were, finally setting our feet in front of the house of Japanese deities. On the way back, the rain started again. I was thinking: maybe the shrine itself is not the attraction I'd hoped to see, it's the walk between.
Beutiful shrine. Escape the craziness of Harajuku by walking thru the lovely gardens to this beautiful shrine - go on a Saturday and you may get to see a traditional wedding

Nice Shrine. We got off the train at the JR Harijuku station near the Yogoji Park. It's calming to walk along tree lined paths leading to the main shrine building. Along the way we saw sake and whiskey casks. On the day we visited to saw a procession of sumo wrestlers walking solemnly to the shrine to ask for blessing i presume. Japan had such a ritualistic culture.

Lovely Respite in the City. This is a "must see" attraction in Tokyo. Large grounds and a beautiful wooded walk through peaceful grounds as you approach the shrine. It feels like you've left the bustle of the city even though you remain right in the middle of it. Never having been to one before, I was fascinated by the purifying ritual before entering. And the shrine itself is a beautiful structure well worth seeing.

A beautiful shrine in a lovely forested area. Walking the forested trail to the shrine makes for a serene experience. The shrine itself is beautiful but most of all, it is its forested surrounding that makes it very peaceful and beautiful. A nice place to spend some time while in Tokyo.

Nice but Park's Much Nicer. Visit to some local friends elicited the recommendation, at parting, to visit the Meiji Jingu Shrine "just near the subway station, and by the way there is a nice park there too". We visited the shrine which didn't do all that much for me or my (adult) son. But the park where it is located is a different story altogether. In a separate review, I awarded the Yoyogi Park five stars. I do not want to denigrate the shrine, and perhaps someone with more knowledge of Japanese history, culture and religion would relate to it more positively than I.

Beautiful forested part of Japan. Surrounded by seemingly endless forest (which was actually established just over 100 years ago), the 10-minute walk to the entrance sets the mood as a very serene place. The shrine is one of Japan's most revered.People from all walks of life come here to seek blessings on their family, career, etc. You may be likely to see executives, newlyweds, babies, school kids etc. take the trek with you.If going there on a rainy day, definitely bring an umbrella/poncho/raincoat (a souvenir shop at beginning of walking track should stock them if you are caught short).And remember to fold the umbrella down & put your camera away as you go up the stairs to the shrine itself.

Strength and beauty. Stunning, enormous entrance to the wooded pathway to the shrine. The strength and beauty are breathtaking. Unknowingly, we were there on respect your elders, national holiday. It wasn't overly crowded, but because of the holiday, here were many weddings/wedding processions, and also baby blessings happening, which added to the beauty of the visit. The grounds are so calming and centering, in the middle of the large skyscraper city of Tokyo. An absolute must see.

A Must See and Visit. In my opinion one of the most beautiful spots in Tokyo. A quick walk from Shinjuku takes you to a Yoyogi gate and through a nice walk through what can be described as a divine forest. If you make it early enough, there is a sumo ceremony at 10am (60min) which I would recommend. The shrine, the wooded area and the gardens are Really good! I would highly recommend to walk to and from here!!

Lovely peaceful experience.. Enjoyed the walk through the beautiful park. The shrine area is currently undergoing renovations and the sound of carpentry was a little distracting. The pathways are small pebbles or gravel which made pushing a stroller a little hard.However overall the feeling of peacefulness prevails. A must do when in Tokyo.

Great and calming atmosphere!. The forest that we had to walk through passing lots of sake and wine barrels made me feeling very calm and relaxing even if there were lots of other tourists there. We were so Lucky that we could watch a couple of wedding parties and wedding ceremony which was so interesting, and the bride and groom in traditional costume. The Shrine was beautiful. I think this was the Shrine I enjoyed most during my trip to Japan.

Stunning. It is a flat gentle rising walk from the parking area to the shrine through a beautiful woodland of cypress trees.You pass a display of rice sake drums and wine barrels before passing under the enormous tori -gate.Meji jingu is Japan's most splendid Shinto shrine built to honour Emperor Meji and Empress Shoken.

Weddings galore!. The walk through the trees to this popular shrine is delightful, as are the displays of sake barrels and wine barrels. Visiting on a national holiday, the shrine was particularly crowded but is nonetheless spectacular.We were also lucky to be there on a busy day for weddings and we saw several fascinating processions.The visitor facilities are good and we were able to rest and relax for a while in the cafe-restaurant for a refreshing iced tea (although the aircon was a bit extreme after the heat of outside!).This beautiful shrine is definitely worth a visit.

Walking tour. This is a great place to visit if only to escape the hustle and bustle of Tokyo for half an hour. There are quite a lot of similar shrines in and around Tokyo, this is one of the busiest.

Okay but not much acess. The park is in the natural style that Japanese parks seem to have, there was much of the park cordoned off for some reason, so not sure if there was more to see. The shrine was not as spectacular as others I've seen, but we had a pleasant walk

Wonderful experience. On arrival you see the striking torii gates. Walking through the camphor trees there is a peaceful feel to the area. The shrine in celebrating 100 years so there is some small renovation of the copper roof going on between August and October 2016. This does not detract from the whole experience. The shrine is still in use so you see priests and of course many tourists. The shrine and buildings are all traditional. You learn the cultural ways of respect washing of your hands / bowing and clapping in the tradional way.it all adds to the understanding of the culture. We were there at 0930 so the area was not busy which was great. I would definitely try to go early.

Beautiful, serene, and traditional wedding took place as bonus. The care for this shrine is obvious with every step. It is very clean and busy. Plan to some "share" time when trying to get a good view of some immenities and features. There was a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony taking place that was a marveous bonus! Check out the sake barrels upon entry. A wonderful place.
Cool place. . A really nice park. Very serene. I would recommend this place. It's tucked in a beautiful shady park.

Meiji Jingu - An Oase amidst Tokyo steel and bricks. Many has reviewed this. So to avoid repetition, I would only say this - a must-see even if just to enjoy the oxygen-rich and lush garden. For history-enthusiasts (me included) head off to the museum in the area also that explained thw meiji restoration and learnt why the Emperor was considered half-God and revered by most Japanese. 100 K trees were donated on his deaths and became the park as it is. Excellent for picnic with family also.

Beautiful experience. This was an amazing place and experience. It is stunningly beautiful both in itself and the grounds. There are good spots of shade if needs be. Make sure you get a guide leaflet as this provides a great background and history.

Beautiful city. We join a tour from Tokyo! Close by Harajuku if you're interested in spending the day exploring this city. Great experience to see and visit - a must see. A beautiful, serene park and gorgeous temple.

Quite a long walk in the heat but worth it . This is a must see if you're around the Yoyogi Park/Harajuku area. Walking along the forest paths towards the temple is really peaceful although it is quite a long way (especially in the summer heat and humidity). Once at the temple it's nice to sit down and take in the surroundings for a while. The sake barrels along the way make for a good photo op as well.

Zen in Tokyo. This is perhaps my favorite place in all of Japan. Although it's near noisy Harajuku, this shrine is very peaceful and quiet. It's well maintained and beautiful. I especially recommend it if it's your first time visiting Japan.

In exploration of the religious heritage of Japan. From the elegant winding avenue that leads to the mammoth wooden gates to the scale of the buildings and courtyards, it is possible to imagine guards on horses, protests praying endlessly, the sounds of drums calling parishioners to vespers. This is a beautiful preserve in the middle of the city, intact from Meiji times, actively used as a shrine--a place for Shinto weddings and christenings. If you're lucky you'll,catch a ceremony in process.
Enjoyable Walk. Close to JR train station.Nice but long walk towards the shrine.Huge gates or "Torii" at the entrance.Beautiful and peaceful park/gardens/shrine.No entrance fees & toilets available.

Beauty in City!. Visit this spot on your tour of Tokyo! Close by Harajuku if you're interested in spending the day exploring this side of the city. No matter, great experience to see and visit - a must see. A beautiful, serene park and gorgeous temple - include in your visit if you can!!

Wonderful site if you can attend a sevice. Pure Shinto and we were able to attend a service for babies to press for good luck.
Interesting service and well worth the 20 minutes and walk in the rain

A walk down decades of time. The walk to the shrine proper is arguably more than half the reason to visit the shrine. The trees, planted nearly over 100 years ago create a canopy above the path that is unique to say the least. Perform the purification ritual before entering the quintessentially minimalistic shrine.

Great Shrine and walkway through the forest. This was a great shrine to visit - especially the day we went we saw a traditional Japanese Wedding. Its a great walk to the shrine through the forest. The only down side was that it was raining on the day but it wasn't too bad as we came prepared with umbrellas
Greenery place. Great Greenery in the heart of the city. Very calm and cool place. You can experience complete Peace .

Enjoy the Wonderful Temple and the Park that surrounds it.. It is within walking distance from Shibuya Metro station. There is an even closer JR station if you prefer. The gorgeous Meiji Temple is situated within a park with 100,000 trees brought from various parts of Japan. There is the gigantic Temple Gate at the entrance with other gates located in different parts of the park. On the way to the Temple from the entrance, there is a nice display of sake barrels with different paintings on them. The stand symbolizes spirits and people. Very impressive park in an urban area. The woods provide a peaceful get away from the bustle of the city.
So beautiful . Loved the walk to the shrine. So serene and peaceful. Some construction happening at the moment but nothing too bad or disruptive.
Lovely!. Nice to visit all these places in Japan! This one was really nice and the weather was nice so could stroll around.

Shrine with strolling grounds. At the northeast shrine entrance (from the Shinjuku neighborhood) there is an information booth, where there was a spray bottle of insecticide for use. It's free, so make use of it as there were plenty of insects buzzing around. There are many photo opportunities. There were also free toilet facilities for use. (In fact, Mt. Fuji was the only place we encountered that required a fee/donation to use the toilet.) We enjoyed a quiet stroll along the many tree-shaded paths in the shrine area. We exited through the southeast (Harajuku) exit.
Good walk . Good for walks as the area is very big and not to mention if you're a Pokemon Go player, this area is full of pokestops.Be sure to go and visit the area as a whole.

Peaceful and beautiful, an oasis in the midst of busy Tokyo. This was an oasis in the midst of busy Tokyo for us. Entered through the large Torii gate at the south end of the park, then enjoyed a shady, peaceful walk up to the shrine itself. Passed the barrels of sake and wine along the way, an interesting sight. Was lucky enough to see a traditional Japanese wedding processional as we arrived at the shrine. Very nice, very traditional and an added bonus to our visit (which was on a Saturday) Visited the gift shop on the way out and found some nice small souvenirs to remember our visit by. Very close to the station so that made it easy to find.

" Beautiful Grounds and Shrine ". This shrine is like a huge forest park, with beautiful trees right in the middle of the city of Tokyo. Along the walk to the shrine they have several wine barrels with some very expensive wines from all over the world displayed. They also have a huge display of Sake barrels for you to look at. The shrine itself is very big and has a copper roof on all the buildings. A great place to visit, that makes you forget that you are in the noisy city of Tokyo.

One of my favourite temples in tokyo. If you get the green circle line train to harijuku, walk across the bridge and you'll see the entrance to the temple. It's a lovely walk in with loads to see on the way in any photographers dream. It's hard to imagine you're in a city. If you walk straight through out the other side you come to yoyogi park & station which is on the green circle line.You may be lucky enough on a Saturday to see a wedding

Quiet, authentic and powerful. I was just in Tokyo for a day and a half, and wanted to see one attraction while I had the chance. I walked to the shrine early on a Sunday morning and it was such a beautyful experience. The park is big and the trees are green and huge and so different than in Norway. There were some people there who walked to temple, but evertying was so peaceful and quiet. The gates and temples are powerful and I love looking at the Japanese architecture. I don´t know how it is later in the day, but I recommend Sunday morning walk around 6:30 for a good zen moment.

Green and fresh shrine to go... it is good place to see traditional wedding as well. This shrine is really like a huge park.It is so green and it is good to walk around.From this station to the shrine can take around 15 - 30 mins of walk.It can be reached through Harajuku train station or Meijijingu-Mae metro station.The entrance is free of charge.If it is lucky, traditional Japanese wedding ceremony can be seen during the weekend.And if you believe in lucky charm, you can try also to see your own fortune by buying 500 Yen for your own charm.

Must see, forest in the middle of tokyo. it is a huge forest in the middle of tokyo , when you vising this place you will feel in a real forest and not in one of the most crowded cities in the world.the shrine itself also nice. get ready to spend abou 2 hours here

Very special place. Definitely my favorite shrine in the capital city. It's simply so huge, so soothing, so plain yet so beautiful. Once you've made a step after the great torii that's marking the entrance of the sanctuary, you simply forget you were in Tokyo just a second ago. The noises of cars and people got replaced by the sounds of cicadas and wind in the trees. You forget everything and just relax. Pure magic right there.
interesting visit. near JR Yamanote line harujuku station. free entry. if you are lucky, you get to see traditional wedding procession through the courtyard.

Shrine of "significance" though not "too grand" :). Being the shrine honoring Emperor Meiji & his wife, it should not be missed while in Tokyo, but don't expect to see a grand shrine (like Nikko's Toshogu Shrine) as it is a pretty ordinary shrine though yes the main shrine building is a "fairly big" one.I got there from the north side entrance which is on the north side of Yoyogi Park - went through the torii gate there, followed by a 5-to-10-minute walk to the grounds of the Shrine which is kind of like a courtyard with the main shrine building on one side and corridors on the other sides (with bonsai tree displays in some and like long benches for people to sit & relax in some). And there are some other smaller buildings & structures too right outside the main shrine grounds area; but it was past 5 pm when I got there, so those surrounding ones were pretty much all closed, and I was just thankful the main shrine was still open! For leaving the Shrine, I want to suggest leaving from the south side where you'll go through the 'Grand Shrine Gate' which is the "largest" wooden torii gate of that particular style in the whole country (as the sign nearby says) and where you'll also see displays of sake & wine barrels on shelves (with an info sign nearby that says Emperor Meiji started to drink wine from the West to show his people that the western food can be included in the Japanese diet). There's also a gift shop on the south side, not too far from the main shrine grounds; most importantly, right beside the south-side gate (upon exiting through the torii gate there) is Harajuku Station (a small station with just JR Yamanote Line but you can take a short train ride from there directly to Shibuya Station where you can connect to a lot more lines).Also, Shinjuku Gyoen (a pretty decent park with a beautiful French Garden) is just about a 10-min walk away from the north entrance of this shrine (the entrance I came in on the north side of Yoyogi Park as mentioned above; I got here after leaving Shinjuku Gyoen from its south gate called Sendagaya Gate; the south side of Shinjuku Gyoen and the north side of Yoyogi Park are in a fairly close proximity to one another).

Steamy visit to the Shrine. An oasis of peace and tranquility in the middle of hectic Harajuku, the shrine has beautiful woods in which to wander and a few traditional buildings to see.There was a beautiful traditional Japanese wedding going on. Go for a nice walk and to catch your breath. There's a little area with a café where you can get a snack or drink for a reasonable price and get refreshed before tackling Harajuku.

Interesting . The cultural insight into Japan was obvious in this shrine. Starting with the washing of your hands, writing a wish on a tablet or paper to the typical Japanese wedding that I got to see. Amazing beauty!
1hour is enough. This is one of the must do list if your nearyby harajuku which you will coincide with a visit at yoyogi park, shibuya cat streets, omotesando and takeshite st.

Forest in the middle of the busy city. I've visited Harajuku many times, but never been to Meiji Jingu before. When I first stepped into the wooded path towards the main shirne, it was like stepping into a different world. Tons of green, birds chirpping, and absolutely no noise from traffic, trains and shoppers who are eager to drop some money on some Harajuku goodies. It was a very nice walk and a change of pace. The shirne itself was amazing. Very open and a good mixure of regulars and tourists. Will definitely go again.

Make a Wish here. This is one of the most popular and important Shrine for locals. The name indeed to remembering the Meiji Emperor and his Empress.Located right after we come out from Harajuku Station, there is entrance ( South Entrance ) with typical Shrine Gate ( Torii ) and very dense population of big trees ....amazing if compare to the dense concrete building surrounding this very huge park including Yoyogi park at the south.As most shrine, the hall is the prominence building and for Meiji Shrine, it has some paid area, The Inner Garden, with entrance near the Main Hall ... we don't know what so special till we have to pay cause we don't go inside.Another point of interest is Amulet office which from here we can get a wooden tablet to write our wish or wishes and hang it onto a hook under a big big tree ( see photo ) or ... we can bring it home. There are two building near the Main Hall which named Treasure Museum and Anex, but again it is not free to enter ... but if you are fancy of Japanese culture 500 yen is nothing.

Beautiful park in Shibuya (close to Shinjuku's hustle and bustle). This park/shrine is located just south of Shinjuku, in the Shibuya area. If you want peace and tranquility after a day out, go here. Lush green trees and vegetation, a place for a peaceful stroll and to make a wish at the shrine.
On your list to visit. The area id great to visit and the shrine is well worth a visit. There is renovation going on with one of the gates, but the rest you can see.

Meiji Jingu Shrine. It has a well cultivated and lush garden. The surrounding trees are also nicely planted and arranged. During the weekend you will find many elderly Japanese and their family coming in troves due to perhaps the historical and also cultural significance of this place. We were pleasantly surprised by two traditional weddings conducted within the vicinity of this shrine. The married couples together with their families were wearing the traditional Japanese Kimonos and forming a train of procession led by a Shinto Priest who presided the occasion .I would recommend the end of March and beginning of April for those who fancy the magnificent blooming season of the Cherry blossom .Apart from the classical and traditional Japanese buildings one can also enjoy and appreciate the architectures and artistry of diverse poles, structures and buildings which make up the shrine. Some areas of the shrines are out of public as they are still functioning religious and cultural Centres to the local Japanese. Not far from this shrine is the Imperial East Garden or Kokyo Higashi Gyoen. It is another beautifully maintained garden with small lakes and bridges. An ideal place for photo taking especially with the splendid Cherry blossom in full bloom!.

Beautiful Shrine. A Beautiful Shrine close to Harajuku / Shibuya ! A must visit for the tourists (along with Senso-ji) if you want to see the Japanese shrines (especially if you're not going to Kyoto for some reason). Serene atmosphere, Beautiful Shrine with lots of walking areas. If you're lucky, you might see a traditional Japanese marriage happening.

Tranquility in the middle of bustling Tokyo. You would never know you're in one of the world's largest cities. This park is amazingly large, beautiful and tranquil. Plenty places to look, artistic things to see, a cafe or two, a beautiful temple and loads of history. A must see for those who love parks

Great way to get away from the city . After a day trip to Nikko this left a lot to be desired. The park and trails surrounding it are however a great escape within the city. It is only 100 yrs old. If you have a ton of time go. If you are tight skip it and put your time together for day trips to Nikko or Kamakura
Mega Meji. Beautiful green park-esque road to the big Meji shrine. When you're lucky, you see a Japanese traditional wedding. Must go visit, near Harajuku.
Serene and beautiful! . Definitely worth a visit to the Meiji shrine for first timers in Tokyo! It's a bit of walk to get to the main shrine but it's serene and beautiful! We enjoyed our visit

Beautiful. The walk through the park to get to the Shrine was stunning and peaceful. On a hot day the trees provide reprise from the heat. The shrine was as expected beautiful and on a quite day I would imagine it would be peaceful. We were lucky enough to witness a traditional wedding procession at the shrine too.

Plain beautiful . Perhaps the most beautiful shrine in the Tokyo Area. Sheltered in Meiji Park.
It's a 10 minute walk from Harajuku station.
perfect scenery. went there during winter, it was very crowded but I had a cool experience seeing people around there walking to the shrine for praying

Beautiful shrine in the middle of the park. Visiting here was a lovely experience! Unfortunately the shrine was under a construction so some parts were covered. However, it was beautiful and the park itself is worth a walk!

Excellent shrine and great for walks. We hit the Meiji shrine area the first thing we arrived in Tokyo. Easily accessible (as everything else in Tokyo) and a great area to start off with. It's a great mix of the buzz around Tokyo with a sense of calm around it. We also got to witness the local talent show with various dance displays which seemed like they were from the various prefectures of Japan. Fantastic gardens around the shrine and was a great start to our trip.

Peaceful. Someone suggested we visit on a Saturday and we were pleasantly surprised with two wedding parties. Witnessing the entourage complete with priests from the shrine was the highlight of the visit as the bride and groom were in their traditional outfits, something you only see in guide books or documentaries. The shrine is located in a very peaceful area. Harajuku is just on the fringe of the forested area giving you a contrast to the area. Pleasant visit accessible by metro.

Mypiglife review . The entrance to this shrine is unbelievable serene and somehow magestic as you are surrounded my tall trees and a peaceful sense of nature. The shrine itself is simple as you go there and pray or make your wish .The museum for 500 yen is worth it if you want to learn more about the history of Emperor Meiji who basically modernized Japan.
Love it. Even on a drizzly day the walk through the park was fantastic. The Shrine is busy with good weather so get there really early

Peace out. Amid the Tokyo hustle is this historic and venerable shrine. A place of peace and wonderful architecture set in a massive park in the heart of this city. The walk through the gardens to get there was worth it. Leaving the shrine and exiting the park into Harajuku is a great counterpoint. A highlight of Tokyo.

Relaxing walk through a forest in Tokyo. We visited a lof of great parks in Tokyo during our stay and for me, this was my favorite one. As soon as you enter, you enter a new world. The sounds, the shadows from the trees and the calm vibe, it's like you just take part in a Ghibli movie!

Worth a visit if you're in Shibuya. This shrine / garden is right in the heart of the city, and Shibuya JR station has an exit right at its entrance. So if you are going to Shibuya, it's worth going in. However, I don't think it's spectacular. And it's very crowded, and not quiet at all! Went there on a Saturday afternoon in January and there was this endless long queue to get into the temple!! See my picture here.If you want to visit nice old temple, I recomemd Karakuma which is just a 45 minutes ride away from Tokyo station by train.
Excellent first Tokyo visit. We went early before the crowds and it was beautiful and peaceful. Lots of trees, within walking distance from Shinjuku. One of my favorite places!

Spacious Ground Awesome Experience. I was explained by the guide that's this shrine was completed and dedicated to the Emperor Meiji and his Empress Shoken . It was destroyed during the Second World War and was rebuilt after , if you get a chance to go to harajuku the shrine is right at the back of the harajuku station . Be prepared also there is some renovation work going on now as a preparation for the 100th anniversary celebration in 2020. My experience is just wonderful , it's just large Forrest are within this city , the ground are so spacious and has many walking path and it's just nice to walk while enjoying the scenery . The main complex is about 10 -15 minutes walk from the entrance . When you enter this shrine there is this huge gate which is called " torri gate". What's astonishing is that, I think maybe thousands of trees that make up shrine and that is remarkable . You will love it as for me it just gives a lot of peace and calmness in my mine . This is one of the most popular shrine in Japan so if you have the opportunity please do visit .
One time deal. It was really a beautiful place with many things to see and do. Great for people of all ages to see.

Ancient Shrine. The shrine is located in the city centre accessible by subway and it is completed with big greenery garden with thousands of 100 years old trees planted in the Meiji era. It served as a shrine for young couples getting married and pray for good health
Weddings. I visited the sanctuary on sunday afternoon. Despite the number of people it s calm est fresh compared to chibuya. I saw a lot of traditional weddings. Magic
Breath taking. Amazing greenery in the center of Tokyo. Great shrine to visit so Zen and relaxing. Must visit. Good for walks and pictures in nature

Nice and calming from busy day. The walk to the shrine from the JR station isn't as bad as some other review said. It's about 20 minutes walk. This is nice and serene. Very quite with the cricket sounds that soothes your mind. Enjoy the nature and quietness as you walk to the shrine. If you don't like quietness and nature, then this is not your attraction.
Sightseeing. A great place to enjoy nature in the heart of Tokyo. A great place to unwind from the city and the stress that comes from being on vacation.

Greens in the city. Despite the number of tourists, the place is relaxing. You feel you are one with nature. It is also a good cultural experience. But I advise you go to other places apart from the Shrine. Go to the museum and nearby dojo. The pathwalk to those places are so serene. It feels like you are in medieval Japan.

Serenity . Peaceful walk in the gardens leading to the shrine, quite a contrast to Tokyo's fast pace. We chanced upon a wedding entourage in traditional Japanese attire-- lovely scene amidst the cultural setting of the shrine edifice and lush park greens.

Extraordinarily peaceful. This is a lovely, peaceful sanctuary in the middle of the busy city. The walk along the gravel walkway through the woods prepares you for the shrine. We enjoyed our visit very much.
Amazing cultural experience. For those who are interested in knowing more about the japanese culture and its religion, it's a great and peaceful place for meeting with friends and family
Pretty shrine. A relaxing walk through the tree-filled park leads to this shrine, which is nice to look at, though close-up pictures were not permitted. Free to enter.
Peace and tranquility in a busy area. Just loved walking through these magnificent tropical gardens to the temple. So quiet and luscious vegetation all around. Free too

Nothing Special!. You can skip this place if you have a limited time. However it deserve to visit the park and also the shrine. In late August there is dance festival by different groups all around Japan. So plan to be there at that date if you want to visit.

Very nice walk in the middle of an urban forest. This is one of the unique experiences we had in Tokyo, Japan.Coming out of the Harajuku Station on the JR Yamanote Line, we found ourselves walking in the middle of a dense forest in middle of Tokyo. A short walk later, we were in the shrine, which is very peaceful, and well maintained.We would also recommend you to visit the Inner Garden where there is a pond, and a well.

Newer Shrine. If you go here before you go to Kyoto you will be impressed. There are over 7,000 trees which have been transplanted here from all over Japan. It is a beautiful space. The shrine is newer, but a nice addition to the park.

Delightful . We took a walk in the park that surrounds the temple, it's wild and impenetrable. The temple is big but you wouldn't see it if you were 100 meters away. We were lucky and as it was the weekend we saw a wedding party for a Shinto wedding enter the shrine. It's a gorgeous building but there is some restoration underway and a part is concealed. Worth seeing!

Amazing shrine and gardens. The Meiji Jingu shrine is a must do on any trip to Tokyo. The shrine is free for access and within a short walking distance from the metro station. The park surrounding the shrine is great for a relaxing walk or picnic. A must do when in Tokyo

Shinto shrine in a beautiful setting. A lovely shady walk along a wide gravelled road edged by huge cedar trees brings you to this impressive Shinto shrine. It's a real pleasure to witness the goings on of a working shrine, watching people buying charms and trinkets and praying, we were privileged to be there as a marriage ceremony took place.
Tourist visit. Lots of amazing history here. It was great seeing the ancient carvings and all the cool stores....:) must have a camera hit the shops up too it's a must

Enshrined beauty. You'll love it here if:- the idea of exploring a Shinto shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken sounds fascinatingReconsider if:- it's crazy hot out, or raining heavilyA fair amount of walking is required to reach the Shinto shrine. Once there don't miss the temizuya (手水舎), a water-filled basin for symbolic purification of the soul. Simply use the ladle to rinse your left hand, your right, then pour water into your hand for rinsing your mouth. After you're done, let the remaining water run down the ladle's handle and that's it! You've washed your hands, your mouth, the ladle and you're ready to approach the main shrine.When standing before the shrine, whipping out your camera is only going to invite dirty stares from the locals. Instead, why not throw a coin or two into the offertory box and make a wish Japanese style? Just bow twice, clap your hands twice, then make your wish and finally, bow one last time.If you're visiting in the summer do bring along mosquito repellent! Alternatively you can ask for some at the entrances.

Interesting Shrine. A very nice and interesting Shrine with 2 beautiful huge gate. Need to do a little a bit of walking to the Main Shrine but worth the walk for the first timer. Managed to see a ceremony during my visit.

A Fitting Tribute to a Great Emperor. It was Emperor Meiji who resisted internal opposition and brought Japan kicking and screaming into the modern world. It is therefore fitting that the shrine dedicated to this great emperor is one of the most important shrines in Tokyo. Set in a woodland park, this traditional shrine is absolutely beautiful, and it speaks to the elegance of the country. It is a popular place for traditional weddings, and on the weekend you are often going to be treated to wedding processions that again harken back to the grand days of the old empire. Every visitor to Tokyo should go to the Meiji Jingu Shrine.
Meiji Shrine . This is a Shinto Shrine, locals still use it to pray. The place is wide enough and lot of big tree grows here. To reach the main shrine we need to walk along the garden for about 2km

Nice time at Meji Jingu Shrine. This was a very energizing, spiritual experience, to come to this place where people come pray and find peace. Love reading the prayers left by many visitors and found some in Spanish :)
One of the essential sights of tokyo. I've been to the shrine in two separate seasons and it always has a beautiful aura about the place.i would recommend starting a day in Harajuku here.
Serene grounds. Temple is beautiful and the grounds are as well. It gets crowded but even so you are able to see everything

New Year Japanese style. Visiting a shrine after New year in Japan is a cultural experience and standing in the queue with 100000 others waiting for the clock to hit midnight New Year's Eve puts into perspective how many people live in this megacity.
Very Good Shrine. Went here first thing in the morning to see this shrine. It is surrounded by a big area and involves a little walk but nothing too bad. It is a nice shrine and has many visitors.
Very nice park with lots of shadow. We went there on a very hot day, because of the trees we had lots of shadow so we hd a good time there

Must Visit. Meiji Jingu is a Shinto shrine. Shinto is called Japan's ancient original religion, and it is deeply rooted in the way of Japanese life. It's located just beside the JR Yamanote Line Harajuku Station, Meiji Shrine and the adjacent Yoyogi Park make up a large forested area within the densely built-up city. The spacious shrine grounds offer walking paths that are great for a relaxing stroll.The wooden torii gates at the entrance to the shrine are 40 feet high. It's hugely impressive!!Tips while visit: At the torii (shrine archway):1) Bow once when entering.2) Bow once when leaving.At Temizuya (font):1) Rinse your left hand.2) Rinse your right hand.3) Pour water into your left hand.4) Rinse your mouth.5) Rinse your left hand again.6) Rinse the dipper (allow the remaining water to run down the handle of the dipper).Please do not touch the dipper directly with your lips, and please do not throw coins into the water.At the main shrine buildings:1) You may put some coins into the offertory box.2) Bow twice.3) Clap your hands twice.4) You may make a wish if you like.5) Bow once again.Please do not take photos or videos close to the main shrine buildings.
Worth the visit. A very nice park in the middle of Tokyo with a beautiful shintoist shrine in the middle. It is close to other interesting spots such as Harajuku and Omotesando.

Impressive Shinto shrine. Whilst in Tokyo we made sure to go and see the largest and most famous Shinto shrine of Meiji Jingu and we were not disappointed. Really close and easy to find from the Harajuku station (Omote-sande exit) this place felt a million miles away from the hectic streets nearby. The wooden gates (Torri) at the entrance are hugely impressive in scale and are a teaser for what lies within.Be sure to watch and follow the 'purification' ritual before entering the main shrine - fascinating experience. We were also lucky to see some couples getting prepared for wedding ceremonies in traditional dress!
Must see . If u come so far, make sure u have tour guide, the top and all small details start making sense and u see it from different eyes.Enjoy

Number 1 recommendation from lonely planet. Unless you love culture this is not the place for you it was interesting and everything but honestly there wasn't much for me personally. Worth going though but not a whole day trip or anything.

shrine for free but some of the attarction gonna cost you. the shrine is located beside JR harajuku station, deep in forest giving you quiet and peace feeling, this shrine gonna takes time for 1 hour long to explore
Beautiful Shrine. We went on a Sunday around 11 and were able to see a couple in traditional Shinto wedding ceremony attire. The shrine was beautiful and the Torii were awesome.

An oasis. So happy I made the time to visit. The contrast between the city and the peace I found here amazed and calmed me. I imagine it will look even more beautiful during the spring blossom or autumn seasons.

A serene visit. The shrine is set deep in a serene park. The walk to the shrine is as pleasant as the shrine itself as you meander through a tree-lined path with a couple of enormous Tori gates along the way. It is a well used shrine as even on the weekends and in 30 degrees plus heat you see people all dressed up praying at the shrine. It was a nice respite from the hurly burly Harajuku.
nice. located in the yoyogi park,very peaceful shrine.well maintained. theres a garden next door,entry fee is charged which is beautiful.
Unmissable shrine. You can't miss Meiji Jingu if visiting Tokyo, it's a very beautiful shrine in an incredible park.Suggested.

Beautiful, peaceful sheine. We only had one day in Tokyo and wanted to show our kids (ages 11,10) some history of Japan. we were staying in Shinjuku so we took the green Yamamoto train line to be able to see a few key things. We stopped at harajuku station to get off for the Meiji shrine for emperor Meiji. What a beautiful walk through the trees to the main shrine. We enjoyed waking around and reading things about the history of the location. May have been better with a guide who could have told us more. But a great impression for the whole family

Really beautiful - but undergoing major rennovations at the moment ahead of 2020 anniversary. The shrine is located in a really busy part of Tokyo - the entrance being only a minutes walk from Takeshita Street in Harajuku - but you would never know because the woods and the shrine is so peaceful and calm. The walkways up to the gates are beautifully maintained and the Shrine itself is very nice..however I feel like we didn't see the shrine at it's best. There are major restoration and renovation works going on ahead of a special anniversary in 2020 so just be aware! There are so many beautiful shrines all over Tokyo and Japan but we were still glad to have seen Meiji Jingu.

Incredible Japanese Experience. Simply the walk through the forest is beautiful and the shinto shrine is immense and impressive. Once we got to the actual temple a japanese wedding was taking place which was an incredible experience

Calm and peaceful place to "get away" from the city. I love this place. I usually take a stroll here each time I visit Harajuku. It's such a convenient place situated right across from the JR Station and the estate it resides on is large enough for the shrine to be secluded making you feel as though you are outside of Tokyo.The gravel laden paths leading you to the main shrine take 10-15 minutes to stroll and this place is a fantastic setting for photographs. Catch the golden hour and you'll get some amazing photos.My family combined a visit here with a family photo shoot at a nearby studio. They let us rent the costumes and we walked over to the shrine to take photos. This was so convenient!!!

Calm and respected. The Meiji Shrine is located just behind the exit of the Harajuku station which is easily accessible turning right as you walk out.It was beautifully surrounded by tall healthy tree life, and the walkway leading to the shrine is a pleasant and calming one taking about 10-15minutes. Though a few tourists there the shrine itself was clean, quiet and really nice to see. I recommend going for anyone in Harajuku as it is free and unique to see.

A Beautiful Shinto Shrine for the deified Emperor Meiji. This was my first Japanese Shinto Shrine visit during my trip. Shinto ("the way of the gods") and Buddhism are the two main religions in Japan.I was told by my guide that this shrine commemorates Emperor Meiji, who died in 1912, and his wife, Empress Shoken. The original shrine was built in 1915, but was destroyed in World War II. The shrine was rebuilt in the 1950's.As we entered the shrine there is a huge torii (Japanese shrine gate). Inside, there is a large courtyard sanctuary signifying where Emperor Meiji eats in the after life.There is also an area where you can Purchase a wish/prayer to the god Meiji.Learning about the Japanese Shinto Shrine culture is fascinating and it made our visit very memorable. This is definitely a place where you should visit when you are in Tokyo area.

Overrated..... Comparing this temple to some other temples in Tokyo or in Kyoto, I find the review in this site is overrated. It took a lot of walk just to reach the temple from the nearest subway. The temple itself has nothing spectacular. During our visit, there was a traditional wedding which made up my disappointment a little bit.
Under construction!. This is one of the must visit places in tokyo. There are 2 main shrines and 1 of them is covered in scaffolding.

Forest is as interesting as shrine . A really great experience of a working shrine and stroll through an immense forest. Easy access from train station. The sound of the forest is indescribable..Amazon rainforest like.

3.75...... It's good but not great is the conclusion here. Maybe we were unfortunate that some of the main shrine was covered in scaffolding but it didn't really take my breath away to be honest. It was nice to throw in some money and pay respect to the shrine; this felt an authentic experience. We paid for a trip around the private gardens which was decent too but again nothing breathtaking. Best part is walking through the forest to get to it which is more of a jungle and adds to the atmosphere with its jungle tones. I'd go if you can but I doubt you'll go twice.

Serene. This was the very first shrine that we visited in Tokyo. It was a nice walk up to the shrine itself. We were lucky to spot a local bride and groom taking part in a traditional wedding procession. In addition to the shrine, the sake barrels were nicely arranged, we took loads of photos of it.

Meiji Drums on New Years!. We went here for the Midnight celebrations on New Years Eve. It was freezing cold and I am fairly certain I almost got frost bite but it was nothing short of amazing. Seeing the thousands of people lining up and hearing the drums strike at midnight was an experience I'll never forget!

Beautiful shrine and surrounding park. Go early to avoid the tours and crowds! We went early morning around 9-10 am and it was wonderful and peaceful. As we were leaving, many tour buses pulled in with large crowds.

Magic!. Very beautiful place almost magical, definitely one of my favorite places in Tokyo. I had chance to see a traditional wedding, it was gorgeous. One must remember that it is a place of cult and behave respectfully. There is a little bit of walk if you want to get there, but its definitely worth it.

Beautiful Grounds and Shrine. This is both an impressive shrine and a beautiful park set in the middle of a crazy busy city. I believe I was told there are over 300 acres of trees (check me on this) and the 10 minute walk from the metro stop to the main shrine is serene, wooded and peaceful. It really sets the stage for contemplation.Be warned: there is apparently a Treasures Museum with personal articles of the Emperor and Empress, which we were excited to see. However, it is only open on the weekends and holidays. So, check the times and dates if you are interested in seeing this. We weren't able to do so.

Wonderful green spot in the middle of the city.... ...but my particular favorite spot would be the Inner Garden (Gyoen) which has an entrance fee (500 yen as of August 2016). Well worth it - very secluded and calm. A true testament to the Emperor Meiji's love for his wife. Recommendation: if at all possible, wear closed toe shoes to this park. Most of the trails have tiny river pebbles that do a very good job of getting in under your feet in sandals.
Our favorite shrine in Tokyo - shady too. We enjoyed a lovely peaceful walk in the shade to visit this shrine. We happened upon a processional which was very interesting.
Peaceful. Nice change of pace from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Beautiful walk through the man-made forest (evergreen trees donated from people all across Japan).

Meiji Jingu!. Meiji Jingu or Meiji Shrine is one of the few landmarks I visited in Tokyo.Meiji Shrine is located in the middle of a forest so there was a bit of walking to do before reaching the shrine itself. The entrance was really close from the Shibuya subway station and you would have to cross a white marble bridge that shows a divide between entrance/park and the streets of Shibuya.I would also recommend wearing sneakers or runners because the ground is very uneven and very rocky/sandy on the path to Meiji Jingu!Being greeted by the huge torii gates at the entrance of Meiji Jingu, I would say that the path to Meiji Jingu itself would be 10-15 minute walk (straight walking, without stopping to take photos, etc.)You’ll pass by these wall of sake barrels on the way to the shrine.These sake barrels are offered every year to the enshrined deities by the members of the Meiji Jingu Nationwide Sake Barrel Association, including the Kotokai, which has made offerings of sake for generations as well as other sake brewers around Japan, wishing to show their deep respect for the souls of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. All these sake barrels were donated by sake brewers, in hopes for the continuous prosperity of the sake brewing industry and all the other industries maintaining Japan’s traditional culture.The above excerpt was from the information plaque beside the sake barrels titled as “Barrels of Sake Wrapped in Straw” right beside this beautiful sight :) .Finally reached Meiji Jingu!The entrance was slightly covered because they were doing construction, but after walking by that, here is the view of Meiji Jingu:)Meiji Jingu was quite surreal…Its clear white tiles, big green trees, the temple, and the wishing tablet area. It’s quite peaceful being in that area. It’s temple grounds are quite big and the temple itself, where you get to pray (is photography prohibited) is peaceful as well.These Ema (wooden wishing tablets) come at a price at ¥400 or ¥500, which you can purchase from a Miko (shrine maiden in Japanese). There are different patterns of Ema(s) which were all beautiful.There was also a cheaper option of prayer which was nearby the prayer wall. They offer papers, pens and an envelopes for you to write your prayers/wishes. They ask for a donation, and you just drop it off at a drop box nearby. There was also a paper that teaches you how to get a successful prayer – such as, not wishing for greed like wishing for money, or wishing for unrealistic stuff.I was also lucky to witness a Japanese wedding!!People were rushing up to take photos but there was security guards around to create the barrier for the ceremony.Meiji Jingu is one of the more popular shrines in Tokyo, and it was definitely a sight to see. I was definitely happy to be able to witness a Japanese wedding as people have mentioned that you must be lucky to do so.
Day trip to shrine. A great place to pass away a few hours . Gret facilities to eat , toilets . Saw a Japanese wedding there too .

Lovely shrine, oasis in a mad city! . This place was a welcome oasis in the middle of a crazy city! As soon as you enter the park gates it feels calming and a lovely walk up to the shrine itself. It is beautiful but I would say there are much better to see in Kyoto, but worth a visit on a Tokyo itinerary. We liked the rows of French wine and sake that line the walkways, an interesting symbol of the relationship between Japan and France in years gone by.

Compared to Kyoto.. . Maybe for Tokyo it's impressive, but compared to Kyoto temples and shrines it's becoming "small".. It's funny to think you are very close to the super crowded and lively Shibuya..

One of my favorite places in Tokyo so far. This was my second visit to the Meiji Shrine. First visit, I was fortunate enough to visit in June when all the irises were blooming in the empress' garden. It was absolutely stunning. Different types of irises everywhere, different Violet's and purples. I felt very fortunate to see such beautiful flowers and blooms in the garden.This time it was in the dead heat of summer and the walk through the Meiji Shrine provided some needed shade and peace after braving some of the crowds in other popular tourist sites. Walking up to the shrine is wonderful. I think our guide said there were 100,000 trees around the shrine. Some have grown to spectacular heights and provide heavy shade from the burning sun. It's a 15-20 minute walk to the shrine. You enter into the shrine through large gates. The shrine itself is quite spacious with a big courtyard in front of it. I was lucky the first time I visited to see a wedding procession. We made wishes in the offertory and also in front of the shrine around a big tree (wooden tablets but also can make wishes on paper and put in an envelope).The Meiji Shrine is a place I could see myself coming back to often while visiting Tokyo and seeing it throughout the seasons. It is a peaceful place to stroll around in, a perfect weekend afternoon. It is also conveniently located next to one of the best shopping areas in Tokyo as well as the fun Harajuku shopping district.

Worth a bloody look!. This was the first of many shrines I visited while in the greater Tokyo areaAnd all I can say is wow! Being in a area older than my own countries established government you have a sense of awe and wonder as you walk through a 40foot gate and think "how did they build that 600 years ago? And take the longish gravel path way and then realise some of Japan's most important people may have walked through these grounds at one time or the other. Then you get to the shrine itself (no photos, respect the culture it's sacred ground) And wow a tree (and I know it sounds boring) that's as old as the shrine and great plaza that's just massive! Only let down is the shrine is cut off from the public but you can pray to the deity and ring the bell it's a sight worth the walk and the entire shrine has masses and masses of open fields great for a family lunch and a bit of a loiter Go ahead check it out you only live once!
peacefull and beautiful. After you visit Sensoji, you won't be very impressed with this shrine. Anyway, it's a very peacefull and beautiful place
To visit on a sunday morning. We experienced 3 traditional Shinto marriages in a row and what to say, wow, absolutely jaw dropping of beauty and elegance. The surrounding park is very very beautiful.
Amazing view. A definite tourist must! This iconic part is hidden away in the middle of the city. You will forget that 2 minutes into your walk to the maid temple though

Big love for Meiji Jingu Shrine. Perhaps it was the day we visited, a little rainy, but it wasn't terribly crowded. This shine, dedicated to the former emperor, was a highlight for us. It is beautifully designed and easy to access. The gates are impressive, design is beautiful, and we would have stayed longer but had a list of other sites to dash off to. If you have children or consumed too much coffee/tea for breakfast, their restroom facilities are modern and clean - a nice practical plus. Go and enjoy!

Awesome, beautiful.. This place is amazing. We were fortunate to visit, quite by accident, during a ceremony for the Emperor, and there was a wedding going in too. It's really easy to reach on the train too.

Peaceful break from high-tempo city. Although the shrine itself was far from extraordinary, the walk through the shrine grounds was mesmerising. Once through the torii, you were met by silence. The huge trees effectively isolates the shrine and grants a peaceful retreat from the bustling city. Walking on the paths, you really did not hear anything other than gravel crunching underneath your feet, not even the usual din and bustle of the city. The Omamoris (charms) sold here were on the pricier side - about 800 yen each - but they were of good quality and I'm sure bring good luck. There is also a well-stocked and fairly priced souvenir shop on the shrine grounds that's worth checking out.
stunning. The walk up to the temple is a great way to get out of the sun. The woodland is beautiful and magical.Shrine itself is very pretty - there are also lots of places to sit.Gift shop is good

Worth the trip. This is a relatively new shrine, but it is in the middle of a lovely park that gives you an uncommon sense of green and peace in the middle of Tokyo. It's right off a main drag of the fashion district, which is very fun to walk through. Then go to the main entrance of the shrine, and take the wide avenue that leads to the shrine under mature trees that arch over the gravel path. It is usually crowded, particularly on the weekends, but somehow it all seems worth it. There are a couple of museums in the park that show lovely Meiji-era artifacts and artwork that is absolutely worth seeing. Otherwise, there is no food and drink allowed outside restaurants, and it's not a touristy shopping explosion outside the shrine like others. The shrine is a multi-courtyard complex, with simple darke wood, white plaster and relatively natural design that is quite stunning. If you are not there for a ceremony, like a wedding, you will not be allowed to enter most of the shrine proper. But you will get peeks and glances, and I found it quite satisfying. I was there on a Saturday, and there were 3 wedding processions in the hour or so I was there...very moving, with the traditional dress, etc. Take your time, and write a prayer on a small piece of wood for 500 yen, and priests will collect them and say your prayers. Then, wander around in the park through a variety of secluded paths. There isn't much signage in English, so either read up before you go, or just enjoy the landscape without worrying about the significance. Either can be enjoyable.

Good walk. The walk leading to the temple was awesome, you have to pass thru beautiful old trees along the way. Some pebbles on the road thou but still a great walk to reach the temple.A very peaceful place.Not to miss
Beautiful and crowded. So beautiful and serene, but also so crowded. 15-20 min walk from the nearby subway station (orientation signs all over).

Very divine place among greenery.. Really impressed with the place. Huge trees completely takes the city away from you and brings fresh air and refresh yourself . Close to nature and lovely experience of the visit to the shrine. Enjoyed a lot. A moment to cherish for ever!

Oasis in metroplos. Hard to think this huge park and temple complex is right by frantic Takeshita Street. It's a great place to escape the crowds although it is busy the wide , tree lined pedestrian paths make you fell like you are in a forest miles away fro a city. And then you come across the temple complex, with its magnificent buildings.We went on a Sunday and the best thing about that was seeing all the traditional weddings taking place with their Shinto processions and traditional dresses, the feeling of a truly traditional Japan is here.And walk out to Harajuku and see the rockabilly dancers! What a contrast.
