Peaceful walk and very green. We walked up to the gardens from Shibuya in really hot and humid day. Was really nice to get out of the Sun under the lush Forest covering.
The actual shrine was pretty disappointing compared to the others but given the proximity to the city, worth visiting.

Nice for a stroll. Perfect place to experience rich cultural history and to appreciate the lives of Emperor Meiji and his Empress. The setting of the shrines are in a lovely wooded area. Beware though, major re-construction work is taking place ready for the 2020 olympics.

The calm amidst the chaos!. The Meiji Jingu Shrine gives a little peace in a very busy city. We got off at Harajuku station and walked the avenue up to the shrine. It was calm and quiet and a lovely visit. While there is some maintenance going on, it didn't affect our visit.

A little bit of calm in a busy city. We walked to the shrine from our base in Shinjuku on a very muggy, damp, hot day. The shrine and the surrounding area was a lovely peaceful oasis and well worth the walk. There are restoration works going on at the moment so it is not completely open but still worth a look

Nice walk in the city. This is where u can find peace in the busy district of Harajuku. A nice relaxing walk through greenery and big trees. All aim for the destination where the shrine is located.Reaching here also very easy by train.

Cheek by jowl with Harajuku. An amazingly peaceful space considering its proximity to some of the busiest shopping streets in Tokyo. Heavily wooded and shady on a blazing hot day. The shrine itself is interesting but not exactly mind blowing. The gardens (500¥) are pretty but summer is probably not the time to see them at their best. Mosquitoes everywhere so wear as much clothing as you can! We were here by 9am & walked to the shrine when it was very quiet. We did the gardens in the afternoon by which time the shrine complex was very busy, however the gardens weren't. English signage confusing as the entrance to the gardens is labeled as the entrance to a well - they're one and the same.

Calm and Peacful in busy Harajuku. Arrive via JR Harajuku station or Meiji-Jingumae staion. Cross the bridge and you will be greeted with the huge Torii. There will be a bit of a walk before you get to the shrine, but its a lovely stroll through an urban forest. Lots to see along the way. The Sake and wine barrels make for a nice picture. Large trees create a feeling of calm. More Torii gates along the way before coming to the cleansing and purifying station. Some the structures in the shrine are undergoing restoration and will be under tarps, but they have made it so that you can imagine what it will look like when restored. A very nice place to visit and one not to be missed.

Shrine was under maintenance when visited. . Interesting place to visit, although when we visited unfortunately there was maintenance work on the main shrine, and no signs in English suggesting this as we entered the site. Good for a medium distanced stroll through, presumably, what Tokyo would have looked like before civilisation spawned here. If you visit in summer, bring insect repellent!

Nice. Different from what I expected but worth a visit, nice walk with a museum at the end. I actually thought it would be more fun, or more beautiful but the beauty is really at the entrance. Don't let this deter you

Meiji Shrine, Harajuku. A beautiful, well-preserved and tranquil shrine dating back to the Tokugawa era. Easy to get to via the JR Yamanote Line / Harajuku Station, and right on the doorstep to Harajuku for other sightseeing opportunities. It costs nothing, though as with all shrines you can make a donation (which we did). There is also a tourist information centre and a gift shop selling the usual tourist fare. Well worth a visit.

Make sure you get off the subway at Harajuku .... Perhaps it was because I was hot, or because part of the shrine is under construction, but I though the shrine was just average. The shrine, and Yoyogi park, cannot be accessed from the Yoyogi Koen (park) subway stop. Having done it, trust me, you do not want to walk from there to Harajuku, the correct stop for the entrance. The shrine has a separate entrance from the park, but it was pretty well labeled and we found it. The walk to the shrine is a gravel road, mostly in the shade. It was very crowded. Halfway, it looks like there's a small shop, bathrooms, and maybe cafe. Our entire shrine visit was maybe 10 minutes (perhaps we missed something?). For the walk back, we took the back path, through the woods, and it was pleasant and shady.

Nice and calm. A glimpse into the shintoism.. The major religion followed in Japan..help you to understand thr local culture and plsce of worship. I managed even to catch a glimpse of a japsnese wedding
A piece of ancient nature. This park is filled with the atmosphere of ancient times. You can take a walk and contemplate long alleys with really high trees.

Close to Harajuku and should be done preferably on a Sunday. We took the subway to Meiji-jingumae station which is right next to the shrine. Its a very pleasant walk amid calmness and serene surroundings. If you are lucky you could see a traditional wedding while you are there.We saw vendors selling all types of good luck charms (even for good driving!!) which we thought was interesting.You should visit this shrine preferably on a Sunday because Takeshita street and Harajuku fashion is only 10 or so minutes walk away from here.You need about at least 1-2 hours to fully explore this place.- Milespointstravel.com

Peaceful walk. This was just a lovely walk and visit. From the sake barrels and wine barrels, to the towering gates, to the cleansing fonts. We wrote our messages and wishes and made an offering. A serene and peaceful way to spend the morning.

Old Japan . This shrine and the surrounding parklands are worth a visit to get a sense of Japanese culture, architecture and history in the middle of the buzz of Tokyo. A fair bit of walking is required to get to the shrine itself from Harajuku station although the entrance is close by. Being there on certain festival days/times gives a good glimpse into religious traditions. The building itself is impressive but there is limited opportunity to go inside. A walk around the grounds is a must as an insight into old imperial times and offers a number of serene spots to sit and contemplate. Interesting history. There are often weddings there and we were fortunate enough to be there to see one and the obliging bridal party didn't mind photos being taken. The gates are really impressive. Coincide it with a trip to Harajuku itself where wondering the streets of this hub of pop culture and street fashion is in stark contrast.

Worth the visit. It is Tokyo's most famous Shinto shrine. It is wonderfully serene and austere, not colorful or flashy like other Asian places of worship, and is less of a tourist trap than Senso-ji, the big Buddhist temple across town in Asakusa. Beautiful park to walk and get away from the city's noise for a while.

Peaceful, beautiful shrine. We happened to come when there was a wedding and we saw the bride along with the guests walking across the main shrine building. This is a very quiet area, and many come to give offerings and write their wishes on the sacred tree. Very cool experience.

Beautiful Japanese shrine (and free too). This is a gorgeous, well looked after shrine in a beautiful peaceful part of Tokyo. It's a great place to escape the heat and crowds. It's free too, so a definite place to visit.
Peaceful. Went during the sakura season so it was a little crowded. Like all parts of japan, it's a must go! It gets really cold though.
Escape:). Green land, calm, not so many people, you can easily find free space. Shrine very nice to see. Close to harajuku. Easy to get by Jr or subway.

A peaceful retreat steps from chaos of city.. So peaceful and quiet. We were there in May and the shade was delightful. It was during golden week so we were able to enjoy amazing performances. The gardens are beyond gorgeous.

A stroll to remember. This quiet and peaceful place is one of my favorite to walk around in Tokyo just whenever I want to get away from the city's hustle and bustle. Just a short walk from Harajuku station and you can indulge in this well landscaped garden well surrounded by breathtaking ponds, and beautiful Japanese seasonal plants and animals that makes you feel so close to nature. 500Yen is really worth it.

Beautiful. A peaceful and relaxing spot in the heart of the city. Lovely to read the prayers of different people from around the world outside the shrine. You can write yours on wood or on paper. Don't miss the purification fountain where you can cleanse your hands and mouth. Beautiful walk through woods around the shrine and amazed to find the woods are planted only 100 years ago.
Nice and peaceful. Long walk to the shrine is always nice and peaceful....almost like walk in a park. You may bump into wedding as we did. Nice stroll after busy Harajuku streets and shops.

Beautiful Shrine and a must visit in Shibuya, Tokyo. This is a wonderful shrine and a short walk away from the Harajuku station. The shrine is very beautiful and is surrounded by beautiful gardens. The entry to the shrine is free however if you want to visit the garden, you will have to pay 500 yen entry fee per person. It is totally worth it as it offers a serene environment surrounded by trees and beautiful ponds with colorful fish. We walked through the garden and eventually reached the shrine. We also go to witness a japanese wedding taking place within the premise of shrine.

Beautiful Shrine. This was a great experience. It's a bit of a walk but it's all very enjoyable. Very beautiful shrine and landscapes. There is also a gift shop at the end. The only reason I did not give 5 stars is because some was under renovation and thus not visible. Take some time off from the busy streets and enjoy this peacful place.
Beautiful Park. I love Walking around in Japanese Parks because they are not crowded like the rest from the City, but ist a shame that they are all closed Long time before sunset already.

Very nice temple near Shibuya!. It was a long walk from Harajuku station going to the Meiji Jingu shrine but it was all worth it. I went the just before closing and we (together with the other travellers) were lucky enough to see a procession ceremony going inside the temple.
Place to visit in Shibuya. Big park and beautiful temple. Nice to walk, excellent trees from all tokyo.Place to enjoy it, take your time. No charge it free.

Nice shrine in a big park area, in the middle of Shibuya. This shrine/temple is located in a beautiful park, next to Harajuku station and at the end of Omotesando shopping street. I particularly liked the entrance to the temple complex, with a large torii and rows of sake barrels and Bourgogne wine barrels (which the latter you wouldn't expect in Japan). It is a quiet environment, away from the hustle and bustle of Omotesando Shopping area and Shibuya.

Peaceful . I went there in my first rainy day in Tokyo and I was straight given a sense of peace and calm you just want to be there and stroll around. Do not forget to purify you one bit in the right and one in the left s d a zip in your mouth. And just feel your inner soul breathing.
wearing yukata in meiji shrine. The energy you can feel here is amazing. We went there wearing yukata, it was definitely a special feeling.

Short visit. I had not much time to sightsee in Tokyo while on a business trip, so when I asked friends for ONE Japanese garden or park to visit, the answer was this place. I was originally going to go alone but then a friend decided to tag along which was nice as the walk to the Meiji Shrine was quite long from the Harajuku station. We only had two hours to spare after work that day before the park closes, so we brisk-walked to the Meiji Shrine. It was a gloomy, cloudy day with off and on light rains, but the trees provided much-needed cover for us. It wasn't the best weather to visit the shrine as it made everything quite grey, but we had no other time to go so tried to make the best of what we had. The entrance to the park was being renovated for the 2020 Olympics so it was a bit unsightly for photos with the bright orange cones, but the fact is that the Japanese work in the tidiest of conditions, given the nature of construction work, and the place was kept really neat and tidy and some people would not even realise there was construction going on. It was a good 15-20 minute walk from the main gate to the shrine. There were signs showing the way so it was easy to navigate. Upon nearing the shrine, you see the sake barrels alongside the paths, which were really intriguing. There was even a sign giving information about the barrels and the history and significance of them.Entering the shrine, you will see more construction work being done but again, it was kept in such a tidy and neat state. The scaffolding was covered with a canvas that had a life-sized image of the shrine, so it was a good way to give you a sense of how it would have looked like should it not have been covered up. Not unsightly at all and was left really impressed with the way the Japanese work. Inside the shrine, you have a large open space with two large trees in the foreground, providing a really pretty "frame" for the place. The trees were so round, almost too perfect-looking! Surrounding one of them is a structure where you can hang your "ema" on - a wooden tablet where you write your wishes which can be purchased at the shrine. To the right is another area where you can buy some souvenir charms and get your fortunes told. There was also a restaurant. The shrine was really quite gorgeous. I loved looking at the architecture and how the wooden structures perfectly blended into the natural surroundings of the shrine. It was a very spiritual, peaceful place. Try to go when the weather is good!
Great place to visit. Highly recommend waking up early to experience it while it's still quiet. A good place to escape the hustle and bustle of tokyo.

Very peaceful place. We are literally just live 5 mins walk beside this place. So I decide to visit in the morning after I woke up at 5:30. I love those traditional architectures. And it's a good place to relax and just to walk. Unfortunately, the treasure museum closed because I was too early lol. I made some wishes and walking back. And if you lucky enough you can see the weddings. Love it, it's so peaceful.

Nice shine, but lots of tourists there. It's a pretty nice shrine, situated in the middle of a beautiful wooded area. There are streams of tourists coming through... so it is not very peaceful. I got to observe a traditional Japanese wedding while I was there, which is the only thing that saved my experience there. It was actually quite cool to see the traditional garb they were wearing.

Instantly Relaxed. Instantly leave the crowds behind and walk through the forest to an impressive shrine. Tokyo amazes me as it is so crowded but you can leave that behind in moments. This is the perfect place to cool off in the summer, leave the asphalt behind, walk though the woods, and visit the Japan of the past. Highly recommend.

Lovely Sacred Place. The forest surrounding the temple is amazing. The trees are from all over Japan and some of them are seriously tall and beautiful. We don't usually apprecitate trees, but this kind of nature is truly awe inspiring. Getting to the temple and moving around requires a nice walk. We went on a really warm and humid day. We had to buy water bottles to stand the heat and moisture (July 2016).The atmosphere in the temple/shrine is inspiring if you are the kind of person that seeks insightful moments. If you don't appreciate silence, diversity and sacred places, then don't bother, you will just spoil the mood for others. It was nice to see respectful tourists, not abusing of taking selfies and stuff like that. Most, if not all, tourists respected the rules and took pictures only in open areas.

A must see. coming in from the south Shibuya, harajuku, this place is a nice peaceful pause environment even if crowd is in. large alleys make it breathable and u ll smile seeing at entrance of the site the sake barrels facing the french wine ones ( although it is for a good reason) the whole place is still impressive and worthy to get a spiritual break and with a littl luck catch a wedding ceremony - to watch in silence of course. few buildings currently Under rénovation. try to choose your way in order to get in from a door and out from another. north east part was some how like a local central park zone. good spot to recharge before resuming your walk.

The impression places. Beautiful park with tress green and high....fresh area toward Meiji Jingu building. You find a Karugaden and Kyakuden and main shrine in the middle area clean and fresh area in the middle big city is impression culture. Walking to the landmark like as going passed away to the century of Meiji age hundreds ago.You can find treasure museum and gymnasium in there so many collected they keep until now.Interesting place to must be visit in Japan.

Beautiful shrine in the middle of a park. This shrine was easy to find from Harajuku station. You walk through the beautiful park to get there. The beautiful red Tori gate welcomed you. There are a few smaller shrines on the way. There is a wall of sake barrels which was cool to see the various art work on the barrel. The main shrine was very pretty. The kids loved getting calligraphy in their shrine books. 500 yen We bought a shrine book here. 1000 yen. Calligraphy place didn't open till 9. As with most shrines you can buy fortunes, votive tablets to write on and coin boxes to make a prayer. There was also a seal for free with a stamp pad.
Compared to other shrines and temples..... Compared to other shrines and temples, this one was a bit bland, maybe i'm not that educated on it's history.

Zen feeling. Meiji Jingu Shrine is a perfectly zen place in Tokyo. When I visited there, accidentally there was a wedding ceremony and I got very luck to seen it with my own eyes. Also it is good because it is free.

Good but have to walk around 5-10mins just can reach the shrine . Meiji Shrine 明治神宮 Meiji Jingūlocated in Yoyogi station & Harajuku station, Tokyois the Shinto shrine that is dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress ShōkenNot so big than senso-ji temple but it's a historical place so still valuable to come over :)After visit this place can go to Harajuku street to walk and shopping :))

Beautiful Shrine. Visited here on a Sunday and it was very crowded. We were greeted by 3 local men who were volunteer tour guides. It made the visit very special as they explained all of the history, parts of the shrine and traditions to us. They were very friendly and fun. It made the visit especially good for my son. It is about a 50 minute walk and tour. The shrine is located next to the Harajuku metro stop. We also visited the famous 100 yen shopping street--it was packed,
Nice shrine to visit.... It is near the Harajuku station and less crowded than the one at Asakusa / Nakamise street so it makes it more peaceful to visit.

Cool place! Worth a visit.. Read that this was one of the must see places in Tokyo, so we decided to give it a go. Wasnt disappointed. The shrine is located in some glorious grounds which includes some interesting history. There is a nice river that runs through the park which contains fish and turtles... its a nice place to actually go and chill and read/think. Great for photography! The tourists will flock to the shrine part, but there is so much more to this area. Enjoy the surroundings and relax. Pay the money and go see the well. Its circa 250 yen i think, but its worth the entry to this little treasure. Very nice.

Beautiful place...do the special dance and blessing!. We had a great time walking around the grounds. It is a beautiful place. We were about to get inside the Shrine and participated in a special dance and blessing which was really interesting.

Good Opportunity to See Japanese Culture. Our English speaking tour guide took us to the Shrine and the complex was stunning. The architecture was striking and getting the history lesson was fascinating. Had the opportunity to see a wedding procession which was neat. Seems to be a key visit for a first time tourist.

Shrine is so-so but the surrounding park has a lot to see. Beware of shrine and temple overdose if you're travelling for a long period in Japan; each individual shrine may be nice but they do blend into one another if you seen too many in short succession. The Meiji shrine in the centre is alright, though there are better ones elsewhere (Kyoto for example). But the park around the shrine is definitely worth checking out; there's a few museums and exhibits, plus an area with a wall of sake barrels, and one of the largest torii gates in Japan.
Beautiful park. Gorgeous, right in the center of the city, across from Harajuku if you want to go shopping. Easy access by subway (Harajuku Station).

Impressive important shrine. Visited with the whole family to see this important Shinto shrine. Got a bonus of a fancy ceremony but we did not understand it! Long walk from there entrances to the shrine and minimal commercialization. Recommended.

Relaxing park in the heart of Tokyo. This park is a perfect example of a traditional Japanese park/garden. There are Torii gates as you enter Menji Jingu and a stunning looking temple at the centre. The park is kept in great condition and we noticed a few gardeners meticulously sweeping leaves from the path. Attention to detail is a common trait in Japanese culture. Great place to go after exploring the bustling streets of Tokyo.

Expected more. Althought Meiji Jingu was one of my main activities on my Japan bucket list I was expecting more from this. There is current construction going on at the moment which may have dampened my thoughts but I felt most of it was more wide open space and not THAT much to see in terms of structures and gates etc. Although it was peaceful I wouldn't have made this the top of items to do on my list.

Central Park for Tokyo. Went in the morning, nice and cool walk. Lots of locals exercising and early riser tourists. The walk from the train station to the main entrance is short, right around the corner from the train station... however, it's a long walk to the main shrine complex. It's not a temple, it's a shrine to the Meiji Emperor, who is not buried there. Very green with lots of big trees lining the main walkways. The arches are impressive. It's a nice stroll but lacks some of the true temple feel of the Kyoto temples. The JR station for Meiji Jingu is itself an architecture legacy from a different era, worth seeing too. We had lunch at the on-site eatery, pretty good but a big pricy for the portions... but good AC space to rest after the long walk.

Long walk to the shrine. The shrine itself is quite a bit of walk from the train station. The path leading to the shrine is lined up with beautiful tall trees and wide walkways. However, am a bit dissapointed with the shrine itself. Not much to see and do.

Peaceful temple. . A very peaceful place to spend the day at and learn about the culture and people. Also a whole big chunk of area in walking distance to it with a lot of cool stores and shops for pretty much anything your heart desires.

Mystic and breathtaking!. The Meiji-Shrine close to Shibuya is one of the most important symbols of Japanese Shintoism. At NYE thousands of people visit the Shrine, pray for luck, prosperity, love and happiness. The walk from Shibuya station to shrine is kind of mystic through a shaded forrest in the middle of Tokyo where you can completely forget the traffic, the rush and the skyscrapers.For more pictures and impressions, check out my blogpost about the Meiji-Shrine :)http://franie-travels.com/2016/01/24/meiji-shrine-japan

A lovely walk through a peaceful retreat. We spent a relaxing couple of hours at the Meiju Jingu gardens and shrine. We were there in July, when the water lilies are blooming. Each season has it's own type of flower display, including azalea, rhododendron, wisteria, iris and camelias. The gardens are peaceful and shady in the summer, which was a welcome relief in July! The Temple was very impressive as well. WE went on a weekday, so it wasn't crowded at all. However, one of the displays - the Emperor's Treasure House - is only open on weekends so factor that into your plans. Overall, a nice nature break in the middle of the crowded city!

Breathtaking experience. I've been to Tokyo several times and this is one of the area attrections that i have enjoyed the most. Trees are gigantic is a Oasis in the middle of the Big City, you can hear birds, crickets and you can feel relaxed. The shrine is a very neat area sober and mystic, if you're looking for Japan essence here's the place. This is a must while you're in Tokyo!!!
A nice escape. Very peaceful compared to the hustle and bustle of the nearby shopping area (Takeshita).Some much needed shaded areas to escape direct sunlight.

A place of serenity in the hart of Tokyo. So close to Takeshita street and yet it seems so far. Peace and serenity in beautiful woods. The temple was being renovated when we visited but still a great place.

Relaxing stroll to the park. The Shrine itself was not particularly attractive but the walk within the park was relaxing with beautiful scenery. You will have to walk quite a while to reach the shrine, on a very wide road with tall and big trees lining the sides of the road. A good way to spend the afternoon after visiting the bustling and vivacious streets of Harajuku nearby.

“Meiji Jingu Shinto shrine". The walk to Shinto shrine is surrounded with trees. It is a popular place for many visitors and it can get crowed. I was able to see a wedding by chance and it was gorgeous and made my experience much better.
Beautiful . If only as an excuse to walk in the park, this is a must visit. The shrine and cultural features make it an interesting visit.

Beautiful!. Meiji shrine is beautiful. There is a bit of a walk to reach the shrine but it is beautiful. This was my second visit. This visit there was a lot of construction that took away from the stillness a peaceful feeling I had experienced during the first visit.
Incredible!. This was our first visit to a shrine while in country. The view when you make the right hand turn and see the shrine for the first time is simply incredible.

Great escape with cultural significance. 1 million people visit this shrine at new year. The size of the park, the 1500 year ald trees used for the largest entrance and the fact wold leaders visited for the G8 summit, illustrate the importance Meiji played in the modernisation of Japan. Worth reading about his influence before your visit to bring to life the experience. It is also a great retreat from the busy city of Japan.

A peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle. As a self-described history buff, I knew I couldn't that I couldn't pass up chance to visit one of the most sacred places in Japan. Here the souls of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shouken are enshrined. Nestled in the busy Shibuya area, It's a massive park that is surprisingly quiet and serene. I found myself doing much introspection as I a strolled through and appreciated its peaceful visage. Signs will point you in the direction of the main shrine, here you can pay your respects to the departed Emperor and Empress. Please note that no pictures are allowed in this area and instructions on how to pay your respects are illustrated (personally, I just mirrored what those next to me were doing). Before entering the torii gate to the main shrine, it is customary to cleanse your hands and mouth before entering the main area. You'll see the fountain to your left before entering. It also customary to bow on entering and leaving through each torii, but no one will make a fuss if you refuse to do so. I really enjoyed my morning there and I will certainly visit again.Happy Travels

Great place for a walk. This place is located next to Harajuku station. Out of the station and on the right. You first walk through a large gate, and on a path with alot of trees on both side. Very fresh air until you come upon a row of Japanese wine barrels on the right and a set of wine barrel on the left. Don't know the meanings, but cool to look at. Then you get to Miji castel. There are places for prayer and a tree for writing you prayers on. When we were there it was under construction, but still look grand.

Forrest in the city. This is a short walk from the Harajuku train station. There is no charge to enter. It is a little Forrest in the middle of the city. There are couple of big tori gates and the shrine itself was undergoing renovations when we were there. Our guide showed us how to cleanse before you enter and also how to pay respect and make a donation so that was good. If you are a nature lover you could spend some time here and it is a longish walk to the shrine on gravel but not really a lot to see at the shrine itself but I would still recommend people visit and there is a lot of other thing to do and see which are close by.

Very touristy, nothing special . I spent the day before in Nikko so obviously the Meiji Jingu couldn't live up to what I had seen the other day. It's very touristy and didn't think it was special at all. It's surrounded in a park, which is very close to Akihabara and really peaceful. Doesn't deserve being ranked as the 2nd best thing to do in Tokyo by far.

Beautiful. Well worth a visit!! very impressive beautiful space. good if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of harajuku ! Plenty to look at , beautiful trees and lots of nature to be seen
Definitely worth a visit. I highly recommend paying the 500 yen to see the inner garden. It was just gorgeous. The birds flew into our hands! There was a turtle and many koi fish in the pond.

Great walk!. As other reviewers have said, this is a beautiful, peaceful walk. The shrine is impressive. It is also right near Takeshita Dori, so it was fun to do both back to back. Talk about contrast!
Great escape. Beautiful temple, with amazing grounds offering serene relief from nearby harajuku. Visit the inner garden with small lake and you will likely have the place to yourself.

Jet lag walk. Our first morning in Tokyo we were ready to go at six am. We wandered to this shrine and were surprised to find it open. Peaceful, beautiful and in sharp contrast to the city when it is awake. We stayed in Hatajuku, so this was a convenient wander.
Pleasant but touristy. Currently there is construction on the main shrine, but the empresses tea house is worth the five bucks entrance. It is quiet and interesting
Wedding Days. Hit the shrine on the weekend as you'll get to see the amazing wedding ceremonies taking place! right next to Harijuku, so you can see some of the crazy stores on Takeshita Street
Impressive, relax and peaceful . It's good to visit such a peaceful and quiet place in the middle of busy city. It's a nice walk from Harajuku with greenary scene. I think it's a must visit.

Meiji Shrine, Tokyo. The shrine is the Shinto shrine dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji & his wife Empress Shoken. Construction began in 1915 and finished by 1926. The original building was destroyed during the Tokyo air raids of WW II. The current iteration of the shrine was publicly funded and completed in 1958. Sheltered by a 700,000 square meter forest of 120,000 (365 different species) evergreen trees donated from all over Japan.
Peaceful. A nice peaceful walk and beautiful shrines. It was nice to get out of the busy city. The sake barrels were very colorful and all the prayers were pretty neat to read.

Worth a visit. This was a beautiful shrine in the middle of woodlands near Shibuya. You pass through huge cedar gates and walk to the shrine. First clean your hands and mouth at special stations. Next write prayers and submit in the envelope provided with your offerings, or throw your offerings into a box and clap and bow. We were there on a Sunday lunchtime and saw a traditional wedding procession, very special. It will take 1-2 hours. In July it is SO hot that you will do it faster.

Peace and quiet in the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Despite the hundreds of tourists visiting the grounds, it still retains a peaceful quality when compared to nearby Harajuku. Take a leisurely stroll to the shrine, and enjoy a little escape from the madness of Tokyo!

Meiji Jingu Shinto shrine - impressing and well preserved. The shrine and the garden and park surroundings are close to Yoyogi Park, so if one has the energy both places can be taken on the same day. Metro stations are Yoyogi or Meiji-jingumae.It is a popular place so there will be many visitors, on Sundays crowded!It is a shrine dedicated to the Emperor Meiji who died in 1912. The japanese people donated 100.000 trees to make the forest park and the shrine was then to the emperors honour!Today you cam also be married here - when we were there a wedding was going on. That was an extra adventure with the fantastic dressings and kimonos.It is worth a visit and people enjoy to relax in the park on sunny days.

Great place to visit in the morning!. We visited this place to make us relax and calm before we travelled around tokyo!II recommend doing a bit of background research on its history before visiting to make the most from the experience.

Great retreat. Great refreshing and calming retreat from the bustle of the streets, juxtaposed to the wild streets of Harajuku and crowds of Omtesando. On a hot day it is wonderful to take a break and sit in this wonderful forest in the city.
Worth the trip . My daughter and I went before going shopping in the area. Beautiful walk Such a peaceful wooded area just blocks from Harajuku

Beautiful!. Definately a place to visit. The long walk to the shrine was tiring but peaceful especially after the utter chaos that is Harajuku. Managed to see a traditional Japanese wedding procession! What a sight!!!!The shrine itself is a statement on its own.You'll see lots of tourist and even locals some even in kimono heading to the shrine!

Surrounded by green. Long walk to get there. There were people in traditional dress. Very clean and well maintained surroundings. Seemed a little more original than some of the other structures we saw in Tokyo.
Nice Shrine. Very calm and nice, the enctrance path was so calm, you can hear birds singing and feel the breezy wind.
Calm place. This is one of top 10 shrines in Japan. The place is very calm, try to go there on weekday so that you will feel calmness in the area. Enjoy the surroundings.

Meiji Shrine. Its a long walk from the train station to the Meiji Shrine, however it was well worth it. Its absolutely gorgeous and surrounded by very tall trees, feels like your in a forest right in the heart of Tokyo

Gorgeous. We were able to see a wedding by chance and it was gorgeous and made our experience much better. To see the culture and dresses was great on top of how beautiful the area is. Its a big area so expect to walk.

Early Morning Gem. I arrived here at about 6 am. (Hey sometimes jet lag is a good thing). It was awesome to get here before the crowds and enjoy the scenery. The forest that surrounds Meiji Jingu is beautiful. Again, walking through here without people was quite an experience. Just me and the Jungle Crows.I did come back later in the day and it was packed so I recommend getting here early.
Loved it. Meiji Jingu is a place where you would have more nature when you are in Tokyo city. It is a nice walk towards the main shrine and there is so much green around.
Beautiful . Alvin must to visit when in Tokyo. It is centrally located and can be combined with a tour through Harajuku and catstreet.

quiet and beautiful place. i went to visit Meiji Shrine in April the weather was good .i walked from Yoyogi station though it is a long walk and from there if you go to the other side harajuku is near .worth going a place .I felt very peaceful .Must go place

Interesting shrine in Harajuku. I visited here recently while in Tokyo. The shrine requires considerable walking but most of it is on the flat. Some parts are undergoing restoration, but it is possible to still enjoy the venue. A wedding was going on during my visit and that added to the experience. Displays were readily accessible for non-Japanese speakers.
Worth visiting. I think it's worth visiting as many shrines as possible when in Japan , they are all unique and set in beautiful garden settings . I really enjoyed the peaceful settings.
A really long walk in. A really long walk in, towards the shrine. Might be too hard on younger children or older folk. Nice views at the main gate, though.

Still good but under renovation . The place is still good for visiting but is under renovation. However that does not spoilt some of the photo taking area. Very nice and quiet place to visit in the morning. After this you can walk to yoyogi Park. We prefer Sunday as more activities on Sunday for yoyogi park.

Beautiful Ambience. A must visit for anyone wanting to understand Japan as Shintoism is unique to Japan.This shrine is surrounded by beautiful greenery and has good facilities including some good souvenir shops.The walk from the parking to the shrine is beautiful on the gravel path, through great cypress wood gates which are meant to purify people.The shrine has various parts and what's most interesting is the culture and traditions. Please note not to take photos of the main shrine to respect the sentiments ( I was surprised to see tourists taking photos despite the signs, which I found disrespectful)We were also lucky to witness a wedding.A must visit shrine dedicated to the Emperor depicted in the movie " The last Samurai"

Beware of renovation work. Review might be tad better, but decided to write this for fellow travelers. Currently in end of June 2016, the shrine is undergoing a lot of renovations. Therefore, a lot of the buildings are covered up. You can still enter the buildings, just that if you are looking for an opportunity, then this may not be a good time. You should likely check online on their website about renovation works before going. It is a tourist spot for sure, so there are many people there, hence not entirely a serene shrine. Once again, I may have just caught this at a bad time this year. I will try to visit again in later years.

Beautiful setting, fabulous dark brown towering torii. It was very busy with visitors when we went but it was still worth the walk. The torii (shrine gates) are beautiful and I loved the display of sake barrels. It's hard to imagine you're in the middle of a metropolis at this shrine. For variety we walked in from the gates near Yoyogi Park then walked out the other end through some smaller gates.

Wonderful walk through the forest to this large and popular shrine. Hard to believe you are in the middle of Tokyo. The forest is lush and green. A solid walk from the station but this is part of the experience. Shrine currently under renovation but an interesting fairly short visit.

Lovely shrine on the edge of Harajuku. A great place to visit prior to a hectic walk to Takashita Dori. It is the complete contrast to the rest of Harajuku's eccentric hustle and bustle. A beautiful shrine with what seems like an impossibly quiet walk in the middle of Tokyo. Less touristy than the others we went to on the trip

Very interesting Temple. walk to Meiji Jingu after we visited Shinjuku National Park, 5 mins walking distance. Saw 2 weddings on the day, one is western style and another is traditional Japanese wedding.
love this place. Experience the beauty of nature, trees all over. A good place to meditate (if not crowded). Lots of visitors especially during weekends.
Jungle and mystery. The walk to the temple, which is in the middle of the city by Harajuku station, seems to move you to a jungle a few hundred years back. A really nice tourist spot

Great but beware of tourism.... Whilst I enjoyed the visit to this shrine, it was mega busy with tourists! A lot busier than just about any other shrine I went to whilst in Tokyo. So it wasn't nearly as relaxing as it could've been. But the sight was worth it!

Get Married!. A fantastic oasis of peace away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo city and folded in with long history and culture. Also we saw a beautiful wedding with the bride, groom and family all wearing the traditional Japanese kimonos. Just a tremendous viewing that you don't see anywhere else. Best of the luck to the wedding party. A view of the temple and old forests 1000's of years old brings you harmony.

Nice change in scenery!. Even though it is in the middle of Tokyo, it feels like you're elsewhere. Instead of being surrounded by tall buildings, you are surrounded by trees. Definitely a good place to get away from the city crowds. Despite being full of tourists, it is still a calming and serene location. You get a little taste of Japanese culture as well.

It's ok but nothing more. If you are in town visit the park with the shrine. Many want to see the shrine. A large part of the shrine was closed due to construction. I expected more. my conclusion: it's ok but nothing more.

An Unexpected Oasis. We'd had a busy day crammed full of the wonderful sensory overload that comes with the sights, sounds and smells of Tokyo. Arriving at the outdoor Meiji Shrine, it was raining. We didn't care. We took a leisurely stroll through this oasis of calm, admiring the huge Tori gate at the entrance. The forest has an abundance of large trees of multiple varieties. There are many barrels of sake and casks of wine donated to the shrine for good luck. This is very close to Takeshita Street. I"d recommend having a wander at the amazing sites and crowdsthat beholds, then come here for a bit of serenity.

Peaceful and beautiful. Although completely full of tourists, you still have a lovely sense of peace when wandering through this temple. You have the opportunity to say a prayer and make an offer under the prayer tree, and also participate in some ceremony before you enter the temple and also within. We were delighted to come across a wedding ceremony within the temple also - I've heard this is quite common so I'm sure you'll wander across one also.

Quiet, serene and calming.. The 40-foot-high torii gate at the entrance to the 200-acre park is made of 1,500-year-old cypress, and leads to the long walk along the pea-stone path (meant to resemble flowing water, we were told), through a smaller gate, to the shrine. The atmosphere along the way through the grounds is quiet, serene and encourages self reflection and thought. We went on a Sunday and were lucky enough to see 2 Hatsumiya-Mode ceremonies - the first shrine visit paid by a newborn baby to pray for the baby's healthy growth which takes place around one month after birth, as well as 2 Wedding processions with the bride and groom in traditional dress. 'Very moving and fascinating to witness. There was also an amazing display of various Bonsai trees up to 500 years old!

Serene. We went on a Sunday around noon after our visit to the East Imperial Gardens. The shrine is within Yoyogi Park which is right off the Shinjuku metro station. It is a more natural setting. Not as manicured as the East Imperial Gardens. You are greeted by a large massive gate. The shrine is down at the end of a wide path shaded by large trees. On the way you will pass a wall of sake barrels. Once you enter the shrine area, you will see the two most beautiful holy trees you have seen. I've never seen trees with such a round circumference tops. Around each of their trunks you will see the prayers and wishes of many. Entrance to the shrine is free. We didn't venture into any gardens. We spent about an hour visiting.

A serene place in the big city!. Once you enter you forget that you are in a city. This is a must see in Tokyo. Just don't wear sandals because the path to the shrine is gravel which can make for an uncomfortable walk.
Well worth a visit. Quite a lot of walking involved with this shrine, but well worth it - especially for the irises in June!

Nice, but not overly impressive. I think it's because I had been to Nikko the day before that the Meiji Jingu didn't meet my expectations. It is in a lovely garden setting, and is very well maintained, etc., but it just looked far too "new". Meiji Jingu is the Shinto shrine that is dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shōken.It is apparently considered something very special by the Japanese - I thought it was a bit dull. Loved the gardens though!

Very beautiful and serene. The Meji Jingu Shrine and Gardens were so beautiful! To be honest, I enjoyed walking around the gardens more than the shrine itself, because the shrine was rather crowded with tourists, but walking through the garden was like walking through a forest - it was quiet and peaceful, and so beautiful. Unfortunately, I was not there for the peak iris season, but I can imagine how beautiful it would be when the flowers are in full bloom. While the Meji grounds are free to enter, there is a small fee of ¥500 to enter the garden area, but I would definitely recommend it because it was very serene.

Serene walk, a must see. Temple was under renovation when we went and they are now strict with pictures, admonishing tourists trying to take pictures of the prayer box, which was annoying (you pay a fee for a number that comes out of a shaken prayer box, then you match your number to a blessing). We had come several years ago and taken great pictures, not sure why it's a problem now (knocked it down a star)The park is well maintained and we went during the iris bloom and was specked in colors! The trails have tight gravel and can be navigated with a stroller with a few areas of stairs that are not too taxing to lift it along if you are similarly encumbered. There are signs in English, facilities and lots of people! Come early or on a weekday to find a bit of that serenity!
Beautiful Shrine. An amazing shrine in a middle of a unbelievably serene park. I did not think this could exist in such a large city. Come early to avoid crowds and to get good photos.

Lovely setting in the park. We had a really nice walk through Yoyogi park to get here as part of a walk from Shinjuku to Shibuya. Quite busy but our first visit to a larger shrine in the country and well worth it.

Beautiful and peaceful - a must visit attraction. We entered via the Yoyogi (NE entrance) which was super quiet and peaceful. Luckily, we were able to experience a wedding procession. The iris garden was beautiful. After spending around an hour we exited the main Harajuku entrance which was considerably busier.

Great Shrine - come early!. We ended up taking the long way around and not through the “main” entrance from Yoyogi Station on the Yamanote Line. This was actually quite nice since we bypassed the parking lot and the tour buses. For a while, it felt like we were walking alone through a forest towards a shrine – until we hit the main shrine area. The shrine itself is pretty plain, but very peaceful and it was a great “first” shrine for us. After visiting over 7-8 other shrines in between Tokyo, Hakone, Osaka, and Kyoto, I still think the charms sold at Meiji Shrine are the prettiest and have the best quality. Also, I purchased my temple stamp book here at Meiji and after going to all the other shrines (and spying on other people’s stamp books while in line), I think the one sold at Meiji is definitely the prettiest – it’s more elegant and distinct that others.
Quiet and serene. Entered from the Yoyogi side, which the path in was much quieter, would recommend rather than coming from the Harajuku side which is much more crowded.

Must visit if you are in Tokyo. Its primarily one of the major tourist attractions in Japan, as such its a must visit for first timers. I've actually taken the time to visit the location all 3 times I visited Japan. I'd recommend taking it as part of a tour package, otherwise its right behind Harajuku JR stop and near MeijiJingu-Mae Metro stop

Peaceful but bring soap. We wanted to go to Harajuku and got off at the Meiji Jingumae station so decided to see this shrine first. It's in a huge park but is currently under renovation. However, being a Sunday, we lucked out and saw a traditional Japanese wedding! Huge park but beautiful and quiet. No place to sit though and the bathrooms have no soap so be prepared!

Tranquility in Tokyo. This shinto shrine, was a peaceful slice of heaven, spent 1-2 hours strolling under trees, and was lucky enough to witness a traditional shinto wedding. Tip: After Meiji jingu, you are only a short stroll away from Takeshitedori, Omote sando & Shibuya...

Peaceful in the morning. We had heard that it was best to visit the shrines early in the morning so we got there on a Monday morning by 9.00am which was great as it wasn't that busy.There is a long path on the way to the Meiji Shrine that show barrels of concecrated wine donated by the French wineries as well as barrels of sake wrapped in straw which make a great background for a photo. Walked up to the shrine and did the usual rituals of purifying yourself with the water, giving a donation then clapping twice and bowing. It was a nice and peaceful thing to do. As we were walking out the tourist buses arrived and there were masses of people so it was well worth getting there early where you could appreciate it.

Our first visit to a Shinto Shrine. Although there were loads of people (tourists) about we still found this place fascinating. Our guide showed us how to purify our hands and mouths and then on to the shrine where we were told to bow deeply twice then clap hands twice then bow again and then pray. As the Japanese say r's instead of l's the instructions made us giggle! We saw several couples going in the surrounding buildings to be married and were all beautifully dressed. A very interesting place.

Beautiful Park to visit in the morning. If, like me, you are suffering from any jet lag and waking up very early, then this is a great place to enjoy the morning sun. Opens and sunrise, is extremely quiet until around 09:00 and is incredibly beautiful and tranquil. I would recommend paying to go into the emperors gardens and seeig the karp pond, irises and the well. I did see a snake crossing the footpath in front of us; something to keep in mind if you have pets/ small children.

Amazing shrine in the middle of the city. We were wowed when we saw the massive Torii (gate) soon after exiting the Harajuku Station. From the entrance to the shrine, the long straight, path is lined on both sides by massive trees apparently replanted from other parts of Japan, forming a green canopy that transports you away from the hustle and bustle of the city. A bit of a pity that parts of the shrine were covered up for restoration works when we were there.
Nice temple with many weddings!. Saw two traditional weddings when visited this place. Very cool. The temple is nice and the park surrounding is well worth a visit.

Nice and Serene. It was a great leisure walk. We started from the Harajuku entrance and walked to the shrine It felt like we were in the middle of a forest and not the middle of busy Tokyo. The shrine is under construction but it didn't take away from it's beauty. I love the ritual of cleansing before sending your prayers. I wished we could have gone into the shrine and seen everything up close. Nonetheless, the entire experience left me feeling blessed and peaceful.
Tranquility personified! . Visiting Meiji Jingu was certainly awe inspiring. Strolling through the beautifully maintained grounds leading up to the temple itself was harmonious!

Nice walk. Being so close to Harajuku this was a nice peaceful walk away from everything, we were lucky enough to view a traditional wedding on the grounds which just looked amazing with the back drop. The shrines were covered with scaffolding this time but I loved how the scaffold plastic had the picture of the shrine on it so you could still see what was there.
Have a walk in Meiji Jingu . Meiji Jingu is very peaceful place, it's like a huge park with historical buildings and art stuff. Surrounding with lot plants, it's also good to have a walk there.

Very beautiful and serene. We visited Meiji Jingu with a local friend, and it was a wonderful experience. Tucked away in a well manicured, deeply shady park (offering a much needed break from summer heat!), the shrine is a once a solemn place and welcoming of foreigners. Signs explain a ritual involving purification with water, bowing, clapping, and depositing of coins. Various charms are available for the equivalent of just a few USD (between about 300 and 800 yen), and make lovely gifts.

Breathtakimg. Visiting this shrine is a must for anyone coming to Tokyo for a visit. It offers some great walks and is effectively free to visit. A great way to experience some traditional Japanese culture when in the hustle bustle of Tokyo.

Peaceful and shady park. The temple is being renovated so nothing to see there but they have a bonsai display of trees hundreds of years old. The park is large, shady and peaceful (no jogging allowed) and seems to be a shortcut across town. We utilized it like that several times.

Peacefull and calm. That is a beautiful and peaceful place to spend free time. I'm happy we went there. It was a lot of people, but I still felt like very calm and peaceful place. Just I didn't see any bench to sit and enjoy a day, so I came back home very tired, walked without stop too much :P

Big and peaceful temple. You will supervise with the big gate. It is not crowded as others. You can see the japanese culture about temple in here, pray for best, drink pure water. Especially it is easy to go somewhere near here like yoyogipark, shibya..

Impressive temple. Impressive size gates and temple and provides a nice stroll to walk through the grounds. You have the option to put a wish/prayer (for a fee) on wood that hangs from a big tree and are expected to wash your hands in the special water before going up to the temple. Can't really go in the temple building but can walk up to and around the grounds.

A-ok!. Located just a few minutes walk from Harajuku Station, the Meiji Jingu Shrine is a peaceful and serene area right in the middle of the city.As opposed to practically everywhere else we went, there was plenty of space here to move around and explore the grounds. The forest area is large and expansive and very well maintained. It was very calming to just walk around and take in Mother Nature for a little bit. The actual Shrine its self, while not nearly as ornate as all the Thai temples I have visited, was still beautiful and quite striking! We would just observe what the locals were doing as far as rituals and customs and the like. It was fascinating taking it all in!The park is free to wander about, however they do have an "Inner Garden" available to see for 500 Yen ($4.14 USD), as well as the Meiji Jingu Treasure House, also for 500 Yen. Don't forget to check out the wall of sake barrels and wine barrels along the pathway as well.Another tidbit I have to throw in is the public restrooms here were freaking spotless! This part alone impressed the hell out of me! lolThis is an easy to find Shrine and worthy of a spot on your Tokyo itinerary, especially if staying in the Shinjuku or Shibuya area!
Massive gate!. Massive gate! Nice shady trail with surprises around each corner. See this to get away from the rush of the city. Temples here and there with nice photo ops!
Quiet place. Nice place to enjoy a quiet nature walk in the middle of a hectic city. A good spot to experience the religious culture.
beautiful. this is another great shrine and park. The wood gates, emperors sake collection, and gardens are all worth the visit. Very easy to get to off the subway.

A temple in the middle of the city. This temple of hundreds of years and it is still standing along with its tradition. Although it is located not far from Harajuku, you felt like you are up in the mountain for the serene of it.

Large Shinto shrine amid serene greenery in the heart of the city. Large Shinto shrine in man-planted forest. Beautiful architecture. Interesting rituals to perform. Kids enjoyed visit here. Lots of space to run around.

Historical place!. Surrounded by lush green garden, this place offer tribute to great Emperor Meiji. Calm and peaceful environment, one of the historical attraction in Tokyo. Remember to check-out various bonsai trees in the corridor.
Beautiful and serene shrine. Very nice and located in a beautiful and serene location. Make sure to pay attention to the custom of cleansing before entering the shrine. Go early to avoid crowds.
Absolutely stunning and very relaxing. The Torii is large and old, and the space is quiet and zen. Very relaxing and surrounded by beautiful nature.

Wonderful . You cannot visit the inner part of the temple, as it usually happens with buddist temples, but both the huge "torii" which open the path to sacred area are really spectacular.
Before the entrance there's a garden (500¥ per person) with a lot of flowers - in this period, the iris are really colourful.
It really worths!
Just awe. Amazing and beautiful place to people watch. There are a lot of visitors but you still have space around you to move freely. It's amazing to understand the history.

Wonderful and relaxing . The whole Jojogi park with Meiji Jingu temple is so calm and peaceful, so relaxing. While there you should definitely spare a few moments to give a pray to goods. Definitely worth visiting.

Beautiful + artistic . Close to harajuku station.. Around 15 min walk from d main street.. Lots of food n shops on d walk.. V reached at around 6 pm.. Luckily in time.. Closing time was 630'' the tori gates welcome you'm lovely place . V peaceful..

An island of tranquillity between Shinjuku and Shibuya. Meiji Jingu is the most important and famous Shinto shrine in Tokyo. It is located between Shinjuku and Shibuya adjacent to Harajuku in the middle of Yoyogi Park. The whole setup is very tranquil especially after busy Shinjuku, where we were staying. While I did not find it impressive architecturally, it has great calming feeling while you walk through the park passing by two stacks of barrels, one with sake and another with Boudreaux wine and then entering the shrine itself. It feels like you are out of town in countryside. As it was the first Shinto shrine we saw, it is difficult to compare to older and more magnificent shrines in Kyoto and Miyajima, but it is definitely worth going. Unfortunately we got there in the late afternoon and the Inner Garden was already closing so we could not visit it.

To be honest...we have seen better in Japan.. This is just our opinion but in all our travels to Tokyo and the rest of Japan I really have to say that the shrine was just not that interesting. I cannot argue the importance for the people living in Tokyo when it comes to this place but it didn't have the impact we hoped it would have on us. The shrine was literally overrun by locals and tourists so it wasn't a very relaxing experience. The park surrounding the shrine is beautiful and a great respite from the hustle and bustle that is Harajuku.

Meiji Jingu. Serene temple in the middle of the city. The entrance is only a 2 minute walk from Harajuku station. The huge tori gate which welcomes you at the entrance is impressive and the walk towards the temple is beautiful. We visited on a Sunday which meant we managed to capture a few wedding processions and few other religious activities going on throughout our visit. We went there around 8.30 in the morning and it was relatively busy but by the time we left around noon, it was very busy as with most tourist spots. Many reviewers has pointed out that there are more impressive temples / shrines around Japan, but I think if you're only visiting Tokyo and have a spare Sunday, Meiji Jingu is a must visit for me. It is also the temple with the most activities going around compared to all the other we've visited in Tokyo, Kyoto & Osaka.

Complete Serenity in the heart of the city. You will completely forget that you are just minutes away walking from the crazy fun that is Harajuku. The serenity that surrounds the shrine is something to be experienced, even if you are not religious. Be respectful (follow the signs), and don't take pictures of the monk activities. This is posted, but many people ignore the signs. This was the only drawback of the experience- people not respecting the signs and just taking pictures of whatever they wanted. We felt most privileged to be able to experience the shrine and enjoyed a nice walk through the forest after. It was a great escape from the city, and had an energy of its own. You can see the giant sake bottles out front as well which is worth the visit in itself.

Gorgeous park. A very peaceful park that bridges Shinjuku and Harajuku. The peace and serenity inside belies the noise and traffic so close, but unseen. Small enough that you can see it all. I didn't do the treasure museum. The main temple building has weddings, which are fun to be a bystander to...the women in gorgeous traditional costume.
Beautiful park. Awesome park that feels as though you have completely left the city. Nice walks and shrines. Recommend to anyone looking for a spot of nature in the heart of the city

Quiet place in the middle of the city. I love this shrine. It's definitely more low key in my opinion. It's nice for a walk when you want get away from the noise of Harajuku. There's also a garden which you have to pay an entry fee for admittance. June is my favorite time here due to the irises in bloom, but I think they also have azaleas in the spring.

If you are going to visit one shrine, this is the one. If you are not familiar with the Shinto religion, this shrine is a must go to. It's situated in a forest setting in the city. After passing thru the torii gates, there are drums of sake and barrels of wine from France. There's signs there to explain to visitors about the wine and sake. It's a nice quiet place to visit in the city.

An oasis.... In the middle of the buy city of Tokyo...we loved walking in this "forest" , so quiet when outside the city was busy as ever....we were lucky enough to see two weddings processionals and a flower arrangement exhibition...don't miss it if you plan to visit Tokyo
Nice walk in the park. Nice getaway from the city. Just like central park in New York.... coolest part was the wedding taking place there. Bride was beautiful.

Tranquility behind the concrete. Jump off at Harajuku Station and wander through the impressive gate and immerse yourself in the tranquility of this amazing shrine and its gardens. We were lucky to experience a wedding there. A must see.

Peaceful first experience in Japan. After getting in late and taking the train from Narita to Shinjuku, we were beat and just slept in that night. The next morning, this was our first stop. We hopped the train from Shinjuku to Yoyogi in Shibuya and headed to this shrine. The walk through Yoyogi park was lovely, and coming up on the Meiji Shrine was impressively peaceful and relaxing. We were there early, so we didn't encounter too many people, just us and a few others. We walked up to the area where you wash your hands and mouth before entering, per tradition -- we tried to participate in these whenever possible and appropriate -- and after doing so we entered the shrine. It was quite beautiful in its simplicity, and it was great to see all the traditional ceremonies in motion (a wedding was happening, Shinto priests were about doing their work). It was a great way to start our trip. Recommend going early in the morning to avoid a lot of human traffic, as it is a very popular shrine.

Very peaceful shrine in huge park. The shrine was tranquil and was an enjoyable trip - the shrine is within a huge park which was good to walk around. A welcome break from how busy and built up Tokyo can be. Very close to a subway stop so easy to get to and from.

Find the hidden lake in the back of Meiji Jingu!. Very nice temple, but also very touristy and crowded. I wandered off the foresty trail just behind the temple and found this nice lake area. Lots of people sitting on the grass and just having picnics. There were also a few people meditating. It was very quiet and peaceful, very different than the main area where people visit. I recommend walking around the premises, away from the crowds.

An oasis in the middle of the city. The shrine is surrounded with lush trees, providing a relaxing walk as you go from one attraction to another. My favorite area has got to be the one with the barrels. One can also offer a prayer made of paper or wood at the shrine. You can find some restaurants and vending machines in the vicinity.

Inner Peace. We came here a few years ago to make a wish. The wish came true and we came back to give thanks.This place is also very popular for weddings and given the surroundings, it's not surprising.If your wish comes true, you MUST return to give thanks.
Good for first time experience. Good to just walk and see the scenery and spend time with friends, take many photos. But put on sunscreen and mosquito repellent during the summer
worth a visit. This shrine is worth a visit, set in lovely grounds. Shrine is currently going some building work but there is still a lot to see. Lovely place on a hot day.
We saw a wedding ceremony!. Amazing surroundings! And timing was so good that we caught 2 weddings going on! One was photoshootIng and the other was progression to their ceremony.

Beautiful and peaceful. Meiji Jingu is so beautiful. The restaurants and apartments are so small. This shrine is located in the middle of Tokyo and it is so spacious and big. Please be prepared to walk a lot. And don't bring any any luggage as the road is fill with pebbles and it's very difficult to pull your luggage.
Nice walk . Decided to passbook morning away by visiting Meiji Jingu shrine . Was lovely walk up to the main temple / really is an amazing sight to take you back to that period of time
One of the biggest temple in Tokyo. We came here in the mid May, no cherry blossom....but the place was nice and very big place. And we we came, there is a thailand food festival near the park.

Beautiful walkand a shrine. The area surrounding the shrine is a beautiful park, it takes more or less 10-15 minutes to walk up, but you can spend a lot longer exploring the park itself. A lovely place, but full of tourists, so next time we would come in the morning to avoid the crowds and make the most out of the quiet atmosphere. The shrine itself is very impressive, and such a stark contrast with Harajuku area, could not be any more different.

Enjoyable, interesting and beautiful shrine. But get there early to avoid crowds. An enjoyable, interesting and beautiful shrine in Shibuya. I would advice visiting this shrine early in the day before the crowds build up. It is one of the busiest tourist spots in Tokyo...for good reason...its cool.

Beautiful natural refuge in central Tokyo. Tokyo is a vital, energetic and constantly changing city. One permanent, unchanging refuge in the center of this busy -- and sometimes overwhelming metropolis -- is the beautiful Meiji Shrine. It is an oasis of calm, quiet, greenery in the great city. A visit to Meiji Shrine will refresh and restore any exhausted traveler!Dedicated to the Emperor Meiji, the Japanese ruler who presided over the modernization and Westernization of his country. Emperor Meiji ruled from 1867 to 1912, and that period witnessed the transformation of Japan from a somnolent agricultural society to a powerful industrial empire in the late-19th and early-20th century. The shrine is particularly crowded on major national holidays, and especially on New Years Day, when millions of Tokyo citizens and visitors flock there as their first shrine pilgrimage of a new year.The Meiji Shrine occupies several hundreds of acres -- much of the space left as natural, barely tended forest. It is full of birds and small wild animals, serving as much as a refuge for them as for Tokyo's human inhabitants. The main avenues approaching the shrine are broad and graveled, easily accommodating the throngs that visit the shrine on holidays or on Sundays. On weekdays, these walkways are quiet and sparsely populated. Step off the main avenues, and one finds oneself on narrow paths through the forest, feeling as distant from the surrounding city life as if one were hiking through the mountains. It feels quite amazing to be so isolated and private while only a few minutes away from one of the largest, busiest cities in the world!Often one encounters weddings or Shinto ceremonies (such as "hatsumode," when a family brings a newborn child for his or her first visit to the Shinto deities) at the Meiji Shrine, and the ceremonials are a faint reminder of modern Japan's connection with its ancient agricultural and animistic origins. The Meiji Shrine was a favorite refuge for the Empress Shoken, consort of the Meiji Emperor, who frequently visited the pavilions surrounded by beautiful gardens. Her gardens have been preserved much as they were in the late-19th century. A spectacular moment to visit the shrine gardens each year is in early June, when the famous iris gardens are in full bloom. Thousands of iris plants (largely of the "shobu" and "ayame" types, generally called "Siberian Iris" in the U.S. and Europe), are displayed in gorgeous rivers of purple and blue and white. It is a spectacular sight, especially beautiful in the gentle rain of the Japanese rainy season, and should be a highlight of any June visit to Tokyo!
Relaxing. Very nice place! A lot of ancient history in this garden. We walked from Sunroute Shinjuku hotel which took about 15-20 minutes.

Gorgeous Shrine to Visit!. The entrance of Shrine just 2 minute walking distance from Harajuku Station (JR Line), however it tooks you 10-15minutes to complete the walking street before enter the main areas of Shrine.
Lots of tourists but why?. A bit out of the centre, quiet area, in the forest, lots of tourist busses, because it's easy to get there by bus? Didn't quite get the attraction.

Under Renovation. It is next to Yoyogi park, about 10 minute walk from Shibuya station. A place of worship / religious ceremony for Japanese but full of foreigner tourists (like me). The front gate is undergoing removation but there is a giant poster with the photo of the original gate in there. I was lucky to came across a wedding there..rare and unforgetable experience.

A beautiful walk. Mieji Jingu is a shrine, located in the centre of beautiful gardens. You'll need a few hours to walk this beautiful park/forest. Harajuku Station is right outside so access is easy. Definitely worth the trip.

Weddings Japanese style. I came yesterday expecting nothing as I had ine day to spend following business trip. I have no experiance with the Japanese wedding ceremony including the ling photo session.
The shrine is impressive, however i guess there are nicer shrines.
The path from the gates to the shrine from every direction is so relaxing.
Loved it.

Don't miss this area. Both the shrine and the surrounding park (or forest?) are really worth seeing in Tokyo. If you only have time to see one park - I'd say this is the one worth seeing, or perhaps the imperial palace surrounds (for the flowers etc.). It's a beautiful getaway from the hussle and bustle of Tokyo, and the best part is the park is right next to Harajuku!

Must see!! Entrance is less than a min walk from Harajuku Station!!. Need more than 20min walk from the entrance actually, so you'd better to have walking shoes. But the walk way is very wide and sorrowed by deep forest. Cannot imagine this is in the centre of Tokyo City. We just bumped into a wedding over there, so my daughter, 7 years old, was very keen on it because of unique wedding dress. There is a nice restaurant inside, so you can enjoy coffee and food if you are tired to walk.

Do not miss!. Easily accessible ( if you are in a private car with people requiring assistance, you can drive right up to the entrance) by subway, but you feel like you're in the forest..which you are! You can have your fortune told in a poem by the Empress Shoken, or write your wishes on a wall; all of these are accompanied by a 100 yen offering- about $1. But entrance is free. It is magnificent and eerie at the same time. If you're in Tokyo, this visit is a must, no matter how many shrines you have already seen.

Island of tranquility in the heart of Tokyo. Meiji Shrine is located in central Tokyo, but upon entering, you will see that it's an island of peace and tranquility in the middle of a metropolis. I find the forest walk relaxing. The shrine is one of the most important landmarks in Tokyo, and there was no admissions fee. If you are pressed on time and have to choose between Meiji Shrine or the Imperial Palace, I recommend Meiji Shrine.

My Number One in Tokyo. This is the shrine of the Meiji Emperor immortalized in cinema as the emperor in The Last Samurai. It's a very beautiful walk to the temple through majestic gates. On the way to the main temple there are tributes to the Meiji emperor; on the right side a wall of sake from Japanese admirers, on the left casks of wine from great French wineries. The shrine itself is beautifully serene despite the number of tourists.  Make sure to get your fortune at one of the kiosks. If it's bad you leave it tied by the kiosk, if it's good you take it with you. It's also possible to make wishes by writing them on wooden tablets which you hang by the beautiful trees flanking the temple. It's an experience visiting this shrine. I loved it. The closest subway station is Harajuku, so you can get to see the diametrically quirky side of Tokyo just across Meiji Jingu.

Nice (but "miss-able" if you are going to Kyoto). An oasis of piece near a particularly manic part of Tokyo. Interesting display of sake barrels along the 20 minute walk to the shrine (the barrels are empty - hadn’t realized the importance of sake as a symbol in the Shinto religion until I saw that). The shrine itself is of limited interest. Overall, interesting, but “miss-able” if you are also going to Kyoto or seeing major temples elsewhere. Makes sense to do this as part of a day in Harajuku or Shibuya.

Just the structure for photos. This is more like a tickbox item and not a must. The nearest station is Harajuku and not Shibuya, really. It's a long walk to the actual temple, but this is where you try the green tea and sakura softies!

Tranquil, peaceful and large shrine nestled in the park. Before reaching the shrine, you'll have to walk through a large park - extremely soothing to the soul and highly recommended. Cool weather (in May), sun filtering through the leaves - one cannot recommend Meiji Jingu enough. The shrine is located beside Yoyoji park, perfect for a stroll.

A MUST-DO! Close enough to the city, but far enough for nature.. I did not think I would love this shrine as much as I did. I knew it was a big deal, and knew it was close to Harajuku, but that's about it. I approached the shrine from the North Entrance because my JR Pass expired, so I used a Tokyo Metro line (which was great because I passed a 7-11 on the way and got to pick up some goodies) and walked south until I saw heavy trees; then I followed the crowds until I approached an enormous torii gate and knew I was in the right place!I easily spent 2 and a half hours here; it was an absolutely gorgeous and refreshing walk to the temple, because the path is covered with a tree canopy and a lovely path. I could walk up and down that path all day and be completely content. The temple path juts off to the side once you hit the intersection, so keep an eye on your orientation; you could easily accidentally leave the temple woods without seeing the Shrine!Somewhat opposite to the temple path is a beautiful wall of sake barrels, and behind the wall is an AMAZING gift shop; I bought some handbags and fans for my family and they absolutely loved it.Anyways, continue onto the temple entrance and you'll be greeted with a BREATHTAKING view of....scaffolding for a restoration project! Haha. I was there in May and the main entrance was covered in scaffolding for restoration, but please enjoy it anyways! Most historical locations are not restored often, so you're actually witnessing a historical event. That aside, the actual shrine itself is gorgeous, with one of the most beautiful prayer trees I have ever seen. It's definitely worth the time to see and enjoy!

Lovely shrine. This shrine is located right next to the JR harajuku station. Just exit station and turn right. No entrance fee is required. The route into the shrine is beautiful. Help yourself to the spring water, the local will wash their hands there. The shrine is also popular with weddings. Go in the morning, if you are lucky you can witness a wedding ceremony at the shrine.

Surprisingly eerie.. We visited Meiji Jingu as part of our must-see activities in Tokyo.It was a great experience. Lots of subway stations around the park so it is convenient to get to. The activity is free.Then we walked through the woods probably for about 10 minutes until we reached the shrine. The shrine is beautiful, though maybe not the most impressive I have seen in Japan.The park and shrine were quite eerie we thought, despite the thousands of people there. As a side note be aware that even at the entrance outside of the park it is forbidden to sit down on the ground, as I found out when a police officer reprimanded me while I was changing shoes.

Beautiful temple. The grounds of the temple are very pretty and serene. It's about a 15-20 minute walk from the subway station to the actual temple. There is no charge for the temple but to see a well on the way to the temple there is a small fee.
Oasis in the city . This shrine and the surrounding parklands/gardens is a green oasis in the middle of a bustling city. Wandering through here makes it easy to forget you're in Tokyo.

Plan to stay more than an hour. We visited Meiji shrine with a tour, and we wished we could have stayed longer because the area was so large that it remained peaceful while absorbing large numbers of visitors. The main buildings, first built in 1920 and built again in 1958, appear brand new or well maintained. The majestic shrine venerates the Meiji emperor and his wife who symbolize the country's abrupt change from traditional culture to a new industrialized and fully-armed country, erasing the samurai class and leaning away from Buddhism toward Shinto which was declared the state religion. Though the grounds and buildings symbolize the new Japan, entering through the torii gate and experiencing them seemed like a return to a more peaceful and graceful past with traditional Shinto shrine architecture and open, lovely grounds.

Peaceful place. The posts are just fantastic which lead in to a lovely forest park, with majestic trees and a peaceful atmosphere. You then walk to the shrine itself. There was a Japanese wedding when we were there and the bride looked stunning in her traditional wedding dress.
