You can look in all the buildings but cannot enter the main part itself, only see through.Once you enter into Meiji Jingu you don't feel you are in Tokyo, its so calm and has its own pace.

Such an important part of Tokyo history. Our guide to Tokyo felt it was a must for us to visit the shrine to the great emperor Meiji who was responsible for revolutionising and modernising Japan despite his very young age ascending to the throne. A huge, beautiful, peaceful and very special garden (forest really) and shrine make this a worthwhile place to have in any tourist's itinerary.

Nice gardens, signs in English and a good atmosphere. Good atmosphere, I really liked the small gardens that cost a little extra to walk around in. I also liked that the signs were in English as well so I could understand what the wine and rice wine barrels meant. Good access to nice food. My family and I were there for Golden Week so it was nice to see the traditional Japanese plays that were going on.

Lovely place to walk. We arrived in Tokyo straight off the plane went to Meiji Jingu. You are greeted with the fantastic posts which lead in to a lovely forest park, with majestic trees and a calm atmosphere. You then walk to the shrine itself. There was a Japanese wedding when we were there and the bride looked stunning in her traditional wedding dress, as well as her guests. You can look in all the buildings but cannot enter the main part itself, only see through, but there was a tree where you could look at requests or thanks to the spirits which was touching. Really worth a visit.

Can't tell you're in a city! . Lovely shrine surrounded by trees. We didn't get long here so didn't get to see the other buildings near the cafe. You would tell you're in yhe middle of a massive city. Very peaceful.

Tranquil . While the spot is quite busy some of the walks are clear of people and just majestic. The entrances to the attraction are large and very cool. The walks in the forest will give you a truly calming feeling. It is free and I would not recommend a tour guide.

Amazingly peaceful. Although there were many people walking through the park to the shrine, it still felt peaceful. I managed to visit as the sun was setting and the sunlight was peering through the trees. This made the experience even more beautiful and finished at the shrine. The fact that there is a park of such beauty and size in the middle of Tokyo just dedicated to the former emperor just encapsulates the Japanese spirit. A must see.

A quite place in the centre of the city. I visited Meiji Jingu last month, the castle itself is amazing located inside a forest in the middle of a crowded city.You will find a huge wooden tori inside the castle, there's so many trees and the place is so quite. with all those great experience it all comes in free.

The Old and the Modern. Our tour group stopped at this temple in the middle of the week. Rather quiet. If you walk further on a certain path, you would encounter a forest and then a modern skyline.The tour guide said that the posts of the temple gate are considered power posts. If you hug one of them, you would gain power.

Absolutely Must-Go. With all the history behind the Meiji Jingu, this place is truly majestic. When entering the park, you can already see the wine and sake barrels with the information of how and why they were there.The gates were huge and impressive and when arriving at the Shrine, it was even better. All the people respecting their past Emperor, praying and being themselves in their thoughts.We paid the extra entrance fee for the garden and it was really worth the money. The tea-house of the Empress, the pond where she used to fish and so on.This place is even good to visit when the temperature is high, as the trees gave us shade and there was a mild breeze.

Majestic!. Such a serene place in the heart of busy Tokyo. Just step out at yoyogi station and follow the signs. If you continue the path through the park you'll end up in harajuku ^^ the shrine itself is beautiful and there are often weddings held on Sundays which is also amazing to witness :)

Pretty but busy. The gates are pretty imposing and the temple itself is pretty, but it's was very busy when we went and there is not too much to actually do.In terms of sightseeing, there are better options out there. I would go if you were in the area but I wouldn't make a special trip.

Must go for those who like Japanese temple. Comparing to the Senso-Ji Temple, this is a bigger and more serene place. Go on a Sunday to see more activities. We caught a Tai-Ku performance and a few wedding processions.

A thoroughly relaxing place. Beautiful, and a great rest from the visual and audio bombardment of harajukuWorth visiting the inner garden too. There is a reasonable amount of walking involved to see the whole place, so wear good shoes. Be aware that while the gardens are open to about 6pm the treasure house closes at 4:30

Experience Shinto Shrine . If this is your first trip to Japan, a visit to a Shinto shrine is peaceful and expressive of one part of Japanese culture. Go early if you can since the tours and crowds do get in the way of the shrine's quiet beauty. And when photographing, try to aim high and capture the huge handsome trees surrounding the shrine.Free admission. Although next to the JR Meiji Station, a bit more walking to get the building. Park like environment. Great thing about traveling in Tokyo- plenty of clean restrooms everywhere. No exceptions here. On Saturdays and Sunday's, usually will be able to spot a traditional wedding ceremony in progress. Then walk across and down the hill to Harajuku for a totally different experience.

Peaceful Setting. This is place is absolutely peaceful and gorgeous. The have a beautiful that is lined with tall trees leading up to the shrine. If you are lucky enough you be sure to see a traditional Japanese wedding. This is a great shrine to explore and a quick escape from the city.

Beautiful. I brought my teens there, who were not impressed with the overwhelming beauty of the place (they said it's just a park). I suggest paying the 500 Yen to go into the Inner Garden to see Kiyomasa's Well and all of the scenery and trails.

Good place. Very peacefull surroundings, good garden and forest. Good walking place from the entrance to shrine. Enjoy the wind blowing through trees and the sound of leaves.
In the shrine we see traditional japanese wedding ceremony.

Large open grounds, huge shrine in the heart of Harajuku . We visited the shrine on a sunny spring day. It is right at the exit of Harajuku station so easy to get there by train.It is a decent walk on compacted gravel to reach the shrine. We had our 2yr old in a stroller thankfully though a little hard to push.We were lucky to witness a Japanese wedding taking place that day there.Huge area, good for kids to run around but not a lot to interest them at the shrine.Glad we visited but won't go back next time.
Beautiful place. You take a long peaceful path towards the temple. There you will find several beautiful buildings and trees. A place worth visiting

Wonderful shrine and park!. Go on a Sunday if you can. We were able to witness a Japanese wedding procession. The gardens is also very nice and big, although I expected it to be bigger because it has a separate 500 yen admission ticket. It is good for relaxing if you need to sit down from walking and want to enjoy nature.

Meiji Shrine. The Shrine is located just across the Meijijingumae station. Will require a bit of walking so wear comfortable shoes. This is a religious site so please behave while in the shrine. Observe how others behave, e.g., washing of hands, bowing, clapping of hands, etc. If you're lucky, you may be able to witness an actual Shinto wedding march which we did!
Beautiful. Well worth the long walk from the station :-) Beautiful shine of historic significance. I can only recommend the experience.

Forest within a ultra modern metropolis. This is one of many areas in the city where you can sneak off to away from the hustle and bustle of city life and relax by communing with nature. I would suggest starting from Yoyogi Park and working your way through the paths towards the shrine and the forest ending up in Harajuku Station JR Line. From there you can either hop on the train back to your accommodations or continue your explorations of Takeshi-dori Street, Harajuku and surrounding areas.

City forest. I was there during golden week and there was a ceremony inside, start from 10am. you can have a fortune pendant for 500yen. The toilet is really clean and modern, but unfortunately it was quite far from the entrance and the exit.

Meiji Shrine. The shrine is accessible by train (Meijijingumae station). A bit of walking is required so wear comfy shoes. Observe the courtesy when entering the shrine, e.g., no loud talking and rowdiness. Read instructions or observe others on the ceremonial washing of hands, bowing, clapping, etc. If you're lucky enough, you might be able to catch an actual Shinto wedding ceremony like we did!

Interesting and in a lovely setting. Enjoyed our wander through Yoyogi park and he visit to the Meiji shrine and various museums. A great day out after the hustle and bustle of Tokyo but would recommend trying to avoid the weekend if you can as it gets crowded.

serene and peaceful. walking half afternoon to nearby Yoyogi Park was a bit tiring for us but soon as we entered the area of Meiji Shrine, we feel at peace; watching and witnessing people bowing respectfully towards the shrine before entering and leaving. Many boards along the way giving info. We went to the "cleansing" place and followed instruction; watching participants is so fascinating, knowing that most, like us, are foreigners. Love it. We witnessed some sort of event where group of people, some in kimono outfit walking; unable to find someone who can tell us what it is but something to behold. Another place is where you buy a wooden plague and you can write you wishes then hang it on the designated area. My husband and I bought one each and when we conferred before hanging the plague, we asked each other our wishes: both - world peace and family health, safety and happiness. Ah, that's what 30 yrs marriage all about, you come to know each other well. I will go back to Meiji shrine if have an opportunity. It has a gift store and next to it, is a cafeteria where foods and drinks are very reasonable. I said this "reasonable" because I find Japan items/restaurants expensive but we have lot of funs while in there.

Great place to relax in the city . I was traveling alone and decided to start my day at Meiji Jingu. It about a 15 min walk from the Shinjuku Washington Hotel and very easy to find. Once I got there, the walk was so tranquil and green. I recommend bringing a blanket and a book to read on the lawn - it was so lovely and relaxing, the perfect way to start off my day of exploring the city. Overall a gorgeous spot with a fascinating history. Highly recommend.

Great green space, with traditional Japanese feel, in the heart of Tokyo!. This was a fun stop during the day...very green and a local sacred place. The shrine was very nice to see and I was surprised as I didn't realize it was an actual place of worship today. The entire park area is very interesting, well shaded, and overall a nice little day trip. You've got to visit if you're in Tokyo!

Scenic and Peaceful. The Meiji Shrine is a lovely park. You walk on a pebbled path surrounded by greenery. People are nicely quiet (cell phones get put away and folks pay attention to their surroundings) and you can enjoy contemplative thoughts. When you come upon the shrine area, you will find the traditional washing basin, prayer envelopes, and people offering money with their prayers in front of the proper locations. Maybe we came upon the Meiji Shrine on a quiet day, but it seemed much less touristy than most popular shrines in Japan. This was an enjoyable place to visit.

Beautiful and a nice little gem. Had the chance to see this beautiful and peaceful shrine. Many people were there but yet it was a place that encourages introspection. Had the wonderful opportunity to witness a wedding procession. While I will never know the couple, I wish them many blessings for a long and prosperous marriage. I thoroughly enjoyed seeing the temple as well as the surrounding nature.

Bonus, we witnessed a wedding ceremony ..... That took place in the shrine. Truly fascinating to watch a traditional wedding. Pleasant walk through yoyogi park to the shrine. Some interesting rituals that you can participate in that makes the visit a bit more memorable

A pretty long walk!. You can access the park from Yoyogi park just next to Harajuku station, right opposite the famous street. From the park entrance however, it is a bit of a trek to the temple across pebbles - I'd definitely be cautious of footwear before heading to this temple as it can be an unpleasant experience otherwise.The area itself is peaceful and the displays before the shrine were beautiful. The architecture is really amazing and its worth a visit. Be mindful as guards will tell off tourists who sit on temple steps or are otherwise disrespectful.

Long walk, nice place. From the train station, it's about a kilometer walk to the temple. As you enter the vicinity prepare to walk on a peppbles. Before entering the temple you will see a well/falls (I'm not sure what's it called) you can follow the instruction on what to do and the purpose of what youre doing. Inside the temple you can relax and take pictures. There are many bench to rest. A very nice place to visit. Just be ready in walking.

Cool and Calm. We weren't planning to go to Meji Jingu today but the stop Harajuku reminded me of the place on my Lonely Planet Guide. The Location was convenient near the JR Yamanote line and there were plent of places to read English information. Also, there was a funeral perfect for the kids to watch and be entertained.
Escape form busy. I have stayed in city so long so visited this kind of place became “something”. There is holy water, remarkable temple, great customs. I suggest to go into the main temple !

Grade A pure awesomeness. It's a cliché to say that this is a haven of peace and quiet in the middle of the Tokyo craziness, but it's actually true. The whole area is surprisingly large, take some time to wander around and have a derive. It's a unique and beautiful environment.

Stunning forest & peaceful temple.. The temple really gives the japan traditional ambience, but don't forget to use comfy shoes because the walk to the temple is quite far. Try writing on the 'Ema' (the wishing wood-block) which is cost for 500yen and hang them on your favorite place :)Interact with the temple staffs & don't forget to take a lot of good pictures at the temple!Make sure not to make a lot of noise and enjoy the peacefulness.

Look for the paths less traveled. Everyone follows the crowd to the main temple, which is awesome and everything that the other reviewers point out, but we discovered that there are other paths back to the entrance torii - duck off to the left towards the treasury buildings, but cut back along the edge of the grounds. We were almost the only ones there for the 20 minute walk back, and felt like crowded Tokyo was a million miles away. Very peaceful walk.

Fascinating. I go to Meiji Shrine when I was in Tokyo for business. It is amazing and great place to feel relaxing. Meiji Shrine is located just beside the JR Yamanote Line's Harajuku station. It's quite easy to get there by public transportation. If you only have little time in Tokyo, you absolutely can not miss visiting Meiji Shrine
Amazing place. Great place with beautiful architecture and Japan soul. I had the opportunity to see traditional Japanese wedding in this temple.

Breathtaking!. I think I saw hundreds of pictures before I went to Meiji Shrine.. and the photos doesn't do it justice.You had to be there to watch the breathtaking view, the sound of the wind blowing through the trees over your head, the beautiful Torii gate.. It was quite an experience.

Peaceful shrine near Harajuku. Highly recommend a trip to this shrine on your day to Harajuku. It is a long walk from the entrance to the shrine itself but well worth it. Very peaceful and a great way to understand and respect Japanese culture.

Amazing. We visited the meiji shrine as part of a day trip to shibuya and harajuku shopping. It was absolutely amazing. the air was great. the walk to the shrine was a bit long but it was worthwhile, great view.

Serenity in the middle of the city. The Meiji Shrine is just off Omotesando and Harajuku, right beside the Yoyogi Park. It's open to everyone and is free of charge except for the inner gardens.You may experience doing a short prayer (with of course, the experience of washing your hands and mouth at the entrance to the shrine itself) without feeling silly as there are instructions in English for you to follow, same goes when you approach the shrine itself to say a short prayer. You may also buy wooden plates to write your intentions or well, if I may say so, wishes on the board and to hang them on pegs near a tree. If you do not wish to spend Y500 on the wooden board, paper with special envelopes are available free of charge but you are encouraged to give a little at the shrine itself.The road leading up to the shrine would remind you of the old Japan, when there were no cars yet. Try to imagine "Samurai X" or "Last Samurai" as you walk towards a shrine or on your way to another town through a forest full of trees.

Wonderful Shinto shrine in the heart of Tokyo. On a glorious day of warm sunshine we decided to visit the Meiji Jingu shrine (明治神宮). This is a Shinto shrine that is dedicated to the deified spirits of the Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shōken.We arrived at Harajuku station and moments later were confronted by the impressive wooden torii (鳥居) gate that leads into the shrine’s precincts, which are set within a very large area of woodland right in the heart of Tokyo.We were even lucky enough to see some of a Shinto wedding while we were there.The Meiji Jingu shrine is certainly worthy of being on anyone’s visit to Tokyo both for the shrine itself and the peaceful shady woodlands it hides within.It’s a beautiful place and even with the visiting crowds it manages to retain an air of peace and tranquillity, which we found can be quite welcome after the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.Highly recommended.

Fairytale woods . Beautiful green park in the middle of the city. We managed to see a lot of people getting married and having their pictures taken in the temple. All in traditional Japanese costumes. We also enjoyed all the small stall selling souvenirs.
Lovely shrine in the middle of bustling city. Very quiet shrine in the middle of a city! Lots of people but very calm. Situated on acres of land and beautiful landscaped gardens. Great scenery.

Peaceful and tranquil surrounded by beautiful wooded area.. The shrine can be accessed either by JR Yamanote line (Harajuku station) or Tokyo Metro Chiyoda line (Meijijingu-mae station). A less than 5 mins walk leads to a massive and impressive Torii gate at the entrance. There is no entrance fees and it's not allowed to eat or drink inside the shrine area.The approximate 10 mins walk to the main shrine is lined by tall trees on either side. You are transported to a world very much different than the hustle and bustle of the mega city that surrounds it and the whole experience is mesmerizing.The structure and architecture of the main shrine is very impressive. A routine of clapping and bowing is required to be followed for offering your respect. Before the side exit there is a place where you can write a wish if you want , place it in an envelope and put in designated boxes (there is an advice on the envelope to offer some money as you desire). As our hotel was in Shinjuku, we walked back through a trail to the left of the side exit. To walk along the tree lined path with calmness all around and listening to the chirping of birds was so refreshing and uplifting.Would strongly recommend this experience.

Beautiful quiet space in the centre of bustling Tokyo. The shrine is surrounded by beautiful gardens which you could easily spend hours wandering around. The shrine is imposing and we were lucky enough to see two wedding parties in traditional dress. The kimonos were beautiful!
The best of Tokyo!. The best of Tokyo. In a crowded and full of lights city, its possible to find peace here to worship a little and get away of the daily basis mass.

My favourite shrine. I visited this shrine on my first morning in Japan and I thought at first that the breathtaking Tori gate, the beautiful forest walk and the serene shrine might have made such an impression on me because it was my first shrine but throughout the holiday I still thought this was one of the best shrines I had visited.

Peace surrounded by 32 million Neighbors. Tokyo is alive and well with stunning architecture, fine dining, courtier shopping, common everyday Ramen and Gyoza shops and 32 million people in or in close proximity to the city. It buzzes and it can be crowded, so that is when you should go to Meiji Jingu to relax and soak in the real world of Japan past and future. The pathways are wide and immaculate. The trees, shrubs and seasonal flowers show their well tended selves as you contemplate nature and the peaceful surroundings and you find yourself whispering or not talking at all. It DEMANDS your silence and that of others. For over 50 years I have trod these paths while living there or visiting. The last time was three weeks ago when we ended our Asian cruise on the ms Volendam in Yokohama/Tokyo and stayed in Shinjuku at the Keio Plaza. When you get to the actual Shinto Shrine area, taking a sip of the cold pure water in a wooden ladle and watch the Priests scurry around in their starched white robes moving like unearthly beings throughout the complex, you remain silent. Though this time was at the end of the Cherry Blossom season there were still some trees that regaled us with their pink delicate patina; but my absolute FAVORITE time to visit Meiji Jingu in its park like setting is in winter on the day of the first snowfall. It is magnificent and silent and mystical. I sadly will probably not experience that again as at 73 I prefer the warmth of our home and usually travel when the weather is more hospitable.And then reality hits you as you exit the park at Harajuku station and you are in the midst of young and middle aged shoppers, posers, and lookers. Though unlike Hong Kong where the cacophony of sounds is what you witness, this is just thousands of trendy people sometimes 6 abreast walking by the expensive and not so expensive shops or stopping to eat at the $$$$$ restaurants nestled next to an $ local ramen shop! It is a glorious way to spend a day! I assure you!

Great peaceful shrine in the heart of tokyo. Very easy to get to - just hop of the JR Yamanote (green) line at Harajuku station and keep to your right leaving the station and you will see the huge wooden tori gate that leads into the park and Meiji Shrine. It is a nice short relaxing walk to the shrine (I would say 5-10 minutes depending on your speed) and the shrine and its surroundings are well worth a visit.

Nice place for a walk (beside the busy city of Japan). Before you walk in to see the Shrine, you will walk in a huge broad walkway with trees beside. It is really something different. We joke about having ninja flying between the trees and start fighting. The directions inside is easy to locate. When we are there, there is a japanese performance going on. We stop and watch a while and later walk out heading to the Harajuku Stn.

a peaceful get away from the city. this shrine is next to the famous shinjuku area. so i recommend going here if you are in shinjuku. Although its inside the crowded city , once you get here you leave all city hassle behind. the shrine it self is small and not so much , but the way to the shrine and the garden sourrounding it is very beautiful with long trees.

nice walk after lunch nearby. Nothing extraordinary about the shrine but it was a nice walk along the way to the shrine. Nearby is the iris garden and some tea room that was once used by the emperor. To enter the garden there was a small fee to be paid for the upkeep of the place.
Beautiful oasis in the heart of Tokyo. Beautiful oasis in the heart of TokyoThis ground of the Meiji Shrine, is a huge green oasis in the heart of Tokyo.Very beautiful, you should not miss it.

Nice shrine, would be better with less crowd. It is an impressive shrine with lot of walking and wooded approach road. The walk is nice but was crowded. We were fortunate to get a free guide volunteer for the shrine. He explained history of the shrine.Overall nice, but crowded.

Quick visit to make a wish. We visited the Meiji Jingu shrine on a wet morning. There were still plenty of tourists, worth the visit. You can make a small donation and make a wish at the main shrine. Lovely lush greenery surrounds the area, quite peaceful and good for a quick activity.

Interesting and free. Interesting visit, the shrine is beautiful but not very peaceful as many tourists (like me)as with all shrines in Japan i would recommend going to visit them.Be sure to do the stick thing, which tells you your future :-)
not worth it . Did not enjoy my time out there long walking distance and finally .. Very ordinary shrine. In my opinion.. Time wasting. I should reconsider going to shrines in Tokyo
Peaceful and good history. Nice walk at the park with rich history if shoguns and samurai of edo period. Nice barrels if sake on the right side of entrance and French wine at the left side!!

An impressive shrine in wonderful environments. Located in a majestic park not far from busy streets, this shrine is has a quiet and majestic beauty. If you like Japanese shrines, you must see it. If you don't, I suggest you give it a chance anyway.
A Sanctuary. What a lovely walk throughout the meandering park and a nice reprieve from busy, crazy, amazing Hirujuku street. With a Matcha ice cream awaiting you in the centre of the gardens.

Nice Entry into Culture. For those travelling to Tokyo who aren't able to check out other places (Kyoto, Himeji), this is the perfect place to feel like you're not in the busy city. It's a nice walk and beautiful grounds. I suggest going on a weekend, as you may be able to see a traditional wedding.

Must visit!. A hop, skip and a jump away from the hustle and bustle of Harajuku Station is the entrance to this beautiful shrine. The tall torii gates greet you as you enter the peaceful sanctuary. Take time out to listen to your footsteps on the stones - the greenery and mesmerizing sounds of the crushing stones will soon over power your mind and take you back in time. A bit of a walk to the main shrine but well worth the visit and a welcome surprise from the noise and people you just left at the station.
nice shrine. not so crowded on weekdays. its nice to know the Japanese culture and their history. You can buy some fortunes herej.

Believe the hype. I have nothing to add to the other raving reviews, but I agree that Meiji Shrine is an amazing forested oasis minutes from Harajuku and Yoyogi park. Go ahead and get lost on the gravel paths and renew your spirits. Keep going past the main Shrine and you emerge on an open area with actual grass (anybody who's been to Tokyo will understand the significance of simple lawn grass upon which one can actually tread) and a view of the skyscrapers of Shinjuku. Because drinking, eating and general carousing are heavily frowned upon (Yoyogi park next door allows all that), this grassy knoll emerging from the woods is a truly relaxing location.
Just old buildings. Well if youre into old stuff, go. If not, there are much, much better ways to spend your precious stuff in tokyo.
Peaceful Meiji Jingu. When you want peace and quiet around Tokyo, you can go visit this park. Park is very clean - you'll see people cleaning the park (in an orderly manner too!)

Outstanding, beautiful and can/should do with children. Large park, with almost no one. Very serene when you think that over 30 million people live in greater Tokyo. The shrine is also very interesting and as it was a Sunday, we were lucky to see three traditional Shinto weddings. The cafeteria/restaurant is good and well located in the middle as the park is big.

Zen Respite After Takeshita Dori. The minute I stepped through the imposing wooden gate of the shrine, the headache which I got from the noisy,loud and crowded Takeshita Dori disappeared. Despite the numerous tourists and visitors , the shrine and its surrounds is calm,peaceful & full of greenery. In fact , I personally think this place is better than the Imperial Gardens. Meiji Jingu is next to Yoyogi Park (which is quite pleasant) but access to the shrine is through separate entrance.

Extremely peaceful environment!. Come here for a rest in the middle of your trip to get that peaceful and relaxing feeling. Write wishes on shrine's wooden board, and ask the Gods for some clues with bamboo sticks.If you are lucky like me, can even spot Bride and groom in traditional kimono!Very peaceful and fun experience.Visited on March 2015

A huge park with a shrine. Beautiful.. After I visited the Japanese sword museum, we headed back towards the Yoyogi Park.We walked thru the park where there are huge trees & actually in some spots couldn't see the sky with the amount of foliage that was around. This park is huge & they're are various paths you can take. There are signs around, so you sort of get an idea on where to go.Then we came upon this shrine. The grounds are quite large. And the craftsmanship is awesome. It was pretty busy. But still an abundance of room around where you're not banging into each other. Saw some parents with their kids, in kimonos walking to & from the shrine. If you ask them, if you can take a picture, then most of the time they'll allow it. But please ask. Just the polite thing to do.On the west side of the park there's a gift shop, places to eat, and places to relieve yourself. The prices at the store were reasonable & the food cost varied, depending on where you were going to eat. The food is good & the staff are very friendly.If you like walking in a park and it's a pretty amazing park & see a shrine & some history, then please come here. You'll enjoy it.

Breathtaking. The entrance was simply breathtaking and the shrine beautiful as well. There was a wedding ceremony that took place around 430pm so we watched that as well. Must see when you visit tokyo.

Close to Shibuya, not too crowded and totally free!. The Mieji Temple is about 10 to 15 minute's walk from central Shibuya located within a mini forest in the middle of the built up city area. There's the main temple itself as well as a few other interesting buildings as well as the nice walk through the trees. There's no cost so I definitely recommend visiting here if you have 1 or 2 hours to spare!

Must-see in Tokyo. This shrine is at the top of Tokyo's hotlist. It is also very popular place among locals, so it can get crowded easily. You can enjoy the scenic Yoyogi park while you walk to the shrine, and go have some fun at Takeshita dori after you visit Meiji Jingu.The shrine is located inside of Yoyogi park, and the closest station is Harajuku on Yamanote line, or Meiji Jingu-mae on Tokyo metro Chiyoda line.

Peaceful and Reviving. as soon as one enters through the huge Torii gate one can forget the hustle and bustle and hectic of Tokyo's streets. It is as others have said an oasis of peace and beautifully tended. 100.000 trees from all over Japan and from abroad were planted in honour of the of the dead Emperor Shoken and his wife and the area was opened to the public in 1920. So there are 700.000m² of forest in the middle of this city and for a respite this is where to ehad to. In addition to this the shrines are inteesting too

The collection of trees is something else. This is a shrine in honour of the Emperor Meiji who died in 1912 and the Empress Shoken who died in 1914. They are honoured for their virtues.The people donated 100,000 trees to this memorial.

A Normal place...dont expect much. Seeing that its one of the most visited places in tokyo...i thought that ill be seeing more...well...i didnt...its an old temple surrounded by lots of beautiful green...it tells a beautiful story...but its not my favourite place in tokyo that's for sure...if you are lucky enough ....you might be able to witness a typical wedding ceremony there...

The walk to the Shrine was the best part!. This shrine is surrounded by the city, but surprisingly it is peaceful and quiet inside. Upon entering the shrine, you are greeted by a Giant Torii (lots of pictures there). Then when you start walking, you start to feel calm because even though there were a lot of people, it was quiet and relaxing. We saw some graduates wearing kimonos and someone who proposed to their girlfriend there. About a third of the way there, you will see the Sake (rice wine) wall (more pictures there). The Shrine was huge when you get inside, there was a prayer box and small souvenir shop inside. I would say the highlight of the Shrine was the walk to the Shrine. Walking through the forest was relaxing and rejuvenating. It does require a lot of walking, but we really didn't feel exhausted after the walk.

Wonderful & Peacefull. A must do. We did the paid part in April and I think it wasn't worth the free part so don't spend time and money, just enjoy those beautiful alley and this remarkable temple and clean yur hands and mouth in the pure water from the well.

Meji shrine. The location is between yoyogi JR station and harajuku. Easier access is to alight at harajuku station and walked to the shine. The whole place is huge. The shrine is right in the middle of a big park, surrounded by trees. It was very serene and peaceful. I like the quietness of the whole place.If you lucky, you may catch the Japanese traditional marriage ceremony.

Solemn shrine. I dont know why I like to go to Meiji shrine but whenever I visit, I feel so relaxed. Before you get to the shrine, you'll pass by big Toriis, gigantic trees that cover the sun, a bridge, series of wine and sake keg, and Temizuya, where you have to rinse your hands and mouth before entering the shrine.If you don't like walking then this is not a place for you.

The Breather You Need. Honestly this was one of my favourites. Tokyo is such a big city and it has soooo much to offer. But the crowded small spaces and neon lights get way to much. So finding something like this was amazing. Once you walk through the gates and into the heart of the shrine, all the noise just disappears and I kid you not, the temperature gets a lot cooler walking around the park (i went in summer). The place is massive and is extremely well kept. If you're lucky you might be able to catch a traditional japanese wedding being held there. Also pay lots of attention to customs before going through the gate and when youre at the actual shrine.

Average. The shrine is big and set in a very nice park. However the shrine isn't old nor does it have any special features. If you already seen a lot of shrines in Japan you could give this one a miss. There is a treasury museum though so that could be nice and as said the park is nice and quiet.

Lovely lush greenery leading in. A simple and small shrine, I actually enjoyed the walk into the shrine more than the shrine itself. The path is lined with huge green trees, making it a cool stroll in the park. It opens to visitors from 5.10am and I suggest going before 10am to avoid the bus loads of tour groups. I was there on a Sat and lucky enough to catch 2 traditional wedding processions!

Saturday is the day to vist. This could be one more shrine ....but on Saturday , when there are all the weddings it really is the place to be. Looking and photographing the wedding parties and having a peep at one more facet of Japanese culture

interesting enough, worth the short walk. Get off the subway at Omote-sando, exit a1 and walk the length of the avenue to Meiji Jingu. Tree lined avenue with lots of very expensive shops but the side streets are really interesting and worth a brief exploration..

Nice Shrine to unwind . We visited the Shrine on Saturday day and is really crowded. Have to walk about 1km or more from the entrance to the the shrine to pray. Some Japanese couple hold their wedding in the premise and be blessed. Is free entry so many tourists visit this Shrine.

A calm religious spot in the middle of Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is a must see in Tokyo. The temple is located in a beautiful forest, nice path leads to the temple, it's a perfect relief in the busy city center. If you arrive early in the morning or later in the afternoon you can avoid the big tourist groups and it's also easier to have a religious experience.

A Great Experience. Meiji Jingu is a cultural oasis in the middle of the city. This shrine is vast, surrounded by a forest with the main shrine in the middle. I went on a Saturday and many weddings and baptisms were taking place - to witness this first hand was amazing the brides were absolutely surreal. This shrine is tourist friendly without sacrificing any integrity. The venue is wheelchair friendly and also contains a cafe and gift shop. The only thing to be mindful of is it is a fair walk up to the shrine - but it is well worth it.

Beautiful, tranquil shrine. Standing in the middle of the shrine, it is hard to believe you are only a stone throw away from Shibuya crossing! The forest surrounding the shrine makes for a beautiful walk and there are toilet facilities dotted around just in case (featuring not squat toilets but ones with heated seats...) The shrine itself is beautiful and has guides on paying your respects. You can also purchase wooden votives for offering prayer and thanks. All in all a beautiful place and definitely recommended!
First Shrine . This was our first Shrine so it's hard to say how good it was. It was busy but still very peaceful. The park around it made you feel miles outside the city.

Spiritual experience!. The walk through the forest and amazing green around you makes you uplifted as soon as you enter the premises. It is just fascinating and amazing. The sake and wine barrels on the way remind you just how great repect the nation holds towards their ancestors, truly unique. During the visit I also experienced a traditional Japanese wedding, which was really one of a kind, loved it. Make sure to leave your prayers at the temple. Loved it!

Fabulous cultural experience. . Yo yogi park is really beautiful. A very tranquil spot to visit in the heart of Tokyo. The shine is a great attraction to visit and provides a spiritual experience and insight into Shinto religion. MWeddings are very frequent events to witness. Don't miss the hand and mouth washing area as you enter the temple. A great way to spend a few hours.

Beautiful walk with great scenery. Great place to spend an afternoon and walk to the shrine through the beautiful trees. The shrine it self is a little bland compared to the Buddhist temples but has its own charm. I was lucky enough to witness a traditional Japanese wedding while i was there. Very nice ceremony with the bride and groom walk silently through the shrine with the guests behind them, two at a time. Great to enjoy the park after you are done.

Good for walking and chilling. The park is huge. It takes at least half to an hour to walk through the park. Nice trees, very chilly place to hang around, for picnic, photoshoot, etc. The shrine is common but there's crowd. If you're there at the right time, you'll get to watch the praying sessions (good time to pray, if you're of the religion). Get your hands rinsed at the Temizuya to get cleansed and purified before praying.

Nice walk and clean air.... You have to read the Meiji Jingu history first before you go there. Otherwise you'll feel like nothing special. And there's very little english explaination. So you won't get what is so special about this, just a regular walk to one of an old temple in Japan. But I enjoyed the walk, as it is very shady from the big old trees.

Amazing New Year visit!. For New Year's Eve this year I convinced my boyfriend to celebrate in a Japanese style and go to the temple at midnight. I had read it would crowded but I had never expected to queue there few hours in the frost to see the main shrine few minutes. Nevertheless I loved the experience, it was very different from our usual parties and it felt nice for once to see such an organized crowd gathered to start the year in a peaceful and appeased way. Excellent experience! There was a stall for English speaks where you can get poems from the Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken to whom the temple is dedicated. We read the wishes people wrote on wooden signs on our way out. I recommend the experience for a New Year and even for a daily visit as it is quite an important and beautiful landmark. It will appease you after roaming around in a bustling Tokyo.
Nice experience!. I was able to witness a Japanese wedding when I visited there! Took lots of photos. It was an amazing experience to witness a Japanese wedding. I suggest you try this too!
Nice park and temple. The only temple worth seeing in Tokyo, located in a beautiful, and atmospheric park. Nice grounds, and free to visit.

Peaceful sanctuary. After getting off the packed streets of Tokyo, this place feels like a breathe of fresh air. The height of the trees made me almost forget that I was in the middle of a busy city. It was very serene and calm.

Peaceful setting in a bustling city. Went on a Sunday. Did not realise how big this park is. The shrine is dedicated to the Emperor Meiji and his Empress and built in 1920. Superbly maintained , its worth a visit while in Tokyo. Were lucky enough to se two weddings take place at the shrine. Just added to the experience. Take the train to Harajuku, turn right and walk for about 5 mins. Park is on the right. Before that cross the road and walk down Takashashi street or something similar. Crowds !!!

Beautiful. What a beautiful walk to the shrine! Walking amongst tall trees puts you right into the nature eventhough you're in the busy city of Tokyo. Visiting the shrine is free so that is also a bonus. The huge shrines are something to marvel at. Make sure you check the hours before you go to ensure it's not closed.

Picnic and prayer. This is one of the busiest shrines in Tokyo for tourists, and it's easy to see why. The scale of the entry, the Beauty of the park and shrine itself, and the proximity and juxtaposition to Harajuku make it part of a great day out.Take a picnic to sit in the green heart of the city, looking at skyscrapers above the trees but hearing more birds than cars. A beautiful afternoon stroll, and a great break from the hectic city life outside the gate.

Peaceful Surroundings. It's amazing how Japan has temples and shrines in the middle of the hustle and bustle of city life. One minute you are walking from a crowded spot straight into nature, serene and fully of beauty. There is a bit of a gravel walk to Meiji Jingu bordered by forestland but it is very relaxing and you would not know what borders this. Yes, there are a lot of tourists but there is plenty of room to get a photo. We could not go inside but enjoyed what we could see and made our wish.
明治神宮　Meiji Jinguu, Imperial Shrine. As the name suggests, dedicated to the Emperor Meiji, who was the head of state after the Meiji Restoration and symbolic of Japan's modernisation.

Very peaceful afternoon visit.. Took some time out on a sunny afternoon to walk through the peaceful forest glades to the large central shrine complex. Beautiful buildings and a relaxing atmosphere. A couple of weddings were also going on, which was nice to see brides and grooms in traditional Japanese formal dress. An easy walk to and from Yoyogi Station.

Saturday is great. Try and be here on a Saturday after 10 am and you'll get a chance to witness traditional Japanese wedding parade. It's nice and the customs are lovely. Other than that, the shrine is one of the plains I've seen (compared to Kyoto).

A peacful place in the middle of a busy city. The architecture was amazing - especially the nice sweeping lines of the rooves. The history of the development of sake in Japan and the association with France during the Edo period was fascinating.

Majestic. I never expected to find such a huge parke an a magnificent temple in the middle of the city.This park and temple site us definitely a must go place, easily accessible by trai Harajuku statin.Me and my family really love the peaceful, very clean and very free park.

Home of the world's largest torii. THe Meji Shine is home to the world's largest torii, the traditional Japanese gate most commonly found at the entrance of or within shrines. Aside from this, it's a great walk and a nice place to find a bit of peace and quiet if you're ever in the busy Shibuya/Harajuku area.

beautiful place. Meiji Shrine is dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Empress Shôken souls place,Japan is an important Shinto shrine. Located in Tokyo Shibuya district, an area of 70 hectares between from Harajuku station to Yoyogi. In addition to the Imperial Palace in central Tokyo is the biggest piece of green space. Meiji Shrine and Ise Shrine in Mie Prefecture, Kyoto Heian Shrine tied for the three major Japanese shrine. Meiji Shrine and is very suitable for a day trip scheduled to begin.Many people travel arrangements, just the way of the discharge location. But often overlook whether the shops are open / closed. So like Meiji Shrine this morning to open the door of pure tourist attractions, will row early in the morning go! Walk around it, you can go shopping to eat.Because the route relationship, we sit in front of Meiji Jingu Eki, then walk past.Comparative people take directly to the JR Yamanote Line Harajuku Eki.But in fact, very close to the two stations. Meiji Jingu also sit in front Eki Just a bit more to go, the station also have indicators. Although there is so many people, If you can I hope you can go there for culture.
Zen in the city. In the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, Shibuya, this is a very zen spot to find calm, tranquility and peace.

Beautiful walk. Large grounds perfect for a stroll and trees provide shade from the sun. The shrine itself was beautiful with the lucky opportunity to see a bride being escorted to and from the temples with her quests in traditional formation. Lots of photo opportunity as the architecture and surrounds are beautiful. Gets quite busy mid day.

Weddings. Not a particularly special shrine visually, but it was very popular due to its location. We did see two Shinto wedding processions in the short time we were there, which was exciting! Worth popping by.
Beautiful. I enjoyed visiting here very much and was lucky enough to see a ceremony. It is a large and imposing shrine in the calm of Yoyogi Park.
Historical . Obviously a very important shrine steeped in history but after visiting the temples and shrines of Kyoto it does not have the same beauty.

a beautiful walk!. Headed to the Meiji park on a winter morning. It was a lovely walk with the mist and quiet. The walk is quite long so best to make sure you have comfortable footwear. Its like a walk in the woods - great for those who enjoy the peace, quiet and nature.The shrine is old and beautiful. Witnessed a wedding taking place and a bit of traditional Japanese customs. Would recommend for a nice walk amidst nature and take a sneak peak into Japanese traditions folklore.

Peace and Tranquility in the city . Another must see while in Tokyo. The place is huge so be ready for a lot of walking. The pathwalk is wide and surrounded by a forest. It is a respite from the chaos in Tokyo. Peaceful and tranquil.

Beautiful Experience. We were guided around by 5 beautiful young Japanese girls from their schools English Club, they showed us around & practiced their English at the same time. Wonderful experience for them & us. Beautiful grounds & gardens.

Beautiful walk in the middle of busy Tokyo. Opposite the very busy Harajuku district and in particular Takeshita Street it was an oasis amongst the business. It was very busy but we were there on a Sunday, I would recommend these areas on a less busy time of week. We were lucky enough to see 2 traditional weddings which were beautiful in themselves.

In central Tokyo, you should moved by holy historycal place in woods. Beautiful woods and traditional small pebble road to go to the Shrine even in central Tokyo it's quiet, clean rich nature. You can go to from JR Harajyuku station 1min. enter without paying but close about 6 oclock.

Quiet relaxing place, perhaps better visited in spring & summer. This is a nice place to stroll around. We visited Feb-end and there were no flowers or anything spectacularly beautiful. At this time of the year, you can perhaps skip it, if you are pressed for time. It is good, but not very unique - just from the visual perspective. Historical perspective...that's different though.
A very old shrine, not colourful but interesting buildings. I prefer more colourful shrines I've seen but I read this is from a different dynasty hence it's bland colours.
Nice walk in the woods.. A quick walk around the park though the temple area is a great way to spend the day. If you are lucky, you might catch a wedding taking place.

nice alk to the shrine and some interesting spots along the way. we were not sure what to expect when we took the metro to this area of town. we were pleasantly surprised to see the shrine and all the local weddings which were taking place. although there were over 100 people walking, we never felt crowded

Tranquil, peaceful and well kept park right in the centre of an urban setting.. A breath of fresh air in this beautiful park reflects the love and nature of the Emperor.
Seeing is believing to witness the joy, serenity in this wondrous park.
The variety of trees and plants in one area is unbelievable.
A must see attraction if you are in the vicinity of Tokyo.
Peaceful . Went here today in the morning. Took my time and walked around. Very peaceful and tranquil. Beautiful temple and was able to make an offering.

A Beautiful Shrine and Park. The park is literally a breath of fresh air and the Shrine is just wonderful to see, in amongst the sky scrapers and throngs of people, this lovely tranquil location is a must see.
Historical. Visit you are history lover.. it was below our expectations... there are better alternative. Visit if you love nature

Important but seen better. Was surprised at how comparatively plain this shrine was, given its importance. Maybe a reflection on Emperor Meiji himself, not wanting anything ostentatious. Surrounding gardens absolutely beautiful. Be prepared for lots of people but plenty of room so doesn't feel crowded. More impressive, older shrines elsewhere but this one is important.
A step back in time. Definitely a must see in Tokyo. There's something deeply tranquil about the Meiji shrine despite the plethora of tourists all around.
A beautiful shrine and park. This park was a breath of fresh air in Shibuya, the expansive paths and the enormity of the shrine was something to behold. A must see if you are in Shibuya.
Serene place . This is a calm and interesting place to visit. A hustle away from the crowd in harajuku. Definitely a must to visit this place if you haven't been here before.

A walk in the park of the shrine. I did not go into the shrine but decided to have a walk in the grounds. This essentially meant walking on a tarmaced road/path with tall trees on either side for most of the walk. One is not allowed to venture off the path. There was an open lawn area close to a lake. It was a good walk in the forest, but overall I did not find this a satisfying time since it was not possible to wander off and find a quiet corner for oneself. No entrance fee though.
Incredible entrance. What huge tree trunks must have been used for this site. A long walk along the drive way to see this masterpiece. Very busy at weekends.
Beautiful!. I recommend getting an audioguide. Bring a few hundred yen for the optional visit to the well. Lovely

Beautiful in cherry blossom season.. A lovely park to walk around but limited refreshment facilities. It was extremely busy with many Japanese companies seemingly having picnic lunches all together which was nice to see. The queue to get in was long and we found the entrance hard to find, probably because we didn't have a map!
Zen in the middle of bustling Tokyo. Great for a walk in the Morning. Lovely atmosphere with a touch of the old Japan in the middle of modern Tokyo.

My favourite place. I've been to Tokyo around 10 times, and every single time I visit Meji Jingu.It's a very peaceful and calm place, and regardless of its location when you enter the shrine you can't even feel that you're in the city. It's like you're transported into another place entirely.To maximize the experience don't go there on rainy days.And if you love shopping. Start your day at the shrine then after that hit Omotesando or Harajuku for a shopping spree!For foodies, there are many interesting modern Cafes nearby.
Tranquil walk through a forest . What a beautiful eacape from urban city life! The forest air smells so good and the sound of the trees is super relaxing. What a beautiful walk.

Lovely // must see. A beautiful shrine settled in a rich forest. A great visit in an even more superb surrounding. Just take a walk and stroll around the park.
Free of charge.

Beautiful and peaceful. Meiji Jingu is a gem in Tokyo. Beautiful shrine and fantastic place to stroll and enjoy the beautiful gardens, water features and tranquility. While I didn't make the time to sit down for a couple of hours, I will, for sure, do so on my next trip to Tokyo

Beautiful forest in the center of Tokyo . Over 100 years old, this park and Shrine was built in memory of Emperor Meiji after his death around 1910's.
The forest of over 60 feet trees is beautiful surrounding the pedestrian way to the Shrines.
Shrines are imponent and very Japanese. Few colors and lots of people and formal praying.

Beautiful walk!. We got there about 11AM and must have got there before the crowds because when we were there it so tranquil and empty, at one point me and my girlfriend seemed to be the only people about! So I would suggest to come earlier if you'd prefer a more tranquil experience. All the way round is a very very long walk! You could walk around for 2 hours easily, for those interested in shopping, one of the entrances/exits is pretty much right next to the entrance for Takeshita Dori!

Nice place for a walk and interesting museum. It is an impressive park with huge torii at entrances and on the way to the temple. The Museum at the back of the park have interesting 19th century exhibits. Interesting are the sake barrels as an offer to the goods.

Peace in the City. Nice place for a slow walk. Do take time to enjoy the peace and serenity. Can't believe that such a place exist in the city, and it's just next to Shibuya. The main temple sells amulets and charms. You can also pay to write your wishes on a small piece of wooden ply.

Very relaxing place to walk, despite the crowds. Although our tour took us past the huge Torii (wooden entrànce gates), the sake barrels and wine battels to the main shrine - the attractions one must see on a guided tour, and thèy were worth seeing it must be said, the real beauty of this place were the pathways which we could explore at leisure during our free time afterwards. I ignored the option of returning to the gift shop and restaurant and just wandered off on my own. There were plenty of other people there - locals and tourists - but one barely noticed them among the wide and winding paths that meander through the park. A wonderful 'get away from it all' place in the heart of the city.

Oasis of peace. Right next to harajuku station, the giant torii gates are impressive enough. Then there is a pleasant 15 minute walk up to the shrine. Barrels of wine and sake line the way. At the shrine itself, you get to see how people worship. We were lucky enough to witness a shinto wedding procession and it was fascinating - lots of tourists lining up beside the processions and taking pictures, wonder how the couple felt about it! Definitely worth a visit and feels miles away from the craziness of harajuku.
Nice temple. Nice temple in a nice area. The Meiji Jingu is worth a visit. If you really want to see breathtaking shrines you go to Kyoto! In Tokyo, the Meiji Jingu is one of the best.

Nice peaceful place near Harajuku. Easy to access by JR Harajuku (Omote-sando Exit) or Subway Harajuku station (Exit 2). It's a very peaceful place near Harajuku, recommend to go before or after shopping at Harajuku. Opening hours is 9.00-16.30 and it open everyday.

City Ease of Access via Harajuku. This is probably the easiest place to visit if you're like me here for work and wanted to enjoy or feel some authentic Japanese tourist attraction. Although it's a little modernized and commercialized. But ! Still good to visit and its a must for first timer to Tokyo. It is easy to go via Harajuku Station, you can see the sign and direction board easily.
Peaceful spot. The shrine is a lovely spot to wander on a sunny afternoon, so peaceful and quiet just a stones throw from Harajuku.
Relaxing and interesting. The tranquility of the park and the temple, very relaxing! And we spotted three wedding couples at the temple, very nice!

Forest/trail right in the city. It was very nice, I enjoyed the 4 km trail walk right in the middle of the city. It was a very busy area and packed in the street, but nice and calm literally just 2 mins behind the entrance... Also tried their Sake and Sakura ice-cream too, very neat!!

Great photo ops, easy walk from Harajuku train station . As you walk in, past the wall of donated sake barrels, past the tall gates, and through the peaceful wooded area, you forget you are right in the heart of Tokyo. Even filled with tour buses, the shrine is peaceful and worth the visit. You might even see a wedding taking place--or two!

Forest of the city. This is a very big park with a very long walk to the shrine...since it situated next to Harajuku area, it can be call as a forest next to the modern city!!Check out the green tea shack at entrance, it offer a really good green tea latte and green tea soft serve ice cream.

Nice and Peaceful. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes going to this park as you will need to walk a lot from one point to another. It's a huge park in the middle of the city and it's very peaceful for a nice long walk in the morning. I wouldn't say there are a lot to see but being in a less crowded environment in the city is such a nice change.

A Peaceful Oasis. I entered the Meiji Shrine from the Harajuku entrance. It was a pleasant walk. I was very impressed by the entrance and even more impressed when I reached the shrine. I also enjoyed the ritual for the water basin as well as making a wish/prayer in the shrine. Visit their home page if you want to know the proper etiquette. My husband and I also got charms/amulets. A perfect peaceful oasis to get away from the busy city life.

Gorgeous forestry path. I was more amazed by the path leading to the shrine than the shrine itself. The shrine is near the Harajuku Station but can also be accessed from Yoyogi Station (which is a bit farther compared to the Harajuku entrance). It has a big decent shrine and the place has this relaxing/calming feeling.

Very tranquil. Despite the crowds this still is a peaceful tranquil shrine, set in some beautiful woodland. Look out for the large wooden entrance gates, which are the largest in Japan. If you go at weekends there is a good chance you'll see a Japanese wedding happening.Be prepared for a 10-15 minute walk from the JR station, and there are no refreshments at the shrine itself.
A Must Visit place in Tokyo. Feels weird rating a historical and national landmark like this. Meiji Jingu is at the intersection of history and modernity in Japan. You have to go.
Beautiful. We used Tokyo free guide. it was very interesting. not far from Shinjuku. Would like to visit again. Japan is so lovely

Go Early Morning. We visited this place at 7 in the morning, right after our Tuna Auction, so it was incredibly tranquil. There were only a few locals walking through the shrine and a few street sweepers working. The morning fog made for some great photos.

Meiji Jingu Shrine. My husband and I made a visit during Sakura Season Meiji Jingu (Harajuku) area had not yet bloomed during then but the park itself was a nice peaceful visit. The entrance is right outside the Meiji Jingu Mae Station (JR); so it was easy to access the park. No entry fee. Although many people were also visiting, it was still spacious enough for us to enjoy the parks serenity and not feel overwhelmed with people. The Sake Barrels were the highlight of the visit which we were able to get some nice pictures

Wasn't very busy even in peak hours . Very nice place, great for pictures. Even though we went in a very busy time of day (peak hour around 3pm till closing) it was still very quiet but I think that's because of how spread out the location is. Easily accessible via harajuku JR station (would recommend investing $$$ into a JR pass it makes things easier and really works out price wise when travelling to other parts of Japan) enjoy!
Cool quiet place in the midst of the city. A nice place to walk around in the hustle and bustle of life. Just adjacent to the Metro and Yoyogi Park, very accessible.

Oasis of calm in Tokyo.. Just a short walk for the hustle of Harajuku, the walk to the shrine, even if you are surrounded by other people, is a peaceful experience. The shrine is beautiful, and gives the impression of seclusion, with the occasional high rise poking out from the tree tops to spoil the feeling.
Peaceful shrine. Nice peaceful shrine - ideally situated next to a park - ideal for a little calm amid the bustle of the city.

Peaceful and Beatiful. We started our sightseeing day at Meiji-Jingu which set a wonderful tone for the day - walking through the grounds to get to the temple was peaceful and beautiful - the ritual of washing at the font before entering the temple area was well explained and made the experience even more enjoyable!

Nice shrine. Today we went to the Miji Jingu. Very nice place to visit, special to be there. It was the first Japanese shrine we went to, so hard to compare it with others. The best part of it all was almost that a very nice Japanese man showed us how to prepare (with washing our hands) before going to the shrine, very nice to be part of that with a ritual. The shrine itself is very beautiful, very different than Western churches or other shrines ever visited.

Very impressive. I love the Meiji Jingu Shrine. From the impressive wooden arch at the entrance to the peacefulness of the shrine itself, this is the place to go to really experience Japan at its best and most traditional. From the moment you get there it is a lesson in Japan. The trees that line the area (which were donated by Japanese citizens and others from all over the world) to the wooden bridge and the rituals of purifying yourself before entering the temple, it is something that must be experienced. You will also see KAZARIDARU - huge collection of sake barrels. Sake traditionally has been a connection between the gods and people in Japan. These sake barrels are offered every year to the enshrined deities at Meiji Jingu Shrine.

Simply stunning. I won't say too much about it, as I think experiencing it first hand is more exciting. It is well worth the trip. If you are a lover of history, architecture, religion and beauty this will make your heart happy. We went on a Saturday afternoon and had the privilege of witnessing 6 wedding processions, which I will never ever forget.

Beautiful shrine, relaxing walk in the forest. . This shrine is absolutely stunning and well worth a visit, even if only visiting for a short time. It is reached at the end of lovely walk through he forests surrounding the shrine and makes for a great antidote to the crowds and bright lights of omote sando and harajuku. Millions of people (literally) visit the shrine in the first few days of the year to bring good luck for the year ahead. Architecturally and stylistically, a must see.

Very refreshing place. Meiji jingu located behind the famous harajuku street and it's very peaceful and refreshing after a long day busting in modern Tokyo street. The gate is very huge and the path to the temple is surrounded by big tree made you feel relax

Stunning! . A beautiful walk through lovely grounds. On the weekends you might be lucky enough to see traditional wedding processions where everyone is dressed up in traditional clothes. You may also get to witness the Buddhist Hong being struck and praying on the temple as you write up your wish and hang it under the wishing tree. A lovely hour or two spent here.

Very cool. Awesome if you're in to temples and Japanese gardens. Still cool even if you're not.Aside from the temple, there is an old large garden which is very well taken care of.If you are lucky, you might see a Japanese traditional wedding at the main temple.

"Pretty Park". I recently visited Yoyogi park to see the Cherry Blossoms. As we started walking towards the park we walked in the entrance to where the Meiji Shrine was. The walk was very woodsy and scenic. This was a very touristy area with many people walking around. The Meiji Jingu Shrine was cool to see. I glad we were able to visit!

Peaceful but big. I really enjoyed my stroll to get here and whilst there were lots of people on there way to and from visting I barely noticed them as the paths are massive and the entire area is really scenic! I went around New Years so there were loads of stall and they were all busy putting up more stalls and decorations for the upcoming celebrations and expected crush of people coming to pray etc so was pretty lively but again it didn't really feel it as the site is quite big! By itself its not much to look around but well worth a visit!

Worth a look but nothing spectacular . JR Yamanote line to Harajuku, Omote-sando exit.It's pretty but nothing amazing. I had a little bit of an "is this it?" feeling as I was walking around.I wouldn't say don't visit but similarly if you are pressed for time this doesn't need to be a 'must do'.

Wedding. We were fortunate enough to be guests at a wedding here and what a truly stunning place it is. Very touristy and the did seem busy on the wedding day but what an amazing place for a wedding. The architecture and surrounding gardens are a lovely sight to see.

Pretty surroundings . This shrine was on our to-do list. We walked from our hotel and it was pretty easy to find. We did get off course and walked around a nearby park before realizing we turned too early before the shrine. But it was a happy mistake.The shrine area itself had beautiful scenery. There happened to be a wedding going on there as well, which made it that much more beautiful.

Meiji Jingu stroll. After spending a few days in Nara and Kyoto, I opted to spend the last couple days in bustling Tokyo. But...one more shrine couldn't hurt, right? Well, glad I made the effort. The walk to the center of the park on wide but peaceful paths gave some time to clear the mind. And the shrine itself, with its surrounding gates, was imposing and certainly qualified as a worthwhile stop. Now, it should not be the only shrine you see in Japan, but if you find yourself with an hour or so, go for it!

Serenity within a concrete jungle. It is impressive to enter a man-made forest within the centre of this giant metropolitan city. Once you get into the area and pass through the Torri (an archway),you can instantly feel the peacefulness of this place. Walking along the unpaved track surrounded by trees, you can indulge yourselves in the beauty of mother nature. Within 15 minutes easy walk, you can reach the beautiful main shrine building that can enjoy the wonderful traditional Japan architecture as well as offer some praying for yourselves or your loved one. You can also purchase some souveniers for your friends.The only bad thing about this place is it was too crowded with tourists. However, since tokyo is full of people anywhere, this is not an issue and you can just bear with it and enjoy this beautiful place instead.

Astounding temple and garden. A must see for everyone - and a such, very crowded. My first experience of such a big temple of surroundings in Tokyo and as such - astounding. Downside of it - really full of tourists that cannot necessarily behave with the needed respect for the religious practices of the locals.
very nice place. very nice place, we lived every moment lovely sunny day and relax, walk us was beautiful, garden is amazing

Beautiful and tranquil.. A must see for anyone visiting. The Shrine and the park around it is meticulously kept clean and tidy. It is an amazing contrast to the bustling city life just a few blocks away. Definitely worth a trip to this famous and historic attraction of Japan.

Visit and rest from the city hustle. Big area which you can actually take your time from the city morning rush hour. A lot of people and student come here and pray. Once you go in the Meiji Jingu, the retrospect in you will kick in. you'll be amazed by the beauty and appreciate the surrounding around area the blends really well with nature. there's a another route in Meiji jingu which leads you to pond and also the ancient tea house. I keep visiting this place when I was studying in Tokyo and its very beautiful during fall season
Part of a tour. We saw the Meiji Jingu during a day tour of Tokyo. Very interesting. Worth a visit. Peaceful even in a busy city.

serene. compared to other shrine in osaka or kyoto, I would saya that Meiji Jingu was quite plain. But I like the forest a lot. I can just walk around and actually having a good day enjoying the trees. At the end of my visit, it was raining. It became so cold, but I loved it!
Beautiful place to walk. We had very nice walk. Right next to busy harajuku and shibuya but there was not one noise. Very quiet. Very old shrine to remember emperor Meiji. Beatiful garden.
Peaceful park and shrine. A very beautiful and peaceful garden amid the neighborhood of Harujuku. Beautiful shrine, there is always a chance to see a wedding on a Sunday.

The Imperial Family's Shinto shrine. This spot is an oasis of tranquility in the heart of urban Tokyo. The example of Meiji era architecture and gave me a real sense of peace and serenity. We really lucked out by having a Shinto wedding procession unexpectedly happen before us.

Great park, cool shrine. There was a Shintō wedding taking place as we visited. Drums banged, priests bowed etc.
Still not enough theatre for teenagers though!
Peaceful. So pretty, I used to live in Tokyo and never get bored of going here. Always return when I visit friends still living in Tokyo.

Walk Here While in Harajuku. We walked to the Meiji Shrine after walking down Takeshita Street. Such a contrast. Peaceful gardens in the busy city. Not a place to sit down and have a picnic but more to walk through and look at the sights. I marveled at the many barrels of wine and sake, which had been there since 1920 or so. Was that wine and sake still drinkable? Had anyone ever tried to drill a hole in one of those barrels and drink it's contents? Hmmm. I dont think a barrel of wine would last five minutes in a park in Australia but that's the beauty of Japan. No one steals anything. I would recommend looking at the Meiji Shrine website before going as it describes the etiquette for your visit. I didnt look at it until later so hopefully i didnt offend anyone. I enjoyed my walk through the park and it was well worth a visit.

Try to go Sunday morning. We had read that we might see a Shinto wedding if we went in a Sunday morning and we were so in luck. Perhaps because it is cherry blossom season there were about 8 weddings in the couple if hours we were there. Heaps of other tourists too but a fabulous experience of traditional architecture and ceremony.

TRULY JAPANESE. This is truly one of the best shrines we have visited. It is located in the middle of the hustle bustle of Tokyo city. Built in the honor of Emperor Meiji and his wife Empress Shoken, Meiji Shrine is a must visit place for any tourist in Tokyo. Just two minutes walk from Harajuku station, this will give you a true Japanese feel.

Meiji Shrine . This place was very peaceful and pleasant to walk around. Nothing blew me away here, but I enjoyed my time here and it was a great place for a stroll. The grounds are kept very clean and the area is quite pretty with many different types of trees growing all over the place (it feels like you are walking in a forest). If you have some time to kill during the day and you want to be outside and get a little walking in, this would be a great place to check out.

Beautiful Grounds and Temple. A much more understated temple reflective of the time period it was built, but despite large crowds, it's easy to find peace and quiet in the parks surrounding it. Explanations and access is quite limited to different areas of the shrine, but you can pay extra to go to different areas.

Beautiful and convenient! . Right beside Harajuku, a ten minute walk from Shibuya. Very beautiful, very peaceful, especially because there is a lot of shopping nearby! Beautiful Park surrounds the shrine too!

Not much to see. This place is great for a pleasant relaxing stroll but that is it. The shrine is surprisingly stale and lacking beauty. I would recommend paying an extra 500 yen to see the garden however, especially if you go when the iris garden is in full bloom. They were planting them when I went, April 1. June should be perfect. It's free to walk around so why not, but I would definitely not recommend going out of your way to visit here, there's literally nothing to see. Sure the wine and sake barrel offerings are cool to see but you can't taste them!If you want to go here, go here for the garden and to stroll around, don't expect much.There is a treasures museum which may be worth seeing...but open only on holidays and weekends (not including Friday)

Great shrine. This is a great shrine to visit. The air is wonderful surrounding the shrine. The walk that leads to the shrine is a good contrast to the hustle and bustle of the city and is a great stroll just to unwind. If you're in the area definitely go check it out.

It's ok . It's free so good start and the path to it is very tranquil even when it was slightly busy. As far as temples go it's ok what works is the forest around it to give more edge then other ones.
Beautiful!. Really nice walk through the grounds, rich history and great photo opps! Right between Shibuya and Omotesando. Easy walk.

Beautiful . It was perfect Japanese culture I was looking for, even in the middle of the busy city.i felt it was worth the adventure to see it Can do the park in about an hour so plan for other adventures near by!!

Tranquillity and serenity. Visited the park in the springtime. There are certain areas of the park which required paid access (I think it was the Inner Garden), and thoroughly encourage anyone to explore that section of the park. Firstly, it gives visitors a chance to really soak up the tranquillity and serenity of the park, and enjoy the cold crisp air. Second, there are far lesser people in this section, so you get a lot more privacy here. There are benches and lookouts for you to just "be present". I spent about an hour just exploring the grounds.While I was fortunate to have witnessed a wedding procession that day, I absolutely did not enjoy the experience for the simple fact that this space is overrun by obnoxious and disrespectful tourists.

Nice temple in a beautiful surrounding. This was a great site and we loved just walking around the grounds. We were also lucky to see 4 japanese weddings while we were there and it was really nice and fun.

Serenity in the city. There's a reason why Meiji Jingu is so highly rated. Amid the hustle and bustle of the city lies a bit of peace. It's quite something to see and is also conveniently located so close to Omotesando and Maisen Tonkatsu. Amazing food, shopping, and the beauty of nature all located on each other's door step.

Worth a trip to see.. This is a very large gardened area with a historical shrine. It is very well presented and has significant historical value to the Japanese people. It will take an hour or so to see properly.

Interesting venue to see mix of culture (if you are lucky). We were lucky enough to see the wedding ceremony of a western male and a Japanese lady. It looked like the merging of two culture. You should try visiting on the weekend, and if you are lucky, you might be able to experience the wedding ceremony.

Beautiful, peaceful park right beside Harajuku. Since it was January, we went on a day that was quite cold, but the beauty of this shrine kept my mind off of how chilled I was. The gardens surrounding the shrine are quite stunning, and the paths are well maintained. If you need a break from the hustle and bustle that is Tokyo, this is a great way to reenergize yourself
Great temple definitely worth a visit . Very nice temple close to shibuya - definitely on of my top places in Tokyo - nice park and relaxing atmosphere in a stressed Tokyo
Ancient Japan . Great easy accessible park from the metro. Authentic and not over exploited. 2 hours is about what it takes to have a good look around.
Calm and serene. We visited the shrine late afternoon. It has a long wooded approach. very peaceful and calming near the actual shrine.

Meiji jingu shrine. One of the biggest shrines and most popular from Tokyo. A must see shrine on my book for most travelers. Ensure not to forget your shrine stamp book to collect all the stamps that you can.
Good walk in the park. The shrine is located in a huge park in the middle of Tokyo. There were lots of people visiting but the walk in the woods is enjoyable. The shrine is magnificent and majestic

Beautiful and serene place in the city. The walk in the forest to the shrine is beautiful. Listening to the birds and enjoying the greenery was so nice after the daily urban assault that is Tokyo. Once at the shine it's a great place to people watch in the courtyard.

Spiritual location. Very nice experience at the largest Shinto Shrine in Japan. We were lucky to see a wedding take place which added to the mystery of the place. Serene and respectful location. Too much to see in a short visit if you also want to see the gardens. Entire structure burned in WW2 and rebuilt. Must see.

Extremely over rated. This garden has some nice trees and you can take pictures of some kind of wedding ceremony at the shrineBut the garden has nothing particular when we visited itI recommend to go to Shinjiku instead

lovely. it's a lovely morning out to go and see the shrine, not too hard to find once you have an idea of where to go. it's pretty much free unless you want to go to certain parts or leave an offering. you can buy some very nice charms. all in all it was great
