Beautiful traditional shrine. Set in a very pretty park, this shrine is beautifully maintained and well worth a visit. You enter via a huge Tori Gate and there is plenty of space to walk around and feel the peaceful atmosphere in a very busy city.

A beautiful, peaceful place. Coming out of the crowded Tokyo Metro station, it was great entering the grounds of the Meiji shrine. The approach road has you walking through a forest, and the shrine itself is quite striking. While there, we saw a wedding procession led by Shinto priests. There are a couple of places to eat, too, along with a small souvenir store.This is definitely worth your visit.
Witness a wedding. Visited this place out of curiosity. Witnessed a Japanese wedding. A beautiful to visit. Took some beautiful photos and that's it.

Lovely place to catch traditional weddings. This does appear to be a wedding hotspot and we spotted three when we were there. They varied in their level of pomp and one was very grand indeed. Had it not been for that I'm not sure I would rave about the visit, but that alone made it very special and we loved it.
Absolutely Beautiful. It's a temple, so if your interested this is an incredible one. a great Forrest walk up to the gates and a very well maintained place right next to its own station.
Beautiful... Our favorite Temple. The grounds are massive... Free entry and plenty of space to roam. After visiting the adjacent shopping streets outside the subway this was a nice relaxing time.

Opportunity to See a Shinto Wedding. We combined the visit to this Shrine with visits to Shibuya and Harajuku. If you have never been to a Shinto Shrine, it’s worth a visit. From the Harajuku Station, we walked along a wide path through a forested area to get to the Shrine. It was interesting to see the barrels of sake and wine lining the path near the Shrine. There is a huge open courtyard in the Shrine complex. Photography is prohibited inside the buildings but is permitted outside.Highlight of our visit was seeing a Shinto wedding happening on the grounds of the Shrine. The Shrine is a popular location for weddings. The Shrine is also a nice break from the city.
A little walk in the park. A good 1hr visit if you are visiting Harajuku and Omotesando. Honestly, I don't feel the sacredness about this shrine.

A nice long walk and timing is everything. This is a late review as I visited in July 2015.My wife and I walked through Harajuku and we decided to split up as she wanted to look at architecture and I wanted to check out the local color. I found the entrance to the temple and made the half mile (maybe more) walk into the main temple courtyard. The temple was beautiful and I took quite a few pictures. However I noticed some well dressed Japanese persons walking in and out of a side building. I waited for a few minutes and was rewarded with a Shinto wedding procession moving its way into the main temple. It was very elaborate and made the visit more interesting.

Absolutely Stunning. Here, you will see couples being married and dressed in traditional japanese garments. The forest is beautiful and makes you forget that you are in the middle of a concrete jungle. This Shrine is definetely worth visiting

essence of japan. this shrine, with charming sake and wine caskets by the entrance, is set in a large garden and is famous for many japanese to hold their weddings. if you are lucky you will see couples and a ceremony or two. a pleasant 1-2 hour outing.

Beautiful Temple. We were lucky enough to go early on a Saturday morning and saw several wedding parties doing pictures there. It was really exciting to see them in their traditional wedding outfits. It was like a scene out of Lost in Translation!

Beautiful setting . Meiji Jingu is an oasis of Forrest inside Tokyo and well worth the visit. A nice introduction to a Shinto shrine and nice place to walk in the park. The grounds are beautiful and I am told it is even possible to see wildlife. We saw some wedding parties and a processional while there which was integrating.

Ordinary shrine, beautiful park. A very popular place and the park generally is an amazing forested area in the city, well worth a stroll. The shrine is over pretty quickly unless you have a religious interest but it's still interesting.

Perfect introduction to shintoism. It's been 6 months since I moved to Japan and this was the first main shrine I saw. Since then I have been to a lot others, of course, but Meiji jingu always remains one of the most memorable ones. Also, it was really pleasing to have a stroll in the 'forest' in the heart of the way too busy Tokyo. Plus, we saw a wedding ceremony march with beautiful couple, monks in traditional wear, awesome atmosphere.It was a short visit but I will surely return. The weather was perfect but rain could ruin the joy.
Wonderful. Amazing place to watch Tokyo at its finest, a really special place where you get a real sense of the people of the city.
Lovely gardens. Very large wooded gardens, we were lucky enough to witness a traditional wedding party going to their ceremony.

Beautiful. The history will wow you if you take time to read all the information about Meiji jingu. It's hard to put in to words the feeling of this place . If your reading this your interested in going , please go and see for yourself . I had the pleasure of going on New Year's Day . Extremely busy and the line was long but it was well worth it . We live very close so I will return again to see inside ( as this is closed on New Year's Day to the public ) take your time and relax and enjoy the walk around this historical place .
Breathtaking shrine. The only way to really describe this shrine is that it is breath taking. It's very lovely to walk around and see it. Really worth going to, a great site in Tokyo!
Review of shrine only. I am reviewing the shrine only not the park around it. We found the shrine to be very commercial and touristy. We have seen better - park is lovely though.

Must see: The Iris garden and well. Off to the side in this beautiful park (It's gate 9 on the pedestrian path) is the Iris garden, South Pond, tea house and the Princess' well. It's well worth the 500 yen entrance fee. Serenely quiet, with lots of birds singing. A favorite.

A fair view-point. It is not as special as the temple in Kyoto, but it is one of famous view-point in Tokyo. If your have already being tired with shopping in Tokyo, it is a place for you to find your inner peace. Special a couple of hours in it and feel the natural power.

Holiday . Only good if you are passing by to Harajuku as there are lots of better Shrine
This is probably a city one but all souvenir are over priced
Bought a few only to find prices are twice other shrine

Shrine in the park. The walk through the forest to get to the shrine is a pleasant stroll in a wide pea gravel road reminiscent of a Paris boulevard. The shrine itself is large and lovely. Won't take long since there isn't much you can see beyond the main shrine. Fill out a prayer block and be in your way. If you are lucky you may see a wedding on weekends.

Beautiful forests, heaps of weddings, too early for the flowers.. We visited late March, and it was a little early for the iris garden, or any sakura trees that happened to be about. It's a beautiful place, very relaxing. It doesn't really feel like you're in the middle of Tokyo city. Good if you need a break from the Harajuku hustle.It was a Sunday when we visited. Apparently a good day for weddings. The shrine had multiple scheduled for the day, starting at about 11am. We witnessed 2 processions. So, if you want to take pictures, it's more than acceptable. Just be sure to stand back behind the security guards directing the crowds.

Nice, it is worth.. Nice place, was one of the bet places we were recommend and it was right. To many people, it was our first experience with the normal crowds you will find almost everywhere in Japan.
Nice big peaceful space.... Its enormous!Loads of walking and not a great deal of scenery changes throughout.. So.. Can be a bit boring after 10mins if youre not into walking in parks..?

Go on a weekday!. Just a few hundred meters away from the hustle and bustle of the city you walk into this beautiful oasis. It's so serene and the massive Torii are a sight for themselves. A lovely walk up to the temple in nature.
A must see shrine in Shibuya. It rained when I visited but definitely worth the visit. The shrine was big and peaceful - couldn't believe it was in the middle of the city.

Wonderful. Set in the middle of a giant park this is a beautiful shrine with impressive features starting with the wooden torii that guide you to the location. There are many shrines throughout Japan, this one should be near the top of your list

A peaceful haven in the concrete jungle. What a beautiful tranquil place ... I walked here from the 46th floor of the Park Hyatt ... Looking down on what appears to be a concrete jungle, I walked for 10 minutes into a beautiful forested parkland and towards the Shinto Shrine. It was so peaceful, simple and beautiful. It wasn't painted brightly .. Just plain wood and not many tourists either. I really loved being there and seeing the sacred greet and the messages around it. This is a great place to visit before or after Harajuku ... Very close but worlds apart ... Such a contrast! That's Tokyo!
Lovely!. Went on a Sunday morning and was lucky enough to catch a Shinto wedding. Is a bit of a walk from the subway to the buildings but totally worth it. Go early to avoid the crowds!

A big shrine!. This is another large area in the centre of Tokyo, incongruently on the other side of the hip and happening Takeshita Street. They really are worlds apart - old world Japan opposite trendy new Tokyo.The Shrine is easy to get to from the JR Harajuku Station in Shibuya. When you exit the station, turn right to the Shrine, whereas the very obviously modern area, including Takeshita Street, is on your left.It's a pleasant walk to the Shrine, which is very popular with locals and tourists alike. It is also a popular spot for weddings and wedding photographs, and we were fortunate enough to see one when we were there. I suppose it's like many Shrines in Tokyo; but this is a big one!

So much peace and quiet in the middle of Tokyo. The Meiji shrine was amazing! It is in the middle of busy Tokyo but it is like entering a secluded forest. The architecture of the shrines and buildings were very nice and there were English instructions on how to participate in Shrine activities for tourists. The paths to different areas were an incredible break from the surrounding city. Beautiful.

Serene Experience in the Middle of the City. We came here as part of an architectural tour and loved this spot. The walk to the shrine is incredibly peaceful and the shrine itself is stepped in tradition. Make sure you check out some of the modern architecture on the surrounding streets afterwards.

Must see . A beautiful Shinto shrine on imperial ground. Very simple and zen setting. There were blessed lucky charm for every aspect in life for sale. I got one for traffic safety to hang in my car. And some for souvenir.

Definitely recommend . This was so nice and a great place to walk around and take it all in. I got lucky and there were a couple of ceremonies that were happening that day. It was perfect. Then I walked around and was able to enjoy an open field in the middle of the city.

Crowded but worth it. Actually we had one of the highlights of our trip to Japan here, as there was a wedding ceremony being preformed in the middle of the shrine, shortly after we arrived. I would have bought the wooden shrine offerings if there had been any English translations available. I know this is a "working" shrine, but there were many tourists who did not speak English there who were not on a guided tour.Nonetheless, it was wonderful walking up to the Shrine, in the tall forest which softened the noise of the nearby city.We exited at the Harajuku Gate and had a fabulous meal.

Shinto shrine dedicated to the Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. Such a beautiful place, so much greenery, you really feel the peace. Just a walk away from bustling Harajuku and Omotesando Hills. We were there for my granddaughter's Shichi-Go-San ( "Seven-Five-Three"), it is a traditional rite of passage and festival day in Japan for three- and seven-year-old girls and three- and five-year-old boys, held annually on November 15 to celebrate the growth and well-being of young children.Fortunate to also witness a beautiful traditional wedding parade as well as all the young children in traditional costume

Busy but peaceful. I liked this shrine because even though there were hundreds of tourists, it didn't feel extremely packed like some other shrines. Luckily, we had a tour guide, our friend, to explain the different spots at the shrine. If it wasn't for him, it may have seemed like a fast walk. The scenery is very gorgeous but do beware that it's busy. The grounds are well taken care of and it's very peaceful within the wooded area. Try to get there early though to beat the crowds.
Peaceful place in Tokyo center. Peaceful place in Tokyo center. Great place to learn and apprehend a little of the japanese culture and way of living. A must in Tokyo.
Very relaxing. Nice to visit on a sunny day, recommend for a few moments of silence and peace. If you are lucky, you might also catch a ceremony, like a wedding and see the traditional outfits.
Loved the park. Absolutely loved the park - one of the highlights of our trip to Tokyo - so peacful and beautiful! Nice early morning walk!

Beautiful and peaceful. It was easy to find and the walk to the shrine was so quiet and relaxing, even though there were lots of people coming to see it. Like other reviewers, we saw lots of couples during their wedding ceremonies. I don't know if they appreciated the tourists' photography but that I guess it's such an important place and so beautiful around there that it was worth it.Definitely on the list of must-do things whilst visiting Tokyo.

Relaxing. Went to the shrine because so many talked about it. When I saw it, it was still amazing but not as amazing as I'd expected. + good if you'd like to get out of the busy scene of the city centre+ good for a relaxing walk+ it's freeTips:- make sure you get it in time, it closes around 6 (not sure about this time)- hoped to see the blossoming cherry blossoms but unfortunately this was a no.

Not good rainy day activity. We went on a cold rainy day. Should have waited for sun. Was worthwhile but uncomfortable due to weather. We saw a beautiful Japanese wedding procession in spite of the rainy day.
very peaceful. you dont need a tour guide to show you around, its very peaceful to walk around the forest and you wont bealieve youre still inside rumbling tokyo.

Must-see, great walk!. Enjoy the fresh woody breeze in the park! The shrine is quite nice and can be crowded at times. There are no benches on the way - beware if you have problems with walking a lot.

Sunday visit . Beautiful peaceful Shinto grounds. We also saw three bridal processions in various formal cultural and modern bridal attire. Small kids should be told there's rules like no sitting on the steps leading to the inner shrine area and they have guards who monitor and are not tolerant of young kids who are not aware of their local customs especially near the inner shrine. There was also a nice food area where you could purchase hot foods and ice cream that resembles a restaurant but was more set up like a small food court. A beautiful historic site.

Meiji Jingu : Must Visited. Meiji Jingu is located between Yoyogi Station and Harajuku Station.You can walk along the park is take time not over 1 hour. Inside of the Meiji Park,It's located Meiji Shrine. It's free and good to relax.

Wonderful temple. We found this temple by accident one day waiting for the harajuku shops to open and has now ended up being a must see everytime we are in tokyo. The grounds are so peaceful even with tourists everywhere and we were lucky enough to see a traditional wedding ceremony on two occasions.

Meiji Shrine. A beautiful and peaceful Shrine to visit with gorgeous gardens.
Well worth the visit if you are nearby.
We were lucky enough to see a bride on her way to be married.

beautiful and serene place. It was a beautiful stroll from the main entrance with the big wooden torii gate to the shrine inside. At first I thought I would feel the lengthy walk take its toll on me, but I didn't feel tired walking around at all. The crisp air and serene environment made all the difference. I enjoyed our visit to the Meiji Shrine, regardless of how simple and straightforward it was. You just shouldn't miss it. It is one of the top destinations in Tokyo after all.☺

Peace and quiet. This is a must see on your visit to Tokyo. It has got a train station right by the entrance and the walk to the shrine is beautiful through the gorgeous park. It is very impressive and I loved it the best out of all the sight seeing in Tokyo. It is so peaceful and impressive.

Beautiful shrine, wonderfull, quiet woods!. This tribute to the modernizer of Japan offers an insight to spirit of nature in urban Tokyo. The woods you walk through are inspiring. The shrine is beautiful with its natural colored wood.
Beautiful shrine. This is an amazing site in a place as busy as Tokyo. It's in the middle of a forest in the middle of the city. Incredibly peaceful
Relaxing for an afternoon strowl. Ended up at Meiji Jingu on a nice Sunday afternoon. It is a very relaxing park around Meiji Jingu, which makes it perfect place to wind down your soul and relax.

Worth the visit. We went on Saturday and saw three traditional Japanese weddings. Very well maintained gardens, lots of English explanations on what to do and why at the Shrine, and the meeting of the past with the present. Would recommend this, approx and hour and then hit the shops. And grab some lunch.

Very busy but a must visit place. You can't not visit the Meiji Jingu when in Tokyo, and if you're lucky you might see a traditional Japanese wedding. It's a great place, very busy with tourists and pilgrims from all over Japan, being the imperial shrine. It's set within a large park / woodland area and there's a lot of space so it doesn't feel crowded.

Definitely worth breezing by and the gardens and nice too.. It's a nice building and has and really calm and cool atmosphere. There isn't really much to see or do, but what you can see is great. Lots of open spaces and gardens and the building is beautiful. Write down your wishes, do the honorary ritual on the way in and pray (all ofcourse out of respect and to experience the culture rather than religiously).

Nice walk on a sunny day. It's a short walk from the harajuku station, but you have to walk a bit from the entrance which I actually liked. There's a lot to see and do at the temple so plan at least an hour of you want to see everything.
Now thats a shrine. You gotta be one cool Emperor to get a Shrine this awesome built in your honor. It's incredible to be in such a peaceful one street away from busy Tokyo.

Serenity in Tokyo. An amazing place to soak up some peace and pay your respects to Shintoism. The gates and the woodland are very peaceful and great to get away from the hustle and bustle.The temple celebrates Meiji who is heralded as the Emperor who opened up Japan to the Western world and ushered in a time of modernity and globalisation.A great place to spend a couple of hours

Great shrine sourrounded by peaceful park.. Even though it's a relatively new shrine it has the appeal of something much more historic. The walk to the shrine is through a beautiful park setting and the shrine itself is wonderful to view. There are numerous side buildings and path to explore either on the way, or on the return. Very worthwhile shrine to make a trip to while exploring Tokyo.

Beautiful grounds. We walked through the suburbs from the Tokyo Metroplitan Building which was lovely in itself. Grounds of the shrine are lovely and peaceful. Lots of info in English. Went on a Wednesday and it wasn't crowded. Walked on to Harajuku but mustn't have been a cosplay day as everyone was dressed pretty sedately. Still lots to look at though.

Wonderful. One of the most beautiful shrines in Tokyo, a must see! Perfect in every season but really amazing covered by snow in winter. Don't leave Tokyo without a picture here. They often perform Japanese styles marriages that are worthy to be seen.
Beautiful day. The park that surrounds the temple is beautiful. It appeared to work with nature. Nice trails to walk thru the wooded areas. A surprise to find this beautiful area in the city.

Serene place, unfortunately no english signage. Was here during my transit in Tokyo. I enjoyed the trail leading to Meiji Jingu. It's a serene walk and I was immersed in the nature during my walk there. This historic and religious attraction is relatively crowded as with other part of the city. The crowd is not a big issue. The most disappointing part is there is lack of english signs and board explaining what we are seeing. There are part of the trail where you see many lantern, there's part where you see huge Japanese gate, some trails have branches; but I do not understand any single thing they have there. If you go there, I think you might want to look for a guide speaking in your language to help you understand.
The park is the experience. Beautiful temple, but a bit crowded. Walking in the beautiful park was the entire experience for us.
Peace!. a place of peace and tranquility! enjoy it! you must come for a walk and meditation, give some coins to the temple and pray

An oasis of calm in a buzzing metropolis. Came here today for a peaceful afternoon and from stepping off the subway and then walking through the park gates this place was like a little sanctuary within the city. Beautiful forest, beautiful shrine and perfect for some quiet reflection. I would definitely go back.
Calm area in the city. Interesting to see shinto customs and learn about the man who introduced western culture into the Japanese society.

You'll forget you're in Tokyo. Once you walk back through the park and into the woods, you'll absolutely forget you are in the heart of one of the biggest cities in the world. Meiji is beautiful.My favorite part of visiting here was seeing a few Japanese wedding parties! It was very glamorous and quite a spectacle. I felt sort of weird being one of hundreds of people admiring the wedding parties.

Majestic. Impossible to miss when on a trip to Tokyo. The place is serene, surrounded by nature, perfect for strolling or walking with your loved ones, or even if you are going solo. Great place to appreciate Japanese culture and architecture.

Serenity oasis . In the middle of one of the biggest cities, is a massive park that will blow your mind. It is a calm oasis of peacefulness that is in complete contrast to the world outside its gates. You could easily spend an hour wondering through the forests here before even reaching the temple! The temple itself is awesome. Quite large and spacious, it is great to see one that is well utilised, maintained and immaculately presented. The whole place is amazing and worth the effort to spend a bit of time there. There is even a little gift shop there which is very reasonable.

Pristine. A lovely walk through a peaceful forest. Everything is perfectly in its place. You can really feel the zen aspect of Japanese Buddhism. Was quite busy, but didn't feel crowded. I recommend stopping by early in the morning when the mist is still lingering.

Interesting. If you love nature, architecture or old building, that's the place for you. This temple is located in the middle of the park, and with a few entries to the temple. Is great to hv a chance to saw traditional Japanese wedding ceremony happened in it.
Nice place. It is a temple which is a short walk from the train station.It is peaceful and quiet walk thru the park to the temple!!

Must go in Tokyo. History is what made a place interesting. For those who have never been in Tokyo, this is one of the must go place. It is peaceful piece of land inside a busy city. It is best to go early in the morning as it can get quit crowd later in the day. Once your done, you may head straight off into the streets of Takeshita Dori. It is a street full of colour. Lots of kawaii clothes and crepes shops. Heaven for teenagers!

Most memorable place in Tokyo. Made a trip to Meiji Shrine on my recent trip to Tokyo. This place is peaceful and you'll be amazed by the shinto shrines in this place. I was here on a dark rainy day which in my opinion added more to the atmosphere, so I would recommend this place in all weather conditions.

Great location, good exercise . Located in shibuya, you get off the metro and it is only 1 minute walk to see the entrance. Then it's a long walk into the temple, but it is a great atmosphere and you can feel a peace of mind just walking towards it.(at least I did). Great memory photos!

Japan's Best. It is without a doubt one of Japan's most iconic tourist attractions and this Shinto Shrine is simply stunning. As you walk through the first Torii (but not under the centre) into the sacred area you are mesmerised by the size and beauty of the complex. Be sure to check out the most beautiful lanterns (toro) that line the path as well as the donated Sake barrels that tower at the entrance. As this is a Shinto Shrine be sure to wash your hands and mouth with the baci (cleaning basin), first using your right hand to hold the ladle and clean your left hand before swapping to clean your right hand cupping some water to clean your face and then running water down the ladle. To pray make an offering (a few yen) bow twice, clap twice (to awaken the gods) prayer and then bow again.
Tranquillity among the hustle and bustle. Made a trip to visit Meiji Shrine during our recent trip to Tokyo. It was tranquil and peaceful, despite located in the busy Harajuku area.

Love it. I think Meiji Jingu is one of the prettiest temples in Tokyo. It helps that it is located near Harajuku (my #1 place in Tokyo). I just think the story, the trees and the building itself are lovely. I visit this place every time I go to Japan.

Absolutely beautiful!. Gorgeous shrine in the middle of a beautiful forested area. Doesn't even feel like I'm in the city! Very touristy area since most signs have English translations as well as instructions on how to properly make a prayer/wish.I also appreciated how all the restrooms have been renovated into modern toilets - don't have to worry about using traditional Japanese toilets!
A oasis in Tokyo. Walking into the preserved nature of its forest from the crazy fashion shopping district and experience the contrast is so cool.

Temple . Just a little walk (less than a mile) to the temple. Sometimes you'll see people all dressed up in their Japanese outfits. It's along a dirt road. Once you're there, there's an area to pray, leave a prayer note, meditate, and take in the experience. It's something to see, but if you're crunched on time, it can be missed. We were there less than 15 mins.
Nice tranquil park. Your average park in Tokyo. Nice to take a walk and escape the hustle from the streets. If you have some minutes extra, take a little stroll and visit the shrine.

Peaceful respite in the middle of the city. I got lost walking here but it was sort of fitting because Meiji Shrine lends itself to wandering around, getting lost physically and in your thoughts. I spent a couple of hours here and enjoyed how calm it was despite the crowds.

If You Have Been In Japan For Awhile, It's Nothing Special. The forest is a nice escape from the city, but besides that it is nothing all that great if you have seen some Japanese shrines before, especially ones in Kyoto. It is overflowing with tourists, the shrine complex is very typical to ones I have seen before. Skip the shrine and go straight to Yoyogi park.
Great day activity . Hop off at the harajuku station and enter into the grounds. It is a nice leisurely walk through the tall trees to the beautiful shrine. Great on a sunny day! Enjoy

Zen moment at the Meiji Jingu. The Meiji Jingu is a place you must visit if you're in Tokyo. Just about a minute walk off from the busy Harajuku station, you'll find yourself in a completely different world! Walking through the entrance surrounded by forest, mini shrines, and large wooden archways was by far my favourite Zen moment. Strongly recommended to visit the shrine during non-touristy hours early dawn, morning or just before lunch.

Wonderous. There are many different sides to Tokyo, and this temple complex is one of the best from anyone's perspective. While some religions are more exclusive with their most revered sites, the Japanese seem keen to share with those who are interested. In this case it is for a stunning temple which ties into the country's history. This shouldn't be missed no matter how short of a visit.
Nice Forest in the middle of metropolitan city. In any seasons, this place is filled with woods and gives you a moment to relax, together with historic Meiji shrine facade.

So peaceful. The grounds of the shrine are large, and you feel transported into another world - despite being in the midst of a bustling city, it is extremely calm and peaceful (even when there are plenty of visitors!). Worth spending some time walking around the grounds - a very different feel from the frenetic activity of Tokyo
Amazing shrine. Beautiful and peaceful shrine in Tokyo. Can sense Japanese "Shinto" from the tranquility and atmosphere of the shrine.

Totoro tree. We went on a Sunday and it seems like there's some sort of event going on. There was lots of ladies dressed in beautiful kimonos queuing to get into the building. It is quite calm to walk around the beautiful garden. We even saw a tree that resembles the Totoro tree.

Beautiful. Beautiful shrine and gardens. In the middle of busy city, a serene place to relax. The shrine is not as decorated as I would have expected but nevertheless, still interesting and beautiful.

Nice to see. Went on Sunday January 17 2016, under a cold cloudy sky, we followed a huge crowd from the train station coming to pay their respect for the new year,. Like most people we walk to the shrine, had a prayer and came back. This place would be better appreciated by anyone having a minimum knowledge of Japanese culture , or Japanese religion or history. From Joe Bloe this remains a collection of structures. While on the site we could see a wedding procession, quite impressive. Wear comfortable walking shoes. A great place to rest, relax before or after visiting Harajuku.

Tranquil and Clean park with a historic shrine. Offers peace and quiet away from the city. The shrine was beautiful and whilst there was fortunate enough to witness a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony taking place.

Peace and green in the city. Tired of the noisy Shinjuku? Take the Yamanote line and in only three stops get off at Harajuku. Just the architecture of the subway station gives the impression to have arrived in a small Swiss village. Cross the small bridge and head to the Meiji Jingu Shrine. It's a beautiful and relaxing walk in the wood, under huge trees. The Shrine was destroyed during the last war and very well rebuilt. There are often many visitors, but the atmosphere is peaceful and spiritual.Take your time and, before taking again the subway, walk to Omotesando to enjoy European style shops and cafés.

Amazing Shrine. Visited this iconic shrine in Tokyo. The immensity is something to behold.On the way in, it is interesting to see the oferrings made to the Meiji Emperor - sake barrels and french red wine barrels.Interesting custom of washing hands and face before entering the temple grounds.Bought and posted an "ema" offering within the temple.Must see when in Tokyo and I think it is on every tour list anyway

Hatsumode during the New Year. I visited Tokyo with my sister during the New Year. Many establishments were closed because of the one-week holiday. Thankfully, Meiji was not one of them. As we heard the Japanese visit the temple on New Year's Day, so we went there too although we are not religious. We were amazed at the discipline of the Japanese and how organized everything was. There were thousands of visitors that day but astonishingly not chaotic at all. The visitors walked on the left side. Then one row go to the temple and pray and then out the gate to where there were food stalls. Then the next row approach the temple and so on and on. This is a serene place in the middle of bustling Tokyo. It is near other tourist spots like Harajuku.

Beautiful, serene, calming, and in the heart of a city?!. I visited Meiji Jingu shrines and gardens in August 2015 with some friends. It is so picturesque and pretty! It was the first piece of Japanese culture we visited and we loved it! It felt 'Japanese', it's stooped in history. We happened to visit on a day when the place was hosting a dance competition, absolutely amazing to see how well choreographed it was! Highly recommended.Best of all...it's free!

Serenity at its peak !. The park was really huge and beautiful! The towering gates are really awesome , we stand beside one of the columns to emphasise how huge it is. Am amazed how it was erected during the early years with out equiment such as cranes.The park is steps away from Shibuya subway station. We were lucky that during that trip there was a wedding ceremony and picturals on going. We enjoyed it very much.

a park in the middle of busy shopping area, RELAXING!. we went here after we shopped and strolled around Takeshita Dori and Laforet.It was only 5 mins walk distance from Laforet. Meiji Jingu Station was right across the street. It was a quiet and green park, where people walk around and enjoy the nature. we didnt walk until the shrine, though. we were only walking around the yoyogi park.Worth visiting, especially after a whole day strolling around the crowded and hectic shopping area.

A must see !. beautiful park with an amazing temple, perfecto to explore Japan culture when traveling for the first time. you can also end your day walking trough the street if Harajuku wich is also really near by.

Beautiful!. The shrine is in the middle of a beautiful and peaceful park. Most signs include english, so it is easy to find your way around. Only steps away from Harajuku. This is a Shinto shrine, so many people were there to pay respects. However, this is also a tourist attraction for Japanese and foreign visitors. Everyone was taking photos, so, I did not feel uncomfortable doing so. There are a couple of souvenir stands with low priced items to purchase. One interesting and low cost item is a poem that is revealed to you by chance. You shake a box to reveal a stick with a number. Give the number to a shrine maiden, and for 100 yen, you receive a poem written either by Emperor Meiji or Empress Shoken. The hope is that you will find some meaning in your life with the poem. We were there on a Saturday, and were witness to three Shinto weddings!

Beautiful and tranquil. Was there on a Sunday and saw three traditional Shinto weddings. Nice parklands even during winter, be sure to checkout the well, it's not what you'd expect but supposed to bring you luck.

Loevly Place For A Sunday Stroll. You must visit Yoyogi whilst in Tokyo, it is a gorgeous expansive park with amazing features and is particularly lovely on a Sunday. Meiji Jingu is a lovely attraction that you should visit.

Beautiful park, pretty temple, relaxing space in walking distance of Shibuya. Meiji Jingu is a Shinto shrine. Its in a beautiful park and gardens and is very easy to to to by Subway and a reasonable walk from Shibuya - a main shopping area. The park is beautiful with a small lake and has lots of local people enjoying the day. The day we visited was a Coming of Age ceremony so hundreds of people were walking around in traditional clothing and there were fabulous ice carvings sponsored by different families. It was stunning to see it all. The temple itself is beautiful and you can throw coins into a specific area for good luck as well as purchase and burn different varieties of incense. It s a beautiful place to wander around, sit and take a break form the hectic pace of Tokyo, a lovely place to bring a picnic with the family and watch the various activites the locals engage in. Lots of photo opportunities.

Instant Serenity. Meiji Jingu has to be one of the most serene, man-made places on the planet. That said, it seems impossible that you would find this shrine in the middle of Shibuya, which has to be the most bustling ward in Tokyo. The forest surrounding the shrine is a 150 year project (it's is currently about 90 years old,) blots out the sun and the surrounding cityscape to create a sensation of being transported into a sanctuary hidden away from the modern world. Japanese people have a long held belief that deities descend to Earth via the tall trees and that their spirits dwell in them. Meiji Jingu should not be rushed. Try to stand still and breathe it all in. You won't regret it.

Nice Urban Oasis . I spent one afternoon walking Tokyo and strolled around Meiji Jingu for hours. Beautiful park has traditional Japanese gardens and shrines. Large open grass area nice for picnic or activities. Small entry fee is worth the price. I wouldn't call it a must see in Tokyo but if you have some free time or want to take a stroll in a beautiful park definitely stop in.

A lovely place to escape the city hustle. My partner and I had a lovely time here wandering around. We wanted to ride our bikes but nobody else was so we guessed that it might not have been allowed. The park was busy but there was enough space to move about and not get lost in crowds. Lots of people enjoying winter sunshine today. The treasure museum was closed but everywhere else was still accessible. A must see spot if you are into going to parks. Always kept really tidy.

Oasis in the middle of chaos. Took a guided tour. The place is nice and calm compared to the hussle of Tokyo. Guide tells us this was originally a grassy park and the locals planted trees to make it look like a forest now. Good restaurant, bathroom and gift shop. Free to enter, but need to pay if you choose to see some special sites.

Great on a beautiful day, peaceful and natural.. The shrine, to Emporor Meiji and his wife, is a beautiful and still bustling Shinto shrine where you can see weddings taking place and will, invariably, pass multiple modern Japanese women in kimono and umbrella making there way here and there. The shrine is in a park full of evergreens and as you enter from the streets of Harajuku the calm and silence will take you out of contemporary Tokyo into another time. this is a lovely part of Tokyo and, really, a part of the city that should not be missed.

Beautiful & Serene. Impressive shrine on our first day in Japan. We got a lot of extra information from our Japanese friend who could tell us a lot about the rituals. We saw a wedding and also a baby who was brought in a kimono to the shrine. The park/forest around is beautiful too
Beautiful!. Way bigger than I expected. It's amazing how quiet it gets there although it's located right in the middle of Tokyo.
Great place in a great park. One of the greatest temples in Tokyo surrounded by a great park ... Totally worth a visit while in tokyo

Long, refreshing walk. It takes you away from the hustle and bustle of the city just outside its gates. You will be enraptured in the solemnity of the place. The path of rocks are neatly piled up. It can take you 20 minutes to walk from the entrance to the shrine.

Respite from the City. Beautiful Shrine in the middle of a forest in the middle of the city. I liked that this place wasn't colored that bright orange that is usually in other shrines. There were also instructions of how to approach, bow and conduct one's self when visiting the shrine.
Not to be missed. A very interesting a historic place. Beautiful place to walk around in. They also have a great gift shop and a restaurant where they sell sake ice cream.

Beautiful Leisurely Time Spent. We spent a lovely morning strolling the Meiji Shrine. It was not busy and was spacious enough to feel relaxed and enjoyable. We love the english explanation of the historical facts relating to the shrine. It was quite an informative and beautifully maintained shrine. It's a must see on most travel books. There's a very good reason for it. Don't miss it. But remember to keep your voices down! Japanese shrines are to be respected by being quiet inside!
Meiji shrine. Once you exit from the metro station, it's about a 5-10 minutes walk to the shrine. I was lucky to witness a couple having their wedding ceremony. Highly recommended.

Beautiful place. This is an amazing tranquil place in the middle of a bustling metropolis. It was relatively late in the afternoon when we visited but it was beautiful. It rates number 1 for a very good reason, a must visit.

Strange mystical place. This place will make you feel like you've travelled miles outside of Tokyo - all just couple steps from busy Harajuku! We visited about 30 minutes before closing which helped this impression - it was quite quiet and the tall trees made the paths quite dim apart from the light from traditional lanterns. So I would recommend visiting either early or late to experience this amazing atmosphere.

Beautiful and amazing. There is quite a bit of walking but it's all very beautiful and a drastic change from the street we walked in from. We took the other path you pay to walk along and we consider that a MUST if you visit here.

Peaceful Early Morning Visit. Go in the early morning before all of the crowds arrive. We arrived at the main shrine about 8:30 and it was almost empty. I would have preferred to have been there earlier but we started later than planned. The grounds surrounding the shrine are amazing. You would not realize that you are in the middle of Tokyo.

Beautiful. We walked from the metropolitan building ( looked closer than it was) and as it had snowed the previous day we were treated to an wonderland as we walked through the grounds to the center area.. a peaceful haven in Tokyo. Well worth the visit.
tranquille place. this place is ideal for a morning walk. u might even catch some ceremony here.then afterwards u could head to shibuya/harajuku.

Be ready for a walk. From the Harajuku Station, the shrine is a few meters walk away. Be sure to be in your walking shoes for comfort because you're not going to walk on plain terrain. Be sure to have a photo taken at the torris, wooden gate-like structures found at the entrance and near the shrine. The shrine is a must see. It was made to commemorate the contributions Emperor Meiji's done to Japan. No photos allowed at the main shrine, btw! You can also visit some gardens in the vicinity, we did not because it was winter when we visited and their are no flowers yet. Best to see them during spring for the sakura also see the wine barrels near the entrance.

Tranquil retreat for tired shoppers. It''s a great place to wander about when you want to get away from the hectic pace of Shibuya (and its free!). The shrine itself is cool and peaceful, with beautiful calligraphy lining the walls. You'll most likely need to wait on line to get to see the inside of the shrine itself, but be aware that there are lots of folks who come here to actually pray, so be aware and respectful. The surrounding park/garden is lovely and the gravel roads are lined with beautiful large trees. Maps of the park aren't great however. I liked it a lot!

Peaceful place. Lovely walk. It opens early which is great for children as most things don't open till 11. We spent a couple of hours there and were lucky enough to see several weddings which were beautiful.

Meiji Shrine - A Must See: Japanese Shrine Architecture and Beauty. The famed Meiji Jingu Shrine spans 175 acres in the center of Tokyo. The Deites enshrined there are Emperor Meiji and his consort Empress Shoken. The shrine grounds include trees and shrubs donated by people from all parts of Japan. The shrine building (Inner Garden) within is a unique example of Japanese shrine architecture. The Outer Garden sits on 77 acres and features the Meiji Shrine Picture Gallery which contains large murals that illustrate events in the lives of the Emperor and his consort. Among the beautiful gingko trees you will find The Meiji Memorial Hall (Wedding Hall) where the Shinto wedding ceremony is performed. The Meiji Shrine is a truly spiritual place that must be viewed and treated with great respect.

serene and beautiful. We took the metro to get to the park, it's about 10min walk from the metro. The trees on both sides stand so tall, the park is beautiful and the feeling is so serene! The most popular attraction is the display of sake barrels, all different branding and colors, it's great to be able to do something more outdoorsy while still being so close to the city.

Peacefulness amongst a busy city. The area around it is so busy the. You turn onto a gravel trail and completely forget you are in the city. It's located in a forested area with many walkways. The shrine is beautiful, it has many details. I would highly recommend coming to look at this.

A good place to spend a couple of hours.. The temple is surrounded by Hugh trees and it's very peaceful. it's no a spectacular temple but if you want to get away from the modern crowded Tokyo, this is a good place to go for a wonder.

Little bit of history and a peaceful afternoon. We went for a very peaceful 2 hr walk in the grounds of the temple and inside the temple itself. There are guided tours if you want one or you can just wonder and take in the surroundings, write down a prayer and enjoy a little bit of history.

Great history and terrific nature walk. This beautiful shrine is located at the center of a forest which provides an excellent walking experience. Wear comfortable footwear as the complex is rather large. A terrific and free excursion!

A wonderfully calming experience in the bustle of Tokyo. To put it simply, the Meiji Shrine is a must-visit in Tokyo. If you've reached your limit on shopping and travelling on the metro, the Shrine is a world of calm in the middle of the hustle and bustle. It is absolutely beautiful, with visitors able to use the temizuya to wash their hands and mouth before entering. You can also throw some coins into the collection box before shrine to pay respects to Meiji: people for all walks of life did so, and it was wonderful to see. The best part is that they do not charge for entry, something which has become a plight of sights like this. Located in a vast beautiful park, you simply must visit.
Beautiful for a morning walk and a dose of history. Beautiful grounds to talk a walk on the cusp of harajuku. Great informative boards giving an insight into the history and culture of japan

Great place to visit!. This place is breathtakingly beautiful!!!Immerse yourself in real Japanese culture by vising here. It is located in Harajuku in the Yoyogi Park, and it's HUGE! Wear comfortable shoes because you are literally walking through some amazing nature before entering the shrine. Also, dress appropriately, you don't want to be rude to the Japanese culture by wearing indecent clothing. Remember to check the opening and closing times to see the shrines. Usually it's sunrise to sunset, depending on the season.Be respectful, no shouting or loud talking. Whisper and don't take any pictures inside the shrine. I get HIGHLY annoyed of obnoxious foreigners with no ETIQUETTE! It makes me want to smack them and tell them the rules and policy when visiting sacred places. SO PLEASE PLEASE make yourself aware of how to act and be respectful when visiting places in Japan. Japan is a beautiful country full of humble people who have the utmost respect for not only one another, but their country as well...so please be respectful, you don't want to be the obnoxious disrespectful foreigner jerks!Front entrance, don't forget to bow once upon entering and once again upon leaving. At the front, Temizuya...rinse both your hands, pour water in your left hand, rinse your mouth, rinse your left hand again, and then rinse the dipper allowing the water to run down the handle of the dipper. DO NOT TOUCH the dipper directly to your lips.Luckily, our great friend Kanata who is Japanese took us here and showed us all the traditional customs..but do not fret...their are rules in English as well and it directs you on how to do things proplerly =)

Lucky to see multiple weddings!. I'd read about this shrine before going out to Tokyo and heard that you can consider yourself lucky if you catch a wedding ceremony whilst visiting. Somehow or another, me and my wife managed to see three ... THREE!It was a brilliant event to watch, it is very different from anything in the western world or even the Indian world (I am Indian). The women are dressed in intricate garments, have the sternest look on their face and are flanked by a hundred guests following them. What is more bizarre is the way the wedding is carried out in the public eye and all manner of strangers snap away pictures of your magical day to take home with them.Other than the weddings, the shrine itself is breathtaking. In a city of so much rush and pace this area is peaceful, well manicured and a world away from the high rises that dominate Tokyo.

Beautiful park area and shrines. Walked through this area after visiting Takeshita street from Harajuku station, and really enjoyed the park and greenery with the temples, shrines and gates. Very enjoyable walk. You dont need to spend any money but there is a small fee for the temple if you want to go in. Very busy on New Years Eve but still enjoyable.

A Magical Place not to be Missed. If you go to the Harajuku area-Do NOT miss out! This whole area is free (mostly-- There was one trail I took where a small fee was paid to the shrine)You pass through the tori enterance and walk into this stunningly quite and beautiful park. As you continue you approach the meiji jingu shrine. The shrine was very spiritual and beautiful. They have small demos. You can have your fortune told, pay respects to the shrine and see some ceremonies being preformed.Plenty of souvineers to pick up inside and outside the shop.The walking can be as long or as short as you want. Mostly flat easy terrain with paved paths.I went solo and had no trouble navigating this area.
!. get off from the mejijingu sta. just have to walk in 2 mins. i really want to say it's a great place.

Sacred and good for walking. 10 minutes walk to Jinja from the entrance made me feel refresh with splendid nature and sunshine. It's close to Takeshita street, delicious pancake restaurant and so on... so here is the greatest place to visit in Tokyo definetely!

Contrast from Surroundings. The shrine itself is quite a long walk in from the entrance. Takes about 20 minutes to walk in. Inside we just followed the crowds and looked around observing what the locals were doing. On the walk out there are some food and a museum as well. A contrast from the built-up areas all around it. Nearest station is Harajuku.

A very serene and revitalizing experience. I would best describe this as a place to find solitude and greenery in the middle of a vibrant city. I encourage anyone trying to revitalize oneself or find inner peace to take a stroll through here. It is by no means very prestigious or spectacular looking as compared to some of the Shrines/Temples in the Country but there is this different serenity and solemn aura in here that you may not readily find anywhere.Tips: *Wear comfortable shoes, it is a huge place and there are many side tracks to various sites*Some of the side tracks/sites are payable to access but the Main Shrine is free for all*Buy some charms off the Maidens or as a gift to your friends/family :) Well, the Maidens are charming in their costumes; something you may only see from the TV/Documentary*Location-wise, to cover more grounds for some of you - I recommend getting off Harajuku Station which as you exit, you will face the very popular Harajuku Street which is apparently very often featured in fashion-related materials; after exploring the Street, then you may proceed to Meji Shrine which as you exit the Station is to head to your right, follow through and take the bridge across to the entrance.

The Emperor's Shrine. It is the power spot for shrines in tokyo. The nearest JR station is Harajuku, once you get out of the station make a right turn, and another right turn shorty after. You will then be facing the entrance to Meiji Jingu. It is a good walk to the actual Jingu, so wear the correct footwear.

Peaceful shrine in Tokyo. The shrine is located in the middle of jungle. It is so green, so peaceful and so huge. It needs 10-15mins (depends on your pace) to reach the main shrine from the entrance. You'll pass trees and meadow. People said that there are lots of wedding in this shrine but sadly I didn't find one when I visited the shrine (you should try your luck). There are lots of detail that I love in this shrine, the water at the entrance, the written wish in the hanging woods and the big rope (I'll upload the pictures). I would suggest you not to skip this shrine if you visit Tokyo.

Greenery in the city. Who would have thought that there could be a shrine, as big as this, be situated in the middle of a concrete jungle?Since this is within the city limits, and we've visited on the first working day of the year, there was people everywhere. Businessmen and visitors were offering prayers to their gods.

Pleasant but nothing more. Meiji Shrine is accessed through a lovely wooded park, which also features a wall of sake barrels as well as some French wine barrels. Along the way there are several large wooden gates too. The shrine itself is nice but not spectacular, unless you're a fan of Shinto sites. It's worth it for the stroll but can seem a little underwhelming.

Beautiful grounds and frequent weddings. I went in late October, and because of the warm weather, many traditional Japanese weddings were held there. On the day I visited, I saw 3 brides. It was wonderful to be able to observe at least part of their wedding, where they made their way through the shrine following the priests. Otherwise, the shrine is still very beautiful, especially knowing the fact that it is so quiet even though it is located in a very busy area of the city. Definitely worth a visit, especially if you're not planning on going to too many shrines, this one would be the perfect shrine in Tokyo to visit.

Beautiful shrine but can be crowded. The walk through Yoyogi park was delightful on the cloudy day we decided to visit Meiji Jingu. We stopped at the welcome gate and the kind gentleman there gave us insect repellant and gave us directions through the park. When we reached Meiji shine we loved the beautiful Torii and temple buildings. There was a wedding while we visited which was quite the cultural experience! Meiji was not the most impressive temple we had visited in Japan and it was busy when we visited. However, if your trip allows for extra time or you are only visiting Tokyo during your trip I would definitely recommend visiting Meiji Jingu.

Beautiful temple and grounds. We happened to be in Tokyo when many Japanese were visiting the temple to pray and make offerings as part of New Year celebrations. The walk to the temple is beautiful, with sake and wine offerings flanking the pathway. We were not permitted in the temple itself, but stood outside and watched Shinto faithfuls make prayers and offerings. It was very tranquil. Past the temple, there were an abundance of stalls selling monkey icons (2016 is the Year of the Monkey) and other items for worshippers and visitors. There were also plenty of food stalls -- smelled wonderful! The grounds are leafy and worth walking around.

If you visit 1 shrine in Tokyo.... Meiji Shrine is a beautiful natural oasis in the middle of one of the busiest cities in the world. I have been in summer, spring and winter, each offering its own delights. It is easy to forget where you are as you walk through the grounds. There is plenty of room for small children to run around. Most of the grounds are free but there are some trails that require a small donation. On a weekend you may even catch a wedding.

Incredible shrine but don't expect it to be peaceful!. As with most of the popular shrines in Tokyo this one is way too busy to be peaceful, this one takes it to an extreme.The shrine is however still impressive with the massive Torii, the long alley of lanterns and other 'offerings' there is a scale and depth to Meiji that make this a real experience.As with many other shrines there is a lot of detail about elements of the shrine (the trees here for instance) and of the construction that many visitors will miss, take the time and really enhance your visit.One note - please be respectful of the rules, far too many people we taking photos where there are clear instructions not to do so.

This is pretty for the gardens. After seeing many Japanese temples, this shrine pales in comparison. It is set in a lovely garden which is beautiful to walk through, so I would recommend going if you are in the area and it is the only shrine you could see; otherwise, there are plenty of more interesting options.

Super crowded but worth it!. We made the fortunate yet unfortunate mistake to visit the Meiji Jingu temple on the 3rd of January this year when many of the locals visit their many temples to pray to their deities for the new year. Whilst in this beautiful expanse of greenery, my fiance and I paid 500 yen each to enter the special garden that houses the tea house and fresh water well. Whilst in there we also saw numerous koi in the ponds and fed the local birds peanuts (as directed by a local) from the palm of our hand! We then lined up for approximately 20 minutes to see and 'wash' our hands in the fresh water well. Afterwards, we followed the crowd to the temple itself which was incredibly busy- the whole place was, really. As always, the Japanese were ever organised and there were numerous security which ensured a relatively organised 'journey' throughout the gardens. Definitely worth the experience, though probably best to avoid the first week or so of the new year to escape the crowds. I estimate it took us 2 hours to complete the above, when it would have taken, perhaps 45 minutes on a 'normal' day.

Great place to walk. Its like a big park with a great Shrine. Great place to get lost and walk and meditate. In beginning of January it is packed for new year celebration, don't go during that time if you want quiet meditation lol.

Great shrine / historical value. A shrine that had worship service going while I was there, the paths over this very large area are well tended and provided easy walking. Get a map and make sure you orient yourself all the time to avoid back tracking as this place is very large. There are two places that cost money (donation), one the Well and the other the Treasure Museum. The Well was of historical interest and was pretty cool for how pure the water is coming out of it and how it works, and the Museum had several interesting artifacts. Mostly it was paintings of all the emperors of Japan.The person said it could get you into two places, however the English was so limited I just passed it off as I was tired and done for the morning.This is a great cultural location to visit - I would recommend this to people coming to Tokyo if they are interested in cultural places of interest.

It was nice, by a bit disappointing . I hate to say it, but I think I was expecting more. This was the first shrine I visited in Japan and was expecting it to be really beautiful and I thought we could go into the shrine. It turns out that you can only go in if you pay about 50$ for a special blessing. I did not walk around the gardens as it was too cold.

Catch Train from Shibuya Stn to Hajuka Stn its Only 1 train stop from Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel. Visited in January. More of a forest than garden although we only stayed 2 hours and there was plenty we missed - the lake. Dry but very cold. We were amazed at how dry everything looked but very beautiful established trees towering above you. Wide gravel paths. Also enjoyed the museum and treasury exhibition inside the gardens. Extra ticket required. 500 yen approx from memory. Both these buildings are widely spaced so allow 20 minutes walking to find each one. The ticket covers entry to both. Treasury Exhibition in new building near cafes etc near main gate. The Museum other side of park in very y old building. Worth it. Some English explanations.

Beautiful grounds. The shrine itself is nothing amazing. If you've never visited a shrine before then I'm sure it's fascinating and impressive. If you have then it is, on the surface as a tourist, much the same as all the others.What I found far more enjoyable were the grounds surrounding the shrine. There are peaceful tracks through the trees, open expanses of grass, and plenty of small wildlife to be seen. It's a great little oasis within the city for a tranquil break. Perfect for a picnic, reading a book, napping or meditating.

One of the better shrines i have been too.. The Meiji shrine is a very large shrine, extremely close to Shibuya station. The shrine is extremely peaceful, and contains a prayer area, various gift stalls and an Omamori (Japanese chimes/talismans) shop with various blessed items to bring you luck.

Very peaceful . I came here in November and loved how calm and relaxed it was in here. It was so green and the shrines were beautiful! I felt like I was in a old Japanese movie. I would definitely Come to this park again :)

Beautiful introduction to Japan. We spent started our first day in Japan with a visit to Meiji Jingu. It is quite interesting as the architecture differs much from the temples we visited in other countries. We were lucky that it was a good month for marriages, so we saw a few bride and grooms in typical Japanese clothing who visited the temple for their ceremonies. The nice addition is that the temple is conveniently located near the shops and restaurants of Harajuku and Otomosando. Well worth a visit!

Nice. Amazing experience at Meijijingu shrine. Wash hand with bamboo water before pray, split it out, this is so different from other places. Throw coins before pray with hand. The shrine was huge, recommended visiting period during winter season as you have long way to walk from Metro Station. You can also pay 100 yen to get a draw for the luck. They have one corner counter which have English speaking staff. If you want to make a wish, you can pay 1000yen and they will give u a small wood and you can write the wishes and hang on the designated area.
A beautiful place for much needed weekend. Well if it's weekend & you want some peace with divine tranquility, this is the place one should look for. A peaceful place away from the city hustle.
Japanese shrine . Major Japanese tourist spot; you can't do Tokyo without coming here. Spend at least one hour and see the koi fish and birds
Incredible. Its hidden in the middle of the city. The walk to the shrine is very peaceful and enjoyable. I would love to go back
A Beautiful Park for a Stroll. Great destination to see in a very cool park. I'd go back if I just wanted a peaceful afternoon away from the city hustle.

Beautiful Shrine in the heart of Harajuku. Visited this shrine as we started our first day in Tokyo. We took JR Yamanote line from Shinjuku JR Station where our hotel is located.The complex is huge so be prepared to walk at least 20 minutes from the main gate. One of the famous shrines in Tokyo, always swamped by both local and tourists. We managed to capture some traditional wedding procession during the visit. There are some cafes and restaurants inside the complex. Very well maintained place indeed.
Peaceful in the city. Just a great park to stroll through.You do get a sense of place, plenty of history.Spring and summer would be quite extraordinary.

Must Do in Shibuya. This shrine is located in the middle of a park full of greens. From Meijijingu-Mae station, it takes less than 1 minute to work to the main entrance (south entrance). One then walks about 10 minutes to go the main shrine (from either the South Gate or East Gate). At the main shrine court, one can wait in line then make offerings while praying. One throws the coins, claps twice, bows once, then prays. When one is done praying, claps and bows again before leave the line. One can also buy a wooden plate and write prayers on it then tie it at the scared tree. My husband and I did not do so, because we do not know the Japanese language (we do not know how to write the characters). Most (99%) people leave from either the South gate or East gate, but I recommend the West gate. It is a much longer walk back to the main entrance, but the path goes through the quiet part of the park. Giant trees are planted on both sides of the path, and the leaves cover the sky (it does get dark around 5pm). Good spot to take pictures!
VIsit to the Shrine. Beautiful Shrine! But a long walk to get there...... But along the way are beautiful forest trees and many photo opportunities!

Free and scenic. If you're already wandering around Yoyogi, might as well wander around to the shrine. It's honestly hard to miss. The arches are massive. Very cool. There is also a large (and overwhelming) New Years fest that goes on there.

Absolutely beautiful. I have vista twice now, once in the middle of summer and just now in the middle of winter. Both visits were equally beautiful and a welcome break from the hustle and bustle of the city. I went on New Years Eve and they were setting up for that evening's celebrations. The walk thought the trees up to the temple and huge timber tori are divine.

Serene. This was a great quiet place to walk and explore. The grounds are well kept and easily walkable for people of all skill levels. Those who have difficulty walking should however avoid this because he distance from the metro station to the shrine is quite long though it is flat.

Highlight of Tokyo!. You can't come to Tokyo and not take a stroll in Meiji Shrine park. It's free, it's right outside the Harajuku station on the Yamanote Line or or the Meijijingu-Mae station on the Chiyoda or Fukutoshin Line

Beautiful!. Located right next to the JR Herajaku Station (through the Yamamote Line) and Yoygi Park , this shrine, dedicated to Emperor Meiji and his consort, is a complete contrast to the hustle and bustle that defines the area. The path leading up to the main area is serene and you'll enjoy the walk. Don't miss out on barrels of Sake showcased during the route. These were actually gifted by traders to the shrine, seena way of bringing gods and people together. A must visit while visiting Tokyo!
Very peaceful . Took a morning stroll around here as I had heard it was lovely place to visit and I wasn't disappointed. Go early to avoid the crowds
Peaceful In a busy city. If you need some respite from the busy city, this place is worth your time . To deep breath, and relax .

An oasis in a big city. We went here early on Christmas day - not a big holiday in Japan (unlike New Years) so it was relatively quiet. A great place for a little insight and experience of Japan's cultural and spiritual life.

Meiji shrine. Beautiful shrine set in a beautiful green park. Definitely worth a stroll through the park; the shrine is inside the park and will take about 10minutes to get to from the entrance near the railway station. We didn't see any weddings though.

In the neighbourhood . Great place as we were lucky to catch some kind of Sumo ritual at the temple which I guess preceded the tournament that starts on Sunday 10 Jan 2016. The whole park surrounding the temple was a great walk to get away from the shopping for a few hours.

So many tourists. Very nice, big shrine, but so busy. Worth a visit (could you not visit this if you're in Tokyo?) especially if you're already heading to Harajuku across the road, but don't bother hanging around for long.
visit to the meiji shrine. great little shrine in the area near shibuya, bit of a walk but worth the trip and you can do prayers or buy trinkets while you are there.

Beautiful greenery. A great place to escape the madness of Tokyo, especially having just walked through the INSANELY BUSY Takeshita Dori. Especially cool if there happens to be a wedding ceremony that you can witness, definitely one place not to miss on your visit to Tokyo.

A peaceful place in the middle of Tokyo!. It was amazing to know that there is such a place even in the midst of crowded place in Tokyo. The entrance to the shrine is a good walk with lots of greeneries and then when you enter Meiji Jingu it is so peaceful. Worth the visit, close to Harajuku station.

A Serene Spot in a Happening City. A very easy walk from the entrance to the Shrine. There are a number of scenic stops and sights along the way hence do not expect a boring walk. I went there on a weekend morning, while there are more people, the place is still very serene and quiet. I even get to witness an actual wedding procession just outside the shrine.Plan it in such a way that you visit Meiji Jingu in the morning and Harajuku thereafter. These 2 places are just next to each other.
Green area of Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is a place worth visit in Tokyo. It is a refreshing escape from the city rush. Expect to find temples and huge forest inside.
enjoy the quiet. Meiji Jingu sits next to the busy Harajuku and Omotesando areas, but is a quiet spot. Take a walk up to the main shrine under the surrounding trees. Always a good place to visit.

A peaceful place within a busy Tokyo. The temple is just a short walk from the Harajuku Station. The walkway are lined with huge trees and you can hear and see some birds flying above. It is a peaceful retreat within the city of Tokyo considering how chaotic and fast paced life is in the city. Just outside the temple is the Takeshita Dori and near by is the Otomesando Hills

One of Tokyo's most famous shrine's. If you come to Tokyo, you should definitely see Meiji Jingu - it's close to the shopping hotspots around Harajuke and Omotesando and well worth a visit. Walk up the long entrance path (probably around a kilometer) - wash your hands in the fountain before you enter - and then take a look at the amazing shrine. You can often see wedding's taking place which is an experience too. There are lots of places to get your fortunes (usually costs around 100 yen) which is a fun thing to do too.

Beautiful But Crowded. The Meiji Temple and surrounding gardens is a must see attraction for this with limited time in Tokyo that want to have a represetative hsitorical experience. The crowds gave the temple a hectic rather than tranquil atmosphere (not like visiting one of the great cathedrals in Europe). But we did have a really cool opportuity to see a couple having there wedding on the grounds make there formal procession through the temple grounds in traditional Japanese dress. We recommend including the Treasure House in travel plans for history buffs.

Good place to visit. Located inside very large garden, beautiful and peaceful shrine. It is a good idea to visit this place then go to Harajuku or Ometosando. You will feel how the different of the peaceful and entertainment atmosphere. Worth to visit.
A MUST do in Tokyo. If you have just one day in Tokyo....This is a must.... plus of course the more crowded, touristy Asakusa.

Not bad - sure there is better around from a tourist perspective. We were there on 3rd Jan public holiday, crowds were massive. Not sure e saw the whole thing because of it, but not bad anyway. Combine with a walk around Yoyogi and the nearby food markets

A peaceful and serene shrine . This shrine is located near a train station and this is next to Yoyogi Park. You can pray here and meditate or walk if you want some peace of mind. Best to go here in the morning when its not crowded yet. Luckily, i witnessed a wedding when I was here. I also offered a prayer hung at the Divine Tree. I was teary eyed reading the prayers and wishes there. Most of the prayers are selfless. According to a friend who went there during autumn, it is more colorful here during the fall.
A must visit when in Tokyo. Try to visit this place on Sundays as they usually have traditional Japanese weddings going on that day. Also Harajuku is just a walking distance.

Very peaceful garden and shrine complex. We wandered through Yoyogi Park and Meiji Jingu one morning. It is a very relaxing and enjoyable place to take a stroll. The shrine is impressive and is a good place to escape the fast pace of the city for an hour or so.
Must go. This really does not require a review since it is a must go must see shrine.. Very local and unique.

Simple beauty. The shrine is a pleasant walk into quietness even with the large holiday crowds . The clean simple colors and lack of colorful decoration are soothing. You can always learn more about Japanese history and customs from visiting these famous sites.

Serene. Very nice place to visit and relax in the city. My husband and I didn't plan to visit here initially, but after walking within buildings we found ourselves wanting to surround by trees (we live in Oregon). We were really glad we had visited here before we got ourselves in another caos, which is Takeshita dori.

Pleasant shrine to visit. Large open garden shrine. Must walk to the big shrine in the park. Pleasant hour to spend. Accessible by subway, when finished can look around the shopping area. Very busy on the day wee went but was still big enough for us to not feel jammed. Unable to get a photo of the shrine without a random in though.

Beautiful Gardens. When you're in the garden, it's hard to believe that such a beautiful place is in the middle of such a busy city. The temple itself is good to see, but it was the walk around the grounds that I really enjoyed. Well worth a visit.

Spiritual & serene experience! . We really enjoyed walking through the long corridor of trees, seeing the Temple, and discovering the Emperor & Empress's garden with the fishing spots and a secret well (paid admission). Definitely a must stop during your Tokyo visit!

Came to pray . It was heaving due to the new year but if you're willing to innocently queue jump by mistake then the wait is just a few minutes. You can then buy many souvineers that may bring good luck. It's a tourist trap but not a bad one. You should come here is you're passing by but don't pass by to come here unless you have a strong reason to do so.

Beautiful but spread out. Make sure not to get lost in this park! We started from Harajuku and when we came out wanted to go back to Shibuya...ended up I don't even know where! Asked a police officer at a Koban station where Shibuya was and he cracked up! Which meant we were far away lol! We got very turned around in the park, so make sure to keep looking at maps wherever you are.Meiji shrine is beautiful.

The forest and the gates are great . The shrine is ok if this is the shrine you get to see in Tokyo. Otherwise, see the one in Asakusa or see those in Kyoto instead.The line was so long that we went all the way to the shrine and then returned. Just the walk through the forest and the gates with lamps, sake etc was interesting and worth the walk. I was clear it ment a lot to the Japanese which makes it interesting to visit to understand the culture.
not too bad to visit. Appart from religious importance of it for Shinto believers in Japan, as a tourist it is an OK place to visit but it hasn't got the wow factor in my opinion.

Peaceful moment. We were here by Nov 2015. It is located opposite JR station. It is free enter. I have to walk along a path with both side are big tall trees to arrive to the temple. I felt so peaceful. Many couples held their Japan traditional wedding ceremony here because it was Sunday. It is my first time watching this. I feel so happy!

Peaceful walk in the morning. Pleasant, peaceful, quiet are fitted words to describe this place. It's best to visit this forest in the morning when there are not a lot of people around. Whenever you want to take a break from the bustling sounds of the city, this is a nice place to think and walk around and just cleanse your mind from problems. We visited this place on a Saturday morning and we were lucky enough to be part of a traditional wedding that was taking place. If you wan't something special, try to visit this place on a Saturday.

omikuji, ema and wedding ceremony. I asked to my friend, I wanna visit this place in the morning because I wanna see someone wedding there. I fans with japanese wedding ceremony. I visit on Nov 23th, my friend said if we came yesterday on Nov 22nd it's very crowded maybe. because in japanese 11/22 means ii fufu (good husband) so there are many japanese couple got married at that day.fortunatelly I can saw one ceremony. so enviable. I took an omikuji and my friend helped me to read my omikuji. my friend and I write our wishes on EMA. I wish I can visit this place again and I wish I can make wedding ceremony here. とってもはずかしいねI can't stop for took a lot of picture there. start from entrance and back way is the best spot. nice forest, torii (gate), jinja (shrine) and everything there is great!!!

Beautiful and peaceful. The grounds of the Meiji Shrine are beautiful and provide a sense of tranquility away from the hustle/bustle and noise of Tokyo. We enjoyed the walk through the park leading to the main shrine. It is worth visiting while in Tokyo.

Ring in the New Year. I visited Meiji Jingu (shrine) on New Years Day. I wasn't around at 7 AM for the 108 bell ceremony but the shrine was still packed around 11 AM with locals going through the hand washing ceremony and tossing yen coins for their New Year's wishes. The shrine area itself is pretty large and, in conjunction with nearby Yoyogi Park, can give you an entire morning's worth of walking/activities.
Peaceful place. Peaceful place,big park and I had the opportunity to see a japonese religous ritual there. There is a nice gift store to buy some tradicional japonese stuffs.

Hatsumode visit: Happy New Year!. It was a beautiful and pristine day at Meiji Jingu. The police were along all walkways keeping the crowds in order and as always it was a serene oasis in the middle of mega city Tokyo.
Quiet in all the Madness. I was surprised at how it reconnects you being so peaceful and serene without the distraction or noise of Tokyo. A lovely attraction that is worthwhile visiting.
Nothing much to see. Not the most interesting shrine (despite visiting in New Year's Day, which meant a lot of crowds). It's not extraordinary in any sense. But the park around it is lovely.

Meiji Shrine where Japanese weddings is popular.. The Meiji Shrine or Jingu is conveniently located within the walking distance of Shibuya Station.
This shrine is also next to Yoyogi Park which is beautiful.
It is also a popular place for Japanese marriages and when I was there in a weekday I have seen to marriages. A must see site when Tokyo.
