Tranquility amongst the chaos. Busy. But tranquil. Went on New Years Eve during the day. Lots of people but well organised and quiet compared to the pumping surrounding streets of Harijuku. Loved seeing the local people dressed up and visiting this important shrine.

Peaceful, serene, and soothing. It was a peaceful walk to the shrine and the experience was a very positive one. If you are looking for intricate architecture or grand buildings, you may not find this here. It is more a tranquil place to visit to get away from the bustle of the busy city

Top Attraction!. It is beautiful here! you walk in and can instantly hear birds tweeting- it's pretty peaceful asides from other visitors! The place is pretty big to wander around and enjoy the atmosphere.You can buy souvenirs, pay respect to the place. There is a lot to see.
Underwhelming. The shrines in Tokyo are underwhelming in comparison to Kyoto's shrines. This one is a beautiful structure but not much to see.

Nicest of all Shrines in Tokyo. I really like the place within the great park. The scenery is great and you can witness weddings there all the time. Nice to see the sophisticated dresses and hair style.

Worth a trip! . This shrine, next to Yoyogi Park is a gem. The walk up takes you away from the city and into a peaceful forest. It can be crowded, but still enjoyable. Once you arrive at the shrine, it's worthwhile to take part in the culture up there. Learning a bit about the Shinto shrine ways is really enriching. If you are lucky, there may be a wedding there where you can see a truly stunning wedding procession.

Cool shrine. I have been here twice, the shrine is nice, and it is a very nice walk in the park to get there. Can walk from Shibuya and then to harajyuku at the other gate, worth a visit when in Tokyo

be sure to visit on a Sunday!. we visited the shrine on a sunday and there were many couples getting married on that day. it was quite an eye-opening experience to witness a japanese wedding ceremony.

Made my day. We were walking near the lake in the grounds surrounding the shrine when we spotted a gentleman surrounded by birds, with some landing on his hands. He had a peanut gripped tightly between thumb and forefinger. He smiled and gave us a peanut so we could try for ourselves ... Magical. Next time I visit I'll take my own peanuts. The shrine and surrounds were interesting. Well maintained grounds... It was amusing to watch the groundskeeper interacting with children who walked by him.All in all a very pleasant break from the hustle and bustle of the city.

A Shrine worth to visit in your Japan trip. You will stroll along all types of shops, restaurants, fast food, shopping centers, spas , famous fashion shops vary from luxury to moderate pricing before you reach Meiji Shrine at the end of the road. After the entrance, you will encounter beautiful decorated barrels of sake piling up, then along the way stalls of various types of bonsai for you to buy bring home.The shrine is simple, but holy as you could feel.Millions of people come to Meiji especially on New Year day to pray for health, love and wealth.
Nice place to visit in between shopping. Located right in the city and and a nice walk in the park before reaching Meiji Jingu. There was a wedding going on too when i visited.
Peaceful Space . Very nice parkland/ gardens in the middle of a busy city. Watch the fish and ducks swim and cross cute little bridges. A nice afternoon walk.

Serene yet surrounded by people!!. We strolled through the pathways and gardens leading into the Meiji Jingu Shrine and I found it quite spectacular to be surrounded by so many people in the area yet the atmosphere was still very serene. A traditional wedding was taking place there with some beautiful children dressed in traditional clothing, As a typical tourist we asked if we could take a pic and the parents were fine with us doing so. I'd take another walk through here, I found it strangely relaxing even with the large amount of people. There is a café nearby which does great food, but make sure you are paying attention to the food ticketing system or your meal may be sitting on the counter going cold.

Lovely place to visit!. I have been to Meiji Jingu and loved the experience! The walk was enjoyable surrounded by the beautiful nature, the shirine was impressive.Being away from the hassle of the city center makes it very peaceful and tranquil to spend time wandering around it. Make sure to write your wish!

One of the Best. A not to be missed Shrine in the land where shrines abound. Meiji Shrine is the Grand Daddy of them all & very well situated in Meiji Jingu Park with easy access via train. Has lots of beautiful gardens to check out as well - beautifully maintained. Don't miss the Sake Barrels for a great photo opportunity.

Lovely, peaceful. Great place to visit. Strongly encourage all visitors of Tokyo to visit the meiji jingu. It's such a beautiful place to take a stroll and to learn more abt the meiji period. Went on a sat afternoon and was lucky to chance upon a wedding procession.

Peaceful and serene. Visted Meiji JIngu Shrine during winter and the walk was pleasantly cool and serene. Loved the peaceful and magical vibes although the pebbled walkways was a little difficult to walk on. Overall, it made for a nice morning walk and the highlight was when we happened to come across a Japanese Wedding Ceremony while we were there as it was a weekend.
Serene Temple . This was a different temple than most I've been to. It sits back in nature in the hustle/ bustle of the city. It was very peaceful and beautiful. Plus- it was decorated for New Years!
Temple . Great temple to visit and you don't have to pay to see. When we were there we saw a Japanese wedding.

A peaceful retreat from the city. Best for a peaceful walk through the native trees. The shrine is not old but reveres one of Japans favourite emperors. Avoid the New Year when 3,000,000 people visit in 3 days.

MeijiJingu Shrine. This temple complex is situated in such pleasant surroundings.. The stroll through the forest to the temple is exhilarating and visually calming. The temple is nestled amongst 170 acres of evergreen forest. This complex also has a private museum housing momentos of the former Emperor and Empress. There is a separate admission to this display as well as to the private park dedicated to the Empress. There isn't any selective dining areas but there is a small covered concession that offers drinks and ice cream. It is an enjoyable way to spend half a day amidst this charming temple.

A must stop on any Tokyo tour. This is a great place to check out and get a good feel for Japanese culture. There is usually a wedding going on, which makes for some great pictures. Also, very close to Harajuku and Omotesando -- so easy to combine with multiple sights.

Nice enough temple, if you're only visiting Tokyo. We'd come here before moving off to Kyoto in our Japanese vacationrounds and temple and while the grounds and temple are nice enough, there was nothing particularly intriguing compared with others we ended up in, and the mass of tourists didn't help either.We did happen on a wedding procession, which is the one nice thing about this temple - it's very much in use.

Beautiful shinto shrine... Walking through the small forest to the shrine you kind of forget that you're in a city with a population of over 30 million. A great trip to get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo city life. Huge toris along the pathway towards the shrine, and the shrine itself is very beautiful..

Love park and shrine. This was one of the first places we visited after arriving in Tokyo. It was nice a peaceful, despite being in the middle of a busy neighbourhood. Easy to access by train and certainly worth a visit.

Calm and Peaceful walk. The Meiji Shrine was built to honor the Emperor Meiji and his Empress. Around the Shinto Shrine was planted 170 acres of evergreen forest. The Shrine complex is nice to visit and take pictures, we saw two weddings being prepared for at the shrine, but the best part is a most beautiful setting for a relaxing, tranquil walk through the forest. The walkways are wide and paved and easy to get around. The serene nature setting is almost spiritual and gives you a calm and restful feeling. You can see the shrine in half an hour or spend more than two hours walking all around the forest.

Nature in the city. Right next to Yoyogi park, definitely go to both. I went here and found it to be serene and cool. A canopy of trees lines the path. Very big cool looking space in the middle of a busy city. Food isn't really near by so bring a snack or eat before you go. Since it is about a half hour to get through it then there's really no food nearby until you get back to the train station.

Calm and serene. Meiji Shrine is very near the Harajuku JR stop. The park is huge and beautiful. We didnt even made it to the actual shrine as it was quite far to walk with an active and unpredictable 2.5 yo toddler :) However, we did enjoy the stroll from the entrance to the souvenir shop. We used the pebbles stone way which is really really not stroller friendly (but with nicer view) however, you can use the tarred road besides (on the left) the entrance which will connect you to the souvenir shop.
Stunning. Featured in Lost in Translation. Unique for its forested setting very near central Tokyo. Majestic, and less crowded than other sights in the city.

Solemn & Simple. It is a wide, tranquil piece of nature with the solemn religious fervor. Doesn't offer anything extravagant...can visit only if you love nature and have plenty of time in Tokyo to explore around.

Stroll down Meiji Jingu. Nice walk. Do eat something near the train/ Harajuku before you walk over and spend about 40 minutes strolling, taking pictures at this place. Limited wash rooms, so, go when you see one. I didn't pay to go into the garden as I felt that I had enough of walking Something to note, it is considered impolite to hold a drink and walk around. I saw some people dragging their suitcase/trolley bag on the gravelled walkway.Must have been difficult and uncomfortable. Better to leave it at lockers, probably there would be some at the train station.

A pleasant stroll, and a lovely walk to kiyosama's well. Meiji Shrine offers a lovely respite from the crowds and urban landscape of Shibuya. We veered off the main route to check out kiyomasa's well. The well itself was unexpectedly small, and u have to queue to see it, and after a few minutes, u are ushered to make way for the next curious traveller. We were unfortunately not very impressed. What did catch our breath was the picturesque park where the well is situated within, with tranquil lakes, friendly birds, and a lovely trail-walk (to kiyosama's well). Take the €500 admission fee as a fee to view the beautiful park, just like visiting the Okochi Sanso Villa in Kyoto.

A shrine near to Harajuku!. This is a shrine dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji and his consort, Empress Shoken. I had a great time walking here. The air was very refreshing. There were a couple getting married there on the day I went.
My favourite shrine in Tokyo. The environment at Meiji Jingu Shrine is awesome. There are many beautiful trees along the path to the main shrine.

Ok attraction. Its an okay temple. If you dont have much time then dont visit it. Long but nice walk through the forest to get to the temple. Is not impresive as other tokyo's landmarks.The highlight was that we saw a wedsing cereomony.Tip: go un sundays to see weddings
Huge and silent. Although it has lots of visitors during the year, it's always relaxing with the nature surrounded and special, religious place

Great shrine surrounded by an awesome park!. I'm not usually a huge shrine person, but this was really special and worth the visit. It's a peaceful place to get away from the crazy hustle and bustle of Toyko! We met an English Club here, and they guided us around and practiced / chatted with us in English. Also saw a wedding taking place, which was wonderful to see. We also bought fortunes at the Shrine which I still have on my fridge!

Excellent Experience. It is well worth going, a lot of walking but it will give you an insight of Japanese history. You have to walk through the whole thing. Also there is an temple area where you can buy a wooden panel to write your wishes. Great experience!

Wonderfully peaceful in the heart of the city. While the path from the main road to the heart of the shrine worried us with the number of tourists walking, the setting is so forest-like.....almost zen, that we stopped noticing others. Buildings set so beautifully in the pine forest.

The Meiji-jingu in Tokyo. The Meiji-jingu in Tokyo is a very impressive and beautiful place you should visit. The entire area is very easily accessible from the nearby station of JR Yamanote Line. Also for wheelchair users is this impressive shrine well passable. It is advisable to visit the Meiji-jingu in the early morning. However, one should always expect that many school groups visit the Meiji-jingu at the same time. Every visitor of Japan, who has never visited a Shinto shrine should select the Meiji-jingu as the first place to become familiar with the subject matter of Shintoism.

Nice enough, but not special if crowded. This shrine is large and the path approaching it fairly long and uninspiring to be honest.The Shrine itself is a nice complex where you may be able to catch a traditional wedding. However, every time I visited it (3 times including once in 2013) was quite crowded, so much so that taking a decent picture or enjoying what should be a peaceful place, is practically impossible.I would still visit, but without having major expectations.

Traditional & Peaceful. We were there on a Sunday morning and the cool weather made the long walk in pleasant. Ladies, please do not wear heels because the path leading to the shrine is covered entirely in gravel and you will have a very hard time walking if you are wearing heels. When we were there, we were lucky enough to witness a traditional Shinto wedding and it was so solemnly beautiful. We also saw a number of locals dressed in kimono and paying their respects at the shrine.

Nice stroll in the middle of a megalopolis. You definitely must visit here to give yourself some relaxation and respite from all that shopping and eating. Lush vegetation and the religious buildings are to the back.

Serene shrine to escape the city. Nice shaded stroll from the Yoyogi train station towards to the shrine. Good escape from the skyscrapers of Shinjuku to just relax and enjoy nature here or at Yoyogi park next to Meiji Jingu. It had multiple entrances and while we were there we were lucky to experience a Japanese wedding in the compound. There were also o-mikuji (fortune slips) available to be purchased to be tied to the wire or kept for luck if its a good one.

Simply Beautiful. A view from an 11 year old, hmmmmmmm let's seeThe Meji Jingu shrine was beautiful. There were amazing maples and gorgeous plants. You could wash your hands traditionally and it was a very relaxing experience. The main museum was closed so I went to the smaller one. I was a bit disappointed because it was only a room filled with artefacts (there is an entry fee for the museum). But don't get me wrong it was very interesting but I don't think it is as good as the bigger museum would be.The visit was very relaxing and fun but I wouldn't spent more than 30 minutes there. But I think that everyone should experience and see this shrine even if it's for 5 minutes.The shrine is a small walk from the train station. I would suggest using a map or asking someone about how to get there in terms of different train lines and some directions.
Nice. Surprisingly charming, was there after a picnic at Yoyogi Park. After visiting, you can head to Takeshita Street and then shopping. Could be a whole day itinerary!

Ok for a quick visit. We went for a quick visit for this huge green forested Shrine. The over one hundred year trees (forest), racks of Sake along the entrance, ancient and huge timber gates were among highlights. The inside and main ceremony hall look similar to shrines comonly found in Korean. It's an ideal place for a quick walk around and would not feel too terrible to give it a miss if constraint with time. Though there are several nice restaurants inside the Shrine and nearby areas. We had lunch at a restaurant inside the Shrine. It was nice.This place is located steps away from Harajuku subway station and the popular teen Takeshita Dori shopping street, so plan your trip accordingly.

Japanese wedding!. Stumbled upon a Japanese wedding procession here which was cool to watch. Lovely Forrest-like surrounds. Hint, wear sneakers or flat boots. I wore heeled boots and it was less than ideal on the gravel paths everywhere.

Beautiful!. You can't believe that such a peaceful park exists right in the heart of Tokyo and yet it does! A beautiful walk through the woods and park is perfect in fall, and the temple is so peaceful as well. Don't miss it!

Why would you not visit this?. I visited on 1st November and was privileged to see some of the annual celebrations/rituals that go on here. Very solemn and very undescribably Japanese - and literally right beside Harajuku!
This period is approaching Shichi-Go-San as well so you'll spot some families in traditional wear.
Don't miss it.

tranquility in the city. lovely and quiet place in the heart of the city. so much history all around the temple. the fact that it sits in the center of a small forest, makes it more peaceful. when you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of harajuku and omotesando, definitely stop by and take a nice stroll around the temple.
Meiji Jingu. Loved the serene and cooling walk into Meiji Jingu! Surrounded by green trees. The walkway were paved with small stones. Recommend to wear track shoes and not slippers.

Lovely park, beautiful shrine. This is short walk from the subway. The gardens and park are beautiful to walk around, and the shrine was one of the nicest one in Tokyo. It's also quite close to some shopping, if you feel like doing that after your stroll.

Tranquil in the middle of Tokyo. I have visited the shrine before and as before to me it is a must visit in Tokyo. Once you are inside the park confines you have no idea you are in the middle of Tokyo. Enjoy the peace and quiet and the beautiful architecture of the shrine.
Beautiful shrine. The traditional building and the beauty of inner garden will amaze you, you can get into the inner garden by paying 500 yen. They also sell charm at the shrine

Serenity. It is had to believe that in a city this size that it is possible to find such a place of tranquility. Only minutes from the train station, you enter the forest that leads to the shrine. The Japanese maples were magnificent when we visited. In the lead up to the shrine there were barrels of sake donated by the Japanese sake Brewers and wine from all over the world. The main museum was closed when we visited and the annexe only contained one room of artefacts which while interesting, probably was t worth the entry fee.The shrune itself was very well maintained but could be seen in 15 minutes.

A peaceful break. Passing under one of largest Tori gates in Japan, a long walk takes you down to the shrine. Often you will see weddings taking place in the shrine as this is a very popular venue for traditional ceremonies. The peaceful of the park and shrine make a nice contrast to the Harajuku neighborhood which is just outside the gate. There are often colourfully clothed youths and street performers outside by the historic station.

Only got to see at night. Beautiful even at night time. The yellow leaves must surely look breathtaking in the morning.
The best time to visit the park for the autumn leaves would be from mid-November when the colors would have peaked. We were a week late. But still!
There isa newly opened Shake Shack- a New York import with lines up to 100 meters long!

A Walk in the Woods. The shrine is a nice patch of green in a concrete jungle. Great for an afternoon stroll. The adjoining woods and parkland are fairly large, but maps with English as well as Japanese will help you find the way.
A nice walk, and interesting!. Very picturesque and beautiful walk to the shrine, definitely worth a visit to see another side of Tokyo

Learn the tradition when visiting Meiji Jingu. Please note to enter from side door of the gate , not from the centre . Japanese believed only spirit walk through the centre.Japanese practice is to bow a little while walking through the gPlease prepare 5 yen if you want to make awish . So you walk to the front of temple, clap a couple of times, bow a couple of times, pray a wish for yourself only . Thentoss the 5 yen into the container .If you find this review helpful, please vote for me!

A must in Tokyo. This is a temple that you must visit in Tokyo. The gardens to get from the city to the temple are great, kind of a Central Park, just a 10 minutes walk from an extremely busy commercial district into the peaceful woods, to get to the Meiji Temple. It is worth the visit.
Must Visit. A must see in Japan. The actually Meiji Shrine is amazing. The walk to the shrine itself is very enjoyable as well. A tourist destination but never overly busy.

Pales in comparison to many of the other shrines around, but some nice scenery. This one's a bit busy too. It was a it underwhelming when we finally reached the shrine itself - the walk leading up to it and the small gardens next to it were much nicer. If in Tokyo I'd recommend Senso-ji instead.

A good morning spent. Being in Harajuku it was a definite stop for us. You walk along tall trees until you reach the shrine. The shrine itself is like a complex and we were lucky enough that the day we went a traditional wedding was occurring, which proved to be great for photos. After this we went to have lunch in the many options you have in harajuku. Make it part of your itinerary, but expect a few crowds. Halfway theres a souvenir centre, a restaurant and a kind of food court - though we found prices to be very expensive for the souvenirs, its also a good place to consider for lunch or quick snack.
Just relax at This park us. Especially when You have enough of shopping, busy Trainstations And All that norse, go to This park! During autumn it'ts very beautiful!

Excellent Visit. We loved this Shrine located in the forests. The walk to get there was about 15 minutes from the metro stop and it was great. This Shrine is also a bit different from the rest in Japan (red and black) as it is in wood and unpainted. We also found the opportunity to take some pictures with Japanese Ladies wearing the traditional Kimono suits. Overall a great experience. Would definitely recommend.

Peaceful escape in Tokyo. The Meiji shrine and the surround parklands is the perfect escape from all the noise and flashing lights of the rest of Tokyo. The trees seem to block all the noise out which makes the whole experience of walking through the grounds and the Shrine even more magical. We saw a traditional wedding procession, a display featuring gorgeous chrysanthemum flowers, and came across a special festival for young children who were dressed in beautiful kimono. Whenever you come here there will always be something special to see!

A sea of peace in a bustling mega-city. I've been here many times, I always try to visit the park when I'm in Tokyo. Weather was perfect this sunny cold winter day. Quiet and wonderful to wander the trails and enjoy the peace and birds.

Amazing History, Silence in Tokyo. The Good: peace, quite, green, history, freeThe Bad: can be crowdedThis is a major historical shrine in downtown Tokyo. It's hard to believe that such a verdant and peaceful place can be located in the middle of a huge city. The age and the integration with nature are amazing. During my visit there were thousands of people passing through with almost no noise. WonderfulThe Road Word: travel a thousand miles for this world heritage site.

Don't plan on going to the other park. I was thinking I was clever trying to go to three top ranked things on tripadvisor in one fell swoop, ack: I foolish I was. NHK Studio Park is for children, Yoyogi park is for... I don't know, people who want to have a hard time going to Meiji Jingu? You'll have to walk 5000m from the park to get to the shrine as they're fenced off.The temple itself is beautiful but too much like the other temples in Tokyo, go to the one in Akihabara for something different instead.

Beautiful scenery. The scenery!! Its such a beautiful ppace right in the middle of one of the worlds largest cities. Its calm and quiet, a very nice escape from the city. Definitely go and take an hour to wander the grounds and find your own inner peace.

Most amazing walk into a giant forest to the temple. Our day was simply amazing. As we entered the forest under the huge gate the forest was absolutely enchanting. It's not a short walk but so worth the journey. The temple is very large. We had the delight of being there during the celebration of 3-5-7 year old children who were dressed in kimonos, often along with their mothers. It added to the enchantment for sure but it would have been a fabulous day anyway. So peaceful and the trees are magnificent.

The weddings were fantastic!. This is a must-see destination for Tokyo. We went on a Saturday afternoon and within one hour were privileged to view 4 different weddings. If you want to see more traditional aspects of Japanese culture and a traditional wedding blessing then this is the place to go. Best access if travelling by train is via Harajuku station (JR Line) or else a few minutes walk from Meiji-Jingumae (Subway). If going via Harajuku station, look out for Takeshita Street. While in the area, don't forget to wander around the Omote Sando area (shopping district).

An absolute treasure. You'd have no idea that this place is located steps away from the busy Harajuku station once you're inside. A stunning variety of thoughtfully-arranged plants and trees leads you down a secluded, tranquil pathway to the shrine itself. There's guide brochures and maps in tons of languages and it is a wonderful escape from the bustle of Tokyo. Bring a little cash and you can donate to the temple and receive omamori or write a wish on a votive tablet - both very nice mementos of your trip.

Peaceful in the town. There are very nice walk path to the shrine. You can enjoy all the giant trees in their places before the shrine. Quite and peaceful. The Shrine are nice and well management. You may see the newly couple on their wedding ceremony in Japanese style here or even for their photographs. Bow and make a wish...

Peaceful. I love going to this shrine and just walking around. It's so peaceful and beautiful. The environment of this place is a great change and moment of peace in the center of Tokyo chaos. I would say this is a must see, and a place to go back to.

A must visit!. Visited the shrine and I was awed by the serenity and beautiful surroundings. A 15 minute stroll into the shrine from Harajuku Station, we chanced upon a japanese wedding. We did some prayers and bought some lucky charms which were inticately made. A must visit if you ever go Tokyo!

Serene.... Beautiful and relaxing to walk through. Halfway through there is a restaurant (dine in on one side and fasr food on the other) in addition to restrooms. Take time to enjoy the tea garden and shrine area, there is such serenity.

Meiji Jingu. The Meiji Shrine is the best shrine i visited in tokyo.located in the middle of amazing park.the shrine is amazing- great Design and architecture,when you will enter the shrine you will need to wash your hands.there is a tree that you can put your wish on, and there is also fortune game that you draw stick with a number and then you get a short Haiku about you. on Saturday if you are lucky enough you can see some weddings...

The long walk was worth it!. The arc by entrance is majestic. It is tall and looks really ancient. I was in awe right then and there. It was a really long walk to get to the inner temple so a lot at least 2-3 hrs for this tour. I say it is worth a visit. I get to see old japanese structures, the tall trees are probably really old too and if you're lucky, a japanese wedding.

My favourite shrine in Tokyo. If you only have time to visit one shrine, let it be this! The shrine is easily accessible using city trains and just a stone's throw away from the busy street of Shibuya. One minute you're in the city, and the next you're surrounded by thousands of trees. Albeit the numerous guests, the place maintains its serenity. Do not forget to get a lucky charm as a souvenir!

Japan tradition and culture in one place. We went here to see the Meiji Shrine. It was a cold day! We saw several weddings on a saturday. Very strict no food and drinks inside. Wear comfortable shoes in Tokyo because one will do a lot of walking!
Relaxing. Meji Jingu is a nice place to relax and take a break from shopping and the city side of Tokyo. You will find the walk through the forest to be extremely peaceful.

Worth a visit.... When I was there, we came across lots of little boys and girls aged around 7,5 or 3yrs dressed in their Japanese attires for a ceremony when they come of age. They need to visit a shrine to thank the gods for the healthy passage to middle childhood..etc I too came across 4 traditional weddings....now its a photographer's dream to capture a traditional wedding...*wink ;) please be considerate and not disrupt their special day and be discreet. Be prepared to do a little walking to get to the Shrine. Put on your walking shoes and soak it all in. You are on a holiday ...let go and live.

Memorable. One of our main aims to visit Tokyo was to visit this Shrine. We took the Omotesando exit of Harajuku Station. Upon exiting, just turn right. Don't cross the road. Keep walking round the building, you'll reach an open space. Continue on straight. Take the crossroad and you'll see the imposing first Torii gate not far away.There're three Torii gates altgether with some distance in between. It's also most interesting to see the historical barrels of sake. Many prayer cards could be seen hanging from a fence circling a huge tree near the Shrine. The Sanctuary was guarded.It took us about half an hour going round the whole area.This is surely a must-visit for anyone travelling to Tokyo.

Great shrine to visit. The Meiji Shrine is one of the largest in Tokyo and included in most city tours. You will do a bit of walking. Prior to entering the shrine, you will come across wine and sake offerings and like all shrines, a washing well is just outside the shrine to wash your mouth and hands. Photography is restricted in some parts of the shrine and should be respected. For me, it is terrible to see some travelers disrespect the traditions and rules for visiting. For a fee, you can write down your prayer or wish on a tablet and have it blessed and hung at the shrine. There are quite a few gift shops and some that have nothing to do with the shrine but want to take advantage of the foot traffic.

Even in the rain it was beautiful. Maybe the rain and the fog added to the ambiance of this beautiful shrine. I visited in November and it was a rainy day but I had my umbrella. The shrine and surrounding forest was beautiful. At the main shrine complex there were 2 large trees to the left of the shrine and one large tree to the right of the shrine. It was explained to us that the 2 trees on the left were for couples' wishes and the single tree on the right was for individual wishes. We witnessed a Japanese wedding procession leaving the shrine when we arrived and it was very beautiful to see.

Beautiful scenery . Meiji jingle is a beautiful shire the entrance is amazing walking in between a forest is quite the experience it feel so peaceful Expect lots of people very busy if you are lucky you could see a traditional weeding taking place make sure you go to the Edo Tokyo museum before so you understand a little of Japanese history and culture

Amazing. This was the first of many shrines that we visited during our tour of Japan and one not to be missed. This very large park in the the middle of a busy area is located within easy walking distance of Harajuku subway station. One could easily spend a half day enjoying the park and shrine but we limited ourselves to the shrine area and the path where barrels of wines from Bordeaux and barrels of sake from all over Japan were stacked as offerings to the emperor Meigi. We were also fortunate to watch a Shinto wedding party march into the shrine. After two hours we moved on to our next adventure

Nice to see. Lovely to see the little children dressed in kimonos. Also happened to see a wedding! The actual shrine was nice to see but compared to some other more luxurious temples it was not something one has to see.

Nice Shrine - break from shopping. Nice shrine. You have to wash up at the designated area before entering (there are instructions on how to do it). Free entry. You can pray and makes wishes inside. Nice break from shopping. Walkable from Harajuku station.

Beautiful. Just a wonderful place to visit. More quiet than the other shrines the tranquility and surroundings are too beautiful. I have been here many times and I recommend during autumn and winter for some beautiful scenes and photo opportunities. There is a high chance of seeing someone get married too.

Tranquillity in a busy city. We spent a morning visiting Meiji Jingu which has been a favorite haunt for us over the years. We were lucky enough to see a wedding underway at the shrine. We also visited the garden which is well worth the modest fee. Finally we had a pleasant and tasty lunch at the restaurant for a reasonable price. A good place to visit if you have half a day to spare. In the spring look out for the irises in bloom.

Loved the peacefulness of the place. My husband and I were staying at Shinjuku and we decided to take a walk from Shinjuku to the Meiji Jingu via the Yoyogi entrance. It was a doable walk. As it was the day before the Autumn festival, we could see the rows upon rows of sake, wine barrels and gifts from around the country in the vicinity of the shrine. We also went into a park within the park (500 yen). I think its called the Meiji Jingu Gyoen to see the tea house (Kakuun Tei) and little pond. There was an old man there photographing the birds and he had seeds for them. The birds will even follow him around. He gave some of the seeds to a western tourist and the birds just flew on to her palm. It's peaceful and calm. As it was late autumn, the flowers were no longer blooming but we still walked the trail to what was an old well (Kiyomasa Ido). It is a very beautiful place for nature with what looked like lovely old trees. And its interesting for me to find out 100,000 trees were actually donated by the people of Japan after the war.We came out at the Harajuku exit into the hustle and bustle of the city.

Greenery Place Not To Be Missed. Is better to go there early morning, easily accessed from Harajuku Station. It was quite amazed n relaxed to walk through rows of greenery trees along the road. On that day, we even had the opportunity to witness the wedding ceremony for a Japanese couple with their cultural gown!

Go on a Sunday. The park is huge and is like Central Park in New York, a peaceful, green sanctuary amidst the busy city that Tokyo is. Steps from the busy and quirky area Harajuku, walking inside you will eventually discover what Tokyo is all about, a nice blend of old and new, modern and traditional. I read from my guidebook to go on a Sunday to witness wedding parades in the main temple and so I did. It was one wedding march after another and I truly loved what I witnessed. There is an option to go inside the Inner park, if you love flowers (irises), japanese gardens, then the small fee is well worth it.

Beautiful place. When you walk in, the trees surrounding the walking path was just amazing. Feels like you are in the forest away from the hustle bustle of harajuku. When we were there, there was a few wedding ceremony which was great experience for us to watch. This place is huge and you could spend hours easily just by walking around. The atmosphere here is really calm and relaxing. Definitely recommend it!

Big park with traditional Japanese Shrine. Meiji Jingu offers a relaxing stroll through a big forest like park with museums, a lake with ducks and koi and the big shrine in its center. U can observe traditional ceremonies and weddings here.

Japanese produce. Vegetables and flowers exhibit. Wow, Wow, Wow. Just wonder how can Japanese farmers grow their produce this way. When you look at them, the freshness and cleanliness of them all is unbelievable. Washing them before cooking is like an option. Amazing! The way they handle the veggies is like handling a fine china. So fragile. Japanese people really take care of everything with love and care.

Beautiful retreat away from the craziness of Harajuku. Great place if you need to retreat to some nature. Only a short walk from Harajuku station. The parks, lakes, temples & scenery are all beautiful, with amazing photo opportunities. As it's a major tourist attraction, multiple signs in English & information booths. Walking paths lead to Aoyama, Yoyogi ect giving you a reason to explore these areas.1 point is deducted due to not being able to take photos in the main Temple, & if you want to explore some of the parks & gardens off the main path a ¥500 ($5) maintenance fee is required for each attraction. Adds up if you want to explore all Meiji Jingu hasto offer.Still i would highly recommend visiting Meiji Jingu.
Green in Tokyo. A lovely area, worth the extra 500 yen to visit the small internal garden. The main shrine though was disappointing to me - it felt like a crowded function venue.

A quiet place to relax yourself. The palace is located in the center of the city, but when you walk in the tree-surrounded path, you will feel quiet and relaxed, it's like the last minute you are still in the crowds in the Harajuku, and the next minute you will feel like in a forest.Just go to the end of the palace, you will see many Japanese are worshiping, in a solemn manner, you can also join by following their instructions.I went there in a early morning, when the air is still fresh, you will also feel the freshness.I don't recommend those who having tight travel schedules to come here, but for those who can spend a few minutes or 1 hour here, really indulge yourself into the nature, into the Japanese culture, it will be another experience which will let you forget you are in such a busy city like Tokyo.

Beautiful . The walk alone was very relaxing, surrounded by wonderful greenery. It was busy, but not crowded, and it was so sweet seeing all of the families dressed up formally. There was a wedding ceremony happening, which was lovely to see. It was very calm and atmospheric, it's definitely a must-see.

Popular shrine visited by hundreds of people on a holiday weekend. Our visit on the Sunday of the local Thanksgiving long weekend on November 22 found the shrine packed with family groups on celebrations. In November families bring their children to a shrine to pray for the health of the child. This occurs when children are 3, 5, 7 and other times. This month we saw many three year olds dressed in traditional dress, both boys and girls. There was also a wedding in the afternoon.The shrine had every alcove filled with displays of harvest products for the Thanksgiving on Monday November 23.All the locals were there dressed in their finest clothes. Quite a wonderful view of traditional Japanese family life

Large Shrine in park-like setting. This is a large Shinto shrine where the ashes of Emperor Meiji and his empress are enshrined. The shrine has treasure museums and surrounding gardens. I visited it by walking from the Shibuya crossing to Harujuku, and after the shrine I went to the Sword Museum.

Nice getaway from the bustle and warmth. Nice getaway from the bustle and hustle of Tokyo, here is nice and calm. The trees is help also keep the heat away at warm days. I really recommend you to go here.

Worth a visit. This shrine is located in Yoyogi park so you get two attractions at the same time. Lovely walk to the shrine on path thro the high trees. Very busy. Lots of locals visit here too at weekends.

urban x tradition. You can literally have you're crepe and eat it too! Literally just around the corner from Harajuku station. It's a little bit of a walk from the first Torii to the main shrine but the walk is nice and there is a bridge that you can stop and take a photo. Make sure you have a few coins so you can cast them into the shrine and make a wish!

Traditional culture in a concrete city . It's a little bit of a walk from the nearest station (harajuku station from what I recall on the Yamanote line). The walk is pleasant as its like a forest which is such a contrast to the rest of Tokyo where there's just man made buildings everywhere without many aspects of nature. The architecture is great, there isn't too much to do other than admire this. However I think it's an important destination as temples and shrines are a huge part of Japanese culture.We spent around 30 minutes there, it was free so can't really complain. It's worth going but you don't need to plan to spend too much time there.
Unmissable. a grand shrine in beautiful grounds. excellent from the high torii gate by Harajuku, to the main shrine and the gorgeous landscape gardens.

One of the Most Well-known in Tokyo. A shrine to commemorate Emperor Meiji. The Shrine is within walking distance from Harajuku JR train station. While the shrine itself is not big, its gardens are huge. Also not far from this shrine is Yoyogi Park and Takeshita Dori Shopping Street.

Beautiful. I visited this shrine through the jr yamanote line. Eventhough i had to walk a bit, i didnt regret it at all. Theres a wooden area leading towards the shrine. It had the calming effect and it built up the peaceful mood before entering the shrine. I managed to witness a Japamese wedding ceremony ans it was so beautiful. Also saw several children dressed in kimono to pray.
Serenity. The air was nice & cool, the walk through this beautiful garden makes you wish you could go back in time to see the life then.

pretty. This was a really pretty shrine and pretty big. There were some kind of wedding blessings going on while we were there which was cool. The park that you walk through to get to the shrine is stunning.

Fascinating shrine. Meiji jingu is really easy to be found, near Harajuku station. It is located in the middle of the forrest, and the complex is quite big. You can see a lot of people wear kimono here, and make a wish.

Another wonderful pilgrimage. Every time I come to Tokyo I visit this shrine. It is exceptionally beautiful set in wooded grounds. Went to the garden for the first time and worth a look. A must for any visit.

Tradition in the heart of Tokyo. The shrine to the Emperor meiji and his consort takes you right back to the nineteenth century, when the Emperor tried to modernise Japan. You can see barrels of Sake opposite barrels of Burgundy, but even better you can see children in particular in traditional costume - An absolute must to visit.

Peaceful spot amidst a bustling city.. Meiji Jingu is a very peaceful space, which is surprising because it is close to a few large roads and crowds of people shopping in Harajuku. Going during the new year is not for the faint-hearted. The masses of people waiting to pray are unbelievable. Outside of that, it's usually pretty bearable.You only need an hour or so to stroll around or have a drink at the cafe inside.

Peaceful. A nice walk through woodlands leads you to the shrine, passing some brightly painted sake barrels on the way. Not the most impressive shrine that I’ve ever seen, but you can almost touch the serenity.An oasis of calm and tranquillity in the heart of the city.

Must visit shrine in Tokyo. Happened to be there on November 15th, the day families bring their 3, 5 and 7 year olds dressed in traditional clothing for a blessing. So, it was crowded, but lively, and lots of observe. The grounds are lovely, and I went back the next day for a quieter walk in the gardens.

Peacefull but lots of walking and no benches to rest.. Come out of the train/metro area and turn right.Walk up the hill and cross the bridge to the right. Cross into the park and you will see the large Tori Gate. This is the first one. It is quite a long walk into the shrine and on fine gravel. Built for the Emperor & Empress. Nice gardens. You have to pay if you wish to go into the Inner Garden and also the Treasure House.

Do not miss this - beautiful grounds and worth the visit!. This is a beautiful shrine to visit, especially if you only have a short time in Tokyo. You will get the full experience and walking the entire grounds of the surrounding park is very calming. It is also near other fun sights in Tokyo including the Harijuku district so can check multiple things off the list relatively easily.

Lovely setting. This magnificent 20th century Shinto shrine is set in the midst of a man made forest in the middle of Tokyo.It is an interesting shrine and the forest area is serene and beautiful and a welcome break from the bustle of the city. We were lucky enough to witness a wedding there in traditional dress.(Amusingly there is also an area for bringing your car to be blessed!)

TRADITIONAL JAPAN WITH GARDENS AND SHRINE. Arriving with a tour group, does not give you a lot of time to explore this beautiful place built in the Meiji Dynasty. You could get here by train just a short walk from Harajuku Station. The good think about being in a tour group you do have the history explained to you. We were fortunate to witness two Weddings whilst we were there. Also the Chrysthamthiums were on display as well. A place you should visit whilst in Tokyo.
A lovely walk to a lovely shrine. This is a great shrine nestled inside a shaded walkway. There isn't soo much to say about it, its not a theme park. Expect many tourists and selfie sticks ;)

Impressive area and shrine. A short walk away from the Harajuku Station, Meiji Jingu has a small entrance fee and it was one of the more interesting shrines we visited. The forest/park area is also worth a walk.

"Central Park" in Tokyo!. Amidst the bustling, busy Tokyo, Meiji Jingu provides a place of solace, with beautiful greenery, and huts to sit and enjoy. The pebble-stone path lead from the entrance to the shrine. It's a solemn place so unlike NY's Central Park where you can jog/cycle in the park, at Meiji Jingu, its' primary walking and strolling to enjoy this wonderful place.

Peaceful and beautiful. Get away from the busy Tokyo pace and visit this serene shrine right in the middle of a beautiful park, right in the middle of town. Don't miss Harajuku fashion right across the road.

Magic and serenity in the middle of Tokyo. The Meiji Jingu Inner Garden is not to be missed by those who love the beauty and tranquility, as well as the mastery of Japanese Gardens. I walked for hours in the rain here and felt the great fortune of seeing a feast of gorgeous plants, a valley of irises, a seriously big spider with outrageously long legs, and at the end of the walk, the magic well of Kiyomasa. Go and get yourself zapped with its lucky energy. There was a traditional Japanese wedding taking place at the shrine and prayer cards are available to all.

For Emperor Meiji!!!. This shrine honoured the Great Emperor Meiji as well as the true proper way into the Japanese ritual.Go early to avoid the crowd. Be advised as the shrine closed as early as 4PM...

The Jewel of the Meiji Dynasty. Take your time visiting this place, stroll along the woodland paths to the Shinto shrine complex, dedicated to the indigenous religion of the island. The Meiji emperor built this amazing place, clinging onto the last embers of the Shinto religion while still embracing the new world of the west. Conversely, the west, so fascinated by Japan's brilliant beauty could not help but disturb the flower, toppling the entire feudal order that held the Shinto, the Samurai, and the Emperor so delicately in balance. The place is largely self-explanatory, and you will want to spend a morning or afternoon here to really absorb a sense of the cultural heritage of this ancient country. I happened upon a wedding ceremony and procession on the shrine grounds, a testimony that a Shinto spirit still has its place in this culture. Walking shoes recommended. A cafe and excellent restroom facilities in the visitor center in case you need to refresh yourself before or after visiting the shrine.

Quite pleasant. Pleasant place, though I wouldn't recommend it if you only have a few days in Tokyo. It's quite plain and really only for ritual use. The park is the best part, though don't bother paying for the gardens. It's full of iris beds only good in spring.

A serene treasure in the middle of crowded Tokyo. The moment you step into Meiji Jingu's gigantic gate you'll forget that you are in the middle of a crowded face paced city which population is more than 13 million. Meiji-jingu is an escape for those who wants a serenity without having to travel too far from Tokyo. It's a lot less busy with tourists than any other shrines in Tokyo. It is truly one of the proof that Japan always stay true to its past as much as its future.

A beautiful sight to behold in Tokyo. I feel this is a must-see while in Tokyo. The walk through the peaceful forest on the way to the shrine is worth it alone. It is tranquil, beautifully maintained, and just a lovely place for a stroll but right near Harajuku station. Come on a weekend and you are likely to witness a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony and see many women and children in kimono. I went twice during a recent trip to Japan and absolutely loved this shrine.

Greenery was refreshing but 1 visit is enuf. Was at Meiji Shrine on 13.11.2015 with temp of 11 deg C, so walk was cool and without sweating. Many visitors in this grand & green garden, but an hour is sufficient for walk plus shots, before u get bored and sleepy...

relaxing walk. From Harajuku Station, we followed the signs at the station to know the right exit to take. It did not take us long to find the iconic entrance gate of the shrine! However, the temple and shrine itself is still a 15-20 minutes walk from the entrance gate but since the weather was cool we didn't mind walking.The Meiji Shrine is more relaxing compared to the Sensoji Temple as there were lesser crowds and lesser noise as it was surrounded by the tranquility of trees. I personally prefer the atmosphere here, I liked the traditional vibe it gave off.

Incredible Peace in the Middle of Tokyo. The Meiji Jingu is absolutely beautiful and after you step onto the grounds, you will quickly forget that you are in the middle of Tokyo. There are some suggested donation amounts for some of the buildings. Also, some of the buildings close without notice so don't be surprised if you go and some parts are closed.

Quiet in the middle of Tokyo. Firstly the shrine is easily accessible by Harajuku Station on the Yamanote line run by JR so all the JR pass holders it is included.The grounds are large and expansive giving the impression that you are in forest instead of a big city, however once you get to the shrine itself you will realise that the shrine itself is not that big and you can easily appreciate it in a single hour.The Japanese were not people for over the top glamour and extravagance and this is easily noticeable. Mainly all Japanese shrines and places like these are restrained and humble in their beauty and tend to use a lot of wood in construction. It is still an active religious place and if you are lucky you may see traditional Japanese weddings as well as religious ceremonies taking place.There are food stalls, restaurants and souvenir shops nearby.

Lovely Natural Oasis in Downtown Tokyo. If the crowds and frenetic pace of Tokyo is wearing thin, enjoy a nice walk in this park located in the Shibuya area. Part arboretum, part gardens, part shrine, it is a great place to spend an hour of free time. The trees are spectacular, with representatives specimens from all over Asis. The shrine itself is interesting since it was constructed rather recently (in the last 100 years) so it is well preserved. The gardens are very nice also.
Breathtaking experience. We entered the park just as a rainstorm was ending and steam was quietly rising from the forest. This incredible sanctuary is a must see on your list.

A place of tranquility in the middle of busy metropolis. The park is perfect for taking a break from the bustling life of Tokyo and for enjoying some calm and tranquility (provided you go there before crowds of tourists flood the place). The path will lead you to one of the most beautiful shrines in Tokyo where you may rest your feet, pray for your luck, buy some charms.Well worth a visit if you have time to spare.

Pretty, free, closes early. I had a long layover in Tokyo so rushed out of the airport to see this first. Good thing because they stop letting people in at 4pm! I just barely made it. Beautiful park, interesting shrine, but go early so you have time to enjoy it.

Not impressive. After a week in Japan you start to loose track of all the temples and shrines. Although this has a recent history and a very nice park around it, it is not remarkable. Actually it is the least impressive I have seen in the last week. The nice stroll through the park might make it worthwhile, but only if you are already in the area.

This is where I get married !!!. At Meiji shrine, from May-July, Sep-Nov r Japanese marriage season, and every 20mins, there'd be Japanese style wedding is held there, so if u miss one, if u wait 10-20mins, another couples and families comes and u can watch Japanese traditional Kimono style with big red bamboo umbrella wedding is going on!!!
Meiji Temple/Yoyogi Park. Relaxing and some interactive elements. Try to go on a Sunday afternoon and go to Harajuku street across the way to make it a full day including food and shopping
Beautiful shrine and park grounds. go early to avoid crowds. Peaceful shrine and garden in the middle of Tokyo. You can wander for a couple hours easy.

Tranquil stroll near Shibuya-Harajuku. This is definitely worth a visit if one is nearby in Shibuya or Harajuku. While the city throbs with life, this park and shrine provide a peaceful place to collect one's thoughts and consider where we truly are. There are smaller exhibits along the path and small gardens, but the shrine is definitely worth the walk.

Right Near Harajuku. Hard to believe you can walk across the street from hectic Takeshita street and find this peaceful and beautiful park leading to the Temple. It makes a nice change of pace. The temple itself is stunning as is the park and it has easy access from Harajuku train station.
A lovely tree lined walk to the shrine.. There was an interesting display of crysanthemums. We were delighted to see a large praying mantis at the shrine!

Peaceful. This place is a nice break from the busy city. Interesting display of wrapped containers of sake with drawings on the them, that were gifts to the emperor. Nice walk through a forest and then the second gate opens up the temple. The gardens were on the way and had a donation charge to enter -500¥

Beautiful Shrine. The Meiji Shrine is located in Yoyogi Park and busy. It is well worth the visit nonetheless. Beautiful shrine you can go into and with the surrounding park it creates a peaceful oasis in a busy city.
Shinta cathedral . This is a Shinta cathedral in Tokyo. Shinta is the Japanese religion created from Budhism to unite people under one empire.

Beautiful shrine in Yoyogi Park. For me a must see in Tokyo. In the heart of this bustling city, you will find the relaxation and beauty of the Meiji Shrine. Monks who are praying, singing and of course selling their objects of Shinto prayer, so you can take part in the rituals. The grounds are in perfect upkeep and we were lucky to visit on a sunny autumn day, it was just stunning!
Loveltly promedade. Lovely promenade in the park and beautiful temple I was lucky to met a traditional wedding so loveley.

Gorgeous Area. So the grounds and gardens of this temple are gorgeous. It does feel a tiny bit overdone though and it is decidedly not my favorite temple in Tokyo. Still, it's totally worth the visit and keep your eyes open for traditional Japanese weddings going on there which are really a site to be seen.

A must see in Tokyo. Visiting the Meiji Jingu shrine is a very pleasant experience. It is Tokyo's most venerated Shinto shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji.who was dedicated to opening Japan to the outside world. A large cypress torii over 1700 years old gives dramatic entrance to the grounds. (A major landmark for Tokyo). The 15 minute walkway is paved and lined with lovely trees, shrubs and greenery. It is a very peaceful place to visit and not extremely crowded. You won't want to miss visiting the shrine when you are in Tokyo.

Beautiful Shrine. Shrines and Parks are usually not my thing, but if you go to Tokyo, at least make a stop here. Nice to see and doesn't take much time out of your day. Also right next to Yoyogi Park, which is epic on a Sunday (The people, as much as the park)

Slow Down and Enjoy the Sights. My family and I went to the Meiji-jingo Shrine because it was one of the things that showed up on all of the top rated attractions in Tokyo and I was not disappointed in what I saw at this stop.We took the Yamanote Line to the Harajuku Station, went out the South Exit and the entrance to the Shrine was just around the corner. There is a long walk to the Shrine, but it is lined with trees and it is a very peaceful walk. We went in the early afternoon, so it wasn't too hot. I don't think I would try this in the middle of summer, as the heat and humidity would be a bit too much.The Shrine itself is a beautiful structure, but the setting and peaceful setting is what sets this attraction off as something special. After walking about for 30 minutes, I came out of the Shrine with a new sense of being, a boost of energy and looked forward to my next adventure, which was Harajuku across the street.This is a good place to relax and get away from the hustle and crush of the Tokyo atmosphere. With your batteries re-charged, it is time to head back into the crush of people.

Absolutely Wonderful - a must see 😍. In the middle of concert jungle surround by rail lines sits this beautiful wonder of a Shrine surrounded by tall trees and woods - the Tori gates are majestic and the whole place has such a peaceful vibe - a must do in my opinion whilst in Shibuya.

Another big shrine. These Japanese shrines all start to look the same after a while, but this one is in a huge park just away from the chaos of Shibuya, so worth a visit for an hour's peace. Lots of locals visit with kids dressed up i Kimonos which look nice in your holiday snaps.

A Calm Moment within the City. After getting off the train at JR Harajuku station, just a quick walk and you're at Meiji Shrine. You'll feel the calm once you reach the Tori gates. Just the sounds of the rustling leaves and the crunch of the gravel stones beneath your shoes; nothing else. It's a welcome relief after the train ride. Calm.Opens at sunrise and closes at sunset. It changes every month. The park is 70 hectares. Entrance is free. There are restaurants and washrooms available.

Stunning. . We were there before 8am which definitely beat the crowds. It was very serene and there were mainly business folk visiting before work. There was a ceremony at 8am which was great to observe. There are instructions on how to cleanse yourself before you enter and also how to pay respects to deities. In the morning sun, it looked truly amazing and it's a nice walk through the park to get there. The souvenir shop is nice but definitely a tourist trap. Still very nice though and I will visit again.
Fantastic Shrine. Be amazed with a place/park within a city. After getting off the subway, a few meters away you will see a huge Tori Gate. Walk through the quiet park towards the Meiji Jingu Shrine.

Nice park but nothing spectacular. I was in Nikko the day before I visited Meiji Jingu so the shrines and the forest did not impress me much. Nevertheless, the whole story behind the park and how it is a testament for the love of one people for their emperor is interesting.

Must-see Shrine while in Tokyo. Very close to Harajuku and Shibuya, make sure you visit this historic site! My family and I were fortunate enough to also see a wedding ceremony while it was in progress!!

Unique. World celebrate or memorize the 70th year of 2nd World War finish. Japanese memorize the 70th year of the great East Asian war. These memorial boards are everywhere in Tokyo. Anyhow this shrine is surrounded by forest, very beautiful. Long entrance path with high tall trees makes people feel isolated from city in very city center. Good place to see.

Break from bustle. Definite must do, just round the corner from Harajuku.
Tranquil and unexpected because it so close to bustling street. Lovely forestry, nice guidance on features, well worth a couple of hours of peace.
Lovely Shinto shrine in the heart of Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is a quiet respite from the noise and busy-ness of the city. Well worth spending 2-3 hours exploring the gardens, shrine and museum.
Definitely make a point to go. Beautiful sites to take in and a serene and tranquil environment. It's a great break from the city. If you're lucky you can witness a traditional wedding as well!

Peace Within Bustling Tokyo. Our Sunrise Day Tour Group went to this Meiji Shrine within busy, noisy and active Tokyo City. It was like another transformation to another world within.Emperor Meiji and his Empress are enshrined here. Emperor Meiji was the Japanese Emperor whose political and actual powers were restored and transferred from the Tokugawa Shogunate in 1868 to present Japan. It was the start of a modern movement for Japan.We passed by the first shrine gate with the imperial seals on it and along wthe passage were hundreds of different brands of saki wine. Wines offered to this shrine. There were also different variety of flowers depicting florists' donations to this site.It was a change of pace and peaceful walk through the pretty and beautiful green , encaged in a concrete jungle city like Tokyo, to the Meiji Shrine where we pay our respect. Its a very educational and cultural visit within Tokyo as any day tour will take one there. Totally not expensive.

Worthwhile visit. This was a good visit to a country where there are many temples! Nice gardens and worth it to pay the extra 200 Y or so to walk through the garden to the spring and pond with the fish. Would have been great to be here a couple of weeks later as the autumn colours were more prominent. On Sundays you may see some weddings which were a nice distraction.

Calm oasis from hectic Tokyo. Great place to go to have a serene walk around the park and temple.If you're lucky you will visit when there is a traditional ceremony underway, regardless, it's a beautiful place to be.Within Yoyogi park, bring some lunch to enjoy in the park before or after your visit.

A walk to remember (with small family). We came here during the day via metro, getting off at Harajuku station. This allowed us to walk through the park on the way to the shrine. Please note the path on the way to the shrine is gravel. On the way we stopped by Kiyomasa's well. It was situated off the main path and required you to walk along a path that included a nice pond, complete with fish and turtles. The local birds even came up close to you if you had bread (we saw an elderly Japanese gentleman sitting by the pond with little finches eating bread from his hands). Just a little further along, we came across a beautiful garden of flowers that was reminiscent of an impressionist painting, a definite highlight. Kiyomasa's well is a small natural well situated in the middle of this 'forest' park.At the shrine we witnessed a ceremony with a Shinto priest and what appeared to be two business men. It was quite interesting. We weren't allowed to take photos within the shrine or of the ceremony but we could around the grounds. Definitely a great visit where past and present sit comfortably together.

relax walk. Main torii and the entrance of the road to meiji jingu is close to Harajuku subway station. The road was very relaxing, calm walk through greens. One can visit the shrine and than go shopping and eating at takeshita street.

Lovely and calm a must visit. Its a collision of the old and new with this shrine on one side and access to Harjuku on the other. We had a tour guide with us on this day who gave us some great insights into the traditions and practices when visiting this attraction. The walk up and down it is also very lovely. Great photo opportunities. Be sure to observe what others are doing when making well wishes, washing hands etc.

Peaceful. My favorite time to go is a Saturday or Sunday morning. Its a nice walk around the surrounding park. Sometimes there will be a traditional Japanese wedding, it is a interesting event to see.

wow. everything is perfect even the atmosphere the food the envoronment. the price acceptable but the food is amazing with the harmony all around. So many people in here and recomand the dinner. the light make you passionate. Even with your family, friend and couple

Active Shinto worship site. We attended a service with a tour group, and were seated on the tatami mats, in the main shrine building. I believe that the service we attended had to be requested, and that a monetary offering was given. Services are held regularly. It was very interesting to watch, with the various types of priests , acolytes and shrine maidens performing prayers and rituals. Their website explains the service well. Our group was blessed by the priest, as were a 3 year old girl, dressed in a beautiful kimono, and her parents, and another couple. Afterwards, we each received a sweet sugar cake to take with us, and a small sip of sake, to drink. The setting was serene, unlike the scene at many shrines and temples, mobbed with tourists. We learned that it is the custom for parents to take their children to be blessed at certain ages. Grounds are open and free to public, except 500 yen for garden.
Nice scenery. In the urban Tokyo, you can get close to nature here. The walk into the shrine is amazing and when you reach the shrine, you can enjoy inner peace.

Don't Miss!. I love love LOVE Meji Jingu. It is a beautiful and peaceful oasis outside the craziness that is Harajuku. If you have a chance try and get a tour because everything in this shrine is symbolic from the giant Torii gates to the gravel walk way. Also if you want there is the Emperor's garden you can see for an extra 500￥. I recommend it because there is a man-made pond full of koi fish and lotus leaves as well as the occasional turtle. Also inside the temple you are likely to see a traditional wedding procession so watch for that.

Must Visit!. It's an Oasis smack in the middle of the city. It amazed me how just a short walk from a train station there is this gorgeous peaceful place. Despite there being a large number of people it was so quiet. Beautiful trees and since it was autumn the changing colour of leaves. Take your time to walk around and just soak it all in.

old-world and other-world. An impressive park, so lovely for walking and feeling distant from the hustle and bustle of the big city. Besides the wide pathways and very tall trees, there were saki casks on display, a magnificent torii from huge timbers and there were at least two weddings in progress so we could observe the traditional pageantry and clothing - very elegant indeed.

Must go. Very nice & peaceful place.. Love the walks Went on Saturday and saw a traditional Japanese wedding taking placeIt's really a must go on weekends in the morning if possible Meiji Shrine is located near to Harajuku
lovely park. Take a slow walk in the lovely park with a lot of beautiful trees by the side. A place suitable for all.
Tokyo Must Do. Such an amazing experience! Can spend hours there with all the things to see. Went on a Sunday so saw traditional Japanese wedding which look beautiful!

Have been many time, still love!. I've visited this shrine several times since 1996. It's still such a great place to visit. Great park, close to Omotesando and the paid garden is worth a visit as well.
A must when in Tokyo. One of the most important places to visit in Tokyo. New Years attracts loads of people but it s worth it. Bring confortable shoes and enjoy the park.

One Day in Tokyo. With only one free day in Tokyo I crammed in a lot. Walking the beautiful backstreets to Meiji Jingu and getting there at 8am I found a haven of peace in the middle of the busy city.

Serene and out of this world.. Meiji shrine is a must go for me in Tokyo. Just cross the street from Harajuku into a totally different environment. The trees lined path to Meiji shrine is probably the best reason to visit. I went on a Sun and managed to catch a traditional Japanese wedding procession. Really eye-opening ceremony to witness with all the finery.
Serene. Such a serene place! It was lovely to see this ancient temple, and witnessing some wedding processions during our time there. Definitely a must see.
Magokoro. The prose of Soseki could rhyme with the verses of the Emperor Meiji to describe this place. Feeling the harmony from the very first instant you get into it.

Central Park of Tokyo. Central Park of Tokyo and thats the best description you can give Meiji Jingu. Went there on a Sunday and saw wedding processions. Saw lots of people wearing traditional Japanese clothing. Its a nice break from the metropolis vibe of Tokyo where you can breathe fresh air. Grab a charm as a souvenir for whatever need you have!

Nice stroll to the temple. Not a priority sight while in Tokyo, but still worth a visit if you are in the neighborhoods. Quite a nice stroll towards the temple especially when it starting to get dark as the lanterns are lit. It is possible to behold wedding processions during weekends.
Great buildings within beautiful park. Well worth a visit and not excessively busy. Green park is very tranquil and easy to reach on rail and adjacent to good shopping.

Serene and tranquil experience. A direct contrast from the rest of bustling Tokyo. The walk through the forest was peaceful and calming despite all the people. At the shrine itself was a mixture of tourists and regulars paying their respect.

Nice place. A nice place to visit to learn a little about Japanese history. This place is used for weddings as well, so you might chance upon a ceremony by a newly wedded couple. This makes a good photograph.
Secluded Wooded Area. Incredible Shinto gates lead you to the shrine located in the middle of a heavily wooded area. Well worth the walk into the woods to leave the city behind.

Go on Sunday to see traditional weddings. This is probably my favorite temple in Tokyo. You first enter the park and walk through this dark heavily vegetated trail to get to the temple. The walk is very nice and cool when it's hot out. The temple is busy with tourists, but we happened to go on a Sunday, so we were able to stay on the side and to observe traditional Japanese wedding ceremonies. No food and free admission, if I remember correctly.
Impressive shrine. A really impressive shrine gift shop coffe shop and clean toilets all by the main car park. Shrine is ok some substantial timber entrance features went as part of tour group
Very nice vast forest walk before the tenple. A must visit in Tokyo , the trees are amazingly tall that it gets a bit darker as you walk toward the temple ... Saw a few weddings in progress as well

Worth a visit. A very peaceful and beautiful place. Located very close to Harajuku and Meijijingumae stations. Didn't go to the treasure room or garden (have to pay for those), just the main temple (free). Not a whole lot to see there once you arrive but worth spending about 30-45mins having a look around.

Meiji Jingu_. Meiji Jingu deeply influences Japanese life. It offers city walkers a sense of nature, peace and harmony. They believe god is in all beings, the way of life, the temple, even the trees, it's just a way of respecting the world. Meiji Jingu has a very long walkway to the temple itself, a long walk in the fine white rocks just relaxes you and allow you to reset your emotions. Although you are in Tokyo but in here, you are close to nature and yourself. We were lucky enough to witness a Japanese wedding ceremony, very nice overall experience.
my favourite tokyo shrine. every time i come to tokyo, i will visit meiji jingu.its peaceful, always filled with a good surprise!
Peaceful. A great shrine that leaves you thoughtful of the history of Tokyo (Edo). It is fairly big but do not take too much of your time.

Respect the crows! . This forest and temple is a great place to visit with amazing photo opportunities. Firstly you may think your walking through a Wizard of Oz set....no lions, tigers or bears but crows! Yes big ones, giant ones!....like the flying monkeys in the Wizard of Oz! I don't know if these are carrion or jungle crows, but there cries and shouting let you know it's their forest. Don't be scared, but I'd refrain from walking along with food.Ok now for the review!A beautiful setting. From the start to the finish. Sake in straw barrels - is amazing along the path to the temple.At the temple there is an option to pay respects in many ways from bowing and clapping twice to lighting incense or writing a message of peace.A must see area of Tokyo.
Must visit. Tranquillity in the big city. A big forest park surrounding the shrine. A personal place to share. Can get there by train and a moderate walk

So peaceful. The forest was nice and peaceful. Great for a stroll. The inner garden was 500 yen to enter. I thought it was well worth it. Beautiful inside. Shrine was okay. Not too different from the others.

Peaceful forest in the middle of Harajuku frenzy. Not expecting to walk through a peaceful forest along wide, wide gravel path. Picture the Emperor and Empress being carried through escorted by the white horses to the shrine for prayer and blessing back to 1920's? Go on a Sunday to view Shinto weddings. Loved the huge mon's,
Not really special if you are visiting Kyoto.. Long walk to a not special shrine. Shrine is ok, but if you have to make choices you can forget this one.

Great temple! Well worth a visit . We visited here after seeing the great reviews on trip advisor. It is a lovely temple, it's massive! It's free to enter, there are things you can pay for but you don't have to. We were lucky to see a wedding which was lovely. Very peaceful and a great place to look around. (Be aware of men outside the temple who give you a lucky charm and then ask for a donation)

Peaceful place. It's big forest/park. Mid of it it's the shrine. Lots of people visit here! I did see two couples have traditionally wedding there. When you stand there you can feel the happiness and the hope for the future. It's nice place to visit and you don't need to buy ticket for entrance.
Nice temple. A nice temple in the middle of a city. There were a wedding ceremony when i was there.So happy i got to see that.

AN OASIS OF CALM. This shrine is situated in quiet woodland in the middle of a bustling Tokyo suburb, accessed through imposing massive timber gateways with long gravel paths being constantly swept of fallen leaves by elderly gardeners what a job.We were lucky to see a traditional wedding - unusual at this time of year apparentlyWell worth a visit - nearest underground station is Harajuku then a 10 minute walk
Nice place. Worth a walk to. It's quite busy but the walk in the forest is really nice. And then you can quite easily walk to the shinjuka crossing

Another popular temple. I visited quite early in the morning but unfortunately they had a function on later in the evening. Construction people were banging and crashing setting up a stage so it kind of took the peacefulness away for me. I left disappointed.I also saw a wedding. The bride and groom were beautiful. The walk up to the temple is nice. Wear decent walking shoes as you have to walk over stones.

Nice break from the city landscape. The approach to the shrine is a nice quiet walk through the trees. It's a free site so it's certainly worth a visit and it's a small site so you can see most of it in 30 minutes or so.

Tokyo visit fall 2016. Really nice shrine/temple situated in the middle of the park. There were two weddings taking place while we were there! Free to visit - walk the park and see the temples. The buildings/architecture is amazing.
Make a point of paying a visit to this lovely landmark. Very atmospheric shrine - definitely worth a visit. A lovely 10 minute walk from Harajuku Station, set in gorgeous gardens.

Ok, but not amazing. The tall gates are nice, you can actually hear the crickets when you walk in and it's extremely peaceful if you consider it's in the middle of the city. I do saw a wedding there, but with so many tourists and the temple not being spectacular I was in and out of there in half an hour.

Another great Shrine. With a flat shopping shoes I usually wear, I still not recommended. A pair of sport shoes is necessary here. I saw a traveller came visit with his rolling luggage, I understand the difficulty of keeping your luggage if you are in rush of time to the trains. *I truly respect Japaneses, on their timing awareness. I personally really not recommended to have luggage strolling all over the pebble stones while you walk in. We should listen to our footstep in this tranquil environment! Therefore, do you get it? Sport shoes is required. Next, water is known to be a symbol to cleanse people of evil and bad luck. I love to have the cold water running down my hand and lip before entering to the prayer, try and enjoy it after coming from so far! 
Beautiful place. It is beautiful place. Not far from train station, just around the corner. It is good to go in the morning, least people. Also don't forget make wish.

Surreal silence in the hearth of Tokyo. I enjoyed the visit to this shrine enormously! It is located right in the heart of Tokyo but you could be in the middle of the forest. We were there on a Saturday and there were loads of traditional weddings taking place. Really magic. And you end the visit with a stroll in the forest. Do not miss it!

Pretty temple, oasis in the middle of Tokyo. If you go on the right day you may see a Japanese wedding in progress, which is very cool. If not, it is still definitely worth a visit to see the beautiful temple buildings, especially if you cannot make it to Kyoto or nearby Kamakura. The forest is very peaceful.
nice. I went there on april 2015. Nice view, need a lot of walk to reach the shrine. I'm so lucky that I could see traditional japanese wedding.
