Peaceful. Beautiful gardens and temple. A lot of Japanese history here. We walked from Shibuyu station but you could have got off at the station that was right there! The temple is amazing and the wide covered walkways give you a sense of tranquility.

Beautiful!. Awesome! Saw a couple of Japanese weddings when we went. So nice!! The walk to the shine is beautiful...it's a forest and you hear the crickets and animals...just being in nature in the middle of tokyo...awesome!

Peaceful and quiet temple. Nice walk in one of the green area of Tokyo (Shibuya) easily accessible by public transportation. The park is beautiful and so quiet that you wouldn't leave it. The walk leads you to this shrine dedicated to an emperor and his wife. 2 huge trees are visible in front of the schrine who is stil in use our days. Like in every other place, you can buy amulets to be protected during all events of your life.
Pretty temple with the possibility of buying a token for good luck. It's a really pretty temple located in a park. You can buy a token for good luck and then hang it at the temple.

One of the highlights of Tokyo. Tranquil and reverent - there's a lot of Japanese history here. Take the time to put a request on the wall and sit quietly and watch as individuals come and pay their respects. An intersection of the Buddhist and Shinto traditions as well.

Beautiful. The shrine is set within the most beautiful and peaceful park, which is clean beyond words! The shrine is where Japanese parents bring their newborn children and also return with them when they are between 5 and 7 years of age, to receive special blessings. The children are dressed in traditional Japanese clothing and are just beautiful. The Japanese people are so friendly and gracious and actually encouraged us to take pictures of their children. Even though the park was busy it is so large that it never felt crowded. Make sure to visit if you're in Tokyo.

Spiritual. To enter the Shrine, you walk thru a tall wood torii and a long tree lined road which bring peace to your mind. It is a very popular place for traditional wedding ceremony. When we were there on Saturday, there were 3 weddings in less than an hour. There was an exhibit nearby but we did not have time to visit.

Lovely shrine. Enjoyed our visit here. Went on a Sunday and visited here and the Harajuku area. Very easy to get to right next to Harajuku station. There were quite a few weddings taking place and it was lovely to see the Japanese people all in their finery including a lot of kimonos. They seemed quite happy for people to take photos. Well worth a visit.

So peaceful! Go on a weekend morning.. When you enter through the gate, you will be impressed with the walk as much as the actual temple itself. Large trees line the path to the second and third gates, and each symbolizes an action that you are supposed to do in order to purify yourself. It is very inspiring and I can understand why the site is sacred.I would recommend visiting on Saturday or Sunday with enough time to walk all the way to the temple before 10 am; you will very likely see a traditional Shinto wedding taking place. The bride's kimono is beautiful!
Tranquil. Great story behind this and how the forest was man made by donations . Very clean and peaceful but still busy . Get a guide to talk through the history and then donate and prey .

Tranquil and gorgeous shrine. The Meiji Shrine is nestled between Shibuya, Harajuku and Yoyogi Park which are all very popular tourist attractions and often busy with too much fanfare and activities. Yet right in the heart of all these is a tranquil forest shrouding the Meiji Shrine. Peaceful and quiet, it ranked as one of my favorite tourist location during our recent trip to Tokyo. As with most shrines in Tokyo, you can make a prayer the Shinto style here. Throw a coin into the coin box, bow your head twice, clap twice and bow again. You can also purchase "omakuji" poems written by Emperor Meiji and the Empress Showa. We picked 2 omakujis and found they're great advise for our life. I really recommend you to pick up these omakujis.Also check out the Meiji Shrine website (http://www.meijijingu.or.jp/english/index.html) and try to visit during one of their festivals. We're lucky to visit during the Ningyo Kanshasai, a festival to thank protective dolls, and witnessed the ceremony. To get to Meiji Shrine, get on the Yamanote Line and alight at Yoyogi station. From there it takes 15 minutes of walking to Meiji Shrine.We really enjoyed this visit and hope you do too.
Not your average park, unbelievably tranquil. Very well kept, calming. Only downer was we paid to see the pond in the middle of the park which I don't think was worth it
Peaceful!. Beautiful trees and very open space with temples and shrines, makes you feel very peaceful walking around, it was lovely.

Lovely taste of japan. Love this shrine although a little bit disappointed the treasure museum is only open on weekends so not open when we visited. The shrine has a beautiful feel to it and it's a place where parents bring their 3/5/7 year old to be blessed and they dress up for it and it's cute. The whole place has a tranquil feel to it and it's free. Plus you can go up to the nearby domi and watch women in traditional dress firing their massive 7 ft tall bows at long range targets

Peaceful oasis in the heart of Shibuya. After a hectic day in the shopping district of Shibuya this beautiful park is a godsend. It is a perfect place to stroll to escape the heat and see many things at the same time. We went on a Sunday and saw many families dressed in their Sunday best, in particular the children in beautiful kimonos. We also saw a couple of weddings and heard the drums at 2.00pm. Well worth a visit not only to see such a large shrine but also to enjoy a park right in the heart of Tokyo. Very easy access to the JR lines of Harajuku and Yoyogi.
Calm stroll. Tranquility stroll into Meji Jingu, its like walking into a forest with full of trees. Best to wear sports shoes cuz pebbles of stones walkway. Must visit.
Find your zen!. Nice shrine in the middle of busy Tokyo. Very relaxing to walk around. We were lucky enough to see the march of the Priests.

Beautiful and unique . Stunning location, can spend a day roaming round the whole park or just take 2 hours to visit best bits, have to say it's a must of your in tokyo(though todaji temple in Mara was far more impressive)

A Must Visit Especially as Part of Key Attractions in this Area. The Meiji Shrine is an expansive pavilion and garden that can be part of visiting the Harajuku and/or Yoyohgi areas. An impressive part of the visit is the torii gates that tower 40 ft high, and the sake and wine offerings that adorn the entranceways to the shrine. The locals and tourists alike visit the chozuya basins for purification before entering the shrine. The gardens feature the Kiyomasa Well which is believed to impart some kind of spiritual power. We visited at a time when few of the flowers or botanical features were in bloom, so the gardens were not terribly impressive in August. I think the shrine is a “must visit” for Tokyo, but mostly because it remains one of the most impressive traditional attractions in Tokyo, but also because it is close to Takeshita Dori, Harajuku and Ebisu and makes for a great part of a day visit along key attractions along the Yamanote Line.
Biggest shrine in Tokyo. Definitely worth a visit as the biggest shrine in Tokyo. A good gift-shop for gifts. Beautiful but do put time aside as it is so big!

One of the two best shrines / temples in Tokyo!. Bring your walking shoes and some change (with holes). Fantastic area with a lot of nature to behold. Lots of history behind this area as well so be sure to read up on it or hire a guide to take you around.If you're lucky you'll get to see a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony!

Excellent place, very beautiful. The shrine is very popular but easy to get to on the metro. It's a beautiful place very photogenic but peaceful and cool through the park. There were two weddings today which added a little extra.Recommended!

Beautiful. Although it was a rainy day when I visited, it was still beautiful. it is a peaceful place and also an opportunity for we western types to appreciate other beliefs and practices. This is a must see. A beautiful place in such a large city.

Shrine in the midst of a forest. Didn't have time to visit the entire place but the Shrine. Beautiful place in the middle of lush greenery -- Was told that the trees were planted by people nearly a century ago. Make a wish at the Shrine after cleansing yourself (wash your left hand, then right before rinsing your mouth at the provided place), buy a charm, and/or get some food at shops.

Quiet place to have a quiet moment. Indeed a nice place to go when you want to be alone and ponder on things happening in your life. Nothing much to see except for some temples or japanese like houses.

Distinguished Emperor Shrine in Shibuya. Hidden behind the shopping streets of Shibuya is a traditional japanese shrine memorial - Meiji Jingu. The gravel filled pathways leading to the shrine is a picturesque scene of serenity and calm. Although tour buses deposit busloads of camera grabbing tourists, the shrine still manages to lend a piece of tranquility to all her visitors. Grab a kohii at the cafe for a perfect mid day rest before returning to the busy Shibuya streets.
Beautiful Shinto Shrine. This large Shinto shrine has an imposing structure. It has very large grounds that act as a park. It completely isolates you from the bustle of the city.

It's a must place in Tokyo.. You can't miss visiting Meiji jingu when you are in Tokyo.It's a must place to walk around in the shrine. It feels zoo good walking around and especially the place to pray is very nice atmosphere.
Relax from the crowd. Go there if you need to relax or get fresh air during the warm days Of tokyo. PLUSfresh and relaxing atmosphereRestrooms for freeMINUSnot so special Lack Of seats

Oasis. The woods and gardens around this shrine make it a bit of a hideaway in the middle of the city. I went in a muggy September and there are a lot of cicadas (and mosquitos) in the woods. It's about a 10-15 minute walk from Harajuku station. The wooden gates are gorgeous. The shrine itself is very peaceful and when I went there were a few couples getting their wedding pictures taken in traditional clothing. I enjoyed the experience, although I didn't go to a ton of shrines while I was in Tokyo, so possibly if you've been to many, it's not as impressive.

Beautiful shrine and surrounds. The gardens surrounding the shrine are stunning and provide a great place to relax and get a break from the crowds. We were lucky enough to come across a traditional japanese wedding so the experience felt very authentic. Whilst it wasn't the highlight of our trip to Harajuku it is worth a visit.

All shrined out, pretty average . We were all shrined out by the time we went here, but even so, it wasn't very amazing after seeing heaps in Kyoto! If you go, which I assume most will, use the bug spray on offer for free at the entrance, the spiders in there are huge and the mozzies are no fun!
Lovely shrine within a park. Great walk in the park before visiting a lovely shrine. It's a wooded park so a Nice break from sunshine. Would recommend comfy shoes.

Beautiful, relaxing place in the heart of Tokyo!. We were there on a Sunday and were fortunate to see two traditional Japanese weddings. The garden area is very beautiful too! I would love to have been there in the Spring or the Fall when there are more colors.
A Relaxing Stroll Away From The Crowd. Shady trees, pebbled path, and a large shrine at the very end. It makes a good evening stroll to escape the bustling city and dense crowd at Harajuku.
Large shrine, worth a visit. Great big shrine dedicated to Meiji. Nice shrine area, but the walk in is good also (takes a good 10-15mins from the roads surrounding the park

Peace and quiet . . . .. Meiji Jingu is beautiful. The park surroundings leading to the Shrine are gorgeous - we have seen the park during cherry blossom season and autumn and both are lovely. It's a very peaceful walk with lots to see on the way. The Shrine itself is fantastic - and we even saw a couple of weddings . . . amazing! On the way out, there is a cafe/restaurant area where we stopped for a coffee and ice cream. This is an absolute must-see . . . . .

Must see!. Beautiful long tree lined path to the shrine adds to the mystique of the shrine. The barrels of wine and sake at the entrance tell their own tale. The shrine itself is very ornate inside and very peaceful. Worth a visit.

Wonderful temple in the centre of tokyo. Located close to the bustling suburb of Shibuya, Meiji Jingu is a beautiful shrine. Not as full of tourist as the Sensoji, it has a special charm. The road leading to the main shrine is surrounded by trees, affording a peaceful break in this busy city. I was also lucky to see a traditional Japanese wedding there. A highly recommended attraction.

Nice break but not as memorable to me. A nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city, but after a while, all of the temples and shrines seem to be the same. There was nothing very memorable to me about this temple or shrine over the others.

Peaceful and quiet. Got here in the Yamatone line to the Harajuku station. the park starts straight behind the station. easy visit and if you are here on a weekend you are very very likely to see a wedding!

Worth a visit. Obviously it's very popular so it gets crowded and that probably negatively affects the "feel" of the place (loud noises, cameras flashing, "pushing and shoving" in general...) but it's well worth going. Actually my favorite part of this visit was walking in the park surrounding the shrine; the park has things to see, it's quite peaceful and one has more room to breathe.

Absolute beauty. Travelled there alone. Best to take the subway to the closest stop and ask for directions. I started wandering the streets before I got to it to get a feel of that part of Tokyo, which was phenomenally rewarding, but still got me a bit tired :)Once here, its a long but gorgeous walk to the center of the forest. There was a wedding being held the day I was there and it was great to see the traditional wear and customs. Very serene area, you will forget that you are in the heart of such a bustling cosmopolitan city. There are barrels of green tea on the way to the restaurant area which look gorgeous with sunlight seeping through the trees. Like much in Japan, its sights and moments like these that take your breath away. Make sure you don't hurry through it.
Peaceful experience. It was different from the noisy clattering of temples that I have been to. The shrines in Japan are so much different, that you feel at one with nature. Definitely a must go!

AMAZING. Beautiful park, it is so magical and you don't feel like you are in a big city anymore. Make sure you go all the way to the temple, I also suggest the inner garden ($5 and worth it). Stunning, go early to beat the crowds.

Tranquil. Meiji Jingu is a great example of a shinto shrine, but unique in that this is dedicated to the late Emperor and Empress Meiji in contrast to any deities. It's a somewhat long, but pleasant stroll to the inner shrine areas where one can offer prayers or buy protective charms. You can occasionally spot the odd wedding party come past too. There are big displays of sake barrels offered to the shrine on the way in that make for great photos too. I definately recommend paying a little to get into the Empress' Garden to the side before entering the main shrine area. There is a lovely spring well at the end, and you can see cranes in the water.

Make a wish at Meiji Jingu on 1st Jan 2015. Went to Meiji Jingu on the 1st Jan,2015, make a wish for a prosperous year in 2015. Not too crowded when I was there and it was quite pleasant to walk around

A walk through beauty. The walk to the Meiji shrine start with walking through a path lined on side with sake drums and the other wine barrels until you come across a tori made of Cyprus . The shrine where you have to purify yourself is peaceful and lovely.

Large park and shrine. Large, quiet and peaceful shrine with many Japanese paying respects so the area feels somber in a nice way. The central area is not as impressive as other big shrines in Nikko or Nara but still pleasant, the surrounding park is a quiet escape from busy Tokyo. Remember not to take any food or drink, we were stopped by security on the way in (should have read the signs!).

Meiji shrine - a unique experience in the Tokyo metropolis. A great temple in the midst of a densely forested area; right in the middle of Tokyo. Almost impossible to fathom such an expanse of green, in the concrete jungle of Tokyo! Extremely well maintained temple with simple rites like washing hands, make it a must-visit location in Tokyo!
Amazing . 原宿の混雑から原宿竹下通りと全く違い、とても静かで伝統的な神社です。This shrine is traditional, different nearly Harajuku Takeshitadori. It's amazing!!!!

Second Visit. We have been here a few years back and coming back for the second time was suppose to be memorable. This should have been a nice tranquil walk but we went on a hot summer day which really tested our endurance. Then there were a few kids in front of us playing with their 'swords' trying to stab at each others. We had to dodge to avoid being hit. Somehow you wonder what their parents were doing? or not doing? This is definitely a must-see place for visitors.

A place to remember.. This was our first stop in japan. And it is well worth it. If u want to by a straw barril of sake this place sell cheaper. The temple is breaking. But be ready to find lots o parole form all the world.

A Must In Tokyo. This is an easy place to access and is a must for Western tourists to get a feel for Japan. Pick and nice day and enjoy the walk and the experience along with many others. Use the Yamanote Line.

Tranquil Walk. I loved walking through Meiji Jingu it was so tranquil. It was a very immersive experience as you're surrounded by lush smelling trees.
The shrine its self is amazing to look at.

Must see in Tokyo. If you are going to see one Shinto shrine it should be this one. It is set within a large park and it is a beautiful walk to the shrine along a wide path through dense lush vegetation. It is a popular place for couples to get married and both times I have visited I have seen a parade of the wedding party walking to the place of the ceremony.To get there take the JR Yamanote line to Harajuku station. Turn right leaving the station and walk up the slight hill to the intersection and cross the road to the entrance to the park.

Peaceful and beautiful. Amazing walk underneath the canopy of beautiful trees to the shrine. It's about 2km round trip. We were lucky enough to see a wedding the day we visited which made it even more spectacular. Don't bother paying for the private gardens inside the shrine. For 500yen its nothing special.

A beautiful city oasis. This was my favourite place on my first trip to Tokyo. It was a beautiful city oasis. My friend and I were particularly excited to witness traditional weddings taking place on the grounds.

Magical place. The oath up to the temple is surrounded by lush trees and you really feel connected with nature as well as refreshed from the humidity. You can buy wood plaques and write messages on them with markers provided. There is peace and quiet everywhere. The path is topped with gravel, so closed shoes are a good to go thing.

Serenity in the Middle of Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is an oasis amidst the technicolor chaos of Harajuku. A short ride from Shinjuku station, the shrine is a serene place of reverence to casually walk through and take in a totally different side of Tokyo.The sake offerings, produced annually by farmers from all over Japan, near the entrance are a great photo op. The shrine itself is impressive, but quite crowded.

Beautiful. A beautiful respite from the flash and glitter of the city. Just a short distance from the metro. Paths are well layer out and easy to walk. The forest is quiet and serene. The temple is a wonderful cultural and historical landmark.
Majestic. This is a must visit place. My friends and I had a long therapeutic walk to the shrine.. I'll definitely visit this place again.

Lovely zen feel. Love the feel of when you walk in and on the path towards Meiji Shrine. It was lovely weather on that day and the smell of surrounding and greenery was so fresh and zen. Beware of the cobbled path towards Meiji, wear suitable shoes or you will have a sore feet!

Beautiful . The day that we were there was hot and steamy, which added to the whole experience. As you walk along the long and winding path, with the sound of cicadas and the tree tops enclosing you, it is a truly unique experience. The shrine itself is a large open space and you can place a small wooden plaque with a wish, for a small fee. It was definitely worth seeing.
Breath taking atmosphere. This place is one of the locations which anyone in visiting Tokyo must visit!The surrounding park and the temples are just breath taking.
Serene. In the middle of tokyo- very majestic entrance theough the gate and down the wide forest. The shrine is beautiful. Go early as it closes at 5:30 and its a little hike

Beautiful and peaceful. I came here while on a solo trip to Tokyo. It was walking distance from where I was staying in Shibuya and open early in the morning, so I enjoyed a peaceful and beautiful walk there. Remember to bow before you go through the arches!

Beautiful shrine. The shrine is in a beautiful area and is an important part of Japan's history. My only caveat is if you've been to Kyoto and seen the temples there, don't make this a priority. I loved the surrounding gardens.

Must see Shinto shrine in Tokyo. Very nice place right in the middle of Tokyo but very quiet! You may see some wedding ceremonies too! A bit of a walk over gravel so, if you are wheel chair bound, that may be tough.

Beautiful! Must see!. The Meiji Jingu Shrine and Gardens are just beautiful! The large wooden gates are huge! The gravel pathway to the shrine has a few gates that you pass through which really sets you up for grandeur of the shrine.I felt this shrine was more elegant and beautiful than some of the others we saw in Tokyo. Great photo ops at the sake barrel display! At the shrine, there are a few benches to sit on. There are several small stalls selling charms and such. There is also a nice gift shop with small cafe. Everything was clean and orderly. It was pouring rain when we visited, so we were only there an hour but it felt like enough time.

Amazing!. I decided to go for a walk to get out of the bright lights, Meiji Jingu Shrine was great. Also worth to mention that the gardens are a must see too. While i was visiting there seemed to been a massive dance festival on, added bonus. The 3hrs of walking around passed by very quickly.

Peaceful. A great place to escape from the busy streets of Tokyo. The Meiji jingu shrine had a serene and calming effect on me while I was visiting the place. You can also write down a prayer or wish and hang it around an ancient tree, the priest and priestesses will take care of your wish the next day.

Witnessed a Japanese traditional wedding ceremony. It was quite a long walk from the outside to the main temple. was surprised to have witnessed a Japanese traditional wedding and infant blessing on the Shrine. Learned how to do hand & mouth cleansing before prayer and how to bow after praying. very accessible from JR Harajuku station and Tokyo Metro Meiji station.

Sprawling park and shrine complex dedicated to Meiji Emperor. The Meiji Shrine is a Shinto shrine complex, one of Japan's most popular. Visitors come in droves especially around New Year's Day, but on any given day, there could be weddings or children dressed in full traditional garb to ask for blessings. The shrine is next to Yoyogi Park in the Shibuya district of Tokyo, easily accessible by the JR Yamanote line from the Harajuku station. The park itself is a sprawling wooded space where one can take a pleasant stroll away from the bustle of Tokyo, but be wary of mosquitoes, especially at dusk. Be sure to stop at the Meiji Jingu Treasure House, which is a museum of many of the Meiji Emperor's belongings, along with some historical interpretive material, although not much of it is in English. There is also a garden at the south end of the shrine. Both the Treasure House and garden charge and admission of about $4. The shrine complex itself is free.
Great nature path in the city. Great for the young and old. It was beautiful with the blooming Iris flowers and a lake full of water lilies.
Spiritual. Maybe it was the long wide path to the temple, along tall old trees that was conducive to the deep spiritual connection that made me mark this place very special.

beatiful peaceful. in the middle of a very crowded and noisy city is this beautiful park with shrines and to enjoy and relax for a while so easy to get there as it is in all Tokyo if you know how to read a subay map. saw a bride and her procession,. understood a liitle of Japanese culture which is very interesting.
Very chilled. Had a walk round and a sit down. It's very calming and pleasant surroundings. Definitely worth a look round.
Lovely area shrine. Pretty cool. Lots of nice things to see in the area and the park. Saw a Japanese wedding going on while we were there,

Spiritual Meiji Jingu. Lovely, peaceful and very spiritual....The walk to Meiji Jingu is not too far, but it's a bit of walk especially in hot weather. The gravel path is a little hard to walk in if you're wearing sandals or open-toe shoes, but it's worth it.As soon as your enter the park area you are surrounded by trees on both sides, until it suddenly clears and you see the actual temple. Visitors are encouraged to wash their hands and mouth at the fountain on the left side, and there are fortune telling sticks on the right side.The shrine is inhabited by monks, and sometimes you can see them wandering around in their kimono robes. On the way up to the temple, there is a sort of wishing well located in the forest that is quite interesting as it's said that there is a 'power spot', a sort of super spiritual spot that you can pray at.Hint: there is a short cut behind the restaurant that makes the walk a little shorter. I suggest going up the forest path, but down through the restaurant as the walkway is paved and more direct.

Peaceful walk and great sightseeing. I love this place. The shrine is gorgeous and worth a visit (free entry). The park surrounding it offers great walks in all seasons. The gardens next to it (small entry fee) are definitely worth a visit as well. It feels like you've left Tokyo and are in the middle of nature. The park is surprisingly lacking drinks' vending machines that you normally see all around Tokyo. Toilets however are available throughout the park.
Great walk. Excellent walk. You can walk through and enjoy the gardens and the temples. One of the gates is close to Harajuku, another must visit site in Tokyo

Peaceful Shintoiste Shrine. This place has special positive vibes , wonderful peaceful shrine in the middle of a huge high tree forest just by the famous Luxury Omotesando.Just by the Meji-jungumae Metro station, the path to the temple through the park, allows you to empty your spirit of the frenetic town and breath a peaceful and quiet atmosphere. Th huge arc "door" to the temple is dark brown and majestic , instead of th typical orange one of the other shintoists temples. A huge holy tree has an incredible presence just in front of the main shrine. You can hang your prier to it. I had my calligraphy done on my holy temple book, and discovered this is a special temple for education and student protection.I adored this place , do not miss it, go there early in the morning , if you can.
Amazing! Especially with a wedding. A wonderful experience, what made it even better is the fact that they regularly hold elaborate traditional weddings that are a joy to watch!

Serene and tranquil shrine. You walk into the pathway leading to the shrine and find peace descending. A broad avenue with large trees apparently from all over Japan leading to a large shrine compound and many locals expressing their respect for Emperor Meiji. Ceremonial purification by water and Ema boards and clapping/praying people all make for a great experience. However as with all these popular attractions it is always full of people but they all seemed respectful when we were there. We were with a tour group so added to the numbers!

Quiet relaxing shrine in the forest mist. I found this shrine to be very peaceful and relaxing. It had rained earlier in the day and the walk in from the metro station was misty and quite nice. The shrine itself is nice but I especially liked the walk in where you will see the sake barrels painted with colorful logos and stacked up neatly. I also enjoyed reading the wishing placards people wrote on for 500 yen, these were all surrounding a Camphor tree. Not as majestic as Senso-Ji but also not as hectic.

Nice break from the city. Nice place to take a break from the madness of urban Tokyo. Literally 10-15 degrees cooler in the park. We went on a weekday and it wasn't crowded which made it feel quiet and serene.
Beautiful serene and tranquil place.. Meiji Jingu is a definite must on your itinerary... a really beautiful place. We were also lucky enough to witness a traditional Japanese Shinto-style wedding!

peaceful shrine in the city. Once you enter the path leading to the shrine, it is very difficult to imagine that you are in the midst of a bustling city. It was historical, green and peaceful place to visit.

Japanese temple you saw at anime and dorama :D. Must visit! Very peaceful, full of Japan culture. There are big sacred trees, a place where you can hang your "Ema" (a wooden board where you write your wishes on), and there are crows and temple officers dressing in all white traditional clothes. It's just like I'm hopping into a temple I watched in anime and dorama!^^

Beautiful and peaceful. A must visit site. It is serene and has a certain aura about it. It is full of history and knowledge.Despite the long walk and the heat to get there, it was a pleasure doing so. While basking in the moment, you could write your prayers and wishes to display on the prayer board, sharing it with the millions of travellers. We loved it because we felt the great vibe of the place and the majestic surroundings.
Must See. Beautiful, peaceful shrine tucked away in a woodland not far from the Harajuku station. Definitely worth a visit, can do in a couple of hours for those with a packed itinerary!

Green but busy temple. Meiji-jingu is open sunrise to sunset. Admission is free. To go there, take the JR Yamanote line to Harajuku station.To go to the temple, there is approx. 15 minutes walk crossing approximately 100,000 trees that make up Meiji Jingu's forest.Meiji Jingu is one of the Japan's most popular shrines. It's a peaceful place in the middle of Shibuya. Lot of tourist are visiting this place.
pray. whilst you are being lost to decide a direction, have to visit this shrine. its quite and vast field although mid Tokyo. you can see a lot of Ema & Omikuji written pilgrims desire.

Peaceful. Study a bit of the background and you'll appreciate more when you visit this place. The shrine is actually dedicated to the late Emperor Meiji and his Empress, and them both arguably built the foundation of Japan today. It is a simple shrine, and exceptionally peaceful. However, do not expect a place too fancy as compared to those you may have visited in Kyoto. Take into consideration that the place is located in Tokyo, a high dense metropolitan. If you happen to see it from Tokyo Metropolitan Government office, the shrine is the only big spot of greenery amidst the busy city. Really exclusive.Be prepared to walk a long road and be sure to wear comfy shoes. The road along to the shrine are of tiny pebbles. You may also want to walk along the street of Omotesando, which is right outside Meiji-jinggu
Peaceful . This is a very peaceful place surrounded by lots of green. The only downside is that is very hot and moist in August and you have to walk a fairly long way to get there.

Outstanding Large Shrine in the middle of Tokyo. Want to get away form the Crazy busy City and step quickly into the quiet woods and serine Shrine setting. You will find all of that at Meiji Jingu and perhaps some inspiration.
Lovely Shrine and park. A beautiful shrine and park, definitely worth the visit. Make sure you read the history to understand the poems at the entrance. Omotesando is a short walk away.
Shady and still place. I was went to this place in September 2015. This place so still. Meiji jingu so beautiful and many tree so shady. This is the place from respect of japanese people.

Tranquil and peaceful place.. Like any attraction you must go there early. Its at the back of the Meijumae station cross the bridge. As you enter the gate you hear the sounds of I think sekeeters or insects, its quite lovely. Continue the gentle walk and try to calm your mind absorb the lush greenery. Before you enter temple you are to follow the ritual of cleansing your hands and mouth.The shrine itself is simple and cannot be photograph. The procedure of prayer is on the board which is easy to follow. But if writing is your preference pay 500 yen you can have a small wood board to write your prayer wish and hang it near a tree.
Great shrine to see. This was one of the nicest shrines we went to in Tokyo. Great walk and beautiful pictures. Easy access by public transit!

Beautiful shine. It is an inspiring place in the middle of Tokyo city. The temple is situated in a forest. Before entering this temple you have to clean yourself with water, just remember that the water is not drinkable! I made this mistake haha. The architecture is great and it is one of the most beautiful shinto shrines.

Meiji Loveliness . This, for me, is a must see, if you're in Tokyo. Once you enter through the giant torii at its entrance, you are transported into another world. After a gentle walk through the forest you'll come to the main shrine area which is lovely. If you're lucky, you'll catch a proper Shinto wedding with all its poise and solemnity going on...it's a wonderful thing to witness.For a couple of hundred yen you can get your future or a confusing quote as a souvenir. This is Japan at its best. Don't miss it!

Surprise City Scene. In the middle of the hustle and bustle of busy Tokyo is a garden of peace and prayer. Classic structures hinting Shintoism. Prayer request area reveals artful paper where you write your wishes. Visiting in the summertime limited strolling the perimeter and I ended up in the shaded area. Choose your battles. Hydrate and enjoy the Shinto shade. Also wash before entering any shrine including a mouth wash. I poured some water over my head to cleanse my thoughts but the tour guide says she has never seen that before. Was actually a relief to do so in the heat.

Gorgeous. It was raining when I came and I hate the humid feeling then. Whatever it is, the temple is stunning in its lush greenery. Cannot compare to Kyoto but here in the heart of the city, such a great place for an evening jog or just simply to enjoy a quiet walk.

Relax afternoon stroll in the middle of the city. Can't believe there's such a vast forest in the middle of the city. I was astonished by the beauty of the gate. Try to touch it, it was made from a very solid wood. The shrine is also big and nice to see, with a dojo like stone terrace in front. Too bad i come in summer, so didn't bother to pay the enterance to the garden. Will come again one day to visit the garden during its prime.

Very Relaxing. A really nice visit. There are so many trees around this site that it does not feel like you are in the city. There are a few routes to get into the main shrine and once you get in, there are a few things that you can do. It's obviously not something exciting but rather a place where you can enjoy the scenery, relax and even pray.
went there when it was hot was not disappointed. not only when it was hot and very humid it was so cool and breezy the treats are beautiful and amazing

Great change of pace. Sometimes travelling in Japan you may want to get away from the noise, crowds and fast pace. This temple was set in a lovely park, a great respite from the city. If you choose you can write a prayer, pray at the temple and take some time out in your day.

Best temple in Tokyo. This is my favourite temple in Tokyo, it's fairly large, the walk to it through the park is lovely, a fair distance meaning it's very tranquil at the temple itself. A lovely place to visit even when crowded.

Very Peaceful!!!. Amazing place to walk through and the shrine area is very inspiring with the idols for purchase and the prayers to put around the tree. It's definitely inspiring. Wish there were more seating areas along the path.

Really Nice, Close By. It is Free. The walk is nice and cool with all the big trees to give you shade. There is a bridge in the park that has lots of turtles. The garden near the shrine that you have to pay for isn't worth it, the well is a small hole in the ground and the garden wasn't anything special. The Shrine is really the star.

Very Relaxing Site. It was a very nice visit. The walk was very easy from the metro. Once you enter the park you would not know you were in Tokyo. Lots of paths to warder around that eventually take you to the sites. We went to the main temple. It was nice not too crowded (Tuesday at 9). We purchased a wood carving for prayers. Nice place definitely worth visiting probably, will take about 2 hrs.

Ode to the man who open japan. An amazing setup to honor the founding father of modern japan. The meiji shrine offer a chance to fully respect the man who open the worlds acces to japan. You could find a unique wedding ceremony every monday on this location and have a glimpse of how traditional japanese bride and groom dressed. On 23rd of december you could see stack of wine and rice wine as an offering to the gods in this location.

Meiji Jingu temple New Year's Eve 2014 with kids😀😀😀. Like stepping down the rabbit hole - one minute you are in the middle of bustling Tokyo the next step, soft gravel under foot, beautiful mature trees, birds tweeting - Fresh air in the lungs. Beautiful place. I went here on New Years Eve where many people were headed, lovely atmosphere, hope for a good new year. will go again this NYE
Calm oasis in a vibrant city. It is a must place to visit when in Shibuya and Shinjuku, to experience a very different energy and perhaps to witness a traditional wedding.

Peaceful Early in the Morning. It was an easy walk from Park Hyatt to Yoyogi. We were out early, so our first shrine experience was unique in that nobody else was there. Meiji was large and there was quite a bit of literature available in English so we were able to learn quite a bit about Shito. We walked the rest of the park and came out at the Harajuku exit.

Forest located in the heart of Tokyo. It's big, it's just beside Harajuku JR Station, a 10 minutes walk into the main shrine. One of the most important shrine in Tokyo. Shinto shrine that is dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shōken.
Decent site. Not very impressive but still worth a look. It is located near Yoyogi park and a relaxing walk. It can get crowded.
Stroll through the park. Go on a weekend and you're sure to see a traditional Shinto wedding. Lovely and quiet shrine. You won't believe you're in downtown Tokyo.
Relaxing. Recommended walk in nice surroundings just few minutes from shopping madness in Harajuku. Also don't forget to go to the garden.
Peaceful walk. Had a very nice and inspirational walk through the shrine and its gardens. Peaceful and lovely way to better understand Japanese culture.

Shinto shrine in picturesque setting. Set inside a spacious 100-year old park, the Meiji Jingu shrine includes a small cluster of buildings around a pedestrian plaza. There is a pavilion for guests to perform ritual purification by washing their hands (and mouths), and there is a kiosk where you can buy a little plaque on which to write a wish or a prayer and hang it up. We happened upon a ceremony and got to see people in robes playing traditional instruments. Visitors stand outside and look into the inner sanctum. I did not see any food or drink concessions, so bring your own water.You can walk to Meiji Jingu in about 25 minutes from Shinjuku station, or take the train. Transit access is on the Odakyu local line on tracks 8 and 9. Proceed to the second stop (Sangubashi), walk south from the station and, at the first corner, look for a pictorial sign indicating the pedestrian overpass to your left. Park entrance is just north of the overpass.

Plan in conjunction with other destinations. This was truly a beautiful grounds and Temple. It is important to see and I am glad I went but I wouldn't recommend going way out of your way to do so. Plan it in conjunction with the national gardens and/or Yoyogi park (both in same area). On its own, the Temple Is small and you actually can't go inside any of the buildings so you really just stand in the courtyard. That said, it's impressive and worth a look.

Great place to visit!. Very nice place to go, tucked away in the city is the beautiful shrine. And around the area of the shrine is a very popular street for Japanese and known for great food and good shopping.

Bring water . Bring water if doing this during the summer months. The shrine is very beautiful and it's very peaceful getting out of the sounds of the city for a moment. Be sure to bring some loose change to offer to the shrine.

A haven of tranquility in the city. This shrine is located in the centre of a large woodland and is a great stroll from Harajuku station. The paths are wide and shaded which means that even when it's busy it's a pleasant experience.

very peaceful in the middle of town. amazingly peaceful area in the heart of Tokyo. Take time to walk slowly and enjoy the park on the way to the shrine. There is a small but relatively new shopping mall selling souvenirs on the way to the shrine - the toilets are much cleaner here.

Very beautiful shinto shrine with entrance in the shape of the colossal Torii (gate). After the first night in our Imperial Hotel in Tokyo, the next day, early in the morning, we headed with our guide to the Meiji Jingu (shrine) in the Tokyo region called Shibuya.First thing that awaited us was the gigant wooden gate,so called Torii, that is the traditional Japanese gate at the entrance of every Shinto shrine in Japan.That is 40-foot-high construction made of 1500- years-old cypress tree and through such giant door, the masses of the tourists pass in 200-acre park every day.This shrine is dedicated to the spirits of Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shoken.As soon as we passed the gate, on one side of the central path were exposed barrels of sake in the height of the two-storey wall. Here we stopped for awhile and listened to the very interesting story from the part of our guide, about the tradition of the making of the sake ( the rice wine) and which was donated here to the Meiji Shrine. Further ,as we were going on the tracks of this immense park, toward the Meiji Shrine Complex, we saw many interesting traditional, historic edifices.There is a central sanctuary, where is the Meiji emperor enshrined, then comes the shrine itself, with the vast yard in front of the building. At one place,on the wooden fence, that encircles the big tree, You may leave Your prayer. Again, in the other one ,some women signed the prayers posed on the tables in front of them.Also assisted to the event of the preparation for the wedding, here at the Meiji Shrine.That was the procession of the priests and maidens, which wore traditional dress for such occasion.In the very beginning of our visit to such old country as it is Japan, I was pretty sure that more miracles were to come yet.

Too crowded for comfort. I went solely for the supposedly cosplay characters sighted in the area as claimed by online reviews. I didn’t see any during my visit. Merely tourists and locals (it was a Saturday), the Harajuku Station was crowded and it was a long walk to finally arrive at the shrine which wasn’t my intended destination, I was actually looking for the Yoyogi Park which was nearby, hoping perhaps I would sight some cosplay characters. There was a mochi tasting event but the queue was long, tourists everywhere. I then left for Takeshita Street and found a treasure – a café serving hand-drip coffee!
Crowded. Very crowded, and a very long walk from the entrance. We enjoyed the Shinjuku Gyoen garden much more. If Kyoto is on the agenda, no burning need to see this sight.
Very spiritual. Visited with my teenage daughter.The walk was very pleasant, the surrounding area is beautiful.We thoroughly enjoyed and would go back.

worth a visit.. This shrine is well worth to visit. Its a 10 minute walk from Harajuku JR station. the temple itself is surrounded by a park and the old empress garden.the temple is in use today so expect to see weddings or other happenings if you visit on sundays. a nice place to experience japanese culture and religion.Combine the traditional with modern youth culture and visit on sundays before you go down to harajuku for lunsj and some shopping. then finish of in yoyogi park.
Fantastic place. well worth a visit to experience some great Japanese culture. beautiful surrounding park and a very nice souvenir shop (there are not many in Tokyo!)

Beautiful and Peaceful. It was a beautiful sunny November day. The walk to Meiji Jingu was something I never could have imagined. When I went here, there was a wedding on and it was a surreal experience. This is a must-see place in Tokyo.

Must Visit!. This is indeed the must visit place. We saw some bridal photoshoots in local costumes. This is a great place to see Japanese architecture and culture. My wife loved taking photos with the large tori gates.
Long walk in to the shrine. Serene place with a very sacred feel.calm and peaceful and it is protected by guards.be warned to have a long walk before you get to the shrine.
Meiji Shrine. Fantastic place to go whenever you want to escape the metropolis. Even better, try and time you visit right after it rains and it seems like you're the only people there
Stunning. Very beautiful and calming. The entrance gates to this shrine are truely awe inspiring they feel so imposing.
Visit !. This was wonderful and serene and I urge you to come and see the beautiful buildings and feel you can leave defend . Thank you

Very peaceful but.... It was a welcome respite from busy Tokyo however, the amount of walking we did just to get here plus the summer heat dissuaded us from going any further from the entrance. But I would go back and probably make it the first activity of the day as it is indeed free.

Birding mecca. Visit the inner gardens for a ¥500 fee. It's so worth it - the historic well, the gardens, and the birds are amazing! No birding trip to japan, especially in the cooler months, would be complete without a trip here.

Amazing Japanese Architecture and Landscaping . This is great place to visit for great Japanese architecture and landscaping and it Free to a point. You do have to pay $500 yen so $4USD to see the Emperor Meiji favorite fishing spot which has large koi and turtles. It his place is great for a nice quiet stroll, with great cultural views.

Very peaceful and tranquil. This is a classic sight to see when in Tokyo and I think overall it is worth the time. The setting is very peaceful and serene. It's a few minutes walk from the bus parking to the shrine. The shrine was built by the great grandfather of the present emperor. There are some activities in different buildings but in general the shrine is the main attraction. Does not take long, allocate about 30 minutes and you'll be fine. There is a nice gift shop and restaurant near the entrance/exit. The peace that surrounds this location is therapeutic.

Incredible Meiji Jingu. It’s a shame that words cannot describe how beautiful Meiji Jingu and Yoyogi Park are but I’ll try my best. Aim to get here towards the late afternoon when the afternoon light on a summer day is astonishing. Although there are tourists everywhere if you can find a peaceful place it’s ultimate zen. The Meiji Jingu Temple is incredibly well kept given the thousands of people who come to experience enlightenment, or whatever it is they’re doing if you can call it enlightenment.

The Holiday Place to Visit. Meiji Jingu is a relatively young temple. It is the official Imperial temple. The grounds are beautiful and tranquil, especially considering it's proximity to Harajuku. If you are in Tokyo in May be sure to check out the expansive Japanese Lilly garden. This is a great place to visit New Years, Girls Day, and for orher celebrations because so many people are in Kimono. Great photo ops.
Secluded and Peaceful. The walk towards the shrine is very peaceful and secluded. It seems like a million miles from the busy city.

One of my favourite quiet places in Tokyo. This is a must see in Tokyo, very easy to access and it's a lovely walk in a very tranquil area. It's a short walk from the metro and there's a lot to see in the area.
fun and easy to enjoy. simple easy to follow tourist destination, not to crowded, accessible from many entrances and free!!!

Seemed like we were miles away from the city.. An amazing peaceful walk through the surrounding gardens and shrine. Mere seconds after entering you are transported back in time and away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Meiji shrine trek. Walking from Takashita Dori in 38 degree heat and 80% humidity, I did not realize that quite a distance was ahead of me, as the shrine is quite a distance away in the middle of the park. The front Tori gate is just the beginning. But soon the tranquility and grace of the giant trees (365 types from all over Japan) helped mentor me all the way to the shrine. Tourists sweating left and right, some walking peacefully, some in tours, we all reached the shrine in various stages of exhaustion (me at the maximum) . I later erred and came out the wrong way, all the way on the other side of the park instead of back where I started, so be careful (I took a cab back to Takashita dori ).
Worth a visit if you're in the area. If the weather's right this is a good place to come for nice gardens and a dose of culture. Short walk from Harajuku station.

Peaceful oasis in the heart of Tokyo. The shrine is dedicated to the Emperor Meiji, who was instrumental in opening Japan to the outside world. In itself it is a small shrine, however it is surrounded by a 700,000 square-meter forest of 120,000 evergreen trees, donated from all parts of Japan. The gardens are beautiful and serene and take you away from the hustle and bustle of modern Tokyo.
monday morning at the Maiji Jungu Shrine. Beautiful temple surrounded by peacefull gardens - I was lucky to witness a traditional japanese wedding during my visit
A must see cultural visit. A must visit. If you can work it, do the walk on New Years day. Be prepared for a large crowd though!

Not much there.. Walking from Haraijuku station is a nice walk through the park up to Meiji Jingu.Having visited plenty of temples and shrines during my visit to Japan I'm not sure why this was rated so highly.We may have missed something but there wasn't much around to see.

serene place in the middle megapolitan city. visit this place in the late afternoon. It very easy to access this place from Harajuku stn on Yamanote line, from the station exit just go straight and turn right on the first crossroads then passed the bridge and you'll be greeted by Giant Torii. Stroll along the forest path (yes it's not a park but a small forest in the city) and you'll passed through sake or wine barrels. after 15mins stroll you'll be reach the Meiji Shrine. Pay a respect at the shrine by tossed a coins to the box; claps your hand twice then bow then again claps your hand twice. At the main hall you can see hundreds of small wooden boards that hangs below the big tree. In each boards there are wishes from visitors and blessed by the monks every morning, i found myself enjoy reading the visitor's wishes. there is fortune teller and stall that sells japanese charms for luck, health etc. Meiji Jingu entrance is free, but if you want to visit the inner garden and treasure house it cost 500yen each. When you leave the site don't forget to take pictures from the bridge, the sunset view with tokyo skyscrapers is magnificent.

Great walk to and through the Shinto Shrine and the Iris Garden is beautifully laid out. Very good place to walk and enjoy the trees. The Shinto Shrine is interesting with good history but could use more languages on the signs. The Iris garden (Meiji Jingu Garden) was very impressive and beautiful (and had good English on the signs). In August there were no Iris's blooming, but you can see that the Iris's are planted to look like a river running through the garden which must be spectacular when it booms. These were all gravel walkways so sandals will have you shaking stones out of your shoes. This is open on Mondays when many other attractions are closed.
relaxing place. very nice experience, place to get some shade and pray. we had a stroll in park, it was relaxing . very very nice

A beautiful escape from the city.. My husband and I enjoyed exploring this park like shrine. Walking through these grounds removed us from the city and allowed us to enjoy the nature surrounding us. There are multiple gardens to walk through and explore along with the exploring the shrine.There are bathrooms throughout the grounds.

Peaceful shrine. I went there on July 24 early morning as early bird after my flight NH814 arrived to Tokyo.There were peaceful walkway, great forest,lovely small pond,superb entrance and impressive shrine.My visiting day was hot summer day,but I arrived there about before 9 am was not very hot and not many tourist as well.But after 10 am,many tourist and Japanese family arrived there as crowded.I love fresh air from green forest.Normally shrine was quiet ,but our visiting time last week of July was very humid in Tokyo.If i have chance,wanted to see again in winter and autumn season.

Great Temple!. A massive set of temples within Yoyogi Park its the perfect activity if you are looking for a brake from Tokyo. The entire stroll would take a couple of hours if you want to do all the little traditional activities (from coin flipping to water drinking) but its a nice way of learning about the japanese culture. The Shrine itself has one of the biggest tori gates I ever seen and its has multiples paths around the park. A great place to visit after passing through Shibuya...!!!

Impressive shrine. We took the JR line to visit this famous shrine, located in a beautiful parc. Very interesting and well explained by a good handout and several signs. Very impressive and beautiful!

Beautiful shrine in the middle of a forest. Just a quick walk from the Harajuku area, this amazing shrine is located within a 200 acre forest was a site to see. The torii gates are 40 feet tall and greet you at the main entrances of the park. The shrine is very serene. It is free to visit but there are very specific rules to follow so please pay attention to signs. We saw a police officer stop a bike rider from entering the gate. For 500 Yen, you can purchase a wooden tablet to write down your own personal prayer to leave at the temple. The colorful barrels of sake were also a treat. Don't miss this spot!

Tranquility in the heart of the city. One approaches the shrine through a walk in a woody forest. It is tranquil, green and very humid in July. One can see the large caskets of wine and straw barrels of sake as offerings on both sides of the walk. The shrine is quiet, isolated and rather nice to visit in the heart of the city. We had a refreshment at the café in the park which was excellent.
Beautiful Shrine. Great peaceful shrine and a lovely walk through the gardens and parks. Early evening is a lovely time to take this stroll.

Very nice, not as nice as other places in Kyoto. Indeed, the walk through the park is quite stunning – so is the large gate. But otherwise this shrine is far from the ones you see in Kyoto. In fact, I would even suggest strolling around little local neighborhoods instead looking for small temples/shrines. These often have far more character. Been there, seen it. No need to go back.

Must-See site in Tokyo. This is a beautiful, serene oasis amidst the urban surroundings of Tokyo. A very moving experience not to be missed. The walk through the large wooded area to reach the shrine itself is wonderful.

Not to miss!. Getting to Meji shrine is amazing in itself, walsking through incredible gardens and parks. Do not miss the sort of botanical garden there is some 200m before the Meiji Jingu entrance, a most peaceful spot with a lake and beautiful gardens.The Meiji Jingu was one of --if not THE one- we liked the most of the temples/shrines that we visited in Tokyo. Very peaceful, with wide spaces (something rare for temples in Tokyio, maybe because it was not so crowded).Loved it.

A hidden gem within Tokyo. If you are looking for a place to escape the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, look no further. Even during the summer heat you can take a comfortable stroll down one of those wide paths. Don't forget to write in your wishes!

Oasis of Trees and Beauty. I was flabbergasted by the size of this lushously green park. The trees are gigantic and form a thick and foggy forest; an oasis near some of the busiest areas of the city. It creates a perfect escape to relax and to suck in a breath of fresh air. The shrine/temple at the center is also beautifully crafted and is a highlight of the park that shrine-lovers should not miss. There also lies an small handful of hidden path ways that can lead to beautiful walks and edo-period buildings; keep an eye out!

Peaceful spot in the City!. The Meiji Jingu was a 5 minute walk from our apartment and was a quiet, peaceful place to start the day. The tree lined entrance is like something from a fairy tale and the age and history oozes from the surroundings.We would go early in the morning before 9AM to avoid the gaggle of tour groups and buses. Only early risers and locals at this time and gives you the best chance for some unobstructed photos.

Beautiful. It is a beautiful spot with well-kept gardens and beautiful architecture, I recommend this for the end of your trip, so you can relax and stroll around and enjoy your last moments in Tokyo.

Power spot and a little escape from norm. . After the entrance, you would feel that this place has a lot of green and you would hear no sound of crowded city. This shrine is well known as a power spot and you would feel it when going. The shrine is big and very nice place to escape and refresh. Even in the summer, the air is fresh and you would feel the good power from Japanese historical shrine. The reason for this place to be know as a power spot is that the place is located on power trail which is protecting Tokyo area historically. It's one of the major power spot in Tokyo.

Beautiful gardens. Very peaceful, despite large crowds while we were there. It's quite a stroll but worthwhile to visit the shrines. Very hot during our visit but well shaded by trees. Timing is important as sometimes access is limited but otherwise a very nice visit with some majestic structures. Check out the sake barrels wrapped in straw and the multiple prayer trees/fortune tellers.
Calm and nice. If you need to relax and learn something new this is the place.It has alot of interesting historic information. And it's calm in the else very busy Tokyo.

Weddings, Weddings, Everywhere!. This is a must-see in Tokyo. The shrine itself has many pretty buildings and the grounds are lovely. Its a big place so even if it is very busy, there is plenty of space. This is an extremely popular place for weddings so if you visit on the weekend, you'll definitely see wedding parties dressed in traditional outfits. It is conveniently located for a visit combined with Harajuku or Shibuya but is worth the trip even if you only have time to visit the shrine.
Beautiful. Luckily visited on a boiling hot and sunny day in July. The crowds were quite low so it was perfect. Would definitely recommend.
Lovely and peaceful. Beautiful shrine. Even crowded, it was easy to appreciate its beauty. The walk to the actual shrine was looooong, but shaded by the tall trees. No entrance fee.
Simply beautiful. Amazed by the huge wooden gates, beautiful path way and beautiful temple. A must visit. Just next to harajuku station by JR and the famous takeshita street.

Something different, and beautiful!. The place looks so genuine, as it was built thousand years ago, although it was built relatively recently - around1922.Harmony and tranquility are unique. Japanese style architecture. It is another one of those "must see" places.It takes about one hour to get a good feeling of the place and to look at many interesting details around shrine yard. However, if you want to have a look at the whole lot (unfortunately we did not have time to do that) - gardens, treasure museum, martial arts training hall, sacred dance hall etc. you would probably need couple of hours, maybe whole morning.Nice shop half way between the shrine and entry on Harajuku station side. Wide range of souvenirs - pricewise and in terms of quality.Forest leading to shrine is very nice, enjoy every step you make at that place.It would be good to check their website before you go there so you can see if there are any events and at what time. We forgot to do that so we missed daily food offering ceremony (at 8am and 2pm).Have a snack and drink before or after you visit the shrine as there is no restaurant there, and you are not allowed to drink or eat on majority of the grounds as it is sacred area (see on their sitemap which area are exempt from that).

A little disappointed. The setting of this Shinto temple in a large park is a welcome relief from the bustle of Tokyo but the temple itself isn't spectacular. Maybe we were unlikely in visiting on a quiet day when there were no wedding parties etc to give the temple its cultural significance.

Great parcel of serenity in the middle of Tokyo. I visited Meiji shrine on my day off, while recovering from jet lag, prior to a week of meetings.
It is a peaceful and beautiful place. Definitely worth a visit before or after walking around harijuku.

Extraordinary . This is a large shrine in a large park. It is breathtaking in its size and a tribute to the Shinto religion. It was quite busy when we were there, but that didn't detract from its scale and beauty. To cap out the visit there was a wedding ceremony and the bride in all her finery was stunning and she didn't seem at all phased by the masses taking her photo as she walked around the shrine

IMPRESSIVE IN A PLAIN SORT OF WAY. Spent a few hours here walking around this beautiful forest area which contains the Meiji Shrine. This major Shinto Shrine is dedicated to the souls of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken, he passed away in 1912 and she in 1914. I thought they must be buried here but no they are buried near Kyoto. The Shrine was started in 1915 and opened in 1920.A magnificent Torii Gate 40 foot high welcomes you at the front entrance to this 200 acre complex which is in a forest setting. When the plan to build the shrine was put in place over 100,000 trees were donated from all over Japan and over seas and were planted by volunteers so that now nearly a hundred years later it looks and feels like a natural forest.When you walk through the front entry Torii it is still quite a long walk before you get to the actual Shrine but it is a lovely walk shaded by all these great trees.The shrine and other buildings are impressive in a plain sort of way, no glitz and bright colours just plain timber with a bit of metal trimming, bronze or copper I"d say. While we were there we were lucky to witness a wedding which was special, apparently this place is very popular for weddings. Very busy , seems every one want to visit the Meiji Shrine. To me it was very different to others I have seen , no great big areas of manicured lawns or gardens or shaped trees, just a lovely forest setting left to it's own devices to grow and prosper, very natural peaceful place. Maybe Meiji was like that I don't know, a no frills sort of guy who loved nature as it was .There is a gift shop and a couple of places to eat and plenty of rest rooms around the complex, admission is free. Just be careful when you leave the actual Shrine area and venture into the forest there are quite a few different tracks and it is easy to take the wrong one and get a bit lost and it is a big area. Lovely spot to visit, join the crowd and go see for yourself this Shrine built to remember the great Emperor Meiji.

Worth it! . Definitely worth a visit. We went here as part of a tour. The grounds are beautiful to walk around, and the French wine and sake barrels are quite a sight. The guide explained how to say a proper prayer by bowing and clapping. And kids enjoyed the process of learning how to wash hands and face at the special station with ladles.

early in the morning. The Shrine and temples were absolutely breath taking, i was glad they had information plaques in english so we could have a better understanding on some of the history of Japan (some historical places do not have this), the hike up and down was very refreshing

Worthwhile visit in Harajuku. Meiji Shrine is free to enter and is so worthwhile visiting! Located in Yoyogi park, the walk to the shrine takes a while but this doesn't matter because you're surrounded by magnificent trees and nature. Though the atmosphere is busy it is not frantic, there is still a sense of calm which I love so much.There's the option to pay your respects like the locals do by throwing a coin in the shrine and bowing, write a prayer or wish, or for 100 yen find out your fortune for the day. It's a wonderful way to spend a few hours before moving onto the busier areas like Harajuku.

A highlight . A highlight - shrine- that can be incorporated in your visit to Shibuya/Shinjuku or Harajuku. The park surrounding it is a beautiful oasis with the shrine in the middle. A bit of a walk, but well worth it. PS it's free.

Famous place. It is a famous place to visit, huge beautiful park, not far from a very busy station Harajuku. Walk into Meiji park, big trees and walk paths have been maintained so well, we found it is a very nice place to have relaxation.Lots of tourists, but you don't feel crowded at all. Most of all, it is free!!Must see place in Japan!!

Must visit!!. Meiji shrine is a must visit when in Tokyo. The surroundings are very beautiful and its like an oasis in the busy area of shibuya. I would recommend everyone to visit this place and spend time in leisure taking in the beauty of this shrine.

Peaceful tranquility in the heart of Tokyo. I visited on a scorching hot summer's day, and thoroughly enjoyed walking through the forest around the shrine. A wonderful spot for contemplation, or just to take a break from the bustle of tokyo. The shrine itself was no real surprise. I'd suggest the park is a bigger drawcard and more unique than the shrine (it's less than 100years old, after all).

Wonderful Shinto Shrine. This Shinto Shrine is not to be missed. The entrance torii is enormous, made from ancient cypress trees, and worth a visit alone. Honoring the spirits of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken, this is a beautiful place for strolling amidst history. The gardens surrounding the shrine are extensive and lovely. A Peaceful Oasis!

Gorgeous sanctuary in the middle of town!. Right behind Harajuku JR station, it's easy to combine with a visit to Yoyogi Koen, Takeshita Dori or Omotesando. Walk through the calm "forest" before coming upon the Shrine proper. You'll need about 90 minutes to see everything, but it's an interesting contrast from the rest of the bustling area. Do NOT go on New Years unless you really love a crowd :)

Great Place for Rest and Relaxation. This Shinto shrine is a free attraction. You will see great craftsmanship, par take in traditional customs, and feel at peace as you walk through the natural setting. Plan your trip with visitacity.

Popular and crowded. Meiji Jingu is a Shinto shrine for the emperor Meiji and his consort. The shrine is a big draw, of course, but the forest that one has to traverse to reach it is worth dawdling in, since it is entirely man-made, having been planted in 1921. The tall trees throwing gloomy shadows over the winding paths which lead to the shrine are an example of Japanese garden architecture which is not often seen elsewhere.You can cross the road from the Meiji Jingu Mae station on Tokyo subway to get to the park, and then follow the broad path to the right to reach the shrine. Almost all the time there are streams of tourists, so it is hard to miss. Watch for the tall gates (torii) on the way: these mark progressively more sacred spaces.The shrine has a fairly strict protocol, but tourists seem to be exempt from most of it. You may read about the history of Japan between the Meiji and Showa emperors to decide whether you want to follow the protocol or not. The kikunogomon (chrysanthemum flower) sign of the imperial house are visible everywhere.In the northeastern corner of the courtyard in front of the shrine you can see the wooden tablet called ema which contain messages from worshipers. A blank tablet costs 500 yen, and you are expected to inscribe a message on it and hang it here.If there are only two things you have time for in Tokyo, then this would be one.

Pure air area. The walk from Harajuku station to Meji Shrine is a calming experience after leaving the crowded city. Several enormous wooden torii's are strewn across the path before you reach the shrine itself.

Dedication to Emperor Meiji. Likes: The Shrine and temples were absolutely breath taking, i was glad they had information plaques in english so we could have a better understanding on some of the history of Japan (some historical places do not have this), the hike up and down was very refreshing. On some days you will also see a wedding ceremony take place wearing traditional ceremonial gownsDislikes: as per usual this is a top tourist destination and it was probably a bit too crowded for my liking, but thats my personal preference.

Pleasurable trip. Best to visit in the morning as it is a popular attraction. I reach the shrine at about 8am and there are already people coming back from the shrine. I was lucky to be able to see a wedding there! The shrine was huge and beautiful and, to the shrine itself is quite a pleasant walk as there are lots of trees around. But, I paid 500yen to its shrine garden I would say its okay but not much of a surprise. One downer is that there's drizzle when I was there.

Tranquility . Right outside the Harajuku station, the shrine is a favorite hangout. The shrine itself is not magnificent but some how it has a sense of tranquility even with the bustling of visitors. Meiji Shrine is beautiful with its Grand Torii gates and wide tree line pathway that takes you to the shrine. Lovely and peaceful park, its a perfect venue to go for an afternoon stroll.

Look, but Do No TOUCH!. Beautiful park situated between Shibuya and Shinjuku. Great for walking around, but all other activities are prohibited. I understand following the rules of the country you are visiting, but you should be able to at least jog in the open air. There are constant announcements to remind you of the no, no's. This means No frisbee, no soccer/football, no skateboarding, no music, no breakdancing, no anything. So pack a lunch with sandwiches and such, but leave the bbq grill at home, cause that is a NO, NO also
Beautiful!. An amazing, beautiful and tranquil temple. A good place to take a break from the busy Tokyo life, and to see some of the historical parts of Japan.

NIce place but nothing spectacular. Very tranquill place, even july rain didn't spoil its clam atmosphere, though i have expected smth more monumental but happy it was a part of a day-tour around Tokyo and that i was taken there by bus))

Worth to Visit but Better to Visit Except Summer. Great place to visit as you might visit Temple of Meiji and the big park next to it. Better to visit there except summer time as summers are mostly too humid, hot and rainy in Tokyo.

Interesting and situated in beautiful, peaceful park.. Interesting history and is situated in beautiful Yoyogi Park which is so tranquil for Tokyo. We went on a Sunday and saw some traditionally dressed Japanese brides having photos which was a highlight.

Meiji Temple haven of peace. The main Temple of Shinto , Tokio. Beautiful complex VERY peaceful. Was lucky to see a special ceremoniy with high ranking priester and Temple dancers. Also a traditional Japanese wedding. The Gardens on your left hand as you walk through the main avenue passing through the Large Tabu gate were planted by Emporer Meiji and his wife.
Peaceful and traditional. It is an interesting spot to learn about the Meiji time period in Japan's history. Quite a bit of walking required. The path is generally shady.

Peaceful place. Huge and beautiful park just two stations away from the worlds busiest train station. Even though there are lots of people there, the atmosphere is really peaceful. And if you go during weekend you might get to see a wedding party leaving the shrine.

Beautiful grounds, a nice break from the Tokyo bustle. This temple is located in a large wooded park, a path through the woods brings you to the temple itself. The temple is nice and the large wooden "mon" (gates) are apparently the largest in the world. I also really like the walk, it's very peaceful and quiet after the hectic Tokyo streets. When leaving the temple try exiting via the back and taking the secondary path back to the entrance. This option must not be well-known because we were alone and it was surreal walking down the path by ourselves through the woods in the middle of one of the highest density cities in the world. Definitely worth a visit.

Fascinating Shintu Shrine. This was the first Shintu shrine we visited, it was located in a lovely forest, the huge Torii gates were impressive, as were the beautifully painted saki barrels. It was interesting seeing a new baby dressed in a traditional robe being brought for a blessing.
The most beautiful park and shrine in Tokyo. I like this place, it's magnificent. This park (and shrine of course) are in my list of the most remarkable shrines in Tokyo and Kyoto.
My favorite temple in Tokyo.. One of my favorite places in Tokyo. We got to see the traditional wedding ceremony at the temple and it was amazing.

Nice Shinto Shrine surrounded by Woods. Meiji Jingu is a relatively recent Shinto shrine near Harajaku station on Yamanoto line. It is very nice location surrounded by woods. Plan on spending couple of hours. Limited eating options.
A place you should not miss. Wow.. we liked the ambiance and will visit again. We loved the traditional look and the peace of mind we had after the visit. People are very friendly and very helpful

A must see Sanctuary in Tokyo before shopping in hustle and bustle Harajuku.. A must see in Tokyo. Not only it's a great shrine for Emperor Meiji, it's really a great sanctuary for everyone in Tokyo with hundred years old trees. You can enjoy the great contrast between the tranquility and beauty of this Shrine and the shopping hustle and bustle of Harajuku. So, come here before you visit Takeshita-dori (street). If you are lucky, you can see brides and grooms in the fancy wedding kimonos.

Beautiful shrine. We were there early in the morning and found the shrine very quiet and peaceful. There is place to wash your hands before praying. It is something about this shrine that makes you feel peaceful as soon as you step inside the main gate.

Beautiful. Beautiful temple in a forest - it makes for a wonderfully quiet ambiance away from the chaos of Tokyo's streets. The temple is beautiful and peaceful, and we managed to catch a traditional Japanese wedding when we visited, which is apparently fairly frequent.

Great place but a long walk to get there. The Sanctuary is a jewel and it requires a long walk to get there after the metro station. Near elegant and lively Omotesando, where all the chic shops are, and exciting Harajuku, where the fashion victims and young people walk the streets. Can walk all the way to Shibuya; great place to visit and spend an afternoon

Popular shrine located within Yoyogi Park. I must say I'm not particularly fond of places of worship. The sight of many tourists (myself included) dragging their luggages through sand and gravel just to catch a glimpse of weddings, buying souvenirs and walking around shrine compound just turns me off further. The shrine is located at Yoyogi Park which is one of the larger green lungs if Tokyo and is worth a visit if you're near Shibuya or Harajuku, especially on weekends.
Beaufiful. As most of the shrines in Japan, this one is exceptionally beautiful. Surrounded by the lovely Yoyogi Park.
Meiji Jingu - A must. We walked a short distance from our hotel in Shibuya. The Shrine is awesome. Lots of tourists but nonetheless the huge arch ways and massive temple is awe inspiring.
A quite spot. A good excuse to exit the buzzing city and have a quiet walk and get a hit of spirituality. Nicely maintained and was not too crowded when I was there in June.

Awesome!. I went here on a Saturday morning and it was great. There were several people getting photographed for weddings in the fancy kimonos. Well worth going, and seeing that made it extra special.

Tranquil and Beautiful. Try to go first thing in the morning - the temple looks best in the morning light and it's a lot quieter. The walk itself is really peaceful and enjoyable. The temple is really pretty and you can post a wish or hang it for all to see. We were lucky enough to see a wedding whilst we were there!

Perfect for killing time. The meiji Shrine is perfect to get away from the Shopping hustle and bustle of Harajuku.
- It will probably take about 1 hour visit the shrine.

Not much to see but the trees.. Large expanse of wooded area around the shrine. The shrine itself is nothing impressive if you have seen the ones in Kyoto. They have a collection of wine barrels sent all the way from France as gifts. There was an area that claimed to have a sacred well and required 500 yen for entrance so we did not bother. There is what is said to be the highest Torii gate in Japan.There was not much to see and do. The only saving grace was a Shinto ceremony that involved a ritual with Shinto monks that was worth seeing and the chanting that followed.Yes this place is peaceful and quiet but the shrine itself is bordering on the austere.

A must see. The walk from Harajuku Station to Meiji Jingu makes you forget that you are in Tokyo.
