You feel as though you are walking through a forest, but for the faint sound of a train whistle.The 500 yen payment to explore the gardens was idyllic - especially the pond with an array of koi fish and at least one baby turtle. NOTE: the tea ceremony must be organised in advance.The temple is beautiful, and the ringing bell and clapping of hands provide a serene atmosphere.Also if you love shopping, it is right next to the busy streets of Harajuku - so you can make a day trip.
lovely atmosphere. lovely atmosphere and amazing shrine.unfortunately a bit of a walk through the park to get there (it was raining when we went)
Meiji remaining site. One of the Shinto shrine, temple that you must visit in Tokyo. The park near is great and the vibe of Japanese people around here is very interesting.
Don't miss. A relaxing walk through quiet old Tokyo with intrinsic foliage. Lovely temple worshipped by many. A must see site for one and all.

Very serene and green. Best way to get there is from the Harajuku station. The map would suggest getting off at Yoyogi and walking, but that walk was quite confusing and requiring you to cross the highway. Once inside the park, its beautiful, green, calming and very quiet. The shrine is lovely and you can easily spend few hours there. Please note that you cannot take your stroller on the level of the shrine, its not allowed. And you cannot sit anywhere on the steps immediately surrounding the Shrine as a token of respect to the deities. We saw Shinto weddings being conducted there on the day we visited.

Can't miss. A peaceful stroll in the park, Historic and cultural sites. Partake in a cleansing ceremony or blessing. Right off of Takeshita to see fun urban culture on live display. Easy transport by train and subway. Near ballpark, shopping district and infamous Takeshita.

Beautiful shrine, easy to get to!. Just had my second visit here and remembered why I wanted to come back. If you're going to visit a shrine in Tokyo, this is the one. Filled with culture and the most beautiful trees. It's very easy to find. Once you get off the Meijijingu station, you cross the bridge to enter the shrine. You will definitely know when you see it. Just follow the path and it will take you straight there!
There is better. As far as Asian temples go this one is average at best. It's a nice walk getting there, but it's actually not that big and not a lot to see.

Beautiful and relaxing. I had a lovely day walking around the Shibuya area, and it was really refreshing to see the sharp contrast between the busy streets of Harajuku and the serene atmosphere at the temple. Definitely a must-visit.

A serene and beautiful place. It was a most serene and tranquil place despite how many people were visiting, we saw a few couples getting married and dressed in traditional dress. The Garden are very beautiful and serene. It is well worth a visit .

A piece of quiet. The temple is located in a big park. There are only 2 entrances to this big park, so make sure you know where the entrance is. From the metro, it can be a bit tricky to find, as you need to walk under some mayor highway bridges to get there.Once arrived, the park is nice and quiet for Tokyo standards. There will be people but we didn't see any tour groups going around. The temple is very nice, but again, can't compare to Kyoto temples. However it's one of the best temple+area in Tokyo.
Relaxing, Calming experience. What a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon. A lovely park leading into a shrine. The day we were there the Bonsai display was outstanding to see

Pleasant & peaceful. The shrine, close to Yoyogi park and Harajuku, is so peaceful that you would never guess you're in the middle of Tokyo. Even the walk from the station to the shrine itself is tranquil, despite the number of tourists around. Once at Meiji Jingu, there are instructions on how to wash your hands before entering (though not everyone does this), and there are a number of gift stalls selling charms and fortunes. The shrine is pretty huge, and definitely worth the visit if it's your first time in Tokyo, and you're interested in the history and heritage of Japan.

Peaceful stroll through a beautiful place. A great place to go to experience such a contrast to the crowded streets nearby. It's a bit of a long walk to get to the main building shrine, but well worth it to experience the tranquility and beauty of the whole place.We were lucky to experience one of the biannual purification ceremonies on June 30th, which was presided over by a group of Shinto monks. The votives hanging under the tree in the courtyard were touching to read. The whole place had a very calming effect. A must see in Tokyo.
A beautiful shrine. Bring your walking shoes and take a walk through the forest environment to visit Meiji Jingu. There are some ancient gates and a beautiful bridge along the way. A must visit!
Meiji Jingu. Quiet and Green, Bring Camera. You can stay a whole day long.Meiji Jingu is the Japanese Shrine of Emperor Meiji. who had modernized Japan.

Great escape from the city. There's a lovely park surrounding the Meiji Jingu. After several days of shopping, partying and sightseeing in Tokyo the contrast to this quiet place was remarkable and refreshing. Recommended for people who need a break from the busy city!

green space. You can walk to the temple via the park entrance at Harajuku station, the park itself is a beautiful relaxed green space full of mature trees, right in the heart of Tokyo. Many foreigners visited the park and temple when we were there. The temple compound is large, there are shops selling special good luck charms in Japanese, and it possess a relaxed atmosphere with a sense of peace. There is a reasonably priced café in the park not far from the park entrance, good food and good service.

Come for the Irises in June. The complex is good - go to the treasure museums for more information on Emperor Meiji. If you happen to be in Japan in June, don't miss the Iris Garden that Emperor Meiji designed for his wife. Has the largest wooden torii gate in Japan.

Beautiful!. Just a short walk through the garden from the JR station, this shrine was stunning, and quite a popular tourist attraction! Just as beautiful as the Senso-ji Temple, but less crowded! We participated in placing a prayer board around the prayer tree, which is quite a sight to see, and only cost ¥500. However we didn't pay the ¥500 entrance fee to the surrounding garden, as we didn't feel it was as worthwhile as the shrine itself. When leaving the shrine, lookout for the souvenir shop, which has a really good variety of gifts for reasonable prices!

Beautiful and non-commercial. We fell in love with Tokyo, and were not disappointed with our visit to the shrine. Easy to find and unlike other countries, where this could have easily been made into a commercial 'attraction,' the shrine was a beautiful experience. There are clear instructions on how to wash your hands and mouth before you enter (an experience in itself!) and the grounds are incredibly. A must see for something that's so different from anything we've ever seen and experienced before.

Make sure to come on the mornings.. I went here on New Year's morning for the Hatsumode, which is a visit you pay on Shinto shrines during New Year's in order to wish yourself luck and pray to have a good year. The only con about Meiji Jingu is that you gotta come here on the morning because after 10 am, it's when it gets so crowded. Other than that, really good place to go if you wanna experience something cultural inside the center of Tokyo.

A place of tranquility. This shrine I believe is one of the most popular tourist spots and shrines located in Tokyo. There is a scenic walk to the shrine which is filled with lots of greenery. The gardens are very well kept. It is almost like you are walking in the woods. When you get to the shrine it is quite big. There was a traditional Japanese wedding going on the day that I visited. There's some tourist shops as well.

Beautiful, tranquil place. A tour guide insisted that we visit while near Harajuku. It was worth an hour to 90 minutes (after passing the gate, there is a walk of about 10-15 minutes before arriving at the shrine, which has a small souvenir stand and understated but lovely architecture). There are beautiful gates (Torii), the grounds are in a forest with large trees and the actual shrine is beautiful and good to see. The botanical garden was a little bit of a letdown but still nice. I think I might visit again some day if I have more time but am perfectly happy with the 60-90 minutes that we spent here.

Underwhelming. There is a nice scenic walk to the shrine and it is quite beautiful and peaceful. However, I didn't find there to be much to do once there. If you're short on time in Tokyo, it might not be a bad idea to skip this. But that could just be me as I probably don't appreciate the history or the cultural significance of the shrine.

A place to find peace and hope. I were totally marveled by this meiji as I arrived after looking at similar buildings in Tokyo. I particularly love the trees that grow around here. The walk through the stone-paved road was very very pleasant. The building itself is beautiful and stately. There are benches for you to sit while appreciating the architecture and the ambiance. Just too bad that I missed the garden which has iris blooming and didn't get to see any wedding ceremony. Will definitely be back if I am going Tokyo.

Positive Energy Hot-Spot - Get refilled here!. So Meiji Shrine was such a great experience. I wasn't templed fatigued yet (yes this is real, pace your temples or this will happen to you) and Harajuku is right around the corner from the temple. We were lucky enough to catch a glimpse of a wedding taking place within the temple grounds as well. Surrounding the temple are the gardens with a koi pond and a well. You have to pay an extra fee of around 500 yen, but it's worth it. The well is said to hold a concentrated amount of positive energy and if you touch the water surrounding the well you will gain some of it. To give you more of a visual of the temple and surrounding gardens watch my video on it here:Starts at 2:51 - https://youtu.be/LdDCscCVs80?t=2m51sThe video also suggest things to do in Shibuya, Shinjuku and Harajuku so feel free to check that out or any of my other videos that suggest places to visit in and around Tokyo. Hope you have a great trip!
Shinto weddings. Beautiful temple. Go at weekend and see Shinto weddings too. Easy to get to and close to yo yogi park which is worth a wander through too to see the japanese at play.

There is a Difference Between a Shrine and a Temple. Meiji Jingu is a Shinto Shrine because there is no Buddha in Shintoism. Buddha has Temples. The Meiji Shrine has quite a picturesque setting in a nicely manicured park. When visiting this Shrine make sure you see and read about the sake and wine gifts given to the Monks at the Shrine. You know when you are entering a Shrine because the entrance has a huge arbor type of structure with two uprights and two cross beams supported by the uprights. A nice stop when in the neighborhood.

Peaceful adventure so close to city. This is worth a visit if you're staying in Tokyo. It is a short walk from Harajuku station. When you first start the walk it feels a mile miles away from the busy city. It is very peaceful and cool among the big trees. Pack some good walking shoes to explore the different areas within.Most of the area is free but some sections require a 500yen fee to access it.

Peace and quiet in the city . A short walk from the subway, there were a lot of people heading over. Was lucky enough to see a wedding whilst there, albeit in the rain. Beautiful shrine and grounds. Well worth the visit.

Picturesque and Peaceful escape. Beautiful green escape inside the city. Feels so picturesque and peaceful despite the many tourists you'll find there. Make sure you've got some comfortable walking shoes on.

Great shopping and local insight. We visited this area twice - once on our own and also on a walking group tour we had booked. Was worth it on both occasions. Because it was the cherry blossom festival the whole area was in bloom and very attractive and in addition to that there was a feeling of seeing the full blend of Japanese culture - from ladies in kimonos to people in manga inspired outfits all eating noodles together in the sunshine. I also managed to pick up some lovely souvenirs from the markets in that area. It is an area where you feel the crush from the sheer volume of people though - not for the claustrophobic.

Very inspiring. Lovely and green, quiet. Find the English brochure on the protocol for approaching the shrine, so you understand what the visitors are doing. Walk over to the Meiji Museum to,see a collection of pictures showing the life of Emperor Meiji, who was the inspiration for the modern Japan we see today.

An oasis of calm in a sea of commotion. Despite the high number of people walking the wide gravel paths through the forest leading to Meiji Jingu, there is an atmosphere of tranquility and peace in what is otherwise a very hurried and busy city. You pass through a couple of torii gates and a rack of sake barrels on the way reminding you that this is Japan. There is a beautiful courtyard with lovely trees leading up to the huge shinto shrine itself. A spectacular sight for a visitor to Tokyo! We went in the late afternoon and also witnessed a wedding, adding to the beauty and serenity of the place.

A haven of nature and the feudal japan inside of Tokyo. In the middle of busy Tokyo lies the meiji jingu, a beautiful shrine surrounded by a large piece of nature. You can get to the shrine by the mother road, which is an easy access, or you can make a small detour through the small forest and watch some of the typical flora of Japan.Don't miss the garden can be found close to shrine, a lovely haven to rest your weary feet.
good for the sight seeing in japan. easy access from metro station, harajuku is very closed. This place is famous for `Power Spot` in Japan.

Huge Shrine!!. This is a really big shrine compared to other shrines that I have visited. It is definitely worth a visit!!
You can also get your fortune for 100 yen at one of the stands. You should also try paying respects to the Emperor Meiji by praying and throwing a coin for blessings.

Tranquility in the middle of Tokyo. The shrine and associated gardens are a short train trip from Tokyo central, and the station is adjacent to the shrine entrance. The walk from the entrance to the shrine is along a beautiful tree lined gravel roadway and you pass under magnificent tori gates. We were lucky because on arrival at the shrine we witnessed a Shinto ceremony complete with haunting music and beautiful slow motion dancing by four costumed young women. The entry to the shrine is free, but there is a charge for entry to the inner garden. Well worth it.
Serene shrine amid Tokyo. We visit in the late afternoon and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere. A lovely spot for calming and refreshing. You should spend a few hours here, recommend it!

Nice quiet place to visit. A walking distance from the train exit. The walk in to Meiji Jingu was a relaxing one as you enjoy the peacefulness of the greenery surrounding the area. An eye opening experience, worth a visit if you are dropping by Shibuya. Along the way in, you can visit the gift shop and get kitschy souvenirs like sakura tea with real cherry blossoms or hand stitched magnets.

Peaceful air in a bustling city. From the gravel paths framed by beautiful woods to the imposing torii gates built out of cedar logs, Meiji Jingu as well as the surrounding Yoyogi Park sends a refreshing breath of air for your body and soul.

Not for tired feet.. The park is huge, green and well kept. You need to walk quite a bit to reach the shrine and pay a bit to see the garden. Good for evening stroll for the elders. Not so much for the youngs. The entrance is at the corner of Harajuku Stn of the JR Yamanote line. Take the Omotesando exit.

Must sightseeing spot in Tokyo. This is very touristy attraction but together with Yoyogi park very recommended to visit when in Shibuya. For first time visitors not easy to unerstand sense of the shrine but maybe after reading some books and Internet searching we will need second visit to get closer to Japaneese culture and tradition.Very Recommended.

Serrene Shrine and Gardens in a busy city. Loved this park and shrine. It was hard to imagine that it sits in a busy city. Its easy to find. We got off the JR Yamanote Green line in Harajuku; the entrance here is a minute from the train station. Admission is free unless you take a side path to see another exhibit - that was 500 yen. There so much greenery - tall trees mask the street noise. There's a lot of walking to get to the shrine. There is a vendor selling various omamori.

Attractive shrine and gardens. Just off the subway, a walk through the forest takes you past a massive gate to a fascinating shrine. The latter, while impressive, takes very little time to see. Fortunately, there is a garden nearby (small admission fee) which adds to the value of making the trip; when we were there, the irises were in bloom and there was quite an expanse of them
Impressive. It's good to see the temple inside the big park but you have to walking inside. Don't forget to bring walking shoes cause it's a long walk. Good a fortune teller too :)

Beauty adjacent to the train tracks. It's hard to believe such beauty and tranquility is hidden right next to the JR tracks. This is a nice outing to do before or after heading down Takeshita-dori. It's a complete contrast with it. I was in a hurry but was able to see quite a bit of it in about 30 minutes. I was walking a bit fast. This can be a tranquil place to saunter through while checking out the peaceful trees and shrines.

The best Cultural in Japan. Here is the origin of Shinto religion emerged. Amazingly this temple has a large garden, and a well-maintained forest in the middle of the modern city of Tokyo. Facilities This temple was very complete, as the place I guess, a best and largest temple in the city. I strongly encourage you to come to this place, especially to know the diversity of cultures and religions in Japan.

Wonderful nature. The quietness is wonderful. It's a beautiful place and we observed 2 weddings while visiting, which gave a beautiful impression of the "old days". The place, while visisted by tourist, commands a quiet attitude, so despite the people you could easily enjoy it there.It's close to Yoyogi park and the bustling city.

History and serenity. History and serenity in the middle of the city. We walked there from Shimbuya (maybe it is better to take the subway). The temple is so wonderful, we stayed for 3-4 hours, savoring the ambience. After that, went to Harajuku for my teen to see the heretic places.

The Park around the shrine is worth a stroll. The Meiji-shrine was on our sightseeing list because we thought it would be a nice place to visit for newer japanese history. When we got there, we walked from the entrance past the bridal showroom to the first torii. We passed the sake barrels and went past the torii. The forest around the shrine is wonderfully cool and quiet, especially on a hot day in Tokyo. When we passed by the washing basin, which was very beautiful, and the second gate, we saw the shrine. The shrine is very plain and can not be visited, you can only make a sacrifice and hang a prayer. Also the two bound together trees to the left are very beautiful and inspiring, but all in all its plain, not as overloaded as the temples in Kyoto. The way back to the praking spot is very quiet and shady to walk and I would really recommend that.
Very nice. Very pretty shrine and walk up to the shrine. But very easy to get lost. You can also see traditional Japanese weddings. Very good experience.

Peace and tranquility in middle of the city. It's amazing that there is a beautiful shrine in the middle of the city. It's a good 12 mins walk to the shrine but the walk itself is enjoyable. There are the wine barrels along the way and everything is signposted with historical facts.It's worth it to pay extra to visit the gardens. If you're lucky you can see a wedding going on especially at the weekend Well worth visiting in Tokyo
Unexpected. A beautiful place to visit in central Tokyo, escape the noise and wander round the park and visit the shrine of Meiji, totally unexpected in the middle of such a vast city

lost in paradise. As soon as I arrived at the entrance, I felt calm and peaceful.I did not spend much time at the shrine where were crowded, but wandered along the walk ways into the lush of green trees. Huge oak trees extend their branches as if to protect us from the sunlight.I simply was lost in serenity. It's hard to believe this park situates in the center of busy city. The shrine is simple yet elegant.There were 3 couples get married on that Saturday. I was lucky to have a glance of simple, quiet ceremony.

Must see for history buffs!. We visited the shrine and spent about an hour and a half wandering around enjoying the park area. There are signs located throughout the area explaining the importance of specific things in the park, such as the sake barrels. It's really beautiful and can easily be covered in about an hour.

Relaxing place. Forget for a few hours the stress of Shibuya at the Meiji Jingu. Go to the Imperial Gardens and relax there on a bench next to the pond. We went during the Sunday afternoon and manage to see a beautiful traditional wedding in the temple's yard.

Not one of my Favorites in Japan. It took me forever to visit Meiji-Jingu! I lived in Tokyo, 30 minutes by foot away and didn't visit this place until a few weeks ago. For good reason, it turns out. Meiji-Jingu is a very well-known shrine, I'll give you that. But the trek to get to the actual shrine is just unpleasant. It's deceivingly well-located right outside of Harajuku station, and the torii gate is big, awe-inspiring and whatnot (not the most pretty; go to Kyoto's Fushini Inari or Hiroshima's Itsukushima for that), but the trek to get from the entrance/torii gates to the actual shrine is pretty long (a good 5-10 minutes) of big chunks of gravel, so BE PREPARED TO WEAR COMFY SHOES you're not afraid to get a little dust on and BUG SPRAY. The fashion boots I wore didn't have enough support at all for the gravel and I ended up with pretty grey shoes at the end from all of the dust. It's also a nice little escape from the hub-bub of Harajuku, since it has its own park, but that also means mosquitos in the summer.The shrine itself is like any other; I didn't think there was anything remarkable about it, but then again, I'm not a history buff and I've been to 2 of Japan's most famous shrines & 1 very well known temple before visiting here, so it's not the most fair comparison. BOTTOM LINE: If you're only stopping in Tokyo, by all means, go. Otherwise, save it for Kyoto and Hiroshima. Heck, Nara's Todaiji is even better than this, simply because there are deer that roam around temple grounds (which Hiroshima also has, but isn't advertised for some reason).

I'd like to think of this as the Arashiyama of Tokyo. Ok, not really an apple to apple comparison but visiting this shrine elicits the same feeling of wonder and awe (well, in my case :D). This is my most favorite shrine so far. So beautiful, peaceful, GREEN. I agree with some reviewers who says that there has a spiritual feeling to it. In shory, it's a very ethereal place.
Visit the garden. This shrine is one of the best in Tokyo, but the garden is what is the most beautiful. You pay 500-600Y bit is well woth it. Don'T hesitate to enter here. We got some pretty photos.

Peaceful. We entered on the opposite side of the main Harajuku entrance, which allowed us to start off our walk with very little disturbance. The path was beautiful, and the main shrine was amazing. It got a little crowed near the main building, but the overall experience was very enjoyable.
Oasis. After two days of stunning but hectic Tokyo, these grounds give you a bath of relaxation, clean air, beatifull temple and gates and wonderfull,flower gardens.

One of the nicest shrines in all of Tokyo. This shrine for me was one of the most special in the Tokyo area. It has a real spiritual feeling to it and the park that surrounds it is beautiful. When you are in the shrine it does not feel like you are in the middle of the largest city on the planet - amazing

Pleasant walk and greenery. If you are lucky, and visit on an auspicious day on the Japanese calendar, you may be lucky enough to see the traditional wedding in procession. Looks like a royalty wedding in action.
Fun to Watch. Tip: Order a Starbucks and sit up on the second level and look down on the crossing, so much to see!
stunning. a beautiful place to spend an afternoon, walking round taking in the scenery and also free, this is a must on any trip to tokyo and if you are lucky you may catch sight of a wedding

Very nice park and shrine.. Get off on Harajuku station (JR Yamanote Line) and by walk only 5 minutes get to Yoyogi park which is very big and nice and free. In park is very nice shrine Meiji Jingu. In shrine we saw typical japanese wedding. In area is also garden and house but you have to pay for it.

Stunning. The park is beautiful with a varied assortment of oak trees. The shrine is hidden amongst the trees. We were lucky to see two wedding parties, as we were there on a Sunday. Must see for first time visitor to Tokyo.

Nice temple and Toriie. A place in Tokyo, really worth to visit. A big tory in the entrance. A beautiful park surrounding it and a temple visited by many japanese (specially families) with kimonos and special clothings. We also saw three different brides and families and also an unusual wedding ceremony (very interesting!).Even though many people come to visit this temple, the area is quiet silent, very different to other Tokyo areas!

Lovely park and beautiful shrine. I walked up here from Shibuya, which was an easy walk and a nice transition from shopping madness into a quiet park with greenery and lovely architecture. There were still a good number of people there, so I'm glad I wasn't really traveling during high season. Of course, there isn't a ton to do here, but it's well worth the walk through and visit to the shrine. It's nice Japanese architecture, and I happened to be up at the main shrine giving my offering when some special family was taken in for a blessing, which resulted in them banging the drum several times -- lots of reverberation and a sense of their ceremonial rites. There were also a variety of lovely bonsai trees around the arcade in the inner courtyard. If I was going back, I'd probably have gone into the formal gardens area even though I think there's a fee. I missed the iris gardens, which I think were probably in there.

Just go. A must see place ..it is so quiet and calm in tbe middel of this gigantic and busy mega city but still so relaxing and nice..just stroll around and enjoy the silence and watch locals do their thing...a must go place and easy to find by subway

An unexepected walk into tranquility.. Right outside the Harajuku Station, the shrine seem to be a favourite hangout for many cosplayers at the entrance and they were very willing and friendly to take photos with you. The shrine itself is not magnificent but somehow it has a sense of tranquility even with the bustling of visitors, everyone was polite, quiet and obedient. You do not hear shouts and talking at the top of their lungs unlike the Chinese temples. Other than a place of religious worship, it is also a perfect venue to go for an afternoon stroll....

Beautiful park and Shrine.. A really beautiful park and Shrine. We visited during the new year festivities, and found the crowds of people not too overwhelming. The location of the park is very close to various major metro stations, which makes accessing the area very easy. Harjuku is a great place to visit after you have been for a leisurely stroll. Ometosando is also not too far away, this area has beautiful; shop, cafes and restaurants.

Historically significant... but dull. The Meiji Shrine is large, lovely and historically significant. But quite frankly there are plenty of shrines in Japan and this is far from the most impressive. If you have a low tolerance for such things (ie. only plan on seeing a few such sights with a more pop-culture spin on your Japanese trip) I's recommend some of the shrines in Kyoto or Hiroshima instead.
Meiji Jingu. Was fortunate enough to not only see the Shrine but two Japanese weddings in progress. Also visited the magnificent Iris gardens.

Nice change of pace. Lovely, peaceful park. Like all tourist attractions therewere a lot of people but the park is large enough to not make it feel crowded. We also saw a wedding procession when we went. We also went on a day where they were taking tourists to a free tea ceremony, apparently this only happens once a year but you get the full experience without the hefty price tag!

Peace amid the chaos. Ok, maybe "chaos" is a bit strong. But, Meiji Jingu does give some respite from the busy area surrounding the park. The Meiji Jingu is dedicated to the spirits of the Emperor Meiji and his wife. When we were there, we happened to see several VIPs paying their respects in the central sanctuary. There are some huge wooden torii gates in the park and the walk from the busy road to the shrine is beautifully peaceful. You can also see many barrels of sake which were donated to the shrine. As with other shrines, you can leave written prayers. There are also many different types of trees in the forest which were donated from all over Japan when it was first constructed. Overall, this is a great, scenic place to enjoy away from the noise of Shibuya.
Beautiful Park. I definitely recommend taking time to visit Meiji Shrine, especially if you don't plan on visiting many parks/shrines while in Tokyo. It's not TOO big, and is very peaceful.
Really peaceful. Take the Chiyoda Lina or Fukutoshin Line and get off at Meiji-jingumae station. It's a good place to relax, specially after to go the Takeshita Street.

A world away from the craziness of harajuku. If your going to be spending a day in harajuku, then you might as well come to this beautiful park. Its a world away from the craziness of harajuku, and the arresting 300 year old tree is just beautiful to look at.

A sanctuary in busy Shibuya. Meiji Jingu or Shrine is a quiet refuge from the bustling city. In fact, it is located amazingly within the busy Shibuya area. Here you can find aged Cedar and Pine trees planted by locals over time. The shrine is dedicated to Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shōken. If you happen to visit the place on a Saturday, you'd be lucky enough to witness Shinto wedding rites. You will also be able to do Shinto rituals while inside the Shrine complex.
Nature Walk. Park in the middle of a big city is a privelege, wish we have this back home. I can walk here all day and unwind. No pets and not sure about alcohols..

Maybe impressive if you don't go outside Tokyo. There's a lot better in Japan than this, but if you're visiting the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, then this is probably a cool place to chill out. Pro tip: Don't bother paying for the little section tucked away on the long walk around. There's not much to see.

Always a favorite. After 30+ trips to Tokyo, Meiji Jingu remains a favorite. While very busy on a Saturday or Sunday, it is always beautiful and peaceful. Over a weekend you will often see a wedding party. The Iris in the Inner Garden are currently in full bloom. Gorgeous and well worth the 500 Yen admission fee.

Great intro to Japan. Our family visited here on the first day of our two week stay in Japan. A great way to experience Japanese culture in a quiet forested area of downtown Tokyo. Also a nice activity to undertake while trying to overcome jet lag. Easy walk for our nine year old. Be sure and check out the 300 year old Bonzai tree at the shrine. Incredible!

Wedding central. If it was not for the back-to-back-to-back traditional shinto weddings that were occurring here, I would give this two stars. The shrine is nice but not anything outstanding. It was also extremely crowded with tourists and locals alike. We got lost walking here through the surrounding gardens, and consequently wasted about 45 minutes getting there. The best way to access the shrine without the park detour is to get off at Yoyogi station. The shrine entrance is maybe a five minute walk from there. If you do end up going on a weekend (as we did) you are more than likely going to see several wedding processions and ceremonies, which are interesting and worth taking pictures of. If you need a respite from the city noise, the gardens are worth a visit. Very pretty paths with lots of old-growth trees. There are many bathrooms interspersed around the park, so don't fret about that.
Relaxing. It as a very relaxing experience as the place was a big contrast from the hustle and bustle of Shibuya. The breeze was so cool and fresh. Try paying your respects in the main shrine.

Neat place and great find in the heart of the city. Amazing shrine that to get to, you had to walk through a park that made you feel somewhere other than one of the larger cities in the world. As for the temple itself, impressive but I guess some of the magic was lost on me. It was old, yes but much had been rebuilt. I enjoyed the walk there more than the destination.

Must See. This is a beautiful area and it's very relaxing. Very large area and a great escape from Tokyo for a few hours. Of course it wouldn't be Tokyo without a shrine in the area. The shrine was alright, but the real enjoyment here is just walking around nature.

Meh. If you are into history, Japanese culture, or just plain pretentious, I say go for it. But, for the average casual traveler, there are literally hundreds of better ways to spend your limited time in Tokyo. Just being honest. No harm intended. P.S. the food court is merely average.

Must-visit shrine in Tokyo. We loved Meiji Jingu - after our previous day spent in busy Tokyo, we were excited to find a shrine in the middle of a forest. Other reviewers have commented on how relaxing it was, and we agreed. There was a wedding during our visit (around 10 am) at the main part of the shrine. We also spent some time walking around the wooded areas.For those of you using Google Maps to navigate - we ended up walking at least 30 minutes more than we needed to to take a northern entrance to the shrine. While there is a lovely forest path there and we enjoyed our walk through the local neighborhoods, follow the groups from the Harajuku entrance if you don't feel like taking an extra walk.

A lovely shrine and park.. This is a lovely shrine, located within a vast beautiful park.While the shrine itself lacks any "WOW" factor, it is still worth the 20-30 minutes walk in the park from its entrance to reach the shrine.The park is also a popular place for joggers, so planning to jog there is also a possibility.I think the best time to visit the shrine and park is in the late afternoon during the summer, when there's still light, but the temperatures had dropped a bit. This time provides the best photo-ops of the shrine.

Beautiful as always. This is the first ime I visited Meiji Jinggu at summer. The forest was so verdant, and the scent of the aromatic cedar trees fills the air as you walk past the main Tori gate.An oasis in the midde of the city , unimaginable calm when you just came from the nearby Harajuku area. love it then, still live it now.Mersmirizing and calming and lucky us we are able to catch a Shinto marriage rite going on. You can reach this place by JR Harajuku station or the MeijiJunggumae station on the Metro subway line, more straightforward and easier to find at the later line because the walk over to the shrine is more straight forward.

Must Go Especially If It Is Your First Time in Tokyo. Such a beautiful shinto shrine/park in the middle of busy Tokyo. Shinjuku Goen is nice too but it lacks the historic/temple experience that Meiji Jingu offers. Sensoji offers the temple but not the park like setting, All to say, Meiji Jingu offers a lot and for free! The grounds are open early in the morning and I believe closes at dusk. Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful Shrine in Tokyo. This Meiji shrine is located near Harajuku. It is like a little forest. You will feel fresh and relaxed here. The giant wooden Torii at the main entrance is amazing. Some days, if you're lucky, you will see a Japanese wedding ceremony at the shrine. It takes 10 minutes walk from the entrance to the shrine.

A good way of learning about the Meiji Era. I would definitely advice to visit this big garden when staying in Tokyo. The shrine building is a representative example of Japanese shrine architecture. After its destruction by fire during the World War II, it was reconstructed in the fifties. The gates of the garden are among the most photographed in Tokyo. A visit of the treasure museum (there is a small fee for this) is worth since it contains a lot of information on the Meiji era. The same goes for the outer garden (there is also a fee for this part). There is also a Meiji Memorial hall which is currently used as wedding hall. If you are lucky, you will be able to bring back home some pictures of a Japanese wedding!

Go on a Sunday for weddings. We visited this lovely place on a Sunday and were lucky enough to witness a wedding which was great for pics. It's a lot of walking along the wide tree lined avenues. This park is HUGE. The sake barrels also made great photo ops. There is plenty to see and do here. You have to pay to enter the garden inside which we did. It was pretty with a traditional well, pond and tea house. Easy to access on the JR line and well worth a trip.
beautiful. a must see when coming to tokyo - the stroll and the quiet is a nice brake from the city, the garden that you pay 5yen to go in to is also def worth a look

Serene and beautiful. Arrive early for a beautiful morning walk in the middle of a bustling city. We arrived at 7am on a Wednesday morning and shared our trip with just a handful of Japanese commuters. The park is beautiful and well kept. The shrine is gorgeous and interesting. As we were exiting around 9am, we passed hoards of tourists and school children entering. Highly recommended to go before 9!

The beauty and calm is overwhelmed by the crowds!. Meiji Shrine is beautiful with its grand torii gates and wide tree line pathway that takes you to the shrine. The setting is beautiful but perhaps it was because this was a Sunday morning, there were tons of tourists like ourselves crowding into the main hall. I think its a glorious space that should be meditative. Instead, you stand there jostling with the crowds. I would try to go on a weekday, perhaps early in the morning.

Tranquil and Peaceful. I went to the Meiji Jingu Shrine on 16 May 2015. It is located at the JR Yamanote Line - Harajuku Station. What is great? The surroundings were peaceful, quiet and tranquil. You feel extremely at peace when you step into the compound. What to see or do? Well, I saw at least 4 to 5 lovely Japanese weddings and a lot of the tourists were taking their photos. The funny thing was that some of those ushers for the couples asked me if I was a guest of the couple, not just one couple but at least for two couples. You will also be able to write your sincere wishes onto a piece of paper and put it inside a envelope and deposit into a box. Alternatively, you can purchase a wooden board and write your wishes and hang the wooden board onto the display standees. My highlight was to purchase the amulets from the Meiji Jingu Shrine. As it was my first time in Tokyo so I was sort of overwhelmed with all the fanciful beautiful amulets and I got myself 11 amulets. They had all types of amulets from love, health, luck, marriage, relationships, air travel safety, study, etc. The average price of each amulet is JPY800.

Historical and spiritual. Our group visited the Meiji Shrine .The walk into the shrine is along wide ,tree lined paths which set the seen for the actual temple.We were fortunate to have the honour of undergoing a purification ceremony in the temple conducted by the Shinto priests.A very interesting and intriguing experience.Well worth going to for the history alone but try to do the ceremony

Very peaceful and calm place. The shrine is spread over a huge space and visiting it gives very peaceful and calm feeling. One can also witness Japanese traditional marriage if you are there on Sunday.The main shrine compound is not open to public and hence one can only pay respect from its entrance. There is a iris garden which is accessible with a free of 500 Yen. The garden is nice.

Beautiful and tranquil. Located just by the busy streets of Harajuku, the calm forested shrine is a perfect escape from the hustle and bustle. Tranquil and spiritual. Try to visit on weekends, if you're lucky you get to see a traditional Japanese wedding as well.

Oasis in midst of the city hustle & bustle . Serenity and calm in the midst of all the city crowds. It was relatively crowded as it was a Sunday. Saw several weddings at the Shrine which normally takes place on weekends. Allow a couple of hours to walk around including the paid entrance to the gardens (¥500).
Rich Cultural Experience. This was a real treat, to experience the impressive shrine, get to understand the traditions, see some local weddings.

Quiet beauty. Serenity & tranquility in a totally oasis like surroundings deep in the heart of bustling Harajuku.
Somehow its quiet transcends the city as the forest of green comes alive before your senses.
So peacefully beautiful.

Tranquility amongst the chaos. Nestled between the crowded hubs of Shinjuku, Shibuya and Harajuku is this 70 hectare park housing the Meiji Shrine. We entered from the northern entrance which was very quiet. The more we made our way towards the Meiji Shrine the more the crowds built which unfortunately takes a little away from the experience but can't help everyone wanting the same thing. Definitely pay the entrance fee to see the Iris Garden!

Japanese shrine in a forest. this is the shrine dedicated to Meiji Emperor. you may appreciate the cultural atmosphere but you can simply enjoy the nature. actually the forest and the park are quite refreshing. the location is perfect for tourists who also visit Harajuku or Omotesando.

quiet oasis. this is for the tourists who don't want the nonsense of tourist trappings. no shops, no food. just a quiet jinjya (temple) . on weekends i've noticed weddings which is a real treat photo wise for tourists. Traditional japanese wedding attire.The road to the temple is gravel and stone , heels not a good idea.

Beautiful. Incredibly nice place in the middle of Tokyo. Really nice to walk around the park late afternoon. Peaceful. Would recommend late pm or very early morning to be able to enjoy the atmosphere.

Nice piece of calm and nature inside the heart of Tokyo. Close to Yoyogi Park, the shrine is in a place of pure calm and serenity. A good change of pace for those wanting to know a different side of Tokyo

Beautiful shrine in central Tokyo. Meiji Shrine is located in a large forested area, near the Harajuku Station in central Tokyo. The entry into the shrine grounds is marked by torii gates made of wood. During weekends, traditional weddings can be seen taking place here. The shrine's visitors can write their wishes on an ema (wooden plates). Meiji Shrine is definitely a must see in Tokyo.

A contrast of natural/spiritual and cool Tokyo metropolis . The long approach is lovely for photos, and if you hope to capture a glimpse of a traditional Japanese wedding, visit Meiji Jingu on a Saturday. Remember that visiting this Shinto shrine is an important, sacred space for Japanese people and enshrined here are imperial souls. The near by Harajuku will shock you with the contrast of modern, fast-paced and cool Tokyo youth culture.

Worth a visit.. The greenery, the forested area, the old structure of the shrine, the cleanliness. Worth a visit on day that's not too warm. It also has a separate enclosure for a Garden. Unfortunately you have to pay separately for that. The premises have their usual share of touristy shops selling "religion-related" items, so if you're looking for a sublime spiritual experience, this isn't the place. But its good to see from the historical point of view.

Nice Shrine. It is located steps away from the Harajuku train station, depending on what exit you use. It is a large area to cover; therefore, if you would like to see the shrine, the garden, the treasure museum, and the other facilities on site, I would allot a few hours of your day. There is no admission charged; however, the is a 500 yen maintenance contribution for guests entering the gardens or the well. I did not visit either. I saw the main shrine and was able to watch a photo shoot for a traditional Japanese wedding. It was pretty crowded but worth the hour or so I spent there.

Nice shrine, great surroundings. A nice shrine, which has a large courtyard. You can catch couples getting married in the traditional Shinto style here, and see the husband-wife tree. Also interesting are the big kegs of wine from France and the large cups for the Japanese wine kept on either side of the path leading up to the shrine. The shrine is surrounded by large trees that make you forget that you are in Tokyo city. A nice, relaxing visit, but be prepared to walk a little.

Peaceful Shrine. It was part of the Tokyo day tour I booked through Viator. This was the first stop. The Shrine is right in the middle of the city, yet the atmosphere is so calm and peaceful. Once you enter this area, you will forget you are still in the city. We got to witness a wedding procession as well and it was fun.

Serene, understated shrine. This Shinto shrine, built to honor the late 19th century emperor and empress who brought modernization to Japan, is very pleasant and serene. Because you reach the shrine through a forest, it's hard to believe that it is located in the middle of Tokyo. You feel like you're miles away. As we went on a Sunday, we saw a wedding where most people were in traditional garb.

A shrine for the soul. A 200 acre park . A 1500 year old cypress. A calm that envelopes you as you walk past the 40 foot high torii gate. This is a shrine ? For those familiar with Asian places of worship – the crowds, the noise , the push, the let’s get the tourists as they come – this would be an experience that will calm your mind. As you walk up you see the impressive gate. We hear the Torii gate marks the boundary between the sacred world of the shrine and the profane world outside. Those from India might note a Buddhist influence to the gate, spotted in some of the Buddhists sites back home . From the place marked to purify your hands and mouth as you enter, to watching a ceremony in progress, the emotive tablets you can write on the prayer wall, instructions on how to pray – this is a welcome prayer place. We believe it is the place many gather on Jan 1, to welcome the new year. As we visited during the Golden Week in May we also got to see some ceremonies . It is a calming and reverential experience amidst the serenity We came back with admiration and curiosity – and reached online to know more about Shintoism . Such is the power of the shrine.

SHRINE ON A LARGE SCALE (PART OF A DAY TOUR). We visited this shrine as part of a day tour. It was wonderful. We had time to see everything and take photos. The tour cost 9,800 Yen including lunch. We visited the Tokyo Tower, Imperial Palace East Garden (from a short distance), Hama-Rikyu Garden and had a river cruise as well.A full day, but we couldn't have done it on our own. The company we used were called The Grey Line. It is IMPORTANT to ensure that the tour company will return you to your hotel as two other companies would drop you at a railway station, for you to find your own way back. you would be dropped off at "Rush Hour". Even Grey Line offered to drop us at a station; no one took them up.

Very interesting. If you come toTokyo, you need to visit this place. It is very cultural and government has look after very well. Even Though there are a lot of people in a day but it is worth a visit.
Nice place . I went there at the early morning and we forgot that we are in city. High and denst trees and nice looking rill. Their were some historical figures and it has a description in English.

A fine shrine and gardens. Well worth a visit when in Tokyo but I thought it was not nearly so interesting as the shrines I visited in Niko, Nara and Kyoto. The most interesting thing for me here was the amount of wedding photos being taken - and the effort they go to with personal groomers and an array of photographic equipment.

serene and sobre. After a long but pleasant walk through the large Tori gate we washed our hands in a traditional way before entering the shrine.In the compound we were treated by sighting a small procession of marriage ceremony. How beautiful and graceful the bride was ! Her headgear in particular was very different and plain but still very classy.Then we walked to the other end of Yoyogi park walking past the blessed Sake cases beatifully painted and displayed and joined the hoardes of people to enjoy the Hanami parties.

Most Peaceful Place in Tokyo. This was my favorite place in Tokyo. I went here early on a Monday morning (7am) and it was so quiet and peaceful. There were very few people around and it was wonderful to be able to walk through the forest to the shrine. The shrine was beautiful and atmosphere was just of complete serenity. I know the shrine gets very busy later in the day, so if you want it to yourself go early on a weekday.

Absolutely fantastic!. It'a pearl! Shinto shrine located in the heart of Tokyo. Built in the beginnig of the last century, destroyed duiring WWII, it was re-built in 1958. Made only from wood: for example, the main gate is made of 1500 years old cyprus! Beautiful park around. Just must be there!

A very serene and quiet place ......... A very serene and quiet place compared to 'loud' Takeshita Street on the opposite side of the Harajuku railway station. Even on crowded days, the walk to the shrine proper is enjoyable. The huge tori gate is impressive enterring into the shrine precinct. Also is the arranged display of the drums/barrels of sake. The shrine is a popular spot for Japanese weddings. We were lucky enough to see two Japanese brides dressed in their traditional Japanese bridal gowns.

An unlooked for treat within... Green space in the Tokyo-Yokohama area is to be treasured and this one is an oasis in one of the largest cities in the world. With that, I only have one thing to add from the thousands of reviews already here: what practically no one did except locals is to use the pathways other than the main one leading to the shrine. For a bit of peace, when you've completed your viewing and are in the main courtyard before the central shrine, leave by the west entrance (to the left from the main entrance). Follow that path past a little used water purification fountain and left again onto a path that is a shady green and practically silent save for birds and the wind in the trees. Don't worry about getting lost, the path will actually lead you back to just before the main entrance. Definitely a recharge we needed in a day of sightseeing. Enjoy!
Area of fresh air and silence. After all the buzz of the city this garden and shrine are a place of wonderful tranquility... Highly recommended. Way less visitors than in Asakusa...

Can skip if you're planning being in other shrine centers. Honestly, this shrine is a little over hyped.We enjoyed visiting it, yes - but only as it was our first shrine visit in Japan.If you plan on visiting Kyoto, Nara or other major shrine/temple city, I think you could skip this shrine.

Another breath of fresh air in Tokyo. Having stepped off the train at Harajuku station and walked up to the beginning of yoyogi park, a small breeze of beautiful clean, fresh air greeted me to Meiji shrine. The walk from the station is serene and stunning and shows just how out of the way the shrine really is from the rest of civilization, even though it is all around it. When I arrive at the shrine, I found out the most famous Sumo wrestlers in all of Japan were about to do some performances in front of the main shrine, including Hakuho. It was really a once in a lifetime experience to see Hakuho and the other yokozuna wrestlers up close and personal. After the performances the crowd dissipated and the line to pray at the shrine itself grew massively long, with waiting times of up to 30 minutes roughly. Overall, a wonderful break from the monotony that is the metropolis of Tokyo and a welcome breath of fresh air.

Tranquilty. Meiju Jingu, located near Harajuku area where people with unique costume usually gathered. Meiji Jingu is a complex of shrines, the complex itself is one of the most tranquil places in Tokyo. We only managed to visit one temple but it is so worth it, very clean and beautiful inside.I think this place is better than sensoji. Highly Recommended

Peaceful Place from the City. This is a really peaceful place away from the city. It's large and is easily found. We actually walked here from Shinjuku and we enjoyed the many views of Japanese life. This is a touristy spot, so go when it is a bit early. The souvenir shops are wonderful and are priced like outside stores with exact items, so grab whatever you want. If you buy tickets for the Treasure Exhibit, you can also use them for the Tale of Genji Exhibit next to the souvenir shop. There is a lovely ice cream shop towards the end, and all the bathrooms around the area (plentiful in number) are very clean unlike most park bathrooms.

Beautiful shrine in Tokyo. We were lucky and cound see a few wedding ceremonies during our visit. Even though it was weekend and therefore quite crowded - it did not matter. Japanese people are very respectful and less vocal when visiting these places, which means you stand still enjoy it a lot and appreciate the beauty of the place. People can place wishes on wooden cards provided. A beautiful shrine in a big park

A very tranquil site to visit. Once you exit the Metro station it can be a bit confusing to find the entrance to the shrine but by asking passerby's you will soon find it. You enter under the large Torii and begin the long walk to the Meiji Jingu. It would increase the enjoyment of your visit if you first do a little reading on the difference between Buddhist and Shinto sites and you will then get more out of this Shinto shrine.
Zen. Right next to the Harajuku station. Very peaceful. Walk through gates and down peddle stoned path (z shaped) to shrine.You might be lucky and see people in traditional clothes. Free!

We even saw a Shinto style wedding!. We went on a Monday, but there was still quite a formidable crowd of tourists and "salary-men". There is a lot of walking to do, but the weather was nice and there was a nice breeze, so we even paid the 500yen entry for the Shrine Gardens. The gardens included a pond filled with fish and a teahouse for the Empress. There was a Shinto-style wedding at the main shrine, so we got to see the procession and the bride and groom in traditional outfits with their entourage. Definitely would recommend if it is your first time in the Harajuku area.
We saw a wedding. We went to see the Meiji Jingu on a Sunday morning. As per other reviews, a lot of walking here but was worthwhile. We even managed to see a wedding here.

Peaceful place. It's a huge green spot in the middle of the city. Has an iconic Torii right in the entrance but there are some smaller ones inside. If you go on weekends you may see several weddings going on there in small groups in their traditional clothing.

the park is more impressive than the shrine. Nice walk through a big park. Not a romantic, Japanese 'art' park but rather a 'big city park' with large trees. Don't forget to protect yourself from mosquito's and other insects.

If there's one old era place you could go for your short trip... . We were on our last day and we haven't gotten to a shrine yet. On our last day we followed the suggestions here and went here. Definitely worth it. Be ready for some walking. Go on a Sunday so that you get a chance to see a wedding.

a walk in Meijijingu. this beautiful shinto shrine area in shibuya is a must.covering some 170 acres with more than 100,000 trees it is a sanctuary in a busy city.see the sake barrels,iris garden,creeks and ponds flowing in peaceful quiet.remember do not litter.

Big & Beautiful!. We came across this on our way to Yoyogi park without even realizing that it was on our lists of "musts" while in Tokyo. It is a very big place, but so beautiful and peaceful. The second you enter you walk into a beautiful oasis away from the busy city. There is a little cafe right at the beginning, so for those of you with small children on a hot day you can pick up an ice cream cone for them! ;) If you're in the area, I definitely recommend taking an hour or two of your day and coming here!

Meiji Shrine. The Meiji shrine has some very large grounds, which you walk through to reach the main temple area. We went in through the back entrance, which was slightly unimpressive, but the main area was beautiful. It is actually vey quiet inside the shrine, you can't hear any of the Tokyo traffic. There are many ceremonies performed at the temple, we got to see a traditional wedding, which was very exciting. The temple was relatively uncrowded, and easy to get to from Harujuku station. There are some beautiful ema tablets (wishing tablets) here, much nicer than most other temples. We walked out of the main entrance, which had some impressive torii gates.

Beautiful Shinto Shrine . Meiji Jingu can be accessed using the Yamanote train line exiting at the Harajuku station. Exiting the station stay to your right. You will cross over a stone bridge and on your right you will see the entrance to the shrine. Be prepared for a walk as the site is quite big, approx 1 square mile. Entry is free to the main shrine and there is lots to see. Beautiful big wooden archways greet you and the surrounding woodland and greenery is peaceful despite being located in an urban setting. Make sure you have a camera with you. On the way in a few hundred metres on your left you will see an entry sign to a well and Iris gardens. You will need a ticket here and it's 500 Yen. If you go straight on you will get to the shrine. An emperor and his empress are enshrined here and from the different information points around the shrine they were popular and well loved by the Japanese people. The buildings in the shrine square are wonderful and here and there you will see Shinto monks going about their business. Well worth a visit. Beware if it's hot weather it's a good walk and there are only refreshments at entry points, not inside. Loved it, a real cultural experience.

Culture and quiet in the middle of insane Harajuku. ...as everyone states, the most surprising thing about visiting here is the noise. You go from the hustle of Harajuku, to suddenly being in a tree-surrounded, tranquil place. The walk itself is pleasant, there's curios to the sides, and some giant established trees to see, too. We visited on a Sunday to see Harajuku in action on its best day, then spent some hours exploring here. Plenty to see, and the history is palpable. Worth the visit for the culture, well worth it!

Beautiful. Definitely a must-go if you're in Tokyo (and if you like temples & shrines). Getting there is simple, just alight from Harajuku Stn and follow the directions. The shrine is really popular among tourists, most text i saw had English translation beside it. I also visited the Kiyomasa Well/Inner Garden, it's 500yen per visit. It's pretty nice, there weren't many people inside.

Tranquility in the heart of the city!. Just next to Harajuku station, totally amazed with its tranquillity although it is located at the centre of the city (next to harajuku too, mind you). Coincidentally there was a traditional wedding during my visit, gave me a glimpse of Japanese tradition. A lot of people during weekend and golden week. Must visit!

Worth a visit. This is Temple is not as frequented as the Sensoi-Ji temple so you don't have the same issue with crowds .. as well as the fact that the temple is set on larger grounds so you have plenty of room to move. The grounds are quite large and you need plenty of time to roam and soak up the atmosphere and check out the various buildings on the grounds. We were there in cherry blossom time but there were none in this area ... just lots of green trees and shrubs. We were there on a Saturday so were lucky enough to witness the bridal preparations and photos for at least 5 different weddings, as well as a couple of bridal processions. It is obviously a popular location for weddings. It just added to the magic of the place. A little bit of peace and serenity nestled in the bustle of Tokyo, and right near a train station so easy to get to. There is a lovely restaurant on the grounds if you need a break. Add this one to you Tokyo "to do" list.

Earthy and grounded beauty. Would come back!. This was one of the shrines we went to during cherry blossom season that wasn't adorned with lots of sakura. Instead everything was very green and rustic. I think this area might look really nice in autumn (I'm not sure if the trees turn orange here though) but nonetheless I found it very down to earth and an enjoyable visit and definitely contrasts with Harajuku on the other side of the train station! Worth a visit.

Stunning and serene. Dedicated to the Emperor Meiji and his wife, you'll find many local Japanese making the trek through the majestic forest that surrounds this shrine, to pray for all sorts of wishes.The forest is perfectly serene and so majestic. You must take a walk through it and soak it all in. The shrine is gorgeous and there are counters selling all manner of charms to protect you from bad luck, evil and even traffic accidents!

Not just any temple. Easily accessible and a perfect respite from Tokyo's hectic pace. Bring comfortable shoes and visit, whatever the weather. We tried following traditional customs of hand and mouth washing and ringing of bells. It's quite a magical place - completely harmonious and peaceful. An integral part of any visit to Tokyo. Allow for 2-3 hours, minimum.

Beautiful! A must see while in Japan.. After visiting sensoji temple yesterday and not enjoying it overly I must say I was VERY happy with Meiji jingu today!It is probably a 15 minute walk through yoyogi park from harajuku station. The park itself is very beautiful, with huge trees lining the path. The shrine really impressed me. It is all wooden and it gives you a really nice feeling just looking at it. I'm in no way religious or spiritual but I could easily see how people would be drawn to it. If you only get the chance to visit one temple or shrine, please make it this one!

Nice walk. The park is lovely, and we weren't even there during cherry blossom season. From Harajuku station, is a short and leisurely walk to the shrine. Relaxing atmosphere, wasn't too busy, which was great.

Well worth a look. We caught the Metro from Shibuya to Harajuku station. It's a nice leisurely stroll to the temple. There was an event on when we were there so couldn't get into the temple. Well worth a visit. There is a restaurant, food court, souvenir shop & museum.

Peaceful sightseeing. Very picturesque spot to sightsee but be prepared to put on your walking shoes. Regardless of what entrance you enter the surrounding park, you will be walking at 10 mins. What I'm really trying to say is don't do it this at the end of your day because you will be dragging your feet by the end of it.
Peaceful park with impressive Shrine. Huge and impressive shrine with a beautiful park. When you want to have a nice walk this shrine is great to visit as it's surroundings are huge.

Serene!. Very nice place to visit in Shibuya. Very Calm. Located Inside Yoyogi Park you have to walk a bit to get here! It has a nice botanical garden just outside which you can visit for an additional price(500Y)!

Calming. A big temple located inside a huge park in the middle of Tokyo. The entrance is just next to Harajuku Station on Yamanote Line. You cant miss it. It is a very long walk from the entrance to the temple. However the path leading towards the temple is surrounded by big trees which makes the surrounding very peaceful. The path is made of small stone which makes it quite difficult for baby stroller with small wheels. You can continue your day by walking along Takeshita Dori, a very busy shopping alley just opposite the Harajuku Station.
Quiet place.. Be prepared to walk. Huge temple, very tranquil... Just be prepared to walk a bit.Spent an hour and a half taking a look and offering some prayer.

Impressive. This shrine is definitely worth seeing. The grounds and the shrine itself are huge and impressive and the priests take excellent care of the entire area. It's truly breathtaking to behold. A must see!

A tranquil park and shrine. From Harujuku station turn right and you will see locals clap their hands at the entrance as they enter the park towards the shrine.There is an air of tranquility and the air is cool and calm. The little stone bridge is on the left followed by a small stream. As you walk in you will be greeted by rolls of Sake barrels with narration on it.Before you reach the shrine you will be overpowered by the gigantic wooden Torii gate of Meiji Shrine.I had a wonderful photo shoot with a little kid and mum clad in kimono and grandma gladly took it for us ... Arigato gozaimasu - a wonderful souveniur of Tokyo.

The grounds are more impressive than the shrine. Definitely go if in Tokyo. The grounds are absolutely beautiful and the giant torii gates are a sight. I was lucky to see a traditional Japanese wedding in the shrine when I was there. On your way back, definitely pay the 500 yen fee and see Kiyomasa's Well. It's well worth it. There's also a nice souvenir shop with decent prices. You will find yourself in Yoyogi park immediately after you leave the shrine grounds.

Visit the temple on Sunday to see Japanese Weddings. This temple is very nice, being located in a wonderful and quiet park.It is easy to reach from Harajuku JR Station, with a relaxing walk immerse in the nature passing from stunning gates made with thousands years old trees. We visited it on a Sunday morning and we enjoyed the execution of three Japanese weddings. It is a wonderful experience. I would definitively recommended to go on Sundays to make the visit even more special.The temple is free of charge, other parts of the park require the payment of a fee.

Peaceful and Great. Our trip there was impressive. Meiji jingu may look ordinary through photos but when you are really there you can feel it's grandeur and graciousness. Everything is so big and harmony:)

Beauty and Peace in the City. A calm oasis in the middle of bustling Tokyo. I visited early on a quiet Wednesday morning. There seemed to be an even mix of locals and tourists, some in suits before going to work. The Meiji Shrine is at the center of a decent sized park. My only problem was arriving well before 9:00 AM when the garden opens so I was unable to see that. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.

Stunning architecture, and beautiful surroundings. This place is stunning - just takes your breathe away as you walk amongst the large shaded pathways to the Shrine. We were fortunate to witness a wedding occurring there. Recommend to go early. We were there in the morning before walking to Yoyogi Park. There were plenty of bus loads of tourists later in the morning arriving.

Tranquility in a Metropolis. We were pleasantly surprised to find somewhere so peaceful in the centre of Tokyo. We went there on 1st January 2015 and loved seeing people praying at the temples for the coming year. The whole atmosphere was one of excitement as people bought sheep themed trinkets for the new year. A must see.

Peaceful Oasis. This Shinto shrine sits right off the subway line..one direction takes you down toward a bustling avenue of shops activity. The shrine is a Mecca of beautiful trees and quiet pathways....

Peaceful and beautiful. This is such a peaceful and beautiful place. I loved the calm of the forest among the hustle of the city. A great escape. Very spiritual and fascinating. I read up on the traditions of the shrine before going there. For example when to bow and how to wash your hands before entering. I would advise others to do the same in order to be respectful but to also appreciate the experience. I observed the locals and their customs and I found it to be a rewarding experience.

For me the walk was impressive.. From the sheer size of the 'gate', the length of the walk, the width of the pathway, the barrels of French wine, barrels of sake; you get to appreciate the importance of this shrine.

A Must Visit. We love this place, especially the panal of wall make of vintage wine barrels. Quite a long walk before one could reach the shrine. Not a comfortable walk too as the ground are filled with what i called dark grey pebbles and stones.If you are lucky, you could see japanese wedding ceremony which we saw few years ago but no this time.If it is your 1st visit, then this is a must visit. Just another 10min walk is the Yoyogi park which my family voted as our favourite park for Hanami.

what a contrast picture. this peaceful and scenic meiji jingu shrine is in a walking distance from the busy 'harajuku' area. it is hidden in the forested like park and surrounded by the concrete jungle of tokyo. the contrast picture of modern tokyo at 'harajuku' and the old preserved Japanese tradition at 'meiji jingu' is so awesome. it may help you understand japan in the 21st century better.

A Magical Place. Meiji Jingu, or Meiji Shrine as westerners term it, is a magical place sitting among a vibrant and busy area of Harajuku. It is my favourite spot in Tokyo, and whenever I am in Tokyo, I make it a point to pay my homage to Meiji Jingu.It's magical because despite it being situated in the ever busy Harajuku district, all the hustle and bustle were cut off the moment you turn right and cross over the 40-foot giant torii gate. You will be welcomed by peace and serenity, only with a faint noise that feels so far away. The pathway to the main Meiji ceremonial shrine is made of pebbles and gravels. It is quite a distance to walk inwards before you see, right in front of you, the majestic structure of the Meiji Shrine. This is a tribute to the Meiji Emperor and his Empress. There are many Shinto ceremonies held each year at the Meiji Jingu, and if you are lucky, you may catch a traditional wedding ceremony or even a festival! Getting an omikuji ( 2-liner prose, the Empress' favourite hobby), and the Meiji Jingu stamp, are good and cheap souvenirs. To get to Meiji Jingu, take the train to Harajuku station and upon exit, turn right. Walk straight ahead and you will see a stone bridge. Cross the bridge and you will see the large torii gate. You will then enter the world of Meiji

City Centre Pilgrimage. Was lucky enough to go during a wedding, so we saw the bride walk through the shrine (from far away - although there was a big crowd it didn't seem like it was a performance). This is definitely worth a visit, and is pretty interesting to see after browsing the busy shops of Harajuku next door.

Magnificent shrine for the great reformist. Set in a huge park in western Tokyo this shrine is the Tokyo's most important Shinto shrine and shouldn't be missed. It is dedicated to emperor Meiji, a great reformist who turned the samurai shogun system into a modern Japan society.The great shrine you see is actually a new shrine rebuilt in the '60 of 20th cent, as the original was destroyed during II WW bombing attacks. A great park, say forest, surrounds it, very pleasant and quite to walk through.Try to be there on weekends, and you're almost guaranteed to see a traditional Japanese wedding.

Nice quiet place to enjoy the scenery. This is very near Harajuku. So if you are going to Harajuku, you can enjoy the scenery at the Meiji Shrine. Besides being a place of worship, it's a place where people get married and have their wedding procession as well.We were lucky enough to get to see a wedding procession take place.

Experience the peacefulness and serenity. To get here, you have to walk through the Harajuku/Yoyogi park. Walking through the park itself was a great experience with such a peaceful atmosphere. This place is definite must go for travelers who love to photograph their trips. The main shrine area was beaufitul.

Pretty good shrine to start with in Tokyo. Like all things in Tokyo, it's going to be crowded. I got there early and just beat a few busloads of tourists.Why would you go: It's a wonderful big shrine in an understated Shinto fashion.Why would you skip: It's an easy, but long walk into the shrineI liked the forest you walked through to get to the shrine and if it's peace and quiet you want, instead of exiting through the main pathway that passes the sake barrels, exit the main shrine through the side exit (to your left as you come in the main way) and take that road back to the front. There's only one way to go on that road so don't be afraid you will get lost and there were only 2 people on the road.

Lovely place for a walk and to take in Shinto culture and history.. The beauty of the Yoyogi Park and 'being in the presence of' the great Meiji Emporer was great and he truly was a formidable ruler, when you read about him.

Dedicated to Emporer Meiji. Emporer Meiji was the first emperor when Japan converted from the samurai system to a Western government. This shrine is located just off to the right of the main exit of the JR Harajuku Station where you’ll see a huge torii gate. The grounds consist of a large forested area of 100,000+ trees of over 350 species donated by the people of Japan. Visitors can only look into the Shrine from the doors and are not allowed in. Photos are not allowed once you go up the steps to the front door – guards are constantly on the lookout for warn people about taking photos. A very tranquil and relaxing setting.

Gorgeous, quiet oasis in Tokyo. The main shrine area is fantastic, of course. But be sure to wander a bit through the surrounding park, and you will be amazed by how quickly and completely the throngs of other tourists melt away. Truly a gem of the city.

Peacefulness, Towering Trees in the Center of Tokyo. After the subways to Shibuya and the crowded neighborhood outside, the towering trees were a gorgeous respite. The signs and maps listed intriguing sites around the temple but since it was raining we headed straight to the temple with a stop at the sake barrels. It's a beautiful stroll to the historic temple.

A Forest. An unusual thick forest in a City Centre. The trees are amazing.I don't think any other G8 Capital has such a Forest, although it doesn't make up for the lack of greenery in the rest of the City.The Shrine in the Centre may be of some interest to some people who are starved of historical buildings.

Wedding shrine. Not the shrine itself made our visit special but the peaceful walk through the huge forest, passing the sake barrels leading to the shrine, away from the bustle of a lively city. And ofcourse the traditonal wedding ceremonies on Saturday morning. We found the shrine itself not very interesting. Try to visit on a sunny Saturday morning. You will love it.

Quiet refuge within the city. The temple grounds is a large area that is surrounded by tall trees and you can't see or hear the city when you inside... it feels like the countryside despite being inside the Tokyo city limits. There is also a park next to the Shrine entrance so you cannot enter the temple grounds from the park (opposite the Yoyogi stadium on the other side of the road). You have to walk a few minutes North from the metro station and you will find the massive wooden gates to the temple grounds. It is a very zen like park and is certainly worth a visit.

Meji Jingu. Meji Jingu is is a shrine dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji. Easily located it can be reached by train, just hop off at Harajuku! It's on the top of the street but there are two entrances and exits to Harajuku station, so don't get off at the Takashita St exit - it's the other one! But if you do (Get off at Takeshita St) all you have to do is walk around the block. So it's located on the top of the street right next to Harajuku St. It can get quite cold in there during the cooler months / end of the year as the trees are so tall they block out most of the sun. It's a lovely stroll into the park, relaxing and quiet. If you keep walking on you reach a wall of Sake barrels and opposite that actual barrels. Keep walking and you will find the shrine. You have the options to traditionally 'bless' yourself and to make a wish. Really relaxing and after that you can head back down to Takeshita Street and around Harajuku/Shibuya
peaceful. Refuge from the craziness of Shinjuku and Shibuya. Quiet and peaceful and a beautiful shrine. Mature forest all around.

Must Visit. Came here as a part of a bike tour with Miracle Cycling. Meiji Jingu is definitely a "must see" while visiting Tokyo. The grounds are huge and wonderful to walk. The temple area is impressive and we happened to see a wedding party too. It's a lot of fun to purchase a fortune (Japanese & English available) and read what could be in the future ;-). Also found the sake barrels at the entrance very pretty and rather artistic! The temple is located incredibly close to Harajuku - fun to combine Takeshita Dori and Omotesando with Meiji Jingu.

Nice area and pretty walk. If you are in the area I would recommend stopping as it is nice walk. Also it is interesting to see a shrine that isn't so fancy as some of the others. We also got to see part of a traditional Japanese wedding that was going on, which was really interesting to see. Overall I would say stop if you are in the area but don't feel like you have to go out of your way to see it.

Impressive gates to a peaceful shrine in a beautiful park. Just a few steps from the insane action of Harajuku is this beautiful oasis - a shrine to the meiji emporer surrounded by greenery and beautiful gardens. Walking only - no bkes in the park. Make your way down and meander the grounds.
Nice area to see. This is a hoping area mainly. It s more to teenagers but it may worth to visit to see Japanese youngsters, mainly girsl wandering around.

Beautiful walk. Such beautiful grounds and pathways. We walked and admired all the lovely, huge trees on this gorgeous April day. We walked all the way up to the shrine and were lucky enough to see not one, but two traditional Japanese weddings doing photos. Both brides were stunning in their traditional Japanese silk kimonos. What a treat!

Absolutely Beautiful. Talk about an incredible cultural experience. Meiji Jingu is a short walk away from Harajuku. The shrine is beautiful!
