There's a large Torii, which is perfect for taking a picture under and lots of gardens. We were fortunate enough to see a traditional wedding, which was gorgeous. Be sure to check it out if you're in Tokyo!

Massive gardens, huge Tori gates and a beautiful temple. It was raining when we went to Harajuku, so there were few people in costumes, but the nearby Yoyogi park and Meiji Temple were gorgeous. I was lucky, there was a Shinto wedding going on so I got to see a beautiful bride, her entire entourage and the whole trappings. Just lovely.

unusual and unexpected. In the middle of Tokyo this park filled with trees has a modern shrine, but what is really special are the ceremonies. The ceremonies have Shinto priests walking around in fancy robes are are actually pretty cool. I don't think this shrine is much to look at. The park is cool enough but not special enough to go out of your way for (particularly if you are going to Nara).
Serene place. It is an awesome place with beautiful gardens. We got lucky to witness several Japanese weddings on Saturday morning.

A nice place to walk and enjoy some quiet moment. I've seen mixed reviews about Meiji Jingu, and felt a bit ambivalent about going there as I had limited time in Tokyo. But I'm glad that I decided to go! The place is HUGE. Granted, it's probably not as pretty as some other shrines, but because of its size, you could actually enjoy it peacefully. I went there quite early in the morning. It was cool, not crowded, and I even saw a newly married shinto couple having their photo shoot there. It's surrounded by lots of trees, and I enjoyed listening to the birds chirping as I strolled the area.I would recommend going there in the morning. If you're in a hurry, or your legs are too tired, probably it's best that you skip this attraction, coz you won't be able to enjoy it. The shrine itself was free, but if you want to go to the garden, there's a fee (500 yen, if I'm not mistaken) and it's open at 9am.

Serendipitous Kyudo experience!. We found the temple to be beautiful (and crowded) but the better experience was walking through the beautiful 175 acre forest (with 365 species of trees apparently). On the periphery of the compound, near the Meiji Memorial Hall, we had the lucky opportunity to watch the art of Kyudo (archery) being performed. The entrance was barricaded with a sign that said do not enter but several gentlemen who worked there encouraged us to go in quietly and enjoy. So peaceful and so beautiful!

A beautiful park in the middle of Tokyo. The grounds were the highlight of our visit to the Meji Shrine. They are so peaceful and so out of place with the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. The park takes up 175 acres of prime Tokyo real estate. It was also interesting to see the local people there in their traditional clothes attending various ceremonies going on during the day.

Peaceful, calm, and beautiful. We visited the shrine around 6:30am. It was quiet and peaceful. There were big trees and beautiful landscape surrounding the shrine. It was raining the night before. There were workers raking leaves already early in the morning. I am so glad they did not use leave blower, The noise from the blower would completely ruin the peacefulness of this place. This is my favorite spot in Tokyo in this trip. It is a perfect place to visit when you get up too early from your jet lag.

It's crowded but you must see it!!. So you start off at Harajuku station (which is one of the most insane places I've ever visited) and then you arrive at Yoyogi Park and walk through the serene pathways arriving at Meiji Jingu.It's like you've walked into another land - historical, cultural Japan - ah this is what we wanted to see. It was the first Shrine that we visited in Japan (actually our first ever) and I'm glad it was this one - really special place.There were traditional weddings occuring, ladies dressed in traditional Japanese dress.Yes it's crowded, but it's beautiful and it's free. Don't miss it.
Beautiful, quiet, spiritual place in the heart of a crazy shopping area.. Perfect place to unwind after all the craziness of Harajuku. We went there before dinner, it was perfect.

Beautiful shrine...best shrine in Tokyo. Beautiful and best Shinto shrine in Tokyo. Can really get a flavor for the local people. We were able to see parents bringing their newborns to the shrine as well as a wedding procession. Peaceful setting. Lovely.

Beautiful shrine. One of the most beautiful shrine I've ever visited, the mood was very serene and calming, good for gather your thought. Try to visit before 9am to avoid crowd. The pathway to the main shrine was very beautiful, you definitely have to visit it while in Tokyo
Beautiful shrine. Lovely walk to the shrine, just a rock throw from Harajuku station. This little tranquil oasis of Japanese culture is worth a visit

Worth a visit. One of the better temples, located within a park so good for a walk. We happened to see a ceremony (wedding?) while we were there which was a unique experience. The onsite restaurant was good (we only had an ice cream, but the food on offer looked good, and it was popular). Worth a visit, not least as it is located close to Harajuku and Shibuya!

The best!!. First of all, I'm not a shrine or temple lover, and I'd been to many shrines in Japan in my trip so I started getting tired of them. But Meiji Jingu changed my mind. I got out of Harajuku station and faced the very hot sun in middle of July, then I turned right to the direction of Meiji Shrine and found a big wooden torii which I thought it was my love at first sight. It's so elegant and beautiful and really attractive. I'd never felt like this when I went to any shrines in Japan before. This is just the gate lead to the big park which I thought was a little jungle with many big trees I didn't expected to be in a city like Tokyo. On the way to the Shrine, I passed by many interesting spots like the sake collections of the emperor. Although the weather was very hot and humid, walking in this park was a pleasant time. At the Shrine, it's quite simple but full of power in my thought. Not colorful like other shrines but full of believes and sincerity. This really fulfilled my time in Tokyo. I loved it and I'd recommend everyone to come here. Trust me, you can miss any shrines or temples in Japan BUT THIS!!! Go there, you won't regret!PS. IT'S FREE!!!!
Lovely!. I had visited it many times, always interesting and enjoyable .Wedding ceremonies on weekends! The day of the children and exhibitions of flowers!

tucked away in a massive park. the area surround the temple is really nice, stone lined pathways leading up to the gate and temple. the temple itself is cool, we went on a Sunday and there were lots of Bride and grooms getting pictures taken, and I think a baptism type ceremony had just taken place as there were heaps of families with babies all dressed up. was cool to see!

Oasis in Tokyo. We went during sakura season and the crowds were large but not unmanageable. With all that space you can still find some peaceful areas with a low density of tourists. The main sites will be crowded especially when the tour buses arrive. Make sure to go early to beat some of the crowds and you will be rewarded.
Beautiful temple. A big and beautiful temple in the middle of a "forest" park. Amazing that this exists in the middle of Tokyo!

Actually my favorite temple. We saw several temples and about a dozen smaller shrines in Tokyo, and this one was my favorite. I absolutely love that it is in the middle of such s huge wooded park. It's easy to forget you're in a bigger city. Peaceful, wooded streets and lanes lead to a large meadow, a museum, a lake, and in the middle, the temple. It wasn't nearly as busy as some of the others, though still touristy. At one end of the park, there is a gift shop a restaurant, but I like that they are not near three actual temple. Definitely worth a visit, even if you can only choose to do a few things in Tokyo.

Huge Old Shrine... I had huge expectation for Meiji Jingu because of the high rating and good reviews from other traveller. We've visited a lot of shrines in Japan before we went to Meiji Jingu. I think it is not as special as the shrines in Kyoto. Don't think I would visit twice.

Lots of walking, be prepared. . This very large shrine, is in the middle of a vast forest. There is plenty of walking on cobbled stones so make sure you wear trainers. There is more than one entrance, so make sure you know which way you came in, if you came via local transport.
Japanese Budhist Temple. Beautiful temple in park in Tokyo, very atmospheric. We saw a young couple being married. A lovely experience. Worth the visit.

this much trees in the middle of a city. with the towering buildings of Tokyo, it is quite amazing how they still manage to keep a place this huge for nature. its a long walk from the train station but it is nothing but enjoyable. if you're lucky, you might even get to experience a japanese wedding in the shrine. usually happens in the afternoons. its a really beautiful experience. I'd recommend visiting this place at least once.

Peace in crowded city. it's very peaceful place. so good to be there on harvest festival, see lots of activities. even there're a lots of people on that day but you can feel the respect and peace from them.
You cannot miss this on a trip to Tokyo. One of the quintessential elements of any Tokyo. This shrine including the surrounding park contains all the best parts of Japan.

Oh Those Green Green Trees. The shrine sits in the middle of a heavily treed park (almost feels like a forest), so it's a bit of a trek to get to, and with pebbles for a path, it can tire you out easily; so make sure you wear comfy shoes. The wooden Tori gate is simple yet beautiful as is the shrine itself. The sake barrel decor outside of the shrine is pretty interesting too with a little snippet of history explained on a wooden board. But was was most breaht-taking in this shrine are these two tress in full bloom in the summer. They stand there tall and green. They are of course manicured and look perfectly round, but they really are very stunning. The prayer tablet areas right under these trees are an interesting way to spend a few minutes of your time as well.

Go there right now!!!. After being a bit overwhelmed by the crowds at Senso-ji, I was a little apprehensive about visiting this famous site. I needed have worried. The shrine is an oasis of calm in the centre of crazy (but lovable) Tokyo and a visit here is an absolute must! The grounds of the shrine are peaceful and the shrine itself is beautiful! You can't miss the enormous gates which is course need a photo or two but the whole complex is beautiful. We were also lucky enough to see a wedding party walk through which was just the icing on the cake. My favourite place in Tokyo! Go go go!

Impressive parkland shrine. This is a calming visit after a long flight. The grounds of the shrine are well laid out and a pleasure to walk in. The cherry blossom was holding up quite well and Spring was clearly on its way. This was a welcome peaceful introduction to Tokyo.

Absolutely truly beautiful inner gardens.. Meiji jingu's inner gardens really touches the soul and is well worth the nominal fee. I was lucky enough to visit in the Spring, but I understand the irises look best in the Summertime. An absolute must see!

Serenity + harmony. Conveniently located a few minutes from the Harajuku station off of the JR Yamanote line. Signage excellent, Meiji Jingu exit. Given it was spring break, not congested with crowds of tourists. The usual Japanese standard for cleanliness. In fact, spotted an employee sweeping the gravel lined walkway, leading to the shrine. The Torii gates are huge and one feels diminished in size. Take a look at the sake bottles and wine caskets, most interesting. Given that it's right in Harajuku, you leave behind the hustle & bustle of the city and are immediately surrounded by the quietness & solitude. Take your time, it is a leisurely walk to the shrine itself, maybe 10 - 15 minutes.

Peaceful walk in the park. The park itself can not compete with chiyoda or giyoen which both have the incredibly beautiful blossoms in April.
The meji shrine is an experience. Even more if you prepare so you know some of the history and the rituals to follow : clense your hands at the entrance and offer a ritual prayer at the shrine.
A beautiful location. This is a beautiful location with lovely wooden gates in a tranquil setting. Well worth a visit as it seems to be not the usual tourist stop

Accessible and peaceful. Get off at Harajuku station, one stop away from Shibuya. Try to get there earlier in the morning when there are less people. An oasis of quiet and peace. There were two weddings taking place the day of our visit - great photo opportunity.

Impressive Torii Gates. Meiji Jingu shrine is around 10 minutes by walk from Harajuku station. The park in which the shrine is is serene and tranquil. The Torii gates are quite impressive. The sake barrels offered to Emperor Meiji offer good photo ops. We saw a private ceremony being conducted in the shrine.
Lovely tree lined walk. I enjoyed walking through the trees lovely natural surrounds after being in a big city . It's very tranquil and beautiful temple . Highly enjoyable

Nice, but not breathtaking. This large shrine has some pretty impressive and beautiful architecture. Due to its lack of detail and history, the attraction is not the most interesting or engaging. However, viewing a part of a Japanese wedding made it totally worth a visit.

明治神宮. It is a Shinto shrine to be famous in Tokyo.The neighborhood station is Harajuku Station.From the torii to the precinct, I walk the direction between big trees to me and it takes eight minutes.There is a fast food shop in the Harajuku side.Yoyogi Park is near and can eat a lunch.If it is fine, you can spend relaxed time.
Beautiful place to walk around . Must be on every tourist bucket list when visiting Tokyo. Very popular and historic. Wear comfortable shoes. Bring a camera!
Japanese shrine in the heart of Tokyo. The shrine is in the park lots of big trees along the pathway to the shrine. I love to see Japanese wedding here, look elegant and charming.

Great Shrine and nice walk. One of many shrines in Tokyo but this is a bit of a walk down a gravel path but definitely worth the walk. The area its in is in a trendy part of Tokyo with good places to eat down the backstreets. The shrine is open from sunrise to sunset and is free to enter. There are gardens around this as well so a nice and relaxing place to go.

Peaceful. A great place to relax for a few hours with lots to see and learn about. We paid the 500 yes fee for the extra garden which helps take you away from any larger crowds. Its nice to come here if you are feeling stressed by the bustling metropolis that is Tokyo!

Peaceful, beautiful. Enjoy the walk in the park. It is beautiful at any time but I would recommend an early sunrise morning. You will feel so peaceful that you will even forget that across the street you are in the lively Tokyo city.

Peaceful and relaxing. I recommend setting an hour aside for this. It's a bit of a walk from the entrance, but a nice one. Don't bother going to the museum at the end of the park though, it is not worth the time or money.

A shrine in a very big park. Visited on March 2015 with a group of friends and family.Just 3mins walk from Harajuku station or Meijijingumae station. After crossing the bridge, you will find the entrance on your right with a big gate (tori) welcoming you. It takes 15-20minutes to walk into the shrine, but the journey is pleasant. With big trees on each side, and perfect combination of sand and rocks along the way, makes the journey path memorable. Few minutes walk you will see big sake barrels on your rights, and wine drums on your left. Worth a visit.

Tranquil Gardens in the middle of a bustling city. The Meiji Shrine is really easy to locate, being almost equidistant from both the Harajuku and Yoyogi stations. The gardens and tree lined paths leading to the temple are breathtaking - it's like a retreat in the middle of a supremely busy city! There is a paid (called 'contribution' for some strange reason) path which has all sorts of interesting titbits of information about Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. There is also a tea house, a lovely Iris and Azalea garden, a fishing pond, and a well in there!The shrine is quite an imposing structure, but is, as in many cases in Tokyo and Kyoto, overshadowed by its garden. Visiting the Meiji Shrine is a morning or afternoon very well spent!
Grand garden and scared shrine for the emperor. I love it here, the shrine is very grand, located in the middle of the big forest. The trees is big, really love it here. Recommended to visit here.

Meji Jingu is the perfect place to take a breather from busy Tokyo. Meji Jingu is a great place to walk around and enjoy quiet, nature, and Japanese culture within Tokyo. The Tori Gates are awesome to look at, the trails are peaceful, and the shrine is enjoyable to visit. This isn't a location that I wouldn't take time out of my way to go to, but if i'm in the Shinbuya with nice weather and time I'll definitely stop by. If you are planning a trip to Tokyo and it'll be your first time in Japan, I would recommend this.

DISCONNECT - peace & calm in the middle of tokyo. You would never believe that by putting about 100 m between you & omotesando st. corner you could find so much silence. Well, since the "park" where the sanctuary is is enormous, once you keep waking it only gets calmer and more peaceful by the step. It is somehow a magical place. In 5 minutes you went from city to forest. The toriis are made out of natural wood and everything feels raw & natural. The shrine itself is also impressive, quite big and made in dark wood, beautiful. Everything sort of matches together to give you that feeling of being in the middle of greatness. I was there on a weekday, and it was not busy at all. Fantastic for roaming around & pray without having a hard time to concentrate (which as a foreign not used to do it in japanese style was a common problem for me! he). Feels closer to whatever god is there :)
Great place. It was quite a walk into the shrine but it was worth it. they have a hut outside selling charms for 800yen. the serenity and peace there was a good sight apart from the bustling city.

Peaceful spot amongst vibrant Harajuku. Beautiful spot. We paid ¥1400 to enter Ido's well & middle garden. Too early to see Iris garden in bloom though. Very peaceful location. Beautiful architecture & historical significance. We were fortunate to see a couple of Japanese weddings taking place which made the visit extra special.
Lovely. It's a nice place to go to for a change of pace and peacefulness, we were lucky it wasn't too busy when we were there and to see a traditional wedding taking place.

Serenity in the middle of Tokyo. The path leading up to the shrine is long, but flanked by tall trees and woods and is very peaceful. The wooden arches leading to the shrine are tall and impressive while the shrine and buildings surrounding it are drab in color. If you're lucky, you might see a bridal procession or two which we did--brides in white gowns and attendants elegant in their patterned kimonos.

Wonderful way to spend the day. Had a day to kill in Tokyo. Went to the shrine and it was wonderful . A serene respite from the hustle and bustle if Tokyo . Best part us when you are done you are in Harijuku. Fantastic high energy spot in Tokyo

Beautiful setting even in the rain.. The walk up to the main temple is beautiful and green and almost mystic. The Torii gate is huge and in natural wood- a beautiful sight. For me one of the best things were seeing several wedding parties in their wedding clothes (two brides were in white and one in bright red with wonderful scenes on it). Our guide Yosuke of Discover Japan Tours told us exactly what was happening and why because he had been married a few years before in that very place. This is a wonderful place in the middle of a huge and busy city. Cool, green, and very serene.

Great way to spend a morning. We decided to start our day off going to Meifi Park after spending our first three days in Tokyo checking out the sights and the sounds of the city this was a nice distraction. The park is truly amazing. I was blown away by the size of the entrance gates and cant wait to do a little investigation on how they were installed. The park has some very old trees that give it a feeling of history. We spent some time at the shrine and it was nice to see my son take time to experience some of the local rituals. Make sure you go early so that you can actually get a true relaxed trip.
Do not miss this. The shrine in the hajuku section of Toyko is not to be missed. The walk up the shrine is serine and wonderful. We was two wedding taking place. A must see in Toyko.

Nice!. The walk to the temple was very nice. I went from the Yoyogi entrance so I could get more forest-y views and exited via the Harajuku gate. The temple is nice and got to witness a wedding ceremony. There's a food area nearby that sells Sakura Ice Cream, which was good.

Tranquil in the morning. Visited Meiji Shrine in February 2015 this year. Found the walk around the shrine to be very pleasant with the cool and fresh air. Also witness a wedding taking place there. It was beautiful. Advice would be to visit early in the morning(from it opens) as it usually gets very crowded around 9 to 10 plus AM.

Quiet, peaceful, refined.. We visited on a weekday, and were lucky enough to miss the crowds. The walk around the shrine is worth considering. It is a respite from the noise of shinjuku and harajuku. At the North end, there is a place where traditional japanese archery is practiced. A short distance along is a museum dedicated to the Meiji emperor. My favourite part of the inner shrine are the 3 large trees within the enclosure. A ceremonial rope spans two on the left handside. People offer prayers here. On the right handside there is another tree where people who write their wishes for the year on wooden tablets and pin them to a rack surrounding the tree. The contents of the wishes give ab wonderful insight into people's heartfelt desires.Worth a viit

Such an honest beauty. After a nice walk in a beautiful and special forrest , together with a lot of other people it was surprising to arrive to the builings themselves and discover such a calm and nice place, Had the chance to se 5 traditionnal wedding ceremonies (real, not mmade for tourists). And try to see the exibitions in the neigbouroughs building, learning about the intersting emperor and emperess from the Meiji periode

An absolute oasis of peace and quiet in a very busy city. I have always enjoyed my visits to Meiji Jingu and especially recommend going there on Sunday mornings. That is when you are most likely to see a Shinto wedding procession in all its glory of traditional dress. Even if your visit does not allow a Sunday visit, make the effort to spend an hour or so in the grounds. The peace and tranquility of the gardens and the shrine itself is worth the effort. It is amazing that such an atmosphere can be created by just a few turns in the walkway - all this within a very busy city.Assess to the shrine is very convenient by the JR Yamanote Line which makes it within easy reach of any of the main areas where visitors are likely to stay. There is of course no admission fee and no hassles by anybody.Those who have time, should consider also visiting nearby Harajuku and the shopping on Omotosando.

Magical . Just go. You can't tell that you're in one of the biggest cities in the world. It's just so peaceful and beautiful. I loved walking along the path. During the summer you feel like you're baking. It's breathtaking. I loved the sound of cicadas and crows.I picked up a hefty amount of souvenirs for loved ones. I also got a bumper sticker for safe driving. It's an amazing place to see.

Nice Shinto Shrine with an awesomely peaceful park. After walking through the wonderfully peaceful park surrounding the Meiji Shrine you can enter the shrine through one of the toriis. The whole atmosphere has a really great feel to it and if you go there on weekends you can be lucky enough to encounter a traditional japanese wedding ceremony. :)

Tranquil. This is such a chill place to walk around. The park is beautiful and the temple is incredible. Really worth a walk around if your in the area. It also boast the worlds tallest Japanese gate at 35m or so.

Peaceful. Its really nice to walk in the park full of trees and to reach the shrine , the place is spacious, not crowded (early march 2015), you get to learnt what's shinto religion in Japan. Understand their culture. Its peaceful. Its so quiet and its really near to shinjuku or shibuya.
Absolutely beautiful. Witnessed a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony, think it's because we went on a Sunday. It was a beautiful ceremony in a very tranquil and beautiful surroundings.

Serene. if you want to take time out from the hustle and bustle without traveling too far out of Tokyo... go to Harajuku station and start walking.this is a haven.peace.no noise.no disturbances.everything is surrealit will take you into a different world where you don't see the sky scrappers or the millions of people rushing somewhere.:)
Relaxing walk. This was a great place to visit. The grounds are beautiful. The site is very well kept. The prayer traditions are spiritual and heart warming.

One of my favorite places in Tokyo. This shrine is dedicated to Meiji, who was the emperor at the end of XIX and first half of XX century, and who brought a lot of western culture and modernization to Japan. It is located in kind of a park, so as you walk through the Torii you forget the city outside and feel the peace that surrounds it. The temple itself has has a big patio with two huge trees that are cut round; one of them is called the tree of life, so you can offer a written prey on it. As you walk back to the park for the exit, don't forget to check the wine barrels that are exposed as acknowledgment for the French wine producers who donate it for the monks' consumption, since Meiji time, and the sake barrels as well.

Forest in the City.. When i saw Meiji Jingu on the internet, i thought it was a mere temple. But when i walked through the first gate, i stopped all my breathing and just so stunned to see the forest that was lined up in the front of me. The forest is just gave me chills and keep giving me chills when i am walking to the main shrine. When i reached the shrine, there is so many peace that i feel, there is a ritual that you should do if you wanna pray in the shrine like washing your left hand, right hand, and the mouth. Also, there is a praying cards that you can buy for writing all your wishes near the shrine and hanging it. If you wanna give respect to the shrine, there is also an english guide for you to the step by steps. Near here there is also Yoyogi Park which is a nice place just to sit and enjoy all the surroundings.

Calm, gorgeous park. A gorgeous park and got quite crowded on the weekend. The path towards jingu is much appreciated with trees and curated representation of Meiji era. Look totally awesome in spring.

Peace and calm. Meiji shrine afforded us a bit of calmness during a hectic 4 days in Tokyo. We were fortunate to be approached by a group of Japanese students who spend some of their spare time showing English speaking tourists around. They explained some of the history and helped us through a cleansing ritual that can be taken before approaching the shrine. It made the visit thoroughly enjoyable.
If you have time take in gardens. we enjoyed visiting, wished we'd had more time to walk round the gardens, quite a walk from station, but worth it.

Tranquility amid the madness of Shinjuku/Shibuya/Harajuku. After Shinjuku, Shibuya and Harajuku, who would have thought that one would find tranquility in the heart of Tokyo?Meiji jingu offers a much needed reprieve from the madness of Tokyo. Don't miss it.

Tranquility amid the madness. We had walked for miles this day, and inbetween the very busy bustling areas of shinbuya and shinjuka is the Meiji temple/shrine, and we were lucky enough to be there on a very quiet day, it was like walking around a Forrest, you can't believe such nature, and un pruned, un fussed nature exists right there, literally a breath of fresh air. And a beautiful temple too. Well worth the visit, but allow a little longer than you think, to stroll or sit and enjoy the quiet.
Beautiful shrine. Pretty awesome place, with a lot of viewing/picture opportunities. Visited in October (shorts and t-shirt weather) and was able to find this place easily from Yamanote Line.

Beautiful and serene. I am for from being the spiritual guy, but I found a lot of beauty in the calmness and serenity of the shrine. Even bought an amulet for "soundness of body and mind" at the store

Nice atmosphere. I was surprised when I visit to this shrine. It's like having a forest in a big city. It was quite taking a long way to walk to the shrine but the atmosphere is really nice so I didn't feel any tired at all. When I reached to the place, there're quiet and peaceful. Many couples choose this place for a their wedding ceremony.

A peaceful wonderful shine. I haven't thought that Meiji Jingu shine can be so impressive. And what excited us is that we luckily met the ceremony during our visit. It was a beautiful private walk through the fresh jungle in the quiet center of this big city. It is also a nice place to learn the history of Japan.

Lovely Shrine!. Tokyo's ten top places to go. Travelled there on 1 March (Weather still cold!) I read reviews that this is one of the places to visit. It's easy to come to the Shrine. Take the train to Harajuku Station (Yamanote Line) and turn right, walk straight till you see another ride turn. The entrance of the shrine is just 5 mins away from the train station. It will take you another 10 minutes to walk to the main Shrine. Check the weather condition before going as there is no shelter from the main entrance to the main Shrine. It was a perfect weather,so cooling, the walk in was peaceful and calming. I would suggest go there early as there are much more people later the day.Cleanse yourself before praying. There are instructions in there to follow. The whole visit took us around 1 hr - 1hr 30 mins. Amulets as souvenirs for your friends and family can be purchased in there. Bring cash, I do not remember that they accepted cards there.

One of the most beautiful shrines in Tokyo. Tokyo has hundreds of shrines and temples but this one is special. Even though it's right next to Harajuku, it's embedded in a relatively large, quiet park. You can even learn a thing or two about Japans history while you stroll through it and before you actually get to the Shrine itself.

Visited on Jan 2. It wasn't so crazy.. There's always a loooong line (2-3hrs wait) on New Years Day. I assumed it would be the same but,,, we didnt wait!! Just 5mind at the end.. We went there in the morning, around 9, so it was before getting busy.

A beautiful experience. I came here as it was recommended on multiple travel blogs, and I am so happy I did. I had a little difficulty finding it, I ended up turning the wrong direction. But once I saw the archway, I knew I was there! This is a huge property with tons of things to see, so make sure to wear comfortable shoes. I went in July, where it was very very hot. So I made sure to go first thing in the morning, where there was still a cool breeze. This is a nice change of pace from the city that is surrounding it.

diversity. One of the most beautiful and interesting places in Tokyo. In the entrance and nearby Yoyogi park, lots of different urban tribes. Inside, traditional japanese weddings, surrounded by amazing temple and trees, in the heart of Tokyo.

Serene cultural experience. Acres of trees and nature and preserved Japanese architecture at it's best. It's a peaceful walk throughout and although it was drizzling, didn't want to miss all the sites. Dress comfortably especially shoes as the pebble walkways can be bothersome. Located near the train station and nearby eateries outside the park. Captured a traditional Japanese wedding which was beautiful.
Beautiful!. Take your time. Great to go with a guide so you see more than the sites: you understand the whats and whys. We witnessed a traditional wedding during our visit.
Nice history and atmosphere. I came here on a sunny Sunday afternoon and the atmosphere was great. lots of people of all kinds coming to see the shrine for prayers, photos, and even a wedding!

Beautiful Walk. Wear comfortable shoes to walk through the beautiful trees and nature nestled right in the city, The shrine is sprawling and free to walk through. Wonderful traditional architecture in this serene and peaceful place.

A beautiful walk. In a good location close to Hajuku station. A serene walk through a tall forest ( 700 000 square metres) with interesting attractions along the way (large Sake casks and barrels of French wines). Good modern facilities, shops bathrooms and rest areas. Massive cypress gate some 1500 years old leads to the main shrine which awesome and moving. An enjoyable respite from the hectic frenzy of Takeshita Street close by.

A peaceful place. This time my friends and I walked into it from 參宮橋 instead of JR harajuku station. It was a totally different experience to me because we enjoyed the silence and peaceful feeling while passing by the alleys.

Dare to visit this controversial war dead shrine.... I understand that this large park and Shrine/Temple is to the Japanese war dead as well as the Emperor. But it is a nice walk in the park and well situated near Harujuku and Shibuya. Be prepared for crowds and a shortcut through the Bus/Car Parking may avoid the crowds. Good luck and Enjoy!

Peace and Quiet in the Big City. In a completely unexpected location in the middle of Tokyo is Meiji Jingu. A peaceful walk through a wooded area situated near Harajuku station takes you to an amazing structure and a fascinating part of Japan's history. We went during the week and it was lovely to see business people heading to the shrine during their workday. It is relatively touristy though with large groups of foreigners attempting to take photos of things you aren't supposed to.Meiji Jingu is a slice of history in metropolitan Tokyo and must be experienced.

Serene beauty in the heart of the city. Meiji Jingu is one of the most elegantly beautiful Shinto shrines you'll see in Japan. The temple is all the more sublime due to its emerald green forested setting. From the immense cypress-wood torii gates, to the majestic simplicity of the wooden shrine, the overall effect is peaceful serenity. A visit on the weekend can be all the more special since you are likely to witness a wedding procession, with the bride & groom decked out in beautiful traditional clothes. An amazing sight! (please see my pics)

Pleasant walk through the jungle . I was not expecting to see the beautiful temple after the walk through a typical Japanese forest. Nice ambience, but there is not much to see aside from the walk and the temple.
Great location. Interesting shrine in beautiful surroundings. A haven from the streets nearby. Could be a longish walk if you're not fit.
Oasis near shopping. Lots of trees and fresh air within walking distance of Shibuya, Harajuku and Shinjuku shopping areas if you're wearing sensible shoes.

Tranquil, calm and holly forest in the big city. The entrance gates (main, east and west) open and close, according to sunrise and sunset every day. So early in the morning is the best time to visit. Nobody there but several workers sweeping fallen leaves on approaches and sunbeams streaming through leaves are only things you can see.That's why approaches are always kept in a clean condition, and the forest isn't natural, but man-made: developed by tens of millions of people just a hundred years ago.This is a secret of Japanese beauty, only you can see is their fruit, not themselves.

Peace in the heart of Tokyo. I have visited this place many times over the years, with family, friends, kids, teens...This amazing Shinto shrine ( the Imperial Household uses this) is smack dab in the middle of a busy area, beside noisy, colourful Harajuku, at the end of high fashion Omotesando Dori and beside Yoyogi Park where there always seems to be some festival or party going on. Once you enter the long, tree lined avenues leading up to the shrine, it's like being sent back in time. Huge cedars and enormous torii ( gates) mark the gravel path and the dark wood structure with it's contrasting white accents embodies the true nature of Shintoism. Make sure to stop and read through any of the information brochures available or look it up ahead of time so that you can have your own guided walking tour and understand what exactly you are seeing. Purify your hands at the fountain. The garden is at it's best when the irises are in bloom in June (this has an entry fee) but is totally worth if if you are there then. The rest of the year there are plenty of fabulous gardens everywhere in. Tokyo to see ( Happo en, Korakuen, and the garden at the Nezu Museum are my recs). If you are lucky you can catch sight of a wedding procession at Meiji Jingu, complete with red and white clad assistants, and heavy silk furisode wedding kimono on the bride. In the summer sun they walk under big red traditional parasols. If you are there in the warmer months, this place seems so much cooler than the rest of the city under the big shade trees. If you are there in the winter, note that the bathrooms on site in the woods are clean and have heated toilet seats! You can plan your visit to the surrounding area all in the same day ( Yoyogi, Harajuku, Omotesando, Meiji. Jingu. Note: the super souvenir store on Omotesando Dori ( Oriental Bazaar) is closed on Thursdays. The Ota Woodblock museum is a terrific small place on Omotesando as well.

Free tours by pinpo. We visited Meiji Shrine on a Sunday afternoon 3:30pm. At the entrance there was 3 high schooler holding a sign that says free english tour. Met Jin here with 2 of his peers to give us a tour of the Meiji Shrine. It was a nice 30-45 min tour. He talked about the shrine, when it was built, how long it took, and how many people participated.They told us the methods of entering a shrine and showing the purification process. We also saw a wedding taking place. Overall it was a nice afternoon stroll. Very close to subway station.

My Favorite Thing in Tokyo. The Meiji Jingu shrine is not especially old and is elegant and simple. There is an excellent little brochure in English that explains the significance of the place. But what makes this place so wonderful is the forest in which it is set. You'd hardly know you are in a megacity. It is tranquil and quiet, such a treat.

Peace and Calm. This is a beautiful shrine and a definite must-do if you are in Tokyo. If you are lucky, you might even be able to observe a wedding!
It is located not far from Harajuku and Omotesando, so you can definitely make a day of it. Be sure to walk around in Yoyogi Park while you are there.

A shrine to visit. Compares with Senoji Shrine, Meiji breathes a much slower pace. Located within a park one has to walk there for 5 to 10 minutes. We started off from Yoyogi station and had much less people on our way, allowing us to hear the wind moving the trees branches above us. Such a beautiful and spirituous experience. Once we have reached the main shrine there are for sure a lot of tourists and locals, yet there is still a possibility to enjoy this place without feeling rushed or crowded and that is by just taking a step back and walking along the outskirts of the courtyards. There are beautiful trees, prayer offering opportunities and treasuries to explore. No entrance fee apart from 500yen per person for the adjacent Meiji park (not compulsory).

Simply the best! . There are many shrines to visit in Tokyo but for me, this is the best one. To get to it you get the train to Harajuku station and then walk through the stunningly beautiful Yoyogi park, worth a visit in itself. This is a Shinto shrine and it is simple with beautiful green roofs and big empty spaces. Great to watch the locals coming to pray and buy good luck charms. Really worth a visit!

Sunday Best. Loved seeing the locals come to the shrine and seeing the adorable kids in their traditional dress. I liked how the shrine is hidden away in a mini forest and it shuts out the city noise. It's quite a walk though so be ready :-)
Just Beautiful. It's a great example of how good Japanese are at preserving history and celebrating it's culture.It's great place for a nice photography session to add to the holiday memories
beautiful park. really peaceful park and beautiful scenery in the middle of tokyo amazing gardens a must go if you are in tokyo

Beautiful, Peaceful, Spiritual. On a rather cold damp morning I made way here after a visit to the fish market and the moment I entered the park like setting - the cold disappeared, the sun came out and the birds started to chirp. But what really struck me was how green the park area is compared to Shinkuku Central Park where the trees have lost many leaves. But here the trees are green and leaves on the trees strong and healthy in this the second week of February. The shrine and related buildings are magnificent and well worth a visit. Plan on a minimum of 2 hours given the trek to get into and out of the shrine itself let alone exploring the park and walkways and to leave a prayer for the Shinto Priests to say for you (I did two).

Lovely Experience. The inner and outer gardens have a nominal entrance fee, but visiting the Shinto shrine, rebuilt in 1958 after being destroyed in an air raid in 1945, is free. So is achieving Zen at an array of Buddhist temples, among the most popular being the sprawling Zenpuku-ji in Roppongi that dates back to the 800s.

A moment of calm. The Shrine and surrounding grounds are a great way to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. As soon as you enter the grounds you get a sense of peace.It's a short walk to the main buildings. Along the way you pass racks of sake barrels, and depending on the time of year there are different displays set up along the path. (last year there were ice carvings lining the route).It's an amazing place and worth a visit!

Cool shrine surrounded by a great park. This shrine is surrounded by a beautiful park, and it’s a great walk to get to the shrine. It’s right by the hirajuku area so it’s nice to visit both places at once. On the way to the shrine there were lots of stands with bonsai tree exhibits as well as these flowers what I do not know the name to but they are huge and beautiful. A great place to visit for a nice walk to experience the less hectic busy everyday life and culture of Tokyo.

Beautiful shrine. The shrine was beautiful. Definitely a must-see in Tokyo. There were many traditional weddings held there throughout the day also. It is amazing to see them walk by. You can buy little charms that each have a certain blessing bestowed upon them. You can also buy a prayer board to write on and hang with the rest of the prayer boards.

Very peaceful. What a lovely place to spend an hour or two. Tokyo can be somewhat hectic, so going somewhere like this can be a fantastic break from the madness. You will also get some stunning photos, even in winter.

The most peaceful place on earth. The weather was 13 c that morning so it's really great walking from the first gate to the shrine. While I'm walking I can see the view on both sides full of tree and flowers. That day I visited they had Bonzai tree competition. It was the first time in my life to see such a big Chrysanthemum in this shrine. The path to the shrine is quite quiet. You won't feel tired walking at all. Once we got to the shrine it was a bit rain so the picture was beautiful. You can't take a picture at the shrine due to respect of the god and Kings spirits. Under the big tree you can write your wishes on the wood plat and hang it there for 500 ¥ and don't forget to do the stick fortune teller for 200 ¥ for me it's really precise.

Absolute must see. Visited last weekend during a trip to Tokyo. Went to a few shrines in the city (around Akihabara and Azabujuban) but if you could only see one during your visit -- this would be it. Lovely walk up to the shrine itself through the forest. Some photos here (http://www.furthereast.com/travel/meiji-shrine/). Quiet during the week but doesn't get too busy even at the weekends.

Lovely. The temple itself is nothing spectacular (those around Kyoto are more breath taking) but worth a look. Quite a pleasant short walk away from city.We were lucky to witness a traditional wedding taking place which was quite exciting.The highlight for me was the dozens of small children dressed in traditional outfits. They seemed to be celebrating some sort of milestone. I'm not sure how often this occurs (seems quite regular judging by the number of photos on Trip advisor). Plenty of photo opportunities.

Must see!. Escape the hustle and bustle of Harajuku and enjoy the peaceful surrounds of Meiji Jingu. It's hard to believe this beautiful little temple and park are right in the middle of Tokyo. We were lucky enough to visit during the New Year period, so there were food stalls and markets set up around the shrine. A must-see if you are in the area, allow a few hours to really explore!
Nice. A bit of a walk but it was nice. There was a line however to get in and see the actual thing...so we just hanged around outside and took some pics.

Serenity in Tokyo?. Stepping inside the Meiji Jingu is really an incredible experience, especially if you have walked or been in rush-hour subway traffic to get here. There are people around especially in the actual shrine, but more than half the attraction for me was taking a break from the sometimes-hectic Tokyo atmosphere. At the right time, the flowers would be incredible, but going in the winter is still worth it if you just want a nice stroll and to take in a little history about the Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. Go on a weekend if you can--the Treasure House is open. If you're there on a weekday, I would skip the Treasure House pass which only gets you into the Annex which, though interesting, is a little limited. DON'T skip the inner gardens, though--they're just too impressive and off the beaten path.

A must for a short stay in Tokyo. We had a few days in Tokyo on the way to the ski flields and we found this place by accident, there were hardly any western tourists and it made for a true Japanese Experience. Whilst it is true that there are more elaborate temples in Japan, this place is an attraction for locals as according to folklore, Meiji will grant wishes to visitors to the shrine who throw coins, clap twice and bow twice while making a wish. I'm told to be careful what you wish for, as the wishes do come true! So far my wish seems to have come true....

Kiyomasa's well made it worth the visit. The Meiji shrine itself was ok; it was nice to see the lanterns, and sake and wine offerings and walk through the large grounds. But what it made it special was the visiting Kiyomasa's well -- it was pristine and the visit felt almost spiritual because of the space around the well and how it is tended to. There is a small fee for entering the garden where Kiyomasa's well is located.

Interesting retreat in the City. Nice place, big space in the city and well worth a look. Didn't live up to the beauty of Kyoto but a wonderful place to get out of the bustle of Tokyo and see trees and greenery and escape the crowds.

A must see when in the Harajuku area. Walk from the shrine area to Harajuku and then to the main part of Shibuya. My favorite thing to do in Tokyo.
Here is a video of the shrine area: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ad5yszccFWI&list=PLG6QC0filzK8_UHDRH0KGbBWyJscclw-a

Interesting, but not as attractive as others.. If you have visited shrines in Kyoto or Nikko, then you will not find this one very beautiful. It's subdued coloring of austere brown wood is traditional, but not as artistic as those that are painted or gilded. The long walk on a wide dirt path took us alongside a wooded area, but would not be good for elderly, handicapped or very young children - there are no benches along the way. On the day we visited, the Treasure Museum was closed (open only on weekends in the Fall), and there is no entry to the modern-day ceremony area, in order not to disturb people conducting services.
Lovely Escape. Very peaceful and relaxing place to visit. Easy walk from the underground stop and shoping area. Would recommend to visit for some time out. Not too busy either.

If you're visiting other cities skip this!. This temple was very simple and the grounds unimpressive. I'm slightly biased, I live near Kyoto which is famed for its temples.... But Meiji-Jingo was just plain and boring. If you practice Shinto or Buddhism and come here for religious reasons it's one thing, but if you come to see it as a tourist attraction it's a waste of time. I guess if you're only visiting Tokyo it'd be worth it to experience a traditional temple, but if you're going to be visiting Kyoto or any smaller town I'd just skip and and utilize your time elsewhere!! I just felt like the hour I spent walking through here could have been much better spent at a museum or on the streets.

Get there early to avoid the tour bus crowds.... On my first day in Tokyo i only went as far as the front gate and there seemed like thousands of tourists. Upon returning another morning at approximately 9am there were less than 10 people i could see. Inside the main shrine there were a few more but not many. The walk to the shrine was magnificent. The early morning temperature and a hint of fog and the city yet to awaken made it a pretty surreal and serene experience. I am so glad i returned and had a proper inspection. I don't believe it would have been quite the experience with the crowds. There is also a ceremony held every morning(either 7am or 8am..) if you're up early enough.

Beautiful gardens, interesting temple. An escape from the hustle and bustle! Beautiful gardens and a relaxing walk, we were there in winter and they had ice sculptures lining certain parts of the avenues. The temple itself was interesting and as it was a public holiday when we were there a number of the Japanese girls were in their kimonos with their family to celebrate. The temple visit is free but we paid an extra $5 to visit the inner gardens which were pretty bleak in winter but the highlight was an area where the birds in the trees come down and perch on your hand to eat bread crumbs - got some great photos! We got off the metro at Harajuku station to get here and you can walk down to Shibuya crossing quite easily from here as well.
My favourite shrine. Walking through the forest to this shrine in central Tokyo is one of the highlights of any visit to Japan. Every time I visit Tokjo I come here - it is so peaceful and serene.

Shinto Shrine. This shrine, established in 1920, is dedicated to the divine souls of Emperor Meiji and his Consort Empress Shoken. There is a very large forest, originally created by the donation of 100,000 trees, and formal gardens in which to wander

Nice walk. I took my son here so he can run off his energy. It's a nice walk to the shrine. My son likes to run and wonder on the side. The shrine itself is so beautiful. It's a good place to learn the japanese culture and how to with the shrine. I went to one before this and it doesn't have a guildline: to bow at the gate, to clap, or to rinse hands.
history. I was lucky enough to witness a wedding while I was there. Worth a visit. Very nice park to walk through as well.
Serenity. Tranquility prevails here. Refreshing oasis from the hustle and the bustle of the city. You make your wishes and you feel the peace.

Interesting experience. I'm very glad I did this but you have to make your wish right!First when you're walking in, stay on the left. Don't walk in the middle of the road because that's for the Gods. Next wash your hands in the bamboo thingWhen you approach the shrine, you need to do they following (in this order):- Throw a few coins in (underhand only)- Bow- give your name, birthdate, and address (not aloud, just imagine you are telling it)- make your wish (should be something that you are going to try to do or make happen. You are asking for help)- Bow - exit to the left
Such serenity. I love this tranquil site- meandering through the gardens to reach the temple - it is a place of serenity amidst the mayhem of Tokyo
Beautiful. Definitely worth a visit while in Tokyo. The Shrine is beautiful. The gardens also are surprisingly pretty in Winter. Lovely walk in and out from the nearby station.
Peaceful. A lovely place to visit. Best to avoid the heat as can get a little humid. However, peaceful and quite against the background hustle of Japan.

Favourite place in Tokyo. I loved this shrine as it is set in a little forest and you have to walk through the stillness to get there. A little oasis of calm against the crazy fun of Tokyo. The shrine itself was beautiful and I was lucky to see two weddings while I was there - one in the traditional colours and one in white. Really a must see.....

First beautiful shrine of Japan!. This was the first shrine we visited in Japan and have to say it is lovely and peaceful.We visited on a bank holiday so it was busier than normal and it also meant part of the shrine was cordoned off.Despite this, the walking routes, the lakes, the sake barrels, rows of lanterns and tradtional clothing worn by the Japanese were amazing. We really enjoyed the tradition of cleansing our hands before entering the shrine and you could write a prayer for the future and it would be transposed onto wood and hung from the prayer tree.We didn't visit the well despite paying 500yen for the trail as the queue was too long.Enjoyable morning out and worth a visit!
Beautiful and peaceful . A place of pure peace... Walking through the magnificent tall trees to discover stunning temples and beautiful architecture

Serenity . This should be in your bucket list. Make a wish, walk the park, or simply not do anything but take in the fresh air. There are charms sold outside the shrine and you must get that for yourself, friends and family!

Harmony & Lucky Place. The place is just beside the hustle and bustle Harajuku (known as Youth Town) . Meiji jingu is very peaceful and large religious place. The shrine is very clean and i'm lucky to see the Japanese wedding ! it's very unforgettable moment. It's nearly closed time when we are in this temple.

Stillness in the urban. Meiji Jingu is a relatively new shrine with the history on less then one hundred years. The atmosphere changes as soon as you go through the Torii, the gateway at the entrance. I highly recommend that you visit the shrine with the guide, unless you are good in Japanese language. Remember that only the God of the shrine could go through the centre section of Torii gate.
New Years with the Locals. Went on December 30 - there were thousands of Japanese visiting to say prayers for the New Year. Got to see one of the primary reasons the shrines are there...

its a must visit place. There are lots of temples in Tokyo for you to visit but in terms of religious significance this one takes the highest position. The crowd at the place is itself a testament to this fact. if you are visiting the place on the right day you could catch a traditional wedding ceremony and otherwise too you could catch a lot of people in the traditional attire. The best thing about the place is the environment being surrounded by beautiful gardens.

Calm amongst the hussle of the City. We visited the Meiji Shrine as part of an all day coach tour. Our guide was very informative in relation to the history of the Shrine and it was quite relaxing walking through the trees to get to the main gate/shrine. I think if you don't have a guide or some kind of narrative about the place, then you'd miss out on a lot and it wouldn't be the same.

Peacefull. After a terrible storm i went to the shrine and it was like heaven. It was quite and peacefull, you can't find any sign of cities crowd. The structures and buildings are very beautiful. There is shop in the shrine arena, you can buy wonderful souvenirs and desserts. I wish i could spend more time there.

Calm & Karma. Right next to Harajuku, the Meiji Shrine was really glorious and a stark contrast to he neighbouring surrounds. The paths are enveloped by large green trees and grounds are meticulously maintained. There were several traditional weddings on as well, and the amazingly polite locals don't mind some western tourists ogling at their photo shoots in traditional kimono. There were also a lot of cute kids whose parents are more than happy to let you take a pic of, as they pride in the detail of their appearance. Meiji has a sense of calm, peace and serenity about it, and highly recommended for some down time or a casual stroll. It is one of those places that you can make an audible exhale and smile as you ponder mindfully about everything and nothing.

Relaxing break from the city.. In the middle of the busy city, the Meiji shrine is a sanctuary for tired tourists and citizens alike to take time out, walk beneath the covering canopy out of the summer sun and relax. The atmosphere is beautiful.

Out of place. I was surprised to find this quaint and beautiful little place right in the middle of busy Tokyo life. This is the place for you if you want to be midst natural beauty or a beautiful little garden. But this also happens to be one of the most crowded and popular places and hence lots of tourists could be found at the place. The place is also common for traditional weddings and if you are lucky enough you could catch one in action making it an unbelievable experience but since the place is very sentimental to the natives and also being an active religious center, make sure you are properly dressed and keeping the sanctity intact by not being too “touristy”
Meiji Jingu. Beautiful place and so easy to get there...!!! Lots of walking like every place in Tokyo, it will probably take around 2 hours to walk around.

The Best Spot in Tokyo!. We visited the Meiji Shine on the Saturday after Christmas. We entered from the Harajuku Station and it was quite a long walk through a park lined with big trees. Despite the long walk, we didn’t feel tied since the weather was cold with nice December wind. It felt like being in a forest rather than a big city of Tokyo. There are many spots where we took some nice photos along the way. The shrine is very nice to pray in. On the way back to the Harajuku station we stopped at a very nice proper restaurant where we had our lunch at 3pm. The foods were delicious! There is also a souvenir shop near the restaurant. Overall, this is a nice place to visit if you want to get away from the busy side of Tokyo.

Must See. Meiji Shrine is a beautiful shrine complex in the middle of a forest. We visited just before New Year so the atmosphere was amazing. On a previous visit I did visit on New Years Day but decided not to brave the crowds this time. We went into one of the paid walks and it was well worth the 500 yen entrance fee.If you want to escape the crowds of Tokyo for a while then this is a lovely place to take a walk.

An Oasis among the chaos. We walked here from the Shibuya Station on a cool crisp Jan day, and then went on to Shinjuku on the other side of the shrine/park. For those that like to walk it will take a few hours. Felt like 10-15k. But a nice way to see the neighborhoods first hand. You can also take subway which lets you off right by entrance. The Shrine is very nice, but after having just visited the Kyoto Shrines and Temples it didn't impact me as strongly. Regardless I would put this on/near the top of your list in Tokyo.

Quiet and green in the city. Well worth the experience and the walk. If your don't like seeing temples or parks then this is not the place for you .We found it very peaceful and completed some of the other "paid" walks off the main path. Without ruining it by saying where it is, if you can find the area where the old man feed the finches (I guess they were) and let you do it as well it was a really cool unexpected Tokyo highlight

Oasis within Tokyo city. One of the larger shrines in Tokyo. It is usually packed with tourists. I recommend you to look for a detour to enter the 'oasis'. It costs around 200 yen and the view is breathtaking. For me it felt like an isolated part of Meiji Jingu. Very few visitors would wander into that part but you won't regret it!
Avoid the weekends!. Very crowded on the weekend. Go early to avoid, though you will be likely to see traditional wedding processions. We went on a Sunday and saw many.

Beautiul shrine. I took the south entrance (from Harajuku). It was a pleasant walk from the entrance to the main shrine. The view along the walk is serene and the shrine is beautiful. Visitors can refer to brochures on how to pay their respect before entering the shrine.

Peace. Not old compared to what you find in the rest of the country, but that's typical of Tokyo. It is very important, however, and should be on one's must see list. If you will be in Tokyo on New Years Day, brave the crowds and go then for hatsumode. Yoyogi park is lovely and it's very calming after the frenzy of Shibuya or Harajuku.

Meiji Shrine visit - even on a rainy day!. With a typhoon looming in Tokyo, we didn't want to spend the day indoors, so we opted to visit the Meiji Shrine - the south entrance is steps from the Harajuku Station (JR Line). Follow signs to Meiji Jingu. We walked about a quarter mile to the actual shrine, but enjoyed the 'quiet' - despite the rain falling on our umbrellas. This is an amazing place to get away from the hustle bustle of a busy city, and even better on a rainy day! Please note there are some places which should not be photographed, so pay attention to signage at the shrine. There is a gift shop and a small eatery. The gardens (small fee to enter) are en route to the shrine (free). This sight is definitely worth visiting to give you a sense of the beauty and serenity of Japanese gardens and landscapes. (A note about rain gear - might be good to carry water repellent pants with your rain jacket, as the typhoons are drenching!!!)

Peaceful Oasis. This is a lovely peaceful place to visit in very busy Tokyo. The entrance in right next to Harajuku JR, free to travel on with a JR pass. The shrine is at the end of a long wide path in the centre of the park. Very few people there on a weekday morning.

serenity in the city. this place is huge! just standing before a Torii is enough to take your breath away. i spent almost 15 mins just soaking up its magnificence and the serenity of the forest.i enjoyed a calm, relaxing walk through the sprawling grounds to the gate of the shrine. and i really appreciated the cleansing ritual before you enter the temple. not sure it's necessary, but it does bring you into a more meditative space.make sure you check out the large tree where people hang their blessings, and toss some coins for a prayer at the heart of the shrine. i found a little surprise at a counter where i could pick up a scroll that contains a poem/proverb written either by the Emperor or Empress. wonderful place i will definitely come back to if i'm in Tokyo.

Temple in the Middle of the City. It is quite surprising that you can still find big temple with a lot of trees in the middle of busy city. You can escaping a while from the noisy city to enjoy trees and silent atmosphere in this temple. Once you entered this temple, it feels like you are not in the middle of the city. The temple itself is very nice and represent Japanese culture.

must visit. visit the shrine. be sure to wear comfortable shoes as this is a huge park but also beautiful especially when we visited in autumn. also, go to the inner gardens. we visited the iris garden and it was beautiful with a koi pond, an empress tea house and beautiful foliage. entrance fee is 250 Yen. If you're lucky, you'll witness a traditional wedding at the Meiji Shrine.

A peaceful hideaway from the city. This was another peaceful and beautiful hideaway from the noise and lights of the city. If you're looking for a place to escape from the fast pace of Tokyo then this is a good place to come. The shrine is very interesting and a good insight in to Japanese culture. You can learn quite a lot by just standing respectfully at a distance and watching what goes on here. There's also plenty of notices in English to help you understand how important this place is to many people. I was lucky enough to witness a couple of traditional Japanese weddings whilst i was there which really brought the place to life.

enjoyed the walk along the park to the temple.. Personally, I enjoy walking to get all the sights. We alighted at Yoyogi station and walked to the park that leads to the shrine. It's a easy and quiet walk towards the shrine and at the other exit brings us to Harajuku. The sunny winter day is a plus point too.

Lovely green walk in busy Tokyo. We were trying our luck to see if we might catch the red leaves but it seemed we were a bit early that all the trees remained green when we were there. However, it did not make our trip less impressive as the whole park was so massively green and presented a sense of silence. We were lucky to see a traditional Japanese wedding hosted there and some traditional ceremonies showing their respect to the heritage. Since it is only 5 minutes away from Harajuku JR station, it will be worth a wall before your shopping tour. Feel it and you will like it!

An old and special shrine worth to visit. Meiji Jingu is a shrine dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji and his consort, Empress Shoken. Located just beside the JR Yamanote Line's busy Harajuku Station,built in 1920. You will walk pass sake jars and wine jars, torii. I was relax while walking into Meiji Jingu. There were some flowers booths display along the path. Make a wish in Meiji Jingu and enjoy the peaceful moment here.

An oasis in the middle of Tokyo!. Be sure to visit Meiji Jingu on a sunny weekend to be able to watch a (or two, or tree) traditional weddings! The alley to the shrine is also stunning. Highly recommended!

Serenity and Peace.. I'm surprised how the Meiji Jingu shrine is located right next to Harajuku station that often gets overcrowded with people. So the walk to the shrine was actually a relief from that hustle and bustle. As you go past the torii, sake jars, and scenic route, you would eventually reach this famous holy shrine.The shrine grounds also has ema, the wooden plaques that have a Shinto symbol on the front and the person's wishes on the back, all hanging. You can go by and check those out. You can do wishes on paper in exchange for yen.Upon arrival however, there was a ceremonious wedding that we saw as the bride and groom and co. walked to their photo op. That was pretty interesting. They say it's good luck when you witness such a event.

Beautiful. I visited Meiji Jingu with my family (mom, sister, and her husband). It was love at the first sight. I was amused just seeing the gate. The moment I stepped inside, I was more amazed. It was beautiful. I didn't go through the garden, but I took a picture in front of it. I am sure it was beautiful. You have to pay ¥500 for the garden and the treasure museum.Inside, I was able to see the traditional wedding which was held on that day. There were also a wishing wall which you can write your wish and put it on a wall. You will also have to pay ¥500.
Go and make a wish... One station away from Shibuya.Must visit if you want to experience quiet within the bustling city of Tokyo.

Tranquility amidst the hustle & bustle . We visited the Meiji Shrine & it was a wonderful experience. It is very close to Harajuku station & the moment you enter the park its a totally different experience. It's a must attraction in Tokyo. The history behind the shrine is wonderful. There is a market just opposite to the station , you can get wonderful crepes there. We also got a tee printed with Japanese translation of our names for Yen 2400 in just 5 min.

A great place to walk around and lose oneself in. I was able to go to Meiji Shrine on the last week of November, the end of autumn. It was a national holiday, too, so there was a bit of a crowd, which made the experience even more fun for me. Kids in their finest kimonos, families all dressed up, a Shinto wedding procession... I was just soaking it all in!There are certain parts of the area where an admission fee is required, but even if you stick to those that don't, you will still be sure to have a great time.It's very accessible from the Harajuku Station and is also close to other key attractions, so you can include it in a one-day itinerary. Read more here: http://jeffer.wordpress.com/2014/12/16/tokyo-japan-2014-meiji-shrine/
Nature. A lovely nature park but be prepared for the long although easy walk to the shrine. Having Yoyogi park next to it spoils the mood as the loud music from Yoyongi spills over to Meiji.

Majestic Place.... It's very easy to go here. We just got off from Harajuku station and less than 15 min walk to the entrance.I got this wow feeling when we started walking inside. The place is quite big before you are able to reach the main entrance of the meiji shrine temple. There are trees lining up and it's quite wonderful to see this during autumn. Inside the temple area, you can write and hang your wishes in a wood stand. And there's a nice shop where you can buy good charms, travel charms etc...
Stunning. One of the best experience of life! Would call it the place of inspiration in stone jungles of Tokyo-city. Strongly recommend for visiting.
Invigorating walk. We went the Meiji shrine during the chrysanthemum festival in November. The area was cool, so it was a nice walk with not too many people around.
Felt we had to do it, but you don't get to see a lot. The ground to get in are majestic -particularly for the middle of Tokyo, but I was disappointed there wasn't more museum or temple area to see.

Nature within the urban jungle!. Visiting Meiji Shrine will give you a sense of relief while visiting Tokyo. Excellent place to walk around and recharge. Check the map and will find that the shrine grounds are quite big besides just the main shrine area!

Tranquil, secret garden with a slight "Forbidden City" feel. Meiji Jingu Shrine was a solo visit before some afternoon business meetings. I was not sure what to expect, but in the heart of a city is this huge park of beautiful trees. A wide path draws you to the Shrine. Read the etiquette on their website and be sure and take part in the respectful rituals - the bowing when entering, washing your hands, mouth at the font and then bowing, clapping, bowing at the Shrine. While the thought of doing these rituals "in front of others" was uncomfortable, doing them help me connect to the site, the history and the harmony of the whole place - which made this a very peaceful and worthy use of "a few hours to kill" (and a highlight of the trip). For the rest of my visit, I tried to figure out how to go back - but could not work it in but was so glad i went.

Easily accessed very Japanese temple. For one thing it is set in one of the best gardens in Tokyo it is free , there is a sacred spring with healing water . Good kimono watching on festival days . Two best times to visit are in fall when the maple trees are on fire and when the thousands of iris are blooming . During iris viewing , you must have tea and special sweets served by traditionally dressed kimono ladies

Gem in the city. Take a JR train to Harajuku and the temple is behind the station , this is a busy station as it's opposite Takeshita Dori, once you are in the vincinity all the busting disappear an it's very peaceful. Go to Meiji Jingu on a Sunday morning and you can enjoy fresh clean air and a peaceful morning walk to the temple. You can witness traditional Japanese wedding in the temple. This is the second time my family visited the temple and we still like it very much and it's free.Overall it's a nice way to spent a Sunday morning before Heading to Takeshita Dori which most shop open around 1030am to 11am

Lovely Park in the midst of Tokyo. We enjoyed a nice stroll through Meiji Jinju Shrine and its park on a lovely Sunday afternoon. There are various stops along the way for photo ops and also a inner Kiyomasa's Well you can pay to see. Going in September none of the flowers were in bloom; however, there were lots of insects, birds and lily pads to see. If you're short on time, skip this portion, there is also a few to get in. I believe it was 500¥ per person. Once past the old saki barrels you can go left and see a large gate which leads to the main shrine or if you continue straight/right that is also another option, but you approach the main shrine from the side.We had the fortunate opportunity to be there on a day when there were three different wedding processions occurring. It was a lovely treat to see a traditional ceremony. Granted, I'm sure that those booking their wedding at the shrine expect people to stop and watch, all the groups were very gracious.To the right of the shrine is where you can buy amulets and charms. As well, have your fortune "read". It's 100¥ and you shake the wooden box, read the number and advice the staff inside the booths. They then provide you your fortune in either Japanese or English. There is a place to make donations at the main shrine and to its immediate right you can write well wishes on an ema. I believe that was 500¥. We accessed the park grounds from I believe the south? Closest to Harajuku station and it was a quick walk in towards the main shrine area. It's an odd sense of self as you walk out of the park with all of its history and immediately step back in to the present. I lovely culture and history and would say this is definitely worth a stop! Beware there can be mosquito warnings at certain times of the year, so if that's when you are there be sure to have mosquito repellant and/or long sleeves/pants.

Beautifull. This shrine is just a beauty in the middle of tokyo. We kind of stumbled upon it but it was definatly worth the time we spend there.There are a lot of people visiting but there is no pushing or impatience, this is tokyo at its best

Worth a visit. The Meiji Jingu shrine is worth a visit, regardless of what religion you believe in. Easily accessible from the JR Harajuku station, the visit starts with a walk in the park on gravel ground.. go in autumn to see the red and gold leaves, but other seasons it is just as pretty too.The shrine is huge, and very peaceful. and if you are lucky you may witness a wedding there.
Beautiful!. Come in autumn, the trees are spectacular in the gardens. So breathtakingly beautiful I would love to come back in another season. Worth the look!

Peaceful Area, Got to see Japanese wedding.. When you're here you forget that your in Tokyo!!! There's a nice peaceful nature walk before you get to the shrine!! Away from all the big noise of the city. I've been here twice already and probably will go again. I was lucky enough to see a Japanese wedding happening! It was beautiful

Beautiful contrast to the busy streets. Only steps away from busy and fashion-crazy Harajuku streets you'll be surrounded by the huge trees and total calmness. I love the contrast every time I come here. Air is different, very serene and calming, yet those massive wooden gates excites my senses. The buildings at the central shrine area are beautiful and you'll see a traditional wedding ceremony occasionally. Put down your camera or smartphone for a second. Stand still and breathe deeply. Take it all in. It's relaxing and calming. Everyone needs that kind of moment while you are in Tokyo.
It's just very huge.. It's just a very very big place with a shrine. hmmm nothing very impressive to be honest. Go there, together with Harajuku to make the trip more worthwhile.

A must for Tokyo. This is a beautiful Shinto shrine, though situated in downtown Tokyo, feels very remote because of the beautifully maintained gardens that surround it. It is literally feet away from the metro exit (by the same name) and free to visitors. Though tranquil and serene, it is still family friendly and good for kids - they can burn off steam by running around a bit while adults can enjoy the history of the shrine. There are a couple sets of clean public restrooms, a restaurant and a cheaper snack place on the grounds. Though strollers and wheelchairs beware - most of the paths are gravel and very hard on wheels.

Feel good air . We can feel like a huge forest park. Because they have big trees. Yes, also Yoyogi park is next to Meiji Jingu. Everyone can enjoy there. In Meiji Jingu, sometimes we can see happy wedding of Japanese traditional style.
Don't miss it.

LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!!. it's soooo serene but it's located just next to a super busy harajuku line!!! Came here on a sunday and saw at least 3 couples having their wedding here! And sooooo many kawaii childs who came here dressed in kimono for prayers. Love it here! Must come if u r thinking betwn asakusa or meiji jingu!
Beautiful shrine in a park area. A little oasis of rest in the bustling city of Tokyo. A nice walk through a tree-filled park to the shrine. The shrine complex is quite big.

serenity in the heart of tokyo. not a place for high heels.. the walk from the entrance toward the shrine is quite a distance. the road is filled with pebbles so definitely not comfy to walk on high heels.I love the serenity it gives (despite the noise created by stream of tourists). It's calm,cool and peaceful .. I spent about 1.30 hours walking around and also pay a little extra to walk toward the Inner Garden which is home to various floras and fauna.. you will find several bird watching group there..No entrance fee for the Shrine but a 500 yen fee is collected for inner garden.

The most famous shrine in Tokyo!. Located right besides Harajuku station. We went on a Sunday and the place was crowded! It was a long walk into the shrine from the entrance but definitely worth the walk! We even managed to catch a traditional Japanese wedding!Make sure you wear comfortable footwear as there will be a lot of walking and the walking terrain was rocky.

Interesting enough. Turn right out of Harajuku Station on the JR Yamanote Line and then right again. It is a bit of a trek along a pleasant wooded path to the shrine which is dedicated to the Emperor Meiji, who was the first westernising emperor, and to his Empress. On the way there you can see several wooden Torii (gates) as well as dispays of wine saki barrels. The shrine itself is of average interest but the prayer plaques are interesting. It was full of tourists/pilgrims from Japan and other Asian countries. Many Japanese children had been brought there - the girls in traditional Japanese dress and a few boys in Western suits.
