There were also some Shinto wedding ceremonies with the bride and groom and most lady guests in traditional Japanese dress and most of the male guests in Western suits. All of this added interest but I do not know if they occur other than on a Saturday which is when I was there. Apparently, this is a major destination for Japanese to make their first shrine vislt of the year in the first few days of January.

A place to get to know some interesting Japanese rites. This is my third visit to this shrine.Love the cooling and pleasant walk through the forest to the shrine and love the shrine that is always bustling with interesting activities. On my last visit, I had a great time watching and taking photos of a few couples taking their wedding photos in their traditional costumes. This trip, I also got to see quite a few wedding couples going through the rites and taking wedding photos in their traditional costumes. In addition, I was very blessed to have chosen to visit the shrine on the 15th Nov, which happened to be the Japanese Shichi-Go-San (lit. "Seven-Five-Three"). It is a traditional rite of passage and festival day in Japan for three- and seven-year-old girls and three- and five-year-old boys to celebrate the growth and well-being of young children. Lovely children in their colourful kimono were all over the shrine, mostly posing for photos with their family members. The usually solemn shrine had become the playground of the lively children. It was very heart-warming to see the children enjoying their time with their families.I will surely visit the shrine again.

Great place to escape from Tokyo city scene. Walking toward Meiji Shrine, the sounds of the city fade away. It's an easy leisurely walk through to the shrine. I went in the morning and there were an even mix of local temple-goers and tourists. What's lovelier is seeing the locals: there were multiple weddings taking place that morning (one after another), and many young children dressed up in kimonos accompanied by their parents.There is a tree with votive tablets/offerings hung all around it. You can purchase/donate and receive a tablet for your own prayer/wish and add it to the tree as well; it was nice to pause and reflect for a while what I wanted to wish for. (Not three extra wishes, but tempting.)Also visited the garden "next door"--well worth a visit especially if the flowers are in bloom.

good. Meijei Jingu sit nicely in the forest and you will enjoy the walk to the temple. This is also one of the place where Japanese will put on their traditional dress for praying or photo taking.One advice from personal experience, please do not buy the food from the cafeteria which is next to the souvenir shop, the quality and standard is bad.

Best Shrine in Tokyo!. This was my favourite place in Tokyo. So serene and so much culture! i managed to catch a few weddings on the day I visited too. Try and visit during the weekends and catch a traditional Japanese wedding. Make sure you follow all the Japanese customs (i.e. washing hands and mouth, bowing etc) so you can really get involved :) Right next to Harajuku, so i suggest visiting Harajuku on the same day. Visited September 2013. Review with pictures: http://goo.gl/hEfrR5

Wonderful. What a lovely serene place. Even with the crowds this was a fantastic location to visit. The entry gates are impressive and what you would expect of a Japanese garden like this. The cherry blossoms attract a large audience so expect a crowd when they are in bloom.

Relaxing just to take a walk.... After busy day in Tokyo, bricks and mortar, etc. it is nice to visit a nature surrounded Meiji Shrine, where Japan's history made a turning point from tradition to accepting new culture...

60 liters/m are springing.. パワースポットとして有名。
加藤清正が掘ったと言われている井戸は、実はまったく自然の湧き水だったらしい。
都会なのに不思議ですね。
入場料500円
Famous as a better luck spot. Wonderful springwater in a city.
It enters from the admission fee of 500 yen, and a north entrance.

Nice and peaceful. I went two times to Meiji Jingu and was lucky enough to find a wedding ceremony going on there.I went through the parc from side to side for about 35 minutes walk, it was calm sunny but not hot. Typical April Day in Tokyo.The shrine itself is beautiful but the whole experience is about walking to get to the shrine and walking off from it, as it is surrounded by nature.Don't be shy to try the Japanese prayer (shinto ?) .
Most popular shrine in Tokyo. Serene and beautiful. It's a nice breezy walk and it feels like you stepped foot outside of Tokyo. Occasionally, you'll see wedding ceremonies!

A great place to visit in Tokyo in Summer. There are green forests inside so you can enjoy a walk in hot summer without sunlight burn. Besides, it is a place where you can see how peaceful and saint Japanese Temple is.

Worth a visit?. We visited this place late in the evening in November, almost before closing, and unfortunately did not get the best impression of it. The garden was huge and the gate and buildings impressive.I am sure you get a better impression than we did if you visit it in broad daylight.

Great cultural experience. A magnificent setting in the middle of a city. So peaceful and calming. We saw two weddings and the cultural dress was amazing. There were also many children in traditional dress at the shrine when we were there. There were so many people, but all orderly and it did not feel crowded. Definitely worth a visit.

Peace in the middle of a bustling city. I love how Meiji Jingu and its gardens can take you to another place when it's also a few steps away from the busy Harajuku and Shibuya station. To enter the gardens, you have to pay a small entrance fee, but it's all worth it. Had a great time reconnecting and taking in all that nature can offer.
Nice to see. We visited numerous shrines in Japan and this certainly wasn't the most memorable but definitely worth a visit if you are only in Tokyo.

Really lovely. We were lucky enough to see a wedding when we got to the shrine, it was amazing to see families in their traditional dress! It is a really interesting, scenic site that I recommend everyone visits.

Peace & Tranquility. Having travelled to Tokyo for work, I decided to spend a day doing the tourism thing and that took me to Meiji Jingu - thanks in the main to the already fantastic TripAdvisor reviews.I arrived shortly after 8am and the first thing that hits you is the silence - especially as the hustle and bustle of Tokyo is literally around the corner.Having walked around the main site I took a stroll through the gardens (500 Yen for the upkeep) and enjoyed feeding the birds and taking in more breathtaking surroundings. There is enough here to keep you busy for an hour or two and, exiting through the furthest gate, you are very close to Shibuya station and other exciting locations.
Amazing buildings. Nice open gardens with temple in the middle. Worth seeing if it in the area but similair to the other temples

Lovely to see Japanese families in traditional dress. Japanese families visit this Shinto shrine to receive blessings, get married etc. During our visit there was a wedding couple and quite a few children in traditional dress - delightful to see and we didn't feel we were intruding.As a park and buildings this is a place to spend a couple of hours. Lots to see and appreciate.

Japan all warm and fuzzy. This was my ultimate takeaway experience after visiting Tokyo (and Japan) for the first time. It's quite a scenic walk from the metro station. Once you get through the first Torii, you are led to what could be one of the most positive places in the whole in Japan (without knowing it).Young travellers only occasionally think about family when they travel. Meiji Jingu will change that. You'll see families happily bringing their kids - all dressed up in their kimono best - to attend Shinto protection rituals, their parents and grandparents beaming proudly. Young people going through their coming-of-age ceremonies. Happy couples getting married and parading with their entourage. Old couples praying piously but happily. All simultaneously happening in a centuries old shrine with comparatively very little bells and whistles - very Japanese. And then you remember your family back home. Not that you suddenly want to go home, but you happily realise you're not dreading the thought so much.

Interesting shrine. Interesting place to visit with long avenues leading to actual wooden shrine buildings. Really not much to see here although worth a visit if you are in Tokyo as quite a tranquil park except for the modern shopping area.

HIGHLIGHT OF TOKYO!. This was a definitely the BEST attraction for Tokyo as far as historical venue is concerned. It was acres of very tranquil forest setting for this shrine dedicated to the Emperor Meiji. The architecture was wonderful with many peaceful courtyards for ceremonies, especially a traditional Japanese wedding.You are easily transcended into a whole spiritual experience in this hustling and bustling city, a real gem of Tokyo.
Very nice. We enjoyed a nice and quite afternoon here. Very clean and quiet place. There are some nice eateries and souvenir shops around

Gem in the bustle of Harajuku. in the midst of the craze of tokyo, esp Harajuku... you find this temple/ shrine.walking from the gates into the gravel walk way, you sense peace and descending onto you.the age old displays of sake barrels. Temple doors and side buildings. sensual silence.the gravel walk way makes you feel like you are in a shogun era.great break away from the pace of the city.

Plan to spend some quality time at the shrine. The approach to the shrine is a long walk through gravel road surrounded by wooden areas.You walk through a huge gate( Torii gate) which otherwise is pretty ordinary.You also pass rows of caskets of sake and French wine.Make sure you clean your hands before entering the shrine.After entering the premises of the main shrine rest on benches,soak in the atmosphere and admire the peaceful ambience.Like I did, you can write your wish on an paper,put any contribution you want in an envelope along with your wish and it will be offered to the deity.Do not forget to have a Meji Jingu Memorial seal stamped on a brochure made for the purpose,near where you wash hands.Whilst the entry to the shrine is free there is a charge for the Treasure house(which was closed on the day of our visit)and the Inner garden(which we avoided).It is a good idea to combine visit to this shrine with your visit to Harajuku area/Takeshita street.

Better than nothing - but not by much. If you only visit Tokyo on a trip to Japan, and are only staying a few days, and only have a little time to look around, and big old (looking) buildings are your thing, then maybe a quick trip to Meiji Jingu is worth it. Frankly, it takes about 30 seconds to look at it, stick your nose inside, and then walk out. The grounds are nice, the walk into the area pleasant enough, but it is hardly a highlight of Japan. Yes, it is quiet compared to much of the huge metropolis. But if you came to Tokyo for a quiet relaxing break...hmmmm. And you cannot eat your packed lunch there, oh no, much to disrespectful. Go to the park next door.Are there better temples/shrines in Tokyo? Well, since they are all pretty similar, and only the surroundings differ it is much of a muchness.Better than nothing if this all the 'temple trekking' you are going to get.

Magical in the mist. It was a rainy day in Tokyo when we made our way here and we absolutely loved it. The drizzle and the mist made it all seem a little magical. The high point was the spectacular garden (that you have to pay to visit) with a lovely pond. At the end of it is a well which was a bit of an anti-climax but the rest of it was spectacular. One of our top spots in Tokyo.

City Serenity. Call me a philistine but I am a subscriber to the 'seen one temple, seen them all' philosophy. I've toured Japan extensively and I remain steady in this view. That said if Tokyo is the only destination on your whirlwind tour of Japan (or you're just not a huge culture buff, like me) Meiji Jingu is nonetheless a must see. Right in the heart of one of the busiest cities in the world you would be forgiven for thinking you'd suddenly stepped into a rural setting - the shrine surrounds are bordered with thick woods and the noises of the busy city are eerily absent. It's a truly peaceful place and a stroll around the grounds are guaranteed to calm the nerves of even the most frazzled tourist.As for the temple buildings themselves they are a pretty stock standard examples of those throughout the country. If you're lucky you may glimpse monks busily at work or a heavily adorned traditional wedding ceremony. Feel free to cleanse your hands and mouth with the blessed water (instructions are on the English guides for the novices amongst you) or make a wish to the shrine deities (don't forget to add an offering).My favourite way to get there is to get off at Yoyogi station, stroll alongside the train tracks down the back alleys to the left of the station exit and venture into the temple grounds through the sweeping back gates. It's a lovely walk.Meiji Shrine is, among other things, an excellent way to unwind and detoxify from the unending exerberance that is Tokyo. Make sure you visit, if only for a moment, to bask in the cities more chill side.

You Will Forget You are in the Middle of the City. This is an amazing temple, from the entrance and the walkway to the temple, and the temple itself. The entire park surrounding the temple ail surround you and you ail forget you are in the middle of one of the world busiest cities. If you are lucky, you may even see a wedding, (I just missed seeing the couple as they drove away). Do not miss this Temple and the surrounding park.
An evergreen forest!. An exquisite Japanese garden, complete with lake with coi carp and kingfishers and many beautiful sculptures.

A Peaceful Feeling. The long walk was tiresome....but then as I am entering the gate of temple I was feeling relaxed, peaceful. I can say the long walk was worth it, after having this kind of refreshing feeling.I will definitely return here again next time! ;)

Beautiful Shrine in the heart of the park. Just on the other side of the busy Harajuku area is the Meiji Jingu. It is a beautiful quiet walk through to the temple. Once at the temple, it is quite an impressive building. Please do not sit on any of the steps as the staff will ask you to move. We saw a wedding procession while we were visiting to add to our experience. Take the the JR line, get off at Harajuku to get here. Free admission.

Peaceful Feeling. In my opinion, the best place to visit in Tokyo is Meiji Jingu. I love the temple, love the atmosphere that surrounded by beautiful forest. Such a peaceful place, very calm. And it's located in the central Tokyo. No words can describe how grateful I am visited this amazing place.

Perfect Japanese Garden. You can find a peace of mind while visiting this shrine. Set up is perfect and easy on getting there (JR Line, Harajuku Station). Best visiting season I will vote is late November which you can experience the red maple leaves!

Outstanding building surrounded by forest. the park is quite huge with impressive avenues that draw you to the temple. Large gates dwarf the crowds. If you go away into the park from the temple you will feel like you are in the country rather than central Tokyo

Sunday Weddings. Yet another beautiful place to visit in this amazing country. After reading other reviews we went on a sunday and were thrilled to see many ladies in traditional dress and watched 4 weddings quite a sight! highly recommended and free to visit

Shinto Shrine. We took the subway to get to this shrine. It was well worth it. It was a walk from the exit of the subway line to the shrine but it was very beautiful. The temple grounds were interesting. We sat through a Shinto ceremony that lasted 20 minutes. It was wonderful. This was an experience that I will never forget. What wonderful pageantry. We spent about an hour here which was plenty of time. It is worth visiting.

Majestic and peaceful. Many parts of Yoyogi Park were closed due to the dengue fever outbreak when we visited, but we were able to walk through the magnificent gates to the Meiji Shrine. It's a beautiful, tranquil spot and a real contrast to the nearby bustle of Harajuku. Well worth a visit.

Mysterious Surrounding. Walking distance from Harajuku JR station. Was there around 4pm. Notice that the last admission time to the temple changes by the months. I didn't know that, so when i was there i really needed to rush to the temple before it closes.i love the surroundings especially when the sun is setting. Somehow creates a mysterious feeling.

Majestic shrine in the middle of bustling Tokyo. The scale of the Meiji shrine is pretty cool, I really loved the gates. That said, we were there for a grand total of 30 minutes and kind of felt like that was plenty of time.
Holy shrine. This is great, extensive and silence.Entrance is very near from Harajuku station, but it takes about 10 minutes walk to main shrine.You should go there if you are in Tokyo.

Extremely popular but be aware of what time it closes. My family enjoyed our visit to this Shinto shrine immensely. Having come from the excitement of the city, walking in on a broad pedestrian path past quiet woods was like being transported to a different world altogether. Dedicated to the spirits of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken, the royal association is evident in the chrysanthemum symbols placed on the cross beams of the massive toriis (at the entrance and another along the path) that you pass under. Along the way, we passed the (now empty) sake barrels that were donated by various manufacturers from around the country for the shrine's use for the year. Even though it was mid-afternoon, the crowds were still there, and this made for an air of devotion at the shrine. The shrine is also apparently very popular for weddings, and we were lucky enough to come across a wedding couple (with their families) that had undergone a blessing ceremony.Access to the shrine and its surrounding park varies with when you visit. Opening hours start before sunrise (although surrounding attractions like the garden and museum open at 9.00 am) but closing time varies by up to 2 hours depending on the month, so it's best to check their website before you go. I didn't see any signs regarding dress codes but like all religious buildings, it's probably best to dress sensibly.

Beautiful, but historically irrelevant. Compared to other temples in Japan, this is brand new. Built around 1915, it was rebuilt in 1958. It's nice to see, but if historical is what you want, don't come here.

A little piece of serenity. Visited the shrine on a rainy day. Still the walk through the park and Meiji Jingu itself were impressive. Peaceful, serene, beautiful. A real feeling of Japanese history and culture.

Peaceful. Each time on my visit to Tokyo I pass by this shrine.It is in my opinion maybe the best in Tokyo.You will almost forget that you are in Tokyo. It is very peaceful.The museum is highly recommended to.I am proud of having this heritage to share with other visitors.

My favorite shrine in Tokyo!. The walk to this shrine takes you out of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. You walk through a park surrounded by tall trees to get to the shrine and you enter through tall wooden arches.The shrine feels very tranquil and it made us feel at one and at peace when were here. We were lucky enough to see a Japenese wedding too which was beautiful to see.
Peace of mind. located near Shinkuju & Shibuya and its surprisingly quiet. You feel at peace. if you are lucky, you may just see a traditional japanese wedding
Special temple i Yoyogi park. This was the first visit we did in Tokyo, it was on Sunday and we saw a japanese wedding. It was so special. This sintoist temple is a jewell in Tokyo

Peaceful retreat. Visited as part of an all day tour of Tokyo so the only problem was the limited time available to explore. It is really nice to discover a green lung in such a built up city. You enter via the traditional Shinto gate and follow wide paths to the main shrine, built to commemorate the current Emperor's great grandfather. We were lucky to see a tea ceremony taking place with the Shinto priests in their robes and many ladies in kimonos. The shrine itself is bustling with sightseers yet a feeling of tranquility still exists. Well worth a visit for a taste of old Japan to compare with all the glass and marble of modern Tokyo.

Beautiful Park in the Heart of Tokyo. Meiji Jingu Shrine is in a huge park in Shibuya, one of the most popular neighborhoods in Tokyo. It's a very peaceful and lovely park, rarely crowded even while being in the middle of a bustling area. At different times of year you can see a variety of flowers blooming, and there are many trees and areas for strolling. The shrine itself is impressive. Many people like to have a traditional wedding there, so you just might see one when you visit. The Shinto shrine is very traditional and is dedicated to the spirits of Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shōken. The Emperor and Empress are considered to be divine. A research institute located in the park is dedicated to studying their divine attributes. Shintoism is the original Japanese religion that is very much a part of Japanese life. It has no founder or holy book. It is focused on virtues such as living with sincerity and harmony with nature. Followers of Shintoism believe in a multiplicity of beneficent divine spirits called Kami. Many Japanese people include both Shinto and Buddhist traditions and ceremonies in their lives. The Meiji Jingu park area is about 175 acres, with thousands of trees, and many flower beds and ponds. It was created in 1920, about 6 to 8 years after the passing of the Emperor and Empress. Well worth the visit, even if you only have an hour.You'll notice some ceremonial practices, such as hand washing, taking in some incense smoke, donating some coins, and doing a double hand clap. It's fun to watch others and then partake in the practices yourself.

sacred and holy. a short walk from station harajuku, meiji jingu is in a huge park in the middle of the city. a pleasant and peaceful walk to the shrine, watched a traditional japaness wedding taking place, beautiful scene

Easy to get to. It’s a long walk from the entrance next to the Harajuku train station to the actual temple. It’s an interesting and peaceful walk to the shrine but the shrine itself wasn’t that interesting.

Beautiful park. This is one beautiful and peaceful place to visit. Located near Harajuku and a short walk from Shinjuku (or an even shorter train journey). We visited on a Saturday and there were so many wedding's taking place it was just amazing to see. You really forget you're in Tokyo!
Beautiful. A beautiful walk and such a peaceful location given how close it is to the hustle and bustle of Shibuya and Shinjuku.

Can't believe it's at the CENTER of TOKYO. Although it's right at the center of Tokyo (Harajuku), I think most Japanese people haven't been there...and so did I. So, it was really surprising to find (even as a Japanese!) that there's such a quite and relaxing place in Tokyo. Once you take a step into it, what you'll see is the traditional styled Japanese Shrine in such a huge scale. It's surrounded by the broad forests, so it's like a completely isolated "island" in Tokyo. I think it's good idea for tourists to make a stop at here, Meiji Jingu during your exploring of modern city, Tokyo.

Peaceful and close to nature. Meiji Jinqu is one of the the-must-places in Tokyo. Animals lovers, there's a kiosk to collect maintenance donation of 500 Yen at entrance road, you could ask for few beans there to feed the birds around.

Peaceful, amazing. Walking into the park from the Harajuku JR train station, you're greeted by a huge gate or Torii. The walk to the shrine itself was peaceful since we went early. We got to watch a prayer ceremony and two couples setting up for a traditional Japanese wedding. It was a nice change of pace.

Oasis in the Madness of Tokyo. Surrounded by a nice Park. Next to Yoyogi Park. Using JR Train the station is Harajuku.The hugh Gate comprise hugh and tall Timber structure.Very peaceful .Can even witness wedding ceremony in Traditional wedding dress.It is a Shinto Shrine.Wash your hand and mouth before entering the shrine.Throw 50 Yen coin, bow twice clap hands twice, say your prayer , Clap hand once.Now wish your prayer will be answer.Definitely a Must See in Tokyo.

A peaceful site in a very busy citty. You have to take the long walk in the nice part and enjoy the atmosphere of the place. The site is relatively new (less than 100 years) but aspires the emotions of an old temple.
A Must See in Tokyo. Large park in Tokyo. A very scenic walk through the woods to get to a large and beautiful Shrine. If you are in Tokyo, don't miss this!

A great walk. Meiji shrine is located almost centrally within a park. The walk itself is very scenic and peaceful. The barrels of sake (an offering) at the entrance to the shrine was my personal highlight and a great photo opportunity. The shrine is immaculately kept and we were lucky to view two weddings taking place. Do not miss this in Tokyo
Find peace in a busy city. A beautiful shrine surrounded by wonderful greenery. We were lucky to see a wedding take place at the temple nearby. A nice break from the madness of Tokyo.

So nice. Amazingly beautiful place in the middle of the city. Explore yoyogi park and go to the shrine. You may even get to see a wedding. The park is huge. Take time and have a picnic. Go on Sunday and see the performers at the entrance of yoyogi.

Peaceful. Nice little place to walk around away from the main hustle and bustle of the main street. A few things to look at to keep you interested, and a nice chilled vibe around the place. The nearby park is also worth checking out.

Peaceful oasis in the city. The shrine is very easy to access, being in central Tokyo. Which is great with two kids under 4. Easy access with the stroller through the beautiful green surrounds. A very peaceful and serene experience. Really beautiful to stand and read prayers, hopes and messages of gratitude left by visitors. We also witnessed 2 weddings in traditional dress. A really beautiful experience. Highly recommended for families.

Oasis in the city. Meiji Jingu is in the centre of a large wooded area and it is very easy to forget you are so close to the bustle of the city. The long path passes beneath cedar torii gates and over streams to reach the main area. The beautiful buildings are very interesting in themselves, and there are often displays of whatever the local festivals are focused on at the time (for example farm produce around harvest time, crysanthemums earlier in the year), monks performing daily rituals and ceremonies, and if you are lucky you may see a traditional wedding (this is a prestigious venue). Of course there are the usual votive tablets to be written and hung on the sacred trees, charms for sale etc too. There is also a botanical gardens although there is an extra charge for this. I don't recommend a visit at New Year though - thousands upon thousands of people turn out and we ended up pressed into a large , unmoving queue on the main path from 9pm until almost 1am! While it was nice to hear the bells, there are more fun ways to spend an evening. The rest of the year though, this is a serene and lovely place to visit, and we always bring visitors here. Highly recommended.

Peace in a busy city. The entrance to the temple is through a wooded path after passing a huge Torii gate which is made of 1500 year-old trees. There weren't too many people there when we visited one morning so you could wander around and enjoy the peace. The wooden buildings with copper roves are beautiful. There is an area to wash hands and an incense burner. Those who wish can purchase charms or prophecies to present at the shrine. A bonus when we were there was seeing a traditionally dressed wedding couple posing for photos. Another quiet walk through the woods brings you back to the car park.

Beautiful park and temple. We loved all the entrance to the temple,which its a beautiful park ,away from the hustle and bustle of the city. The temple its quiet and serene, and we even saw a japanese wedding. There are a little corner with prayers in bamboo pads,and you can make your own prayer,purchasing the pad or just writing in the sheets and making a little donation if you want.The bathrooms of the park are impecable clean and very modern, I was surprised!I highly recommend this place for your visit to Tokyo.
Wonderful park and temple. Come towards dusk, the atmosphere is magical and on the weekend you'll be able to see a local wedding ceremony.

Serene Setting. The blurring buzz that is Tokyo falls silently away as one enters under one of the most massive Hinoki Tori gates. A stroll along a wide heavily forested pathway presents a breathtaking reward. The shrine is glorious and quietly requests the visitor to linger.On a lucky day, a number of processions of brides may be enjoyed.

Worth a stroll through the park. Nice area - very calm. It is not my favorite temple, but the fact that it is so easily accessible in the middle of Tokyo is unique, But beware of the dengue fever mosquitoes.
Interesting . Interesting but not the best shrine we saw. We were lucky to see 2 weddings take place while we were there. The shrine was relaxing and a place for the kids to explore.

Tradition and peacefulness. When you think on a temple, you come up with words such a quietness but in Tokyo you will come across with people everywhere. This shrine, however, gives you a more quiet experience as it takes you through a great park full of trees and serenity, before you reach the main temple.

Best place to escape the city . For me this is the number 1 attraction of Tokyo. A unique serene place where you can completely escape from all the noise of the city. Don't forget to visit the garden on the left side of the main way!

Serene and lovely. This Shinto shrine is located in the center of a forest planted recently but it has grown to point that it seems to have been there forever. You won't believe you are in one of the largest city's in the world. When you walk through the gate its like entering Narnia.
A walk in the park. Beautiful walk through the park to a beautiful picturesque Shinto shrine, loved the barrels. Good shop and toilets. Worth making a prayer to the gods..still waiting!

Drop by Temple. There will be lot more temples in Kyoto but we decide to visit it anyway. Is free entrance and the walkway is just long enough to get sweat. Great photo can be taken along the way so is not that bored.After the Shrine, walk further down to Meijijingu-mae & Omotesando station. You will find Kiddy Land, Oriental Bazaar, Daiso etc nearby.

Leave a Prayer by the tree. Shrine is located in the middle of a beautiful park with pathways around it covered with tall trees. A lake and all facilities to make visitors very comfortable.Was lucky to see a wedding ceremony happen. You check your fortune or leave prayer or wish by buying a small block, writing a message and then hanging it on the tree.

Amazing temple and history there. Loved the fact that there were Japanese university students around that wanted to take us on a guided tour so they could practise their English. They gave us a lot of history about the shrine that we never would have known otherwise.The walk up to the shrine itself is very beautiful and only adds to the character when you get there. Great to spend an hour or so, and if you're lucky, you'll get to see a wedding going on as well.

Must visit attraction. It is a must place in Tokyo. It is quite a long walk from entrance to Shrine. You can feel the visitors pay respect to this historical attraction especially at the main hall. There are security guard to make sure no photo taken at that area.Outside the main hall, there is an area you can write your wishes, which is the popular things to do.

Interesting. One of the larger shrines I've been to, with all the things you'd expect (charms, prayer boards, incense, etc.)If you're not familiar with Japanese Shinto shrines, I'd recommend this one as it is large and well geared for English speakers. If you're already familiar with shrines, there might not be a huge reason to go here specifically unless you specifically wanted to.

Meiji Jingu Shrine. The popular Meiji Jingu Shrine was built and dedicated to the Meiji Emperor and his wife. A route (15 mins walk) leads from the Harajuku Station through a tranquil forest to the Main Shrine. We were greeted by a huge wooden Torii gate at the main entrance. The toriis are commonly found at Shinto shrines and temples and represent a unique icon of Japan. No visit to Japan would be completed without a photo with a Torii.The main building inside the shrine is the Offering Hall. We needed to walk through a large square to offer our prayer. At the right side of the hall, there is a fence around a tree which many "Ema" are hung. An Ema is a wooden plate which you use to write your wishes.There is an inner garden (500 Yen) which is famous for the Iris flowers. They are supposed in full bloom in June. We went a a tad too early and only a few of them are fully bloomed. The garden is good enough for a stroll but in my opinion can be avoided if you do not have a lot of time. There is also a Homotsuden (Treasure Museum) which we did not explore.The experience at the Meiji Jingu Shrine is an enjoyable one. Compare with other temples and shrines I have visited, the setup of the shrine may not be very impressive but the atmosphere and culture that bind to the holy ground are invaluable. Seeing many Japanese (young and old) offering their sincere prayers at the shrine, I could see the highly-esteemed place Meiji held inside their hearts. I could finally understand the reason why Japanese couples like to celebrate the wedding at the Meiji Jingu Shrine. Do not miss this place when you have the chance to visit Tokyo.

Piece of tradition and history of Japan.. If the high tech Japan is not your thing and history and tradition is, visit the Meiji JIngu shrine near Shibuya. Amidst the chaos and the hussle and bustle of this huge metropolis of the city of Tokyo is this green oasis which was man made to celebrate the Meiji emperor. Tall tress abound but what impresses most are the huge Torii gates and the actual shrine itself. If you are lucky, you may even witness a prayer ceremony or a traditional Japanese wedding. Be sure to purchase a lucky prayer tablet to see what sort of fortune the gods will bestow upon you.
Magnificent gardens. Beautiful, peaceful location with the shrine being the centrepiece. Always plenty of people there but there is plenty of room, so it doesn't feel crowded. Easy access by train.

Not to be missed. Despite the drizzle on our approach to the shrine it was worth the walk for a quiet tranquil moment from the mayhem of Shibuya. The whole experience is also photogenic - from the Sake drums to the prayer plaques, not to mention the courtyard, buildings and shrine itself.

Serenity in the middle of the city. It was a really nice walk into the shrine with the lush forest and sound of nature. The shrine was well kept, and we even witnessed 2 wedding ceromony which gave us an insight on how weddings are conducted in Japan. Really enjoyed it.

Tranquillity in the heart of the city. Meiji Jingu is in a beautiful park a couple of minutes walk from Harajuku station. After reaching the entrance to the park & passing through the giant torii, it's a ten minute walk through the forest to the main shrine. The shrine is very beautiful in the forest setting and is a great juxtaposition to the hustle and bustle of Harajuku. A must-see when visiting Tokyo.

Serene and Peaceful ~. Breath in all the air when you enter the woods. Take time to relax and calm yourself within the shrine itself. Enjoy this very nice unique experience of the Japancese culture. Learn how to pray in the japanese way. Able to purchase their amutlets but no photos of them. Meiji, a must visit place to relax the mind in this quiet and pleasant Shrine!

Unique Japanese Culture. A nice but a bit long walk from the Metro station to the temple. The woods are great considering it's prime location in such a busy city. A very unique experience of Japanese culture. The site is not very large and may take 1-2 hours for the whole tours. If you are lucky, you an witness an old-fashioned Japanese marriage ceremony, which is quite interesting. It's interesting to learn from the locals how they wash their hands before they enter the temple.

Beautiful park and shrine. This shrine is located in a park. Has a very simple and sober construction where the dark wood predominates. The contrast with the green of the nature that surrounds it makes it a quiet and very pleasant place. A must visit inTokyo

Location, Location, Location. Among the myriads of religious sites in Japan, Meiji Shrine may not seem to have much to offer other than its fame, but it’s one of those places you have to experience in person. It’s a fair bit of a walk to get from the entrance at Harajuku Station to the shrine compound itself, but as you go down that path, the forest around you instills a sense of secluded tranquility which belies the bustling city just outside. Other religious sites in Japan may boast more interesting aesthetics, but its location and its size are Meiji’s major selling points.

Nature in the city.. The walk from the subway station to the Shrine was surprisingly comfortable and nice.Even though there was a lot of tourists, it was not like a typical tourist attraction.I was lucky to witness a traditional Japanese wedding!They sell traditional Japanese amulet here! (I heard Meiji Shrine is famous for the love ones)

a peaceful break from Tokyo chaos. Take a break from the bustle and chaos of Shibuya when you enter the 175 acres park surrounding the Meiji shrine & gardens. The shade makes a welcome break during the blazing hot summer months as well. Besides enjoying the shrine, which is large and attractive, if not particularly old, we loved strolling through the gardens (where the local variegated tits will come snatch peanuts from your open palm, if you're patient enough). It has a much more removed and peaceful feeling than any of the other temples or shrines we visited in Tokyo area. Well worth a visit.We did not have time to go to the treasury Museum in the Naien.

Serene. Lush forest. A calm and tranquil place. The Tori (gates) are impressive as you begin your walk to the shrine. I wandered through the gardens after which was peaceful. English brochures offer historical snapshot. I was there for the drumming at 8 but none of the shops or museum were open then.

Serene. The best part is the gardens and the walk upto the shrine. Make sure you have a lot of time for this place as a rushed visit will not do it justice! Just a 10 minute walk from the Subway station!

Beautiful and a great attraction!. The Meiji Jingu shrine was a beautiful place to walk and to see. I was fortunate enough to be there in the morning when a wedding party was arriving which was a really nice experience! It was overcast on the day that I went which meant that there was less people there. I really enjoyed the whole grounds and there is a beautiful garden that you can stroll through as well! This is definitely a must-see in Tokyo since it had a different feel to it than the Temples and so it was a nice addition to my trip.

Peacefully temple nestled into the heart of the city.. I reached this place during a fantastic walk from the famous Shibuya crossing or pedestrian scramble nearby the Shibuya train station, walking quietly for about 20 minutes you can easily reach this beautiful Shrine nestled in the heart of an immense green area in the heart of Tokyo. Once you get to the gates of this park and just keep walking for another 400 meters along the path that leads right in front of it. The temple is very beautiful and charming, you will see people there praying or simply get some relaxation. Visit enthused about 1 hour but absolutely not to be missed.

The best shrine in Japan. The Meiji shrine was an amazing experience. We made sure to be in the main courtyard area by 8am, and were treated with the morning ritual, including the hourly drumming. Check to see when the museum is open, it was closed when we went so we sadly couldn't see it. Also, make sure to wear good walking shoes, as it's a very large area you'll be walking around.Beautiful views, culture, and history. Easily one of the best parts of my trip.

Meiji Jingu, Tokyo. I arrived at the end of summer. It rained the night before so the air was lovely and cool. Arriving at Yoyogi Park gave me a real spiritual and magical feeling like you're about to enter a Miyazaki fairy tale movie. The wide gravel pathway leads you through two enormous wooden torii gates with beautiful brass embellishments. Sake barrels lined part of the pathways as you make your way deeper into the forest canopies and to the shrine. I arrived just in time to witnessed a Nikkusai ceremony of a mass of 45 children and priests in crisp white robes. Food was offered to the deities with prayers of prosperity and world peace. It was a tremendously humbling and beautiful sight to behold. This is held at 8am and 2pm everyday so time your visit. I always try to make this spiritual place part of my visit each time i'm in Tokyo. Definitely one of the Top 10 places to visit while you're here.

Must see in Tokyo, bring cash. This was part of our excellent Grayline full day tour.I could have spent all day here. We were privileged to be here during a special time when the children come to the shrine as part of a ritual. We also saw a wedding. The shrine was lovely and typical of the simple shrines. Do not expect a fancy shrine like in Thailand or Malaysia, this is a Shinto shrine and is peaceful and lovely in its simplicity. It is respecting of nature. It is calm.This place takes time. It is a long walk. The terrain is rock so be prepared. The walk is interesting with much to look at.The shrine itself has multiple areas to view. It is lovely and calm.Bring lots of cash. They offer many lovely items for sale - but cash only. I wanted to buy many items but could not. All of our stops were this way - we needed cash for them all. Be prepared.In sum, Tokyo is amazing and wonderful. The people are kind and helpful. But take tours. Most locals do NOT speak English well enough to help, even though they try.Amazing place, worth the flight time.

Bask in the glory that is the Meiji Shrine. Go there to feel awed and be hit by the feeling being inside a premise of history! Its linked to the Yoyogi park where you could go for stroll, a picnic or even a jog.

Peaceful. If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo and Shibuya a walk in the peaceful surrounds of Meiji Jingu is well worth it. Lots of trees and in the centre a Shinto Shrine. It is a short walk from Shibuya or next to the Harajuku station on the Yamanote Line. You can stroll through the trendy shopping area of Harajuku and Omotesando after visiting Meiji Jingu.
Must see...if you are in Shibuya. Beautiful surroundings, relaxing atmosphere, well laid out and spacious. Quite a bit of walking but worth the effort.
Zen in Middle of Tokyo.... In the middle of this busy city What a peaceful place Meiji Jingu is, you'll love it don't forget to visit the budist temple and write a wish note

Worth the walk if in Harajuke . Grand and interesting temple but as with most Shinto temples it's kind of seen one seen them all. Better then it's competitor across the city (simply for the lack of gaudy tourist market) but it is a tranquil and pleasant walk to temple that is probably a nicer draw then the temple itself.
Elegant temple in a beautiful park. The park and setting is beautiful. It is definitely worth to see when you are in Tokyo to get another glimpse of Japan history, culture and religion.

Not so unmissable for me. It is considered by many people how a “must-see”, but even if it was the first temple I saw in Japan, he didn’t arouse my enthusiasm! It is placed in a big park and the scenery is really nice, inspiring and relaxing, but I didn’t like so much the temple in itself.In my opinion there is not much to see.It is interesting look at the observants making ablution.The thing, I loved at most, was the big tree where you can hang up your prayers and wishes on a wooden tablet bought in the shops.

Its like a park in the middle of a concrete jungle. If you are tired of walking the streets of Tokyo, head on to the Meiji Jingu. A rather long walk leads to a shrine built in honor of the great Emperor Meiji. Being an outdoor person, I truly enjoyed the walk in the forest, gazing at the huge trees and the other floras. At the end of the walk, you'll reach a temple where many visitors stopped to perform the purification ceremony and to make a wish. The exit leads to the busy Harajuku area where life of excitement continues.

Well worth traveling to see. Well worth the visit and a peaceful break from the rest of Tokyo. Easily accessed through the subway. No entrance fees. After touring the park you can then easily transition into the shops and restaurants of Harajuku.
One of best sightseeing of tokyo, unmissable. Very nice place surrounded by amazing park. A kind of ny central park but in tokyo. Huge temple, great zen experince. Lovely place

Peace and Quiet in Tokyo. This is a must see if you are visiting Tokyo. We make a point of visiting the shrine every time we visit Tokyo.Walk through cypress Tori gates and a forest before reaching the shrine itself. Incredibly peaceful experience away from the activity of Tokyo. No entrance fee. The subway stops right at the entrance.Then walk down Ometisando for some retail therapy and explore the shops of Harajuku.

Another Must See. Calm and quiet in busy Tokyo. My son and I stopped at the purification station, made our wish, bought our tablet to record our visit and intentions. You'd never know you're in the middle of an incredibly busy city. Nice.
Nice getaway from busy Shibuya. Very peaceful, surrounded with greens and trees, very relaxing, nice for taking a break from busy Shibuya and Harajuku...

Superb. One of the best temples to go to while in Tokyo.Not as exciting as the one at Asakasu,but more peaceful and quiet. More interesting is that it is only on the opposite side of Harajuju Tokeshita Dori which has all the excitement. Tip: When you go in, you will see a few places where you need to pay. Just skip all this and go to the main temple first. Once you see the temple, you may not want toenter these places/gardens at all.
Beautiful gardens and shrine. I enjoyed walking all around the gardens, and ended up at the well and lily pond. I made a 500 yen donation. This place is gorgeous!

Amazing temple. This is an amazing temple really close to the subway station. You can see a lot of locals doing their rituals. I wouldnt say that this is the best temple in tokyo (i prefer the akirabara one), but it has a different atmosphere that is worth checking.

Beautiful grounds and a wedding!. Meiji Jingu is located in the Shibuya area west Tokyo. The park is right when you exit the "metoro" eki at Jingu Mae . Its main attraction besides the wonderful well maintained grounds is the Temple and Shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji and his wife Shoken. It's a wonderful place that oozes with history and tradition and maybe you will be Lucky enough to be the witness of a Japanese wedding! ( I think it was a wedding unless it was something else....Nonethelss it was wonderful! I am no specialist but any person eager to learn more aboput that period of Japanese History should pay a visit to the Temple and shrine. You will simply love that place and no need to take a guided tour, just trust yourself! I will be back in October and I can't wait.
Not very exciting. You can't really compare this shrine to those in Kyoto but it's a nice walk through the park and always interesting to see all the typical elements of the shrine.
Great Escape from Urban Tokyo. Make sure you make time to visit this beautfil shrine. Completely transports you away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo with a wonderful walk

Best viewed early before the crowds arrive. This is a large shrine with several buildings based around a quadrangle. The buildings are the main event so do not expect Japanese gardens and landscaping here. We were lucky enough to see a traditional wedding taking place where the party have to cross the grounds several times and we must admit to feeling sorry for the bride in her formal Japanese clothing in 35 degree heat.It is also free to get in.We arrived by 10:00 in the morning and the place was not crowded and when we passed again 4 hours later it looked like the shrine would have been packed. This is one of the key tourist attractions in Tokyo with coaches catered for.

Tranquil escape from the busy Tokyo. The shrine was built in the memory of Emperor Meiji. The original was was destroyed during WWII, but the current one is a beautiful reconstruction and quite authentic.The shrine is just a stroll away from the busy Shibuya & Omotesando area. It is nestled in the middle of a nice park. So, even if you are not into shrine visit and all, it's a nice escape from the hectic Tokyo streets.There is a museum and Japanese garden as well in the same vicinity.

Lovely shrine in the middle of Yoyogi park. Yoyogi park is huge and so dense (we viewed it first from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office observation deck). In the middle of the park is Meiji Jingu and it's a gorgeous shrine.We went on a Sunday, it was very hot (in the middle of a heatwave!), so the shade of the trees was welcome. The actual shrine was lovely, we were lucky enough to see three traditional Japanese wedding processions.A lovely place to wander around and soak up the atmosphere. Although there were a lot of people there, it was still a peaceful visit.100% recommended!

Amazing park. The shrine is of course great and if you're lucky, you may have the ability to see traditional japanese wedding (I was lucky!).What's really amazing in my opinion is the park surrounding the shrine. Very high trees that grow narrow make you feel like in a forest. I think it's pretty unique - there's no other park like this in Tokio. I also happen to be there at the time of rain so it was also doomy and it really smelled like forest!

Quiet, Cultural Area. If this is your first temple or shrine visit you may find this interesting. It is a quiet place with a few Shinto activities. The long walkway through the park leading to the shrine is nice and peaceful amidst the city. But… it is a long walk to the temple entrance. This isn't the most interesting religious temple or shrine out there, but is in a big quiet area which is nice. It is also right beside the old Olympic stadium and another shopping area that makes it a convenient stop along your route.
Peaceful park and shrine . Enjoyed the peaceful surroundings and watching the locals. Lovely shrine with lots of shade for relaxing walking. It was very easy to access by public transit.

Our First Shinto Shrine. Meiji was our family's first shrine on our week long visit to Japan. It set the standard. The tree covered grounds provide respite from the moist summer heat. The tori are impressive thresholds that prompt a shift from Tokyo's urban spaces to the mindfulness of nature. Explore the grounds and linger at the shrine, before returning to the city sidewalks. We left written wishes at the holy tree to invoke the spirits of Shinto guides for the remainder of our journey.

Shrine with parkland!. We came upon this after a long, hot morning of walking around Harajuku, this was AMAZING!So quiet and peaceful. So nice to be able to wander through the walkways and find our own way to the shrine. Some of the pathways were packed with people, but if you turn off the main route, you can find a quiet track with barely anyone on it! While we were here, we saw a traditional Japanese wedding procession, it was so beautiful. A must visit while in Tokyo for sure.
Beautiful park. Worth a visit. Lovely park, with a big lake and a shrine. Nice way to spend an hour or so. Can catch a train directly there.

Oasis of calm. One of my favourite places to visit, particularly in sticky summers. It's cool, calm and glorious. Try and get there out of peak times: weekdays are lovely. Weekends though give you the entire experience with the Harajuku thing happening on the way into the shrine. Spend some time just strolling the gardens and grounds. Toss 100 yen into the box and say a prayer. Buy a charm for traffic safety to hang in your car. Leave your wishes on a purchased plaque and the priests will pray for you (sneak a read of others too, for an insight into what's missing in our lives these days!) a must see if you're in Tokyo for any time at all.

Lovely educational walkway, shrine-meh. The shrine itself is not that interesting (there are better ones in Tokyo) but I'm awarding four stars for the beautiful passageway to the shrine right next to the Omotesando shopping. Broad passageway with lovely tall trees on either side make the walk very peaceful. Huge exhibits provide a history of the meiji empire that was very educational. It's worth the trip.

Quiet Oasis. Lovely temple in a park. Since it was hot, the shade was welcome. This is also a good place if you hope to see a Japanese wedding. We were there on a "taian" day, which is an auspicious day for wedding and saw two.

Impressive Shinto shrine in the centre of Tokyo. A walk through the park from Harajuko station leads you to this beautiful Shrine. The surroundings are very peaceful and I came away feeling recharged.

Lovely. Peaceful tree lined walk to the shrine. Lots of people paying their respects to the emperor and empress. Beautiful sake barrels given every year to the shrine. We were lucky and saw a beautiful wedding going on

Awesome Scenery. This place is a must visit when you visit Tokyo.. Its full of Japanese culture & feel.. This place was surrounded by lots of tree, like a forest.. Due to that, you will feel very peaceful, very nice & enjoy walking from the main gate to the shrine.. when you enter the shrine, you will notice 2 big "round" tree in front of the main hall.. local people call it "wishes tree".. its really amazing.. if you like to take picture, this place is definitely worth for visit.. You also can buy amulets or charms in along the souvenir stall..

Iconic Japanese Images. The shinto Shrine is easy to get to and filled with iconic Japanese images. There are so many great photo opportunities here and it gives an insight into the Shinto religion. Beware it can be very crowed so best to pick your time.

A nice, calm oasis. The shrine is at the heart of a forested area of Tokyo with over 100,000 trees. Most of the park is taken up by a garden that has a suggested donation of ¥500.The shrine itself was rebuilt after the Tokyo firebombing, using the proceeds from locals. It is quite small. As a working shrine there is the opportunity to write your wish on an ema or buy charms and amulets.For us, it was a nice enough short walk out of the heat but it was rather underwhelming with nothing that stood out especially compared to other places in Japan.
Shrine. This is a big shrine/temple in the middle of a park. Its many people going there, but it is a must see in tokyo. Both if you like seeing the culture, architecture or the handwork.

Sunday Stroll. We went to this park today. It was fantastic to see all the different people who go there for tourism, leisure and ceremony. Head for the central shrine of Meiji Jingu as this is where people gather. On a Sunday you will be able to see many couples getting married. We were there for about 20 Minutes and saw 3 weddings in that time alone.BUT, be warned there are no drinks available in the park, so go prepared and bring enough drinks for the time you are there. Great walking area, with plenty of shady areas.

Fabulous area. This area is very peaceful and tranquil compared with nearby Shibuya. There are some cafes nearby to re charge the "batteries" before walking around these beautiful gardens and Temple. y There is a "suggested donation " to a special garden area. It is worthwhile to pay the small fee and enjoy this garden. It is very beautiful.

A definite must see!. This is a must see in Tokyo. I loved this and it was one of my favourite Shrines. It is not far from the train station and it is lovely to take a casual stroll through the trees. You forget that you are in the middle of the city. Meiji Jingu is beautiful and really sits within its surroundings so subtly but at the same time is quite majestic. There is a spiritual feel to the place and it is lovely to see all of the prayer blocks written in all languages. Before reaching the Shrine there was a sign for Kiyomasa's Well, which was 500 yen to enter. It was worth every penny!! This is part of the Meiji Jingu Imperial Garden. Having gone in June, the Iris garden was beautiful and so unexpected. It really is a wow factor when you move across the bend. The garden itself is a journey and is so peaceful.

Beautiful and serene. This site is a short walk from the train station. It's a lush and shaded walk through the gardens to the temple. The atmosphere is quiet and contemplative. Seeing the trees, the huge gates, the barrels of sake and the shrine is an unforgettable experience. Wonderful in so many ways.
Just go!. It is by a train stop, it is popular, lots of people go there, it is pretty, and it interesting to look at. Take a walk through the park and enjoy the scenery.

Lovely Day Out!. Walked to this shrine from our hotel in Shinjuky, less than 15 minutes walk. Had a great half day here, they have very clear maps and the information they have on display (in English) on their billboards as you enter the main section was really interesting and well worth a visit. Afterwards we visited the local shopping district where all the young people hang out, heaps of food and good shopping, in walking distance from Meiji Jingu.

Good stroll through serene path to shrine, but.... Just a short walk to the entrance from Harajuku Station. It's quite a stroll through the wide path to get to the shrine, but path is covered with large trees that provide much welcomed shade on a hot sunny day. We went in late August so the cicadas were out in droves and buzzing quite loudly, although they pretty much just stay in the trees and won't bother humans. Be sure to guard yourself and young ones against hungry mosquitos...they were biting me through my clothing. This is a must if you are visiting any of the parks in Japan. From Harajuku Station, walk down a couple streets and look forTakeshita Street. It's a fun stretch for some shopping and food with lots of local young people hanging out.

peaceful shrine. this where you find peace and serenity out of capital city of world's #2 industrial country. coming out of the JR rail Minjijingu Mae station turn right, walk on the marble through the arch made out of thousand year pine trees... real amazing,,,, after that, take a walk around Harajuku then Ometesado Ave for a japanese shopping experience.
Impressive timber gate & gardens. Despite the rain, a lovely walk through manicured gardens, impressive timber gate entrance to the Shrine made of huge timber beams.

Peace in the heart of Tokyo. When shinjuku, shibuya and harajuku get too much then head for the Meiji shrine for some peace and quiet. It's a large park that has the main shrine but also side walks and gardens for rambling.

Awe inspiring. We could hardly believe we were in Tokyo the minute we turned down the gravel pathway and walked beneath the huge wooden torii gate. The walk from the entrance to the shrine is quite a way (it took us about twenty minutes with a toddler in tow) but worth it, and there are shops, restaurants and a museum half way.Keep your eyes peeled for a traditional shinto wedding- we didn't get to see the bride and groom but we think there was a ceremony going on inside. Also, make sure to wash your hands in the water at the shrine to wash away any misdeeds- not only refreshing on a hot day, but a wonderful cultural and spritual experience too.

Peaceful Sanctuary. I was delighted to visit this place and my only regret is that I did not spend more time there or return. It is incredible to be in Tokyo and find this escape from a busy city.Go with curiosity and take it all in, there are many things to explore. Grand gates, gardens, lovely paths, and more. If you are so inclined, you can leave a prayer either on paper or on small wooden tablets for a nominal cost or a small donation. You can also make an offering at the shrine itself.There are souvenirs you can purchase that are quite thoughtful, and nice to bring to friends and family.It is free to visit the grounds, although there is a fee to visit the gardens.
Important Shinto Shrine. Shady place to walk around on a hot day. Many Japanese people here to pay their respects. Leafy green gardens.

Beautiful and peaceful,. This was my favourite temple in Tokyo. Walking through beautiful gardens in a beautiful setting. It wasn't packed with tourists either which made for a pleasant visit. I would like to return here to explore further on our next visit to Tokyo.

Don't Miss This. This is my favorite space in all of Japan. An island of tranquility in today's frantic urban environment. Don't miss the turtles in the pond and go when the irises are in bloom. You will never forget it. It is salve for the soul.

Peace and Nature. We took a train early morning from our hotel Metropolitan in Tokyo to this shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji &Empress Shoken. Over 100,00 trees planted here and they are magnificent. Nice wide shaded paths to walk through forest and gardens. Beautiful irises in June (small fee). Treasure museum and 500 yen and treasure museum annex. I thought both were worth seeing. While there we were able to see the life of the empress displayed along the main approach. She was giving, wise and very selfless. Promoted womens education and welfare. She donated a fund to Red Cross that still is active today helping others around the world. The shrine is huge & while there we were able to see priests in a procession and then we watched a very interesting ceremony but unknown as to what special event was going on. It was big and impressive and guards made us all stand off to the sides with no photography.I'd go here again and again. It's quite beautiful and a must see.

cool and green - worth a visit. This is a cool, calm place to get away from the crowds in Harajuku. It is a bit of a tourist area, so expect more people disgorging from coaches at the cafe. But there is plenty of room, and plenty of calm green places as well.

Nice Shrine in Park Setting. This is a beautiful shrine in Yayogi Park. It is about a 15 minute walk from the park entrance near Harajuku Station. The walk is shaded in big trees and is a nice stroll on a hot Tokyo day. Go see it, then walk over to nearby Takeshita Street for some shopping and food.

Calm oasis amidst the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Don't let the touristy vibe deter you from the real beauty of this place. The architecture gives a great visual insight into Shintoism. Its about a ten minute walk to the main shrine but there are interesting exhibits like the sake barrels along the way. Love the serenity of this place.

Commune with nature and gods. This is the first Shinto shrine I ever visited, and I learned how to worship the gods by cleansing and making small offerings. We even witnessed a wedding procession. This place is striking, but still peaceful and quiet.

Beautiful!. I went here a long time ago, but the scenery is gorgeous, quiet, and all of their shrines have their own personalities and i personally loved this one! I went when it was cloudy and rainy and still loved it.

Worth the visit!. We went on a very hot and humid day, but there are so many trees on the path to the shrine, that it's not too bad. The shrine itself is impressive and immaculate. It's very quite and serene. You can really commune with the Shinto Kami (divine spirits). They have places to write your prayers and wishes, making a donation if you wish, but you don't need to second a single yen unless you want to do so. There's no one there trying to get your money, but you can buy some items if you wish. Leave yourself about 1-2 hours to lazily walk the grounds, then go across to Takeshita Street in Harajuku if you need something to wake you up! It's all quite a dichotomy in Tokyo!

Massive beautiful shrine. If shrine hopping, this is a must see.. Located just outside of the Harajuku station, this is a must go to if you want to see some beautiful gardens and shrines. There is a small fee for going into Empress' the garden and the shrine, so take a little yen with you.The outer area holds big nature paths and massive tori gates. The government left nothing out when dedicating this to the Emperor Meiji. His life is also illustrated and explained. Many signs in English.The inner area held a museum which had treasures and artifacts from the Emperor and Empress along with other artifacts from their time. We got to see a small Japanese wedding and go shopping at the hall located within the area. You can get your name engraved into chopsticks at a small stand nearby.
Great place. This place is quite large. It's a nice place to walk. The shrine itself is really nice. I preferred Meiji to the Asakusa temple, as it's not so crowded.

Absolutely Gorgeous. Great walking, enjoy the side path, small bridges and fountains. You maybe be lucky to catch traditional japanese weddings, be in the crowd, take pictures but be respectful of others and do not impose (the Japnese way). It is a serene place especially on weekdays, less crowded, and you can easily get to have your fortune read, write thoughful notes on small wooden bloks and hang them on the prayer wall. I believe, it is a must.

Oasis in the City. Loved visiting this place, think supersized Central Park. Towering gates, trees and temples is what you will find, you won't be disappointed. It's a moderate walk until you get to the temple, but it's all flat and a nice stroll through the park with a few things and side paths to see along the way. Definitely worth checking out!

A Quiet Afternoon in Harajuku. Such a pleasant afternoon stroll among nature. Surprises along the way such as the sake and wine casks. We stopped to cleanse our hands and mouth before heading to the shrine to pay our respects. Everything was authentic compared to the touristy Senjoji Shrine. And it was such a convenient walk to our next stop - Takeshita Dori,
One of the nicer shrines. This shrine is one of the bigger and prettier ones around Tokyo - but there are lots of them around, and I didn't find this one to be as spectacular as expected.

Tranquility. The shrine is easily accessed via JR Yamanote line at the Harajuku Station. Once you get out of the station facing the Takeshita dori turn right, and walk about five minutes. Passing a stone bridge you are welcome by a giant wooden gate. We spent more than an hour. The sake and wine barrels are very interesting. We also paid to get into the garden (only open seasonally). So glad we did the garden tour, water lilies are about to bloom and iris are almost in full blossom. Beautiful and serene.

You can see traditional Japanese wedding if you go on Sunday. We went there on Sunday and saw 2 traditional Japanese weddings that day. The temple of course was very great, lots natural greens and traditional buildings. Don't forget to get some lucky charms from there!

Really serene. Went in the afternoon, it was a really serene and nice placethe temple/shrine was nice and the inner garden was wonderful. It was a very refreshing and spiritual experience.Not too crowded as well

Peaceful and good exercise. When you get there, you aren't really there!It is a peaceful walk (about a quarter mile) to reach the structural part of this shrine.And that is by design, it is refreshing and a spiritual experience.So be ready to walk some ways, on crushed gravel to see the shrine. The well groomed large trees provide shade most of the shrine areas.

Best "park" in Tokyo!. I absolutely LOVED my trip to Yoyogi and Meiji Jingu. The temple/shrine itself was nice, but not my fav part about this trip. My fav part is the inner garden in this park, I HIGHLY recommend it! The lilypond was beautiful, we also saw many beautiful koi fish and small and big turtles. Go there!
Happy Day in Meiji. Just stay here for a few hour, you'll find the good place to relax in the middle of tokyo. very peaceful and good place

Go On A Weekend. Although it would be crowded to go on a weekend, there are more things happening in the shrine, for instance, traditional Japanese weddings. You'll get to see the couples in traditional costumes and the procession with the priests and the family members around the shrine. This will make your trip to the Meiji Jingu even more special.I like the place for the fact that it taught me a bit of the Japanese history. This place was built really because of the people's love for their Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. Since this is the centennial year since Empress Shoken's passing, there are some displays lined up along the way to the main shrine area to inform the visitors of what she had done in the past. I went away full of admiration for the empress. She really loved the poor, not only in Japan, but all over the world. This place is a nice break from the hustles and bustles just outside of it since this is in the Shibuya area. Most part of Meiji Jingu is free.

A break from Tokyo. A tranquil within a bustling city. I'm not much of a forest kind of person, but I do have to agree that without the forest, Meiji Jingu would not be perfect. Good place to visit for a break aways from the bustling city. This is definitely better than Sensoji (too "touristy").

Come if you are a nature and shrine sort of person. This place is easy access from Harajuku station. However this park is rather spacious and there isn't much to read or see other than greenery and some randomly placed structure (i.e. the wine barrier, lanterns etc.). I was here on a Sunday trying to find the hide-outs of the cos-players but had no luck finding them here nor at yoyogi park. I guess the Japanese government has really cracked down on such gathering in recent years.

Beautiful Grounds. Meiji Jingu was the best shrine that we visited in Tokyo. The grounds are lush and beautiful (in May) and the shrine itself is worth seeing. Take time to read the signs as the historical context is fascinating.

Gorgeous in the rain. I was a little bummed about the rain during our trip, but it made the gardens and shrine more atmospheric and the colours more vibrant. Everything was beautiful and the staff were lovely.Loved all of the information about empress shoken in particular (thankful that it was in English).The iris garden (separate, requires entry fee) was beautiful (as was the story behind it), but we were lucky that it was June and they were blooming - probably not worth the money otherwise

A little disappointing. We found this throughout all of Japan, the shrines and temples are not open to the public as in Thailand or other Asian countries that we've visited. We were very disappointed by this. While the grounds are nice, and I understand that the "park-like" settings are very special to the Japanese people who value this kind of "space" in a very crowded society, we were always disappointed to be shut out of the main event. Perhaps on a tour, I'm reading, they take you inside? Otherwise you are going to have a nice stroll through a lovely park, you will see the big gates, the sake barrels (interesting), and the outside of the temple. Not the cultural experience we were hoping for.

Tokyo's second shrine. Probably not the most impressive shrine in Tokyo (that goes to Senso-Ji) but it has a lot less tourists and we got to witness a wedding procession there which makes it feel more authentic.

A nice walk in the forest. Interesting park devoted to the Emperor. Really liked the 300 year old Bonsai tree. Go early so you can see all the sights since the close a little early. Try not to get distracted on the walk to the park through the interesting shopping area like we did.

So Peaceful. Went there spontaneously while wandering through Harajuku! For being in the middle of the city it is very peaceful! The scenery is beautiful. The shinto shrine was breath taking with priests dressed in traditional attire and dozens of bonsai trees, some up to 300 years old. Definitely work the visit and it doesn't even have to take you very long to get there from JR Harajuku station and to go through the whole there. Was there around 3:30 and it wasn't crowded by any means! So beautiful!

So peaceful and beautiful. I went to this shrine on the Tokyo Morning Tour. I was very impressed by how peaceful this place felt. It is very beautiful and the history very interesting. Our guide explained the cleansing ritual before entering and it was a nice experience participating in it. We were lucky enough to actually witness a wedding which was absolutely amazing!Definitly worth a visit

Lovely temple in Tokyo. Five of us visited in May 2014. Meiji Shrine is a very relaxing part of Tokyo. Set in a large forest, there are a series of gates which lead up to a temple. I've now visited the shrine twice and on both occassions there were multiple weddings - something to look out for. We also saw the Bugatu spring festival too which filled the temple plaza during Golden Week. It is worth visiting the very large tree where people hang cards of prayer. Overall, something relaxing to do in Tokyo and well worth a visit.

Beautiful . What a find tucked away in the middle of the city.. So peaceful, so beautiful. We managed to see the monks going about their business and the people heading to a traditional wedding. To avoid the big crowd we went at about 9am, still lots of people about however not too crowded. The painted barrels along the walkway were worth the trip there alone. Great for photography enthusiasts.
Great temple!. Another great sight of Tokyo! Not to be missed!! It can be crowded at times but it is worth your time!

Simply lovely. Meiji Jingu shrine is located in the middle of Yoyogi park. The park is beautiful and very large. If you want to see interesting activities try come on a weekend. You might be able to catch a wedding. Its not too crowded as compared to Sensoji Temple in Asakusa.

Very peaceful. Very peaceful considering the amount of people. The Japanese are such naturally peaceful people, and I think this shrine naturally embodies that. Very green and serene place. Really male sure not to rush, as it's a relaxing place to see.

Beautiful and quiet. I was amazed at how secluded and quiet and wooded this shrine is even though it's in the midst of busy Tokyo and just steps away from the Harajuku station and the nearby shops in that area. We visited during a special bonsai exhibit which added a nice touch, but even without that, it's nice here. It is in the woods, and you've got to walk down a gravel path for about 10 minutes to reach the main shrine.

Good, but depending on what you want, plan when to visit.. If you are an avid photographer or prefer less crowd, then go after 3pm on weekdays. If you want to people-watch, then weekends or mid-morning onwards for all days. Its a nice quiet place to hang around longer.On my trip there, I didn't plan to visit the place. I only read about it online and that it was behind the Harujuku station. So I decided to just walk a bit more to explore, instead of hopping on a train back to my hotel. I was there from about 4pm to 6pm on a weekday. Can't stay long as they were closing, but it was less crowded. Just wrote some wishes at the wishing tree, and had to leave soon after.Tip: If you are carrying your luggage due to late flight in the evening or night, just give it a miss. I saw travellers carrying big luggage with trolleys and you cant possibly roll them on the gravel surface all the way in to the site. An alternative is to leave your luggage in a locker in a train station. If you are on heels, then you have to walk carefully.

awesome space and experience. Visiting Meiji Jingu is one of those few experiences that has always raised my spirits and infused me with hope and calm. The experience begins for me with a leisurely walk through Yoyogi Park and culminates in offering a silent prayer at the shrine. The setting is beautiful and worth lingering to savor.

One of my favorites. Beautiful shrine in the middle of a gorgeous forest. I so enjoyed wandering the paths on the way. I caught a traditional wedding while I was in the shrine. The history behind it is amazing.
Beautiful shrine. Set in beautiful grounds. This shrine is very grand, towering tori gates and rows of sake barrels to be seen along the way. Quite peaceful here despite the large crowds.

Beautiful. Our favorite attraction in Tokyo in the Shibuya District, great Imperial Shrine, with the monumental Torii at the entrance.A lot things to see and to do here, the barrels of sake, the central sanctuary, and also we have the opportunity to be part of two weddings, amazing, beautiful, is not words to describe the moment.
Peace and quiet. Great way to start or end any day after the frantic pace of Toykyo. The tranquility and reverence for nature was evident and fulfilling.

Beautiful shrine. We loved this shrine however, as we had already been to the Fushiinari Shrine in Kyoto it ruined it for us. Beautiful grounds surrounding the shrine and we were lucky enough to see a wedding procession, worth a look just for serenity from the hustle and bustle of busy Harajuku on a Sunday.

Suddenly... forest. When walking the long walk towards the shrine, you will stop hearing the city all around you and feel like you're in a countryside forest (full of tourists). Furthermore, it's an iconic shrine it is has many performances and festivities taking place throughout the year- check out the website for dates. The shrine itself is beautiful and the gardens worth a visit.

Absolutely Beautiful. I didn't expect a shrine to be my favourite attraction of a holiday, but Meiji Shrine changed this for me. It also helped that the weather was perfect, cool without being chilly. The shrine is located inside of a beautiful forested area. It's a pretty long stroll in from Harajuku station, but I thoroughly enjoyed every moment. Like many shrines/temples in Tokyo that I visited, they sell pretty charms for different kinds of blessings and I cannot get enough of those. Absolutely loved the visit :)

must-see in downtown Tokyo. Very high-frequented shrine in memory of a modern-age emperor. Situated in a great park with towering trees. Nice(st) place to bei in hot&humid weather. Notice the giant wooden gates at the entrances.
A place for long walks and time to ponder.... If you're lucky, you might witness a wedding ceremony and/or a classical Japanese performance the day you visit.
