Awesome!. While not mind-blowing, the Meiji Jingu is a fantastic place for a quick stroll to get that quick reprieve fron the hustle and bustle of the city. Considering its short distance from the Harajuku Station (of which the surrounding area is a must visit anyways), it is highly recommended for you to make the detour for this. Another reason to visit is that you will get first-hand exposure to the more 'folksy' side of Japanese spiritual practices (especially well-suited to those who want to try making a wish as done in mangas / animes, buy lucky charms, etc.).As a general tip, the Meiji Jingu hosts a variety of cultural performances, festivals, and special ceremonies every year, so be sure to visit their website to coordinate your dates of visit to match.

Worth a visit while in Tokyo. This Shinto temple doesn't seem to be as popular of a destination as the Asakusa Buddhist temple, but it is set in a lovely wooded area. In fact, it's one of the largest natural areas in Tokyo. The grounds are beautiful and very well kept. We were able to see a bride having her portrait done before the wedding ceremony. I liked the fact that it wasn't as crowded or as loud as Asakusa.

Go for the Walk & Gardens. The temple is nice, but the long walk through several Shinto Shrine gates to the Temple is very peaceful and the gates themselves, framing the foliage, are awesome. The small garden (to the left as you are walking towards the Temple) is a nice diversion and adds an extra measure of solemnity to the occasion.

Tranquillity. I was lucky that there weren't too many people when I was there. Even though it's quite a long walk from the entrance to the shrine, it is the perfect time to reflect back on one's life.

Magnificent, spiritual, peaceful. This shrine never ceases to 'get me'. I hadn't been in a while and on this last trip I went specifically to write a prayer on a wooden tablet for my friend Michelle who is battling breast cancer. You just jump off the metro at Harajuku and then instead of walking into the buzz of Harajuku you turn the other way and you are enveloped in the peaceful green space that surrounds the shrine. Shuffle along the gravel pathway and walk under the magnificent entrance and you are in another world. Then you come upon the water where you wash your hands and then enter the shrine and it's iconic tree is on the right. You can go to the shop and buy a wooden tablet and write your prayer on and then hang it around the tree and the priests will offer up your prayers. It is all really very special. There is a seasonal garden there as well you can pay extra to visit that is sure to be spectacular when things are in bloom. The bathrooms were clean btw. :) FYI - no pictures allowed at the shrine itself where you throw the coin and ring the bell but you can take a picture of the tree.

Nice temple. There is a nice temple and road here, I went when it started to rain so I had the place almost to myself. There is also a well you have to pay to see, nothing special there if you are not interested in the history though.

Beautiful walk, relaxing shrine. The walk to the shrine alone is lovely - wear good walking shoes. Somehow the noise of the big city just drains away. If you go on a Sunday, you may be lucky enough to see a Japanese wedding. Be respectful and stay back - but photos are ok.

Nice shrine with neighbouring parks and attractions . I reached it by using Meiji Jingumae station on the metro. It's a Shinto shrine bound by two large wooden gates. It enshrines Emperor Meiji who is still held in high regard as being responsible from ending Japan's isolation from the west. For me the shrine itself is not a great visual spectacle (unlike Senso-Ji) but what makes it a good attraction are the adjacent grounds and parks ideal for a picnic and the authentic Japanese feel of the place. In addition there are other attractions nearby that can easily fill half a day. I visited on a Sunday and was fortunate to see a wedding with the bride in traditional dress. Also in the park area behind the shrine there was a large group of school children practicing Kendo which was interesting to see. At the entrance just as you exit the station you have a small bridge where sometimes the Harajuku Cos play kids can be seen but despite me being there on a Sunday I didn't see any. Also 2 mins walk from the shrine entrance is Yoyogi gyoen (park) also worth a visit. If you walk for 2 mins in the opposite direction from the metro station you reach Takeshita Dori street but for me this was very much over hyped, with no authenticity, just throngs of tourists crammed into a small side street. You can also walk to Omotesando street for high end shopping too. In summary I think the shrine in combination with its neighbouring attractions makes for a nice few hours and well worth the visit.

Shinto Shrine. A Shinto shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji and his consort Empress Shoken. He was one of the first Emperors to start opening Japan up to European influence. You can see evidence of this on the long walkway into the shrine. One one side are racks of Sake while on the other barrels of French wine. Closest train station is Harajuku, the park is over a bridge then through the huge Shinto tori gate. The gate is based on the Chinese character for Open. To pay respect here there is a very specific procedure. First wash your hands, then throw some coins in the shrine, bow twice, clap twice then bow once again.

Great to see while in Harajuku. Beautiful shrine which is conveniently located next to the brilliant Yoyogi Park and near the excellent Harajuku shops...Beautiful grounds and great for photos. They had a traditional Japanese wedding on when we went. This is not a complaint (more of an observation/warning) to be careful if you have a stroller or expensive shoes as the long walkway to the shrine is dusty stones. The dust got all over my shoes and the stones made the wheels to the stroller "bog down" meaning a heavy shove and biceps of steel were needed to push my baby. Not a complaint I repeat but had I known this I would have done things differently. Well worth a visit!!!

Spectacular. Very cultural and pretty with a lot of souvenir shops and quaint little local restaurants! Travel by metro & then walk to the ate hotel for a spectacular view of Skytree, with a cocktail on the rooftop!

Peaceful. A large park near Harajuku,peaceful stroll... large with an ancient strine in the middle, typical open air courtyards with history & calm. A good resting place..no tourist traps or hawkers..

I saw traditional weddings here. This is a HUGE Jingu. Lots of traditional Japanese weddings held here. I also saw snow here when I visited here. It's an amazing place with trees, Japanese tradition, and other stuffs. I took lots of pictures. It's also surprise that inside Tokyo city, there is something like this. A great area of green plantation and spirit of gods!

Can you believe that there exists such a place.... ...in Tokyo????...It is such a spiritual place, inside a blossoming nature, right in the centre of Tokyo, but it guards its remoteness and spirituality.It is a must!
Cool spot. Take a stroll on the other side of Harujuku markets and you'll find this little gem. While my visit I witnessed a traditional wedding ceremony take place.

Really? in a city of 13 million people?. 120,000 trees right in the middle of the city. The giant circle of pictures of flora and fauna with a few scattered mirrors so that you can be in the picture, the huge Cyprus gates, the weddings taking place,

Stunning. The Meiji Jingu shrine is absolutely stunning. It is an absolute must when visiting Tokyo.The architecture of the shrine is very elegant and pretty. Very peaceful to stroll around the park with cedar trees.Pity we did not have enough time to visit the museum, well, that is for next time.

Lovely oasis in the hustle and bustle . We were staying near Shibuya crossing so decided to walk up to Yoyogi Park and the Meiji temple. We didn't realise that the two parks didn't allow any internal entry points, so we ended up back on the road searching for Meiji. It was worth the trek. Very lovely and peaceful. We entered from a side entry which was much quieter and less touristy than the front. We also sampled the crisp, fresh water from the fountain. Overall a lovely place and a nice walk.

Peace of mind. After lots of noise in a busy and crowded city, the best yoy can do is to find inner peace by stopping in a place like this. Not so crowded and big as Senso-ji, but a really beautiful shrine in the middle of an amazing park. Take a walk and enjoy the scenery. You'll miss this silence and peace as soon as you go to places such as Akihabara or Shibuya.

A Sunday stroll-any day of the week!. Incredibly peaceful and interesting. Harajuku station is busy as ever, but then the walk to Meiji Jingu blocks out the hustle, as you hear your foot steps on the rocky path. Your mind drifts, and for me, all the thoughts swarming around stop, and I'm given a moment to breath and relax. I take it!

A place to enjoy nature and see a shinto shrine. The Meiji Jungu Shrine, a shinto shrine dedicated to the spirits of the Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken is a lovely quiet contemplative place to walk away from the hustle and bustle of the nearby shopping area. We were fortunate to see some children (in costume) performing folk dances on the stage at the entrance to the shrine. They were happy to pose for photos afterwards. There is also a good gift shop in the grounds of the shrine.
Beautiful forest in a busy city. Beautiful and tranquil place to visit in such a busy city. Don't miss it! Suggest you go early in your trip so that you can return again later if you enjoyed it.
My place in Tokyo. We spend a Sunday afternoon enjoying the early spring. Peaceful park with a nice shrine. A different way to discover Tokyo.
Peaceful. Wonderful gardens and a very peaceful place. We were lucky enough to see a wedding taking place and this was a bonus. The shrine itself is impressive.

Nice Shrine and Park. After visiting some Shrines you get the same sensation as after visiting many cathedrals in european countries... Nevertheless it is a special Shrine mainly because of the surroundings. You walk through a very nice park. I would say not to miss it, but it is not that different from others in Kyoto or Osaka (at least for a foreign).

A great place to stroll. Meiji Shrine is a must visit place in Tokyo, right next to the crazy shopping area of Harajuko. It is not a long walk as some claim, just a stroll from the station through a beautiful woodland setting in the heart of the city. Planted and built less than 100 years ago, this April saw the centenary of the death of the Empress to whom it is dedicated (jointly with the Emperor Meiji). I was there the Sunday before and there were lots of things going on. I am not sure if there would be so much at other times. At the entrance there was a stage with spectacular dancing, drumming and Kabuki style entertainment. In the main courtyard there was large scale dancing, martial arts and a marching band made up of school children - all perfectly drilled yet obviously thoroughly proud and enjoying themselves. I understand this is often the place to see traditional Japanese weddings but the entertainment more than made up for missing that.

Worth the walk.. I think it is best for you to visit this temple on a sunday, and hopefully get to see a wedding procession. The walk on the rubble is so serene you can never imagine that you are in the city. It is surrounded by super tall trees, and two shinto gates. This place is definitely worth to check out.I feel like I am thrown back in time where samurais or monks travel on a pilgrim

Beautifully peaceful. A wonderful place to enjoy a peaceful walk around lush gardens. The temple and shrine area is inspiring and we were lucky enough to watch a wedding procession walk through during our visit.

Time Warp. The park is a blast from the past ! Amidst the concrete Jungle of Tokyo a slight turn from JR station Harajuku . One would find himself in a Forrest of Giant Pine and Cedars trees ! lush and green and gravel road and a shrine dedicated to Emperror Meijji. It is just like walking in ancient Japan in the Era of Samurais and Daimyos!

Peaceful . Nice place, easy to get to. Long walk though but worth it. Better go there in the early morning - less crowded and more peaceful.Not the most beautiful shrine in Tokyo but definitely needs to be seen

Great Shinto Temple in busy Tokyo!. This is one of the must visits if you come to Tokyo unless you plan to visit temples elsewhere in Japan. Overall a good experience. Offerings to the deity happens twice a day. Once in the morning (not too sure about the time), the other once happens in the afternoon at 2pm.

Amazingly Beautiful. I came here through Harajuku, and it’s by far my favourite temple to go in Tokyo. You take a nice stroll through a park (Yoyogi Park) to get to the Shrine, and when you get there, you’ll see how beautiful the temple is. It’s not tall but its wide and spacious and steeped in history. Worth checking out when your around
Beautiful place. A quiet, large and nice place. We went in February during a ceremonie, it was beautiful. A must in Tokyo

Sanctuary in the middle of the concrete jungle. Among all those skyscrapers and department stores, it's nice to find a serene place in the middle of Tokyo. This is one of their major shrines as it is the final resting place of The Meiji Emperor and his Empress. We were fortunate to see a few traditional weddings taking place, giving it an authentic old-world feel.

Beautiful shrine, but crwoded. Probably one of the most-famous and most-visited shrine in Tokyo. Located in a nice park, you get a glimpse of "modern Japan history" since the Meji-Era. You'll see traditional Japanese weddings going on here and there, and I also recommend to visit the "Inner Gardens" for an additional 500 Yen.

Quiet place in the middle of the capital. Meiji Jingu is the place for Japanese people to go on the very first day of the year to pray for peace and healthy life for their family all through the year. It is such a quiet, peaceful place that you will be surprised when you find busy streets and brand-new shops just outside the shrine. You can walk down the pebbled road all the way to the shrine freely, have a good rest in the garden and enjoy green trees. From May to June you may find iris flowering all along the pond; it is a fantastic sight to see. You can stay, if you like, half a day there, and go back to the town called Harajuku, which is just outside the area, and enjoy shopping again.

Great combination with Omotesando. If you want to make good use of your time, you should add the combination of this major shrine with a visit to Harajuku and Omotesando, which are just outside its gate, to your itinerary. The shrine is not unique, but the setting is impressive considering it is in the main loop of Tokyo. If you hit a festival day or a wedding ceremony, you have a great way to pass an hour, before or after taking on the fashion street leading away from Harajuku station. The combination gives you two uniquely Tokyo experiences and you can adjust your pace to your own wishes. I'd make this one of the top three areas in Tokyo to visit.

Limited time is not Zen, but definitely worthwhile. Between my professional activities I sincerely enjoyed time to wander through the meandering pathways of Yoyogi park. Though I do not like flowering, including the infamous cherry blossom, I am passionate about the styling of trees (e.g. Japanese maple leaf, and pinus parviflora etc). The various pavilions were circumvented with beautifully developed trees stylishly grown on the brink of open fields and little ponds containing spawning carps and koi's. The Meiji shrine in commemoration of the highly-respected Emperor Meiji, reflects the loving contribution of the Japanese people, in one of the green oasis in Tokyo, just a brief walk from Harajuka subway station. The very down to earth architecture and use of simple colors with a preponderance of the natural stained wood. The courtyard centre is freely accessible, the shrine itself cannot be entered however. Interestingly, it is a site that enthrals people to marry, allowing the undersigned to see the beauty of people wearing colourful kimono's accompanied by traditional boring suits, and ad libitum happy laughter whether disguised by hand or not. The shrine may be modest in comparison to others, but in Zen spirit just harbours its own beauty.

Nice gardens, but shrine not special. The Meiji shrine is comparatively recent, built in memory of Japan's first Empereror, but does not live up to some of the more historic temples and shrines we had seen in Kyoto. Nevertheless it is set in fine gardens, albeit recently planted, and has an impressive approach up a long drive. The entry arch is huge and photogenic. The shine itself is nothing special, but being so large at least it doesn't suffer from overcrowding as some of the older and smaller temples do!

Average shrine. Maybe because I have been to temples and shrines in Kyoto, Nara and Mt Koya, this shrine in comparison is less interesting and spectacular.The shrine serves as a memorial to Emperor Meiji and his wife. There are information in English as you walked towards the main hall. It is relatively a long walk from the entrance to the main hall. Entrance is free but that does not include an optional garden and an optional museum.

Treasure Museum. Very beautiful park, very quite in the middle of a megacity. The Treasure Museum was for free, maybe due to the lack of visitors, otherwise it is 500¥ which are defenitly worth it. No pictures are allowed in the museum.

Famous shrine but a long walk to get there. There is a long, long walk in to this Shinto shrine, which is a memorial to the highly revered Emperor Meiji & his wife Empress Shoken. On the way there is a sake barrel/French wine barrel display, and (the best thing about this visit) a pictorial poster display celebrating how Empress Shoken promoted Japan to join the Red Cross, and encouraged women to strive for education & travel. The inner garden requires an entrance fee and would only really be worth going to in June when it apparently has magnificent displays of Iris flowers ... the favourite flower of the Empress. The shrine is large and impressive but that was about all unless you want to leave a donation to accompany writing down your wishes for the future. Great photo opportunities in front of the magnificent 12 metre high Myojin gates constructed with 1500 year old cypress trees from Taiwan

Enjoyable. Free access. Not too busy. We arrived while there was a dancing and drumming display on. It takes maybe ten minutes to see everything you need to see. Pleasant surroundings. Right next to harajuku metro so very easy to locate.

Experience the real Japanese culture. The second you enter the wooden gate, it's like coming back Tokugawa period. The road to the main temple is fairly long, i went there on winter time, when snow piled up along the road, and the ancient trees beside me just give this place a sense of solitude, absolute peace. The whole place is huge compare to the size of Tokyo, if you are as lucky as I am, you might also witness the traditional wedding inside the temple. Bride and groom, family and friends all wear traditional costume, i thought it was filming a movie when i first saw it. Anyway, it's the perfect place to get away from the modern world, and treat yourself a peaceful mind. And, if you are done with all the quiet, it is actually inside 表參道, where you can shop until you drop, what a way to get back to the modern world. :)
Nice temple in heart of city. Beautiful shrine in the middle of park. Signs from Yoyogi station made it easy to find. Dont forget to write down your blessings and prayers to submit to the temple.

If you have not been to Kyoto, this is a must. If you haven't seen the Temples in Kyoto yet, Meji is a must. If you already have seen the wonders of Kyoto Meji is not that spectacular. The good thing about this shrine is that they do provide some information in English, about what the washingroom and the clapping that the natives do really is all about.
Great for a leisurely walk. This is one of my favorite places to walk in Tokyo. The main paths are shaded by huge trees and there is a nice garden and pond area as well.
Very good place. This place has a very strong spiritual feel to it, A must see place with forest around it very peaceful place.

Nice Stroll and Close to Largest Daiso in Tokyo. We took the JR line to JR Harajuku Station. FREE admission. Note that Meiji Shrine has a separate entrance to Yoyogi Park. Don't miss street shopping at Takeshita Street in Harajuku (just across the JR station). Must visit the largest Daiso in Tokyo (5 storey) and try Japanese crepe, yummy with long queues. There are several stalls selling, take your pick.

A nice place to visit.. Very nice park with huge trees will lead you to the shrine.The shrine is not a typical Asian shrine, very simple ,no golden decoration. The (priest) if I may call them dressed in old Japanese costumes takes you back in history.

Incredibly peaceful. I'm not religious, but I still think walking through the greenery surrounding the Meiji Jingu gave me a religious experience. Modern and streamlined as Tokyo may be, it still has its hustle and bustle - until you step onto the shrine grounds. Make sure that you stop by all the buildings at the shrine (not just the main building / honden). The informational pamphlets available at the shrine were not, as I recall, available in English. When you get home from the shrine, though, do a bit of reading on the shrine - it has quite a bit of fascinating history to it!

Wonderful park and temple. Yoyogi park is a great place to go to relax and walk in the nature, particularly when you're back from an exhausting tour of Harajuku busiest and crowded shops.The temple is really a must see in Tokyo. It's huge and full of people, with weddings, parties, and in some occasion (like New Year's Eve) it's the setting for some great ceremonies.In the evening lights it's perfect to make some wonderful photo shots.

A must in Tokyo. The Shrine is hidden inside a large wooded area which is fairly peaceful. The joyous part of the Meiji shrine is that it is still active, though certain ceremonies they are quite opposed to you taking photos of, but no matter the case you get a sense of the feudal days gone by as you watch these practices go on. The area itself is beautifully designed and excellent to look at.Access to the Shrine is easy enough, though do plot ahead as this is Tokyo and the subway system is not always a traveler's best friend. Most people spend no more than thirty minutes depending on the rituals going on. Make sure to check locally especially around golden week for special events associated with the holidays.

Easy access, great experience. A wonderful relaxing place to visit. Witnessed 3 weddings (fortunately no funeral) whilst we visited the Shrine. Access from Harajuku station is easy which makes incorporating the Shrine into a Toyko itinerary a breeze. Would love to be there when they crack open a few of those wine barrels...
Step away from the city chaos. Lovely peaceful environment that belies it's proximity to the hustle and bustle. We will be visiting again next month April 2014.

Educational experience. We were fortunate to have great weather the day we walked the grounds and visited the Shrine. Unfortunately the Treasure Museum wasn't open the day we were there. I wasn't really interested in the Emperor or the Empress until visiting and learning about their contribution to global trade.

Absolutely beautiful!. Definitely a must see for Tokyo. The park is old and in perfect condition. The shrine had signs in both English and Japanese so it is easy to find exactly what you need. You can pick up a few souvenirs here as there are a few shops here with the traditional Japanese souvenirs. We were lucky enough to witness 2 wedding ceremonies as well as a photo session for a wedding. This place is steps away from Harajuku, so you can continue tour of the city without using any means of transportation.

Great tour/picture spot. This place is a must visit when you go to Tokyo. The shrine itself is very nice and has many picture opportunities but also the trails to the shrine and the park around the area is very nice. There are some facilities for grabbing a quick bite to eat or a snack near the entrance from the train station. I would rank this as one of the best tourist type spots that I went to on my trip to Tokyo for a couple of reasons, one is the upkeep at the shrine is very good and the second is that the general area and yoyogi park are also great to spending time in. Budget a whole day if you want to do the shrine, the park, and harajuku.

Lovely grounds, great history, excelent trip. We walked casually to the temple through the grounds and observed the various reading options available to us. We saw people from many cultures here and we left (unfortunately) just as the drum show started so we heard it but did not see it. It was a very peaceful walk through. Amazing how so much land exists in Tokyo and you do not hear the hustle and bustle of the city while at the shrine.

The most peaceful place in Tokyo.. Considering it's in the Tokyo Prefecture we were expecting this shrine to be very loud and busy with big crowds but it was surprisingly very peaceful and quiet. It was great to go to the shrine for a nice quiet walk and say a little prayer once at the shrine. The shrine is such a beautiful contrast between Japan's cultural history and modern advancements as it's an old shrine surrounded by the tall modern skyscrapers of Tokyo.It's located within walking distance to Shibuya's Harajuku Street that is also a must see with heaps of very cool clothing stores and cafes.
Beautiful walk to temple. Our family enjoyed the lovely walk to the temple and appreciated the opportunity to partake in a few local customs.

Excellent place to observe Japanese culture. Meiji shrine is a very peaceful place, but may have a lot of activity going on, as it did when I visited. There were two wedding processions while I was there, and the participants were gracious enough to allow many strangers to observe and photograph the goings-on. It was really beautiful and a treat to witness. There are also sacred trees on site, where one can make wishes and say prayers an tributes. There is a place to cleanse in the Buddhist/Shinto tradition and the grounds are spectacular. Free entrance, great way to spend an hour or two.

Relaxing Place. Clean, quiet and serene place to unwind after a busy day.The garden is nice and be prepared to do a lot of walking.Make sure to wear comfortable shoes! We visited mid-day and it was perfect as it was not so crowded and we were able to enjoy the sites.

Nice morning stroll. Right off the Harajuku JR Station. Make a right and then another right as you exit the station. What a nice morning stroll through the park. A peacefull and enjoyable stroll. Entrance is free. Inside the temple there is a large tree that was trimmed. It was a perfect round trim. I thought it was amazing. There happens to be a traditional japanese wedding while we were there. My wife bought some souveniers.

Escape from the busy city. The largest Shinto temple in Japan. It was completed in 1920 and is a symbol of the emperor's important role in Japanese society - both as a political and religious leader. The shrine is a beautiful example of traditional Japanese architecture. On the path to the temple you pass a lots of barrels full of Sake and wine. These are gifts from different regions of Japan to Meiji ShrineRemember to read the sign saying how to wash your hands before entering and do not step on the wooden beam as you enter the temple. If you are lucky you will see a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony taking place. A nice escape from the noisy and busy streets.

Moving, tranquil location. Very moving site. Quiet. Peaceful. Lovely stop in the middle of Tokyo. Free entrance. Can purchase a wood plaque for 5 jpy to write your prayers, gratitude and appreciation. Then place on divine tree to be offered at morning ceremony next day. Facilities available. Very clean. Staff polite. No vending available. Located off Yoyogi Station.

Ninja gaiden. It was pretty awrsome. Me personally I'm not one for religion but I'm more spiritual. This is a great atmosphere very calming. From the walks in the trails with trees and looking at the toonoki. I think there was a wedding going on but I got a great shot of the couple I wish I knew em so I could show em. The gift shop was pretty cool I like the icecream. Sukura blossom flavor ice cream that's crazy but good then thr apple sauce flavor icecream was good. Walking the dirt trail made me feel as if I was in the game ninja gaiden or onimusha. I just felt like if I had a sword I'd have to fight some demon spirits. I just got that vibe of being in a real life video game.

Lovely . This place is just lovey and serene. It's in the middle of the city but you can't feel the hustle and bustle once you enter the gardens. It's so quiet and green even in winter. There's a restaurant, a fast food cafe and a souvenir shop along the way to the temple. Go there early because they close the gates at around 5 PM.

Relax under the watchful eye of the kami. The Meiji shrine is an oasis of calm in an otherwise bustling city. It is a Shinto shrine (as opposed to a Buddhist shrine). We entered from the entrance at Harajuku where all of the cosplay girls and guys hang out (see photos). The shrine is huge and its a beautiful calming walk after a days shopping.A couple was getting married when I looked on during my visit, and it was a beautiful ceremony to watch. Such lovely people, the Japanese.It was blistering hot when I was there and that was in October! But then again, I'm Irish, so not too used to the heat!You can read more about Shinto here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinto

Beautiful. I went there with a group on a very cold Sunday in January. To be honest, not expecting to enjoy a day outside. I was amazed, however, by how peaceful and beautiful the area around the shrine was. I was even further surprised by the magnificent ice sculptures lining the entrance to the shrine on that morning. While in the shrine I witnessed a Japanese wedding, a sight so different to our own, I feel everyone should see one at least once.Overall, it was a day well spent!

A little calm and quietness in the big city. Lovely shrine surrounded by a lot of green. Nice and quiet walk up to the park (although it can get very busy, depending on the day and time you visit). On sunday, there are often traditional Japanese weddings taking place, which makes it an extra interesting visit.

Visit on a Sunday. It is interesting to visit on a Sunday as there is a chance to see a wedding procession at this shrine. Brides, grooms and the entire wedding party dressed in kimonos is a wonderful sight and very special. Shinto Priests are also known to give special cleansing and blessing ceremonies to the faithful - no photos are allowed when this occurs in the inner Shrine.The Shrine is impressive and the grounds are quite extensive. The walk to the Treasury is quite nice and in that building are portraits of all the Japanese emperors starting from legendary times up to the Showa Emperor. There are also several interesting pieces of memorabilia of the imperial family on display.The street leading up to the Shrine is filled with modern and upmarket shops, which provides a sharp contrast to the Shrine. Very interesting. Certainly worth a visit if one has the time whilst in Tokyo.

Awesome. The temple is at the heart of one ot the biggest park in tokyo, and it's simply awesome, huge and you can easily understand how this beuatiful place was built to honor the souls of the emperor and his wife.You'll walk under a lot of giant Torii to reach the inner garden where the temple is located.You can leave your prayers under the big tree, in the hope they'll be fulfilled by the gods and enjoy the time in this beautiful place :)

Beautiful park. I was here for New Year's Eve at midnight and it was an amazing experience! I've been back several times just to walk around and it is so peaceful and serene, a beautiful park in the middle of a busy city.

Very touristy. If you hate crowds, don't come at a peak season. This place would lose its charm. Shrine should be a peaceful place to be but maybe because it's famous it's usually crowded and doesn't feel peaceful. I'd go for a less famous and peaceful shrine for authentic Japan

A beautiful Shrine and downtown park. This is a very nice park in Tokyo with a very pretty shrine in the middle. It is nice to get away from the city and people watch. It is a bit away from subway stations so count on some walking to get there and get back if you are taking the subway.

Peaceful. Hard to believe this is right next to the busy streets of one of Tokyo's busiest shopping areas, it was great just to take a few hours away from the city to walk in forest, which was a lot cooler, and to see the temple, and pay your respects. If you're lucky you'll also see a traditional wedding ceremony procession.
Pretty Cool. Very interesting place, make sure you read up how to wash your hands before entering and also dont step on the wooden beam as you enter the temple.

It's alright. Since we were in Tokyo, we had to stop here to take a walk around the area. While some people seem to love this place, for some reason it just didn't do it for me. The Sake barrels were cool, and the stroll through the forest was nice, but when I went it was very crowded. To me, nothing just popped out to me and said "wow." Nonetheless, Meiji Jingu is very easy to get to from Harajaku Station; it's a short walk from outside of the station. I'd still recommend going to see it, just because of the history here.

Wow!. We took a stroll here on a lovely sunny day and it was absolutely amazing! There are things to see and admire, like Sake kegs which have historical meaning, to also admiring the gorgeous forest as you make your way to the temple. You would not think you were in the middle of the craziness of Tokyo being here.Before you enter, you should cleanse your hands / mouth from the font of water - but make sure you pay attention to HOW you do so.We were really lucky to be able to see a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony take place, it was beautiful!! We did hear these usually take place on a Saturday, but we actually went on a Friday so you never know your luck! I would recommend taking a few minutes to read some of the prayers on the tree and maybe do one yourself :) Enjoy the tranquil peace in this beautiful Temple.

weeeeellllll. the day we went there, it was nice cause we saw a couple of weddings. the structure is kind nuts and amazing but..otherwise, pick a nice day to walk around. there is a garden in there but they charge money so that was loser deals. but we went to the temple, hung out, threw out money, did the blessings. everything is in english here so thats good. and then we walked around omotesando and then on to shibuya so it was a good day.

Absolute beatiful and lovely stroll. We definitely would regret it if we have missed visiting Meiji Jingu. We are so glad that we didn't! We stayed at Ueno and took the Yamanote Line and stop at Harajuku Station. From the station we walked towards the temple which is just next to the station. To get to the temple, we walked through the beautiful forest. It was so serene and there was a souvenir shop where you can stop by before reaching Meiji Jingu. Although you are not permitted inside the palace, we felt that it was good enough since the outside was already that beautiful! The admission is free! They do sell some charms but very pricey. All in all, this is a must! we love this visit more than Sensoji.

Must visit shrine!. If you need to visit a shrine, Meiji Jingu is the place to go first. It is such a nice place for a walk. Totally opposite with the hustle and bustle of Harajuku and Shibuya. I was totally impressed with this place! Plus, its a free attraction!

Tranquility, great for a stroll. This is a beautiful place for a nice walk when visiting Harajuku and Omtesando. The gates are excellent and there is plenty of green space to enjoy. It's a can't miss place while visiting Tokyo really as it is so unique in the busy and densely populated city.

Don't be afraid to visit at New Year. I arrived in Tokyo on December 30, and New Years Eve was our first day out exploring. We visited Meiji Jingu a little hesistantly after hearing about crazy crowds around New Year. At least at the time we visited, mid afternoon on the 31st it was rather quiet. There was a ceremony taking place in the shrine which was fun to watch. Great shrine to visit too, lots of interesting information about Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken.

Great to see a wedding. I wan't too impressed with Meiji Jingu itself but I didn't see all of it. However seeing a wedding procession there was fantastic. Definitely visit Yoyogi park and wander into Meiji Jingu while there.

Lovely peaceful grounds. Took a tour guide with us to Meiji Shrine. Huge tori gates on the entrance and lovely grounds to walk around. Interesting to have someone explain the history and the effect the emperor had on the people and the change over to western thinking/dressing etc. Fascinating. Highly recommend.

Beautiful shrine, great grounds. Meiji shrine is one of the two must see shrines in Tokyo, the other being at Asakusa. Entering into the park around the shrine by the huge Tori gates, you're immediately feel like you're escaping the hectic pace of nearby Harajuku and transported to a calmer time. The shrine itself is a beautiful example of traditional Japanese architecture and offers some great photography opportunities.

A peaceful Tokyo oasis. After several enjoyable days visiting various sections of the city we experienced the calming contrast of Meiji Jingu. Walking under the torii entrance into the wooded area takes you from the fast pace of the city into a serene environment. If you're lucky, you may have the added bonus of viewing a wedding party or children in traditional attire.Recommend meandering around Harajuku Takeshita-dori and other nearby Shibuya areas for an enhanced appreciation of this Tokyo oasis,

Excellent place for photo opportunities. As all the reviews suggest, Meiji Jingu is a beautiful place, that's easy to find and free of charge. Definitely a must for anyone visiting Tokyo. I went in the afternoon just a few hours after arriving in Narita after a 12 hour flight and it was brilliant, I felt awake again. There were a lot of people there but people will wait on you taking photos or whatever.

A beautiful walk through history. We visited the Shinto temple in winter, and it's quite special to see the fog laying low on the ground. There's a beautiful inner garden dedicated to Empress Shoken. There's some excellent interpretive signs explaining the importance of the Meiji Restoration and examples of the valuable work of Empress Shoken. The Temple is also very beautiful, and if you really want to experience it make sure you follow the traditions of washing your mouth and give a prayer.

Beautiful shrine in Tokyo. We went to Meiji on our second day in Japan. The shrine is very easy to access via the subway or local JR line. The shrine is located in a large park that is very beautiful and relaxing. We spent some time just walking around. While not as impressive as other shrines that we saw in Japan, it was beautiful and a great "welcome to Japan" experience. It is a must-see for tourists, especially since it is so easy to access. Combine it with a visit to the Harajuku area.

Suprising area. This Shinto temple is in heart of Tokyo prefecture, located in nice garden full of trees. There are lots of barrels full of Sake and wine located at the entrance to the gardens. These are gifts from multiple regions of Japan to Meiji Shrine. I was lucky enough to see traditional Japan wedding at the time i was there. This is one of "must see" places while in Tokyo.

Peace in the Middle of a Bustling City. My husband & I were taken to visit this shrine by our personal guide Miwa. It is unexpectedly large in a city where everything seems jam-packed. The large shady tree path gives you the feeling that you are going into a magical space. Along the walk we saw sake barrels and flower arrangements. We got lucky & saw children dressed up in traditional Japanese attire (as the national children's day had just passed) and a bride leaving her ceremony.

Beautiful!. Incredible! This location was beautiful! Very accessible by metro, and many good places to eat. The walk to the shrine is beautiful, and the shrine itself is magnificent. Many local events that go on.
Beautiful and serene. This is a beautiful place to visit amongst the busyness of Tokyo. The walk through the forest was beautiful.

Huge shrine in a lovely park. We visited Meiji Jingu on the last day of the year, and we were able to walk around before the crowds that flood the shrine on the evening of New Year`s. The shrine is lovely, huge, and the setting is very nice. From Tokyo Station we took the JR Yamamote line to Harakuju station, and after visiting the shrine we walked down to Shibuya.
Torii. Meiji shrine is the biggest shrine in Tokyo, and the most people come there for one's first visit of the year to a shrine.
Can''t get enough of shrines. Really pretty and clean. We went on Sunday late afternoon and there were lots of wedding ceremonies.

Perhaps earlier in the morning may be best?. We walked from Shibuya for about 30 mins to Yoyogi Park and Meiji Shrine and then to Harajuku. Shinjuku is up the road from these. Meiji Shrine has a separate entrance to Yoyogi Park. We walked around the park only to discover that the shrine was not in there but to enter through another entrance. By the time we walked around yoyogi park and realised we are not at all near the shrine, we got to the shrine at 11.30am. The crowds at Meiji Shrine is mad but within control. You just follow the crowd and it is very orderly – going clockwise. You get to the shrine and follow the locals – throw your money in and make a wish I guess or ask for forgiveness!? We preferred this shrine to Asakusa Sensoji temple, feeling it more "traditional" - perhaps setting in the park amongst beautiful trees adds to the whole atmosphere. It seems more tranquil as well - maybe because it is "within" park environment whereas Asakusa feels like right bang within city life. The walk to the Meiji shrine adds to the calming experience, leaving behind the hustle and bustle whereas coming out of asakusa station, you walk along the busy street and there you are amongst the crowds at sensoji temple - no time to unwind.

The place to go for New Years. Meiji jingu shrine is the most popular place to visit on New Year's day. The line to reach the shrine was over two hours long. Any other day of the year this place is a peaceful place in a huge city.

If you only visit one temple, come here. Meiji Jingu is dedicated to Emperor Meiji who opened up Japan to the rest of the world and thus forever in our hearts. Beautiful buildings and greenery make this place very special indeed

Tranquil, therapeutic shrine in Tokyo. We went in the late afternoon and there were loads of visitors around, but even then the walk to the shrine on the gravel paths was therapeutic, and the shrine exuded an aura of tranquillity. The trip was definitely worth it!

holy power spot. took train to pay a visit to this shrine on the first day in 2014.It was a long long queue and freezing cold outside.But really lucky to be part of the big traditonal event in japan,wish all the best to my family and friends.

An oasis of tranquillity in Tokyo. Situated in the midst of Yoyogi Park, Meiji Shrine is an oasis of calm and tranquillity from the noise and bustle that is downtown Tokyo. Hoping to avoid the crowds, I reached around 8 in the morning and there were very few people around. Walking through the wide gravel paths of the forested park to the shrine was therapeutic. There are small streams, little gold-topped lantern pagodas, a wall of saki and a great torii gate before you reach the shrine. The first thing you notice as you enter the shrine gate is the two large, perfectly sculpted trees fronting the shrine. Perfect for a photo shoot if you have a wide angle lens. There were nuns and monks in their white and red outfits quietly doing maintenance. It was all very tranquil. A must visit if you are in Tokyo but an early visit to avoid the crowds is well worthwhile.

A blissful Sunday morning. We decided to walk from Shinjuku to Harajuku via the main path through the Meiji Jingu gardens; we were blessed with a beautiful crisp morning with sunlight filtering through the tall trees. Many locals were taking a peaceful Sunday stroll which added to the calm aura. We returned on another day for a specific visit to the Shrine and the Inner Garden, which is aptly described as 'an oasis in the centre of a noisy city'. Although we visited in December when most of the flowers were 'hibernating', the garden and the Well were beautiful and unforgettable. The Shinjuku Gardens are remarkable but be sure to also spend time at Meiji Jingu for a different but equally beautiful experience.
Amazing tranquility in the heart of Tokyo. This place was probably my favourite place in Tokyo. Huge wooden arches, an amazing temple and a beautiful forest area. Absolutely worth a visit.

A serene escape from the city. We got around Tokyo using the metro, and this place is a two minute walk from Harajuku Street. It's quite hot in August, but the park is so green and shady that you escape the hustle of the city outside and feel like you're in your own bubble. There's a wishing well, as well as the Japanese custom of washing your hands before entering the shrine. All in all, a great way to spend an hour before heading out to Harajuku.

Blissful. I loved this Shrine - located a short walk from Harajuku Station, its a blissful walk around a park with a serene temple in the middle. Beautifully kept, you feel like you've happened upon an ancient (though it all looks pretty new!) temple, in a secret park. It makes you feel at peace with yourself and left me feeling really pleased to have seen this jem in the middle of Tokyo.

Must see!. Highly recommend you do a little research before visiting to completely understand the importance of this shrine. Beautiful and unique, this shrine is a popular attraction. We visited on a Sunday afternoon and witnessed two wedding parties in traditional Japanese attire and their procession.

Handcrafted forest. Almost lost all hope of getting here, approached Meiji Jingu from the east (from Meiji Park) on foot. We got misled by the multiple Meijis on the map. No phone service sucks. The Shinto gates are darn impressive, shooting up several stories with elegance to boot. I liked the memorials to wine and sake, the wine one seemed particularly popular with the Europeans that were nearby.The plentiful surrounding forest was also hand-planted. It is quite a memorial.When you get a chance, buy a ticket to the inner garden. It was 2 or 3 bucks...But hey, you're here after all. The royal tea house and (creek?) trail is worth it.

Quiet. just about 10 minutes taxi ride from Shibuya crossing/center. Feels very old world Japan. Not as busy as Asakusa Shrine because there's no shops. It's just a wide gravel road leading through a park to the Shrine. Very nice. Peaceful.

Pleasant walk. A nice park to walk through and I found the shrine bigger and more sprawling than expected. Quite busy, even on a week day.One regret - I should've bathed in mosquito repellant before going!

Very peaceful and beautiful. The whole place is different and pretty serene compared to the noisy and busy streets of Harajuki. The whole place is gifted with beautiful parks and the shrine in itself is placed among perfect serene location. There is a whole calm atmosphere to the place and the shrine seems to be quite crowded with both tourists and the Tokyo natives as well.

Green and very cultural. Located near Harajuku JR Station, Meiji Jingu Mae subway station and Yoyogi Park.A very nice place with green jungle along the way to the main shrine building.You will be able to see Miko or shrine maiden with their white-orange outfit walking around...I love the traditional and details of architecture in this shrine.

A nice contrast to Harajuku. Peaceful and beautifully cared for it provides a wonderful contrast to the hyper of Harajuku. A gentle gravel path walk with amenities along the way is rewarded with a spacious and special experience.

Beautiful and Restful Visit. I loved the visit to the Meiji Jingu-- I'd recommend seeing it on a weekend, if you can, as the place was filled with locals and tourists alike on our recent visit. It was apparently a rather auspicious day, as the shrine was filled with wedding guests attending multiple weddings on site-- what a lovely experience. Take a break from the hubub of Harajuku, right around the corner, or use this shrine as a way to rest before jumping into the madness.

Tranquil. When you arrive at the Harajuki station it is difficult to believe that close by there is huge park and shrine. As you start walking along the large tree-lined avenue everything is suddenly peaceful. The traffic noises fade away and all you can hear are the birds singing in the trees. You walk over a little bridge with a stream running below; the woodland is beautiful.There is a huge Tori gate as you approach the shrine, which is quite stunning. You also pass several barrels of sake and wine along the way which were donated to the Emperor.The shrine itself is beautiful and you need to make time to walk around the gardens. Definitely worth a visit.

Serene Park in the Busy City. I found this park to be very nice - very serene and a lovely setting. The history here was very interesting. Also when we were there something special was going on, we could not determine what exactly, but many people were there with quite young children all in traditional dress. Of course they were so very cute it was a delight to see. Also a wedding was underway and we could watch the procession. We walked over to the gymnasium where there was a traditional archery competition going on which we peeked at for a bit which was amazing. It was fun to talk to some young men who had competed and were walking home. Nice place and a nice experience for us.

City oasis. After Kyoto, I didn't have high hopes for Meiji Jingu but I was pleasantly surprised. I concur with other reviewers. The shrine is surrounded by dense, tall trees a short walk from JR Harajuku station. I suggest entering from north entrance if possible to avoid crowds, and leave from southeast entrance close to JR Harajuku station. Alternatively, you can take NW entrance from Yogigi station. Be prepared to spend at least an hour just to cover the grounds. Pavement are lined with small rocks and sand so may be difficult for those wearing flip-flops.
Peaceful place next to most busy shopping district!. Very serene and auspicious place. The park is huge so had a great walk while enjoying scenic beauty.

Shinto shrine in central Tokyo. This shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken who westernised Japan is of great cultural significance. The barrels of wine and sake donated in honour the Emperor are surrounded by a tranquil forest that makes it seems like another world to the busy city altogether. The museum near the entrance was closed the day we visited and the other museum around the back of the shrine wasn't really worth seeing. Definitely worth going to this shrine, but no need to spend too long here if you plan on visiting a few others.

Great Place to See. We were there on a Saturday and were able to observe many weddings. Many of the people, even the children, were in traditional clothing. It make for a wonderful experience. They were very kind and let us take pictures of them.There are two museums on the grounds and we visited both of them. They were well worth the time

A fab cultural experience. One of my favourite shrines in Tokyo due to its central location yet tranquil setting. It is very beautiful in terms of architecture and has a lot of interesting history surrounding it. If you go on a Sunday sometimes university students offer you free and insightful tours which are fantastic

This is a must see destination. I love this place.... the long wide access from Harajuku station though the gate, past the barrels of sake wrapped in straw offered every year in honour of the Emperor Meiji and Princess Shoken; the gardeners sweeping away the leaves in a manner that's a delight to watch and up to the shrine itself which feels a world away from modern Tokyo. This is a place that's held in the highest esteem by the Japanese and understandably so. Its a very popular location for Shinto weddings from the modest to the very grand - they are a delight to watch. If I had to choose just one place to visit in Tokyo, this would be it.

The gateless gate. I took a cab from Shinjuku & paid around JPY1800 to reach, & entered from the other side of Harajuku. Huge entrance, & a total space of Zen, Very wide walkway, & very silent.The main shrine though, was busy, & lot of touristsBut its in the downtown core, & what a space.The Harajuku side leads to the Takeshita Street, so in all its the essence of meditation in the marketplace

I Can't Believe It's In Downtown Tokyo. Meiji Jingu could be compared to Central Park in New York but the only difference is that a few steps into Meiji Jingu, and you immediately feel as though you're in 17th century Japan, far from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Located just to the right of Harajuku Station, Meiji Jingu houses a Shinto temple complex set in a lush park with man made fishing ponds, torii gates, and some of the finest traditional Japanese architecture in Tokyo (similar to the kind you would find in Kyoto or Kamakura). One of my favorite things to do is look at the wooden prayer plaques hanging on stands and read the messages of those who have visited and left their prayers in many languages amongst the ones written in Japanese. I would recommend going to Meiji Jingu after a long day walking around the city to get some quiet time.......oh! and enjoy an ice cream while you're at it.

Serene. The Meiji temple is a favourite spot of mine. I always make sure to take visitors to see it. The gates are stately, the woods are magnificent. I once witnessed the sweeping of the alleys in the morning, it reminded me of martial arts training, in the posture, the gestures and so on.You will generally get to see Shinto weddings, which are very picturesque. If you chance to go during the iris season, make sure to see the memorable gardens, for a fee; otherwise I would just skip the gardens.There is a little shop soon after you enter, with a good selection of souvenirs. Finally, this is right next to JR Harajuku, with Takeshita street and Omotesando, which are also recommended!

Shinto Shrine in The Heart of Tokyo. This shrine is located near Harajuku and Shibuya, and it is a typical Japanese shrine surrounded by the forest. When you get in here, it seems you are not in Tokyo, you are sorrounded by big trees, far away from the city. It is one of the most spiritual spots in Tokyo, although it is in the center of Tokyo and if you just step out you can find the bizarre styles of Harajuku. It is a very good place for a peaceful walk.

Loved the Crows!. Meiji Jingu is in an evergreen forest-like setting. When I visited (early in the morning, on a weekday) there were no wedding processions or children dressed in kimonos. It was peaceful and quiet, except for the crows. They were very big and making lots of noise. Lucky crows, flying over the grounds of this beautiful Shinto shrine.

Meiji Shrine is a sacred treasure in the midst of a busy city!. Meiji Shrine is surrounded by a virgin forest and appears secluded---even though it finds itself in the midst of one of the busiest and most populous parts of town. The woods are lovely enough to takes a stroll, and are especially beautiful in the spring and fall, with new growth and fall colors. The summer. too, is great, with the open-air park being a place to catch some rays while lying on the grass, and the Iris Garden is an absolute must when the flowers are in bloom. The shrine itself is a beautiful example of Shinto architecture, and the whole area is shrouded in a peaceful and serene atmosphere that helps one forget the hustle and bustle of daily city life.If you go, be sure to go on a clear, sunny day---because you will want to stroll around for hours, and also be certain to bring your camera of mobile, because you will want to take zillions of photos.

Nice park with temple inside. it was nice park with temple inside. You can have relaxing time when walking around. Inside the park there is special garden where you have to pay for entrance - i was in November so all plants were down. Maybe worth of seeing in summer time?

Great place to experience Japanese culture. If you visit on the weekend you will get to experience traditional Japanese wedding processions. The procession is lead by a priest and shrine attendants holding a beautiful parasol. They are followed by the groom and bride who wears a white kimono and laquered wig. After that come the parents relatives and friends. It is a great experience!During the first two weeks of November during the Shichi-go-san festival you will also get to see dozens of 7, 5 and 3 year olds wearing beautiful kimono. It is truly a sight that can't be missed.

Beautiful, make sure you have enough time to look at everything. So lovely, we were fortunate to visit at a time when Noh theatre was on. Interesting - not sure of the plot but an experience! Make sure yoiu take a camera and allow enough time to really explore and experience the shrine.

Beautiful!. Meiji Jingu is a beautiful temple and the surrounding grounds/paths are gorgeous. We were there in the fall and the leaves were changing. We saw children in autumn color kimonos at the temple, made for some beautiful photos. I would recommend a few hours on the grounds, to really appreciate the temple and the park.

Beautiful and Peaceful Temple...worth a visit. We went to Meiji Jingu today along with the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden as they are quite close to each other and it was such a perfect and peaceful day. We were also lucky enough to see a wedding ceremony at the Meiji Temple which was wonderful!! I would highly recommend seeing both when in the area and taking a short 20min or so walk to Shibuya to round out the trip.

nice, relaxed, entertaining. we went on a wkend and it was so alive. people everywhere singing, dancing, live music, food stalls in the adjacent park and kids dressed up in full traditional clothing at the temple. also saw a traditioanl wedding at the temple. a lovely day out

Serene place in the hubbub of Tokyo. I would recommend going to this Shrine only if you have visited other must-see places in Tokyo or if you want a break from the hubbub. It offers a peaceful walk in the shaded cool of lots and lots of trees, a chance to look at several Tori gates, and a possible opportunity to get a glimpse of a Shinto wedding. I also ended up buying a few souvenirs and gifts at reasonable prices from the gift shop here. Might have been more interesting to have an English speaking guide with me to learn more about the place and its history.

Always on my list of places to visit in Tokyo. Taking the long approach walk on the wide gravel path, passing through tori, hearing the giant blackbirds complain, and arriving at the sequence of spaces of the shrine...delightfully full of sights, sounds, smells and taste...

Easy access, peaceful visit. This shrine is worth visiting for the grounds alone. 175 acres of green - most trees planted by hand about 100 years ago. It is obviously a very important place for families. Seeing all the young ones dressed in traditional dress adds to the experience.

Lovely shrine. When I visited Tokyo, I was seduced and awed far easier by steel, concrete and flashing lights; tall buildings, busy intersections, crowds of people walking around - than by the beauty and history of the Meiji Shrine. Now, when I go back, I shall visit the shrine once again, and pay much closer attention to its meaning, history and the images of Samurai dancing inside my head.

Precious Heritage. Big temple in the center of Shibuya, very nice environment, i m also amazed with how the volunteers help to clean the temple, they keep all the area clean and nice, there's a souvenir shop also that sell a very unique merchandise. We go out from west gate that cross the street is Takeshita street, with a lot of thing to see and can buy also souvenir for gift. we can enjoy the sweet crepes that famous in that area.

A Perfect Sunday Outing. A stroll around this temple and grounds on a mild Sunday autumn afternoon was a great way to spend an hour or two. Lots of gorgeously dressed children clattering about in their geta and kimonos, wedding parties, and extended families strolling around or chowing down at the excellent al fresco okonomiyaki stall.For a contrast on a weekend, hop over the road to Takeshita St for an idea of what interests Japanese teenagers.

Cultural experience. I love how the cultural experiences in Japan were not removed from every day life. We visited this temple on a Saturday morning and saw 3 weddings, a tea ceremony, and numerous children having their first, second, and third trips to the temple depending on their ages. Of all these events required traditional dress and it was beautiful to see! People were so friendly and obliged happy when we asked to photograph some of their experiences. Gorgeous visit!

Sublime experience. Visiting the Meiji Jingu (shrine) was one of my favorite memories from my visit to Tokyo, Japan. Pictures in photo books and travel guides did not do it justice. If you're visiting Tokyo, the Meiji Jingu is a must. It's free and only takes an hour or so to enjoy. I visited in July 2012, not December 2012.

Meiji Shrine Doll Thanksgiving Day. We visited the Meiji Jingu Shrine on the 6th of October 2013. A very nice sunny day after a few rainy days in Tokyo.This shrine is dedicated to the divine souls of Emperor Meiji and his consort Empress Shoken. it was established in 1920.It was just by chance that we arrived early and were allowed to follow the ceremonies taken place for the Doll Thanksgiving Day.This is an event that has been held in October each year since 1989.All different types of dolls are carried for enshrinement.Since ancient times the Japanese have believed that dolls possess souls, and it should not just discard dolls in the garbage.People comes to the Shrine with bags of dolls, and they write messages of gratitude to their own dolls on paper cutouts in the shape of human figure and place the notes before the shrine altar. The messages are then used by Shinto priests in the rites of purification. Following the ceremony the dolls are disposed in a proper and respectful fashion.We had such an experience watching the thousand of people coming with their bags of dolls to participate in the event, that we will not forget it.

Understand the story behind the temple. I've always felt that visits to temples and other religious sites are meaningless without first understanding the context behind said sites. Meiji Jingu is no different. That said, the temple pays perfect homage to the Meiji Emperor and Empress, two excellent regents of the modern age, with its juxtaposition of the ancient and the modern. Situated right smack in the middle of the city, this temple truly represents the convergence between Japan's past and present, and is a testament to how the Japanese have managed to conserve the things that matter. The temple also features interesting little exhibits and structures (such as a collection of nicely mounted wine barrels), in a wonderfully tranquil environment. There's plenty of walking involved, so dress comfortably on a hot summer's day.

Tradition weddings and a children's day celebration.. We went on a Saturday, which turned out to be a great day to go there. We were lucky enough to see 3 traditional wedding processions (after the ceremony on the way to photographs). Interesting to watch as it is very formal. We also saw many children aged between 3-7 yrs in traditional kimono (boys and girls). Apparently, it was 7,5, 3 Children's Day.. They were so adorable accompanied by very proud parents and grandparents. The temple and grounds were lovely too. We wrote a blessing on a tablet of wood for 500 yen and wandered through the forest that was planted in honour of the Emperor and Empress. It was a lovely peaceful sanctuary in the hectic bustle of the Harijuku area.

Serene shrine and surrondings. Easy to access either via JR or Marunochi line. Best of all its free unless you want to visit the museum. Was lucky to visit on day when there was a ceremony to commemorate Emperor Meiji's birthday. It was a v beautiful event. The shine is built in honor of Emperor Meiji, the 1st Emperor of Japan who also opened Japan to the west and modernised education. Nov 3rd is also the national Culture Day in which arts, culture and education are honored. Check out the website for the list of events for the month you are visiting and it will make it more memorable. Its amazing that a place so central in busy Tokyo can be so serene and beautiful. The shrine is across the road from where the Takaeshita Dori is, so best time to visit is sunday and then you can cross the road to see the cosplay and famous Harajuku dressings. Further down is the Aoyama Dori where the branded shops are.

Shrine in a middle of a large tranquil park. The Meiji Shrine is a break from the hustle and bustle of the city. The shrine itself is about a 15 minutes walk from the Harajuku station. Visited over culture day, and there were many activites going on as well. Also it is free. There is also a treasure museum in the park, not really worth the entry fee.

Beautiful Temple. This is a beautiful temple. We saw children ceremoniously dressed in kimono with their proud parents approaching and leaving the temple and a prayer ceremony where a monk was using the very large drum in the temple. The walk through the park is long and possibly not for those with difficulty walking any distances, but it is a beautiful walk and along the way are prize winning chrysanthemums and bonsai. The details in the architecture such as the little hearts in the iron work are lovely. This is an easy sight to see in conjunction with a stroll on the other side of the subway station through Harajuku Street where all the stylized fashion is..it's like seeing the two sides of the Tokyo coin!

Pretty. It was amazing to see a very old shrine in the heart of Shibuya. It was so quiet and sirene that you forget you're in such a bustling city. It was easy to find on our own with just Google maps and was free to get in and walk around. Very pretty.

An escape into nature. I was pleasantly surprised by Yoyogi Park thinking that it would be one of those parks with lots of benches and ponds and paved walkways but it wasn't - at least not the walkway towards Meiji Jingu.It felt like I was in the middle of a forest with the bountiful trees all around - indeed a gem in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the city life. It is a great and quick escape into nature and experience the serenity of not just the greens but also the holy grounds of Meiji Jingu.There are lots of wooden arches around that is pretty magnificent in size and they also have a restaurant and a snack bar along the way with a gift shop! I didn't actually enter the shrine because I didn't have enough time to spare but it was still a wonderful stroll in Yoyogi Park.A recommended place to visit!

Just go!!. A definite must when you're in Tokyo. A real beauty spot with loads of photo opportunities. The walk (although a bit of a distance) to the temple is beautiful. The temple itself is even more impressive and if you're lucky you may see a traditional Shinto wedding.....we did!!

Tradition and peace right there in the middle of one of the busiest Tokyo's districts. Meiji Jingu is a wonderful park that has an interesting temple right in the middle of the overwhelming busy Shibuya district in Tokyo.It is like going from fire to water...very peaceful, containing a forest which is said to have 700.000trees, it has nice ancient wooden gates and examples of sake containers on the way to get to the temple. It is said as well that trees from all over Japan were donated when the temple was being built. It is a long walk worth while. The temple is a Shinto temple that was built at the beginning of the XX century in honour to Meiji Emperor and his wife. It was destroyed during the World War II and re-build in the 50s. When I visited, I learned a lot about the Emperor and his ruling through a set of pictures placed in muralsalong the way to the temple.It is quite interesting for those who want to learn about history of Japan in a agreeable and peaceful environment. It is also a nice place to meet locals, who enjoy the park as a relaxing place.

Large and peaceful park. This grand park in the heart of Tokyo is a great place to get away from the busy city. There are lots of quiet corners and grassy aresa to sit and rest. The Meiji Jingu temple is a plus, though nothing spectacular when it comes to temples in Japan. There is also a museum on the far end of the park, but the opening hours seem to be merely a suggestion...Come here for an escape from the fast pace of Tokyo, or around 8am to experience the morning prayers accompanied by Taiko drumming.

My recommendation is the approach to the Meiji Shrine.. Honden (main shrine building) has the solemn atmosphere and many people will be impressed. I also recommend you to enjoy taking a walk through the approach to the Meiji Shrine. The mysterious atmosphere makes you feel refreshed.
It is in a big park. Beautiful shrine. Be sure to either have a guide or a guide book so you understand what you are seeing. There is so much to know, see and do. It would be easy to miss something.

Peaceful, beautiful and refreshing. Loved the atmosphere - The park and the shrine with traditional Japanese styles has brought me very pleasing experience. It was lovely to see sincere people making wishes and bowing in humble appreciation. Would have stayed longer there. Gotta see it yourself and enjoy the magical quiet moments in the central city.

Quiet place in busy Tokyo. We visited this late afternoon when the sun was way down west, the ray of light through the large trees were just beautiful. Some walking required on the cobble and sand walkways, so could kick up some dust up the air too.Shrine and temple was large, and turned out in weekend afternoon it was a favorite time and place for weddings, we saw two back to back, beautiful brides, antique cars, the atmosphere were just right for weddings. Nice enough families and wedding guests to allow us to take photographs with them.Quite near to Harajuku (one station down), so come evening we head there for the famous fashion parade, after this well worth excursion.

Alienated side of hectic Shibuya. A marvellous spot to have a relaxing mind and body. A vast area of trees, cool air, open space, and a calibrated chance for eyes to have a relaxation when we come to this place. It's like being in a different town. It was really an alien. Very recommended!

Well Worth Visiting - but tiring too!. We visited here when the weather was still a little too hot.It is a fascinating and informative location with so much to seem study and absorb.As another reviewer has pointed out, there is a lot of walking involved, unless you're on a bus tour. (The buses drive in and park well inside the park).One notable attraction is what is Japan's largest torii; see attached picture!

A long but very beautiful walk to the temple. My husband and I felt like we bonded with nature after visiting this place. We didn't notice how far we walked to get to the temple because of the relaxing feel. It was nice listening to the sound of nature.For me, this was the most beautiful temple that we have visited during our stay in Tokyo. Seeing the temple itself was amazing after the long walk. The structures were very well-kept and the atmosphere was so serene and peaceful.

Weekends are good for seeing traditional Japanese weddings. The shrine is a favourite place for people to get married the traditional way in Japan. No photography is allowed at the actual shrine itself.

A fresh place in the middle of the city. Lots of trees, so if you want to stroll around the city and not get caught by the sun, you can visit this place, because there will be shadow for sure. Temple very nice and weddings take place there.

Must see. We went on a Sunday morning around 9am and it was not busy at all. We got to see a traditional wedding procession, which was very interesting and nice to see. The shrine is very pretty and we had a nice relaxing time there. We spent about and hour there. There's also a nice gift shop and a cafe. By the time we left it was getting very busy.

Visited three times in as many days!. Although the second and third time were technically returning to get the stamp that was missed the first time (the second time was an unsuccessful attempt at getting the stamp; thus the third time). However, the first time, we witnessed a Shinto wedding, and that was pretty cool.All in all, it's larger than your average shrine, but since it was built much more recently, it doesn't have much to set itself apart architecturally from a lot of the other shrines in Japan. Nonetheless, it is an impressive site with a large courtyard and a pleasant forested walk leading up to it.

Witnessed a wedding at this historical site. Leaving the Harajuku rail station, turn right, across the bridge then you'll see the main entrance of Meiji Shrine. It's in a well maintained forested area with tall, shady trees. This is the place where you meet many Japanese women in their colourful kimonos.Also I was indeed lucky to witness a traditional Japanese wedding at this auspicious site.- actually it was my first experience of the ceremony and kept my camera rolling.Really glad to have made this trip from George Town, Penang, Malaysia
Great spot!. Meiji Shrine was my favorite tourist attraction in Tokyo. Its extremely relaxing, peaceful, and quiet. Definitely worth the trip!

Baffled by the good reviews. I'm deeply confused by the 5 star reviews. I realise this shrine is of culture significance, so perhaps people feel bad giving a low rating, but it really wasn't a great sight to see.The walk through the forest was very pleasant and it smelt absolutely wonderful. It was also lovely and cool, which was pleasant after the hot Sunday crush of Harajuku (highly recommended!). However, the shrine itself has been fairly recently rebuilt and was plain and completely uninspiring. Judging purely as a non-Japanese visitor interested in aesthetically pleasing sights, I cannot recommend this shrine.If you have time go to Nikko or Kyoto where the temples and shrines are absolutely breathtaking.
A place to find peace. After a day in crowded Shibuya, the next morning I came to this place. What a way to get back to balance. The natural scene was an ease for my mind.

Pleasant morning visit.. We got off at Yoyogi station, and walked south along a street until we entered the park from the Northwest entrance - this is a much less crowded entrance and it was an enjoyable stroll through the forest, picking up acorns, to the shrine.Highly recommended attraction.

Go in the right season. For the garden area You will want to go in one of three peak times (none of which we did); spring to see the flowers blossom, late fall to see the colours, or winter in the snow. For the rest of the area it was nice, well maintained massive park. We went on a day that was light rain and it was fun. If it got sunny it would have been nicer with the sun peaking through all the massive trees. The shrine is nice, go in the morning and you will see a prayer service with monks and random people in suits. Souvenir shop was good but I later discovered chop sticks from mount Fuji shops were about half price.

Beautiful park, average shrine. After visiting the shrines in Kyoto, Meji Shrine didn't seem like such a big deal. The only thing worth mentioning is the park that gives you the feeling you're walking around in a forest. Very relaxing!

Serene, tranquil, sacred to the Japanese but overrated by travelers. Very tough to categorize this shrine. It's Shinto, so it's fittingly located amid nature. It's among the most sacred shrines to the Japanese and plays host to many ceremonies during the year. It also reveals its standing to the Japanese as it is a frequently used sight for weddings (I was there on two separate occasions and witnessed two wedding ceremonies and saw family portrait photos being taken for the third). One has to keep in mind that it wasn't designed or built with the expectations of visiting foreigners in mind.That said, judging it as a non-Japanese person, it is as I described. The Torii gates are among the most beautiful I have seen in Japan, the walk through the parks [there's actually two separate parks making up the grounds] is simultaneously cooling (not relevant, however, when the weather does not make "cooling" a plus), calming and refreshing.The arrival at the shrine, however, is a bit anti-climatic (its sacredness aside). The architecture is fairly plain and unadorned (in fairness, it is a memorial shrine dedicated to the deified spirits of Emperor Meiji and his Empress). The courtyard, which is utilized in large numbers by the Japanese for celebrations/ceremonies, is nonetheless empty and a bit sterile in its non-utilized state. There's a feeling of barrenness as you stand there.To those who love parks and nature, this is a definite reprieve. Absent that, judging it not as a spiritual Japanese person would but as someone who looks for beauty, form, spirit, culture, etc., it is fairly non-moving. I'll take a beautiful Japanese garden (wet or dry) or a Temple like Senso-ji over this any day.But it is important to the Japanese and, to that extent, it must be recognized and respected. But there's no requirement to over-value its appeal to a non-follower of either Shintoism or Buddhism.

An Oasis of Serenity. This place is just right around Harajuku so visiting this amidst the Tokyo madness is quite a retreat from it all. It's a long walk from the gate to the temple but we enjoyed the serenity the entire park brings. It's like walking in a forest in the middle of the city. Partake in the cleansing ritual before entering the temple as a sign of respect. Offer a yen and a prayer to make the most out of the visit. We chanced upon a real Japanese bride which definitely was a treat!
A sacred peaceful place. This is a great place to see the real culture of Japan and to get a sense of peace and calmness.... The walk to the shrine is very relaxing!
