Escape the Madness. Take a few hours to escape the madness of Tokyo and visit this beautiful park and temple. This is a great cut through from Harajuku to Shinjuku, allowing you to escape the madness and heat on the streets. As you pass through one of the large wooden torri, listen to the calming rhythmic buzz of the Cicadas as you stroll along the tree covered paths to your destination. Stop off at the shrine and undertake the cleansing ritual, then pass through another large torri and enter the temples central courtyard. Make a small yen offering and leave a prayer. Look at the stunning architecture and sit under the cloistered walkway watching the world pass. This is a beautiful location to visit. It is a working temple set in a beautiful park and some areas are, understandably, off limits to tourists and locals alike and other areas request you avoid photography. However, these small requests do not detract from the experience. On a side note, this place also has fantastic toilet facilities, very clean and modern (just watch out for the odd curious huntsman spider who may scuttle over to see you).

Beautiful place. Fell in love with this place . Loved the stroll inside and it was zen like . The serene peaceful place filled with nature and it was cooling when i went there at 1.30pm . Would love to come back again but with someone special .

The park is great. The temple, not so much.. This temple is in the middle of Yoyogi Park, which is amazing and beautiful. The temple is probably cool, but you cannot really go inside, and you are not allowed to take pictures or video of it even from the outside, so there is not really much to see and do there.

Great scale tori gates and beautiful shrine. It's an easy walk from the Dromy Premium Inn to the Shrine and well worth doing. I particularly liked the wide avenues to walk to the Shrine itself and once there it was well worth the effort.

Quiet slice of serenity right by Harajuku. We spent a few hours just chilling in the quiet of Meiji Jingu. It was totally calming and great for people-watching. It's nestled in a lovely forest, and it's a wonderful bit of traditional Japan in hyper-modern Harajuku.

Definitely Put On Tokyo To-Do List. Stop at Harajuku on the Yamanote line and walked for hours, beautiful gardens and shrine. Has some areas people just lay out on a weekend and relax or bring a picnic. In a big city like Tokyo this is a forest oasis, you feel like you're in the countryside.

Iconic Shrine. This is another must-visit place apart from Sensoji Temple. It's a tranquil and peaceful compound amongst a traditional landscape. Nearest station is Harajuku - a 10mins walk to one of the entrances and another 5 mins walk or so into the main hall.

I love this place!. I love this place. It is so tranquil. Fortunately, I visited early in the morning (6.30 a.m.) so there weren't that many people yet and being there felt like being on retreat. Walking around at a leisurely place took me around 1.5 hours. The disadvantage of going early was that the Treasure Musuem (open only on weekends) and one of the gardens were still closed. They open at 9. Arriving at around 730-8 might just hit the sweet spot. Both require payment of 500 Yen. It is almost right next to the Harajuku station (has another name on the Metro Line) so it is extremely accesible. If I only had one place to go to in Tokyo, I'll definitely go here.

A must go place. I really love Meiji Jingu! I would stop by this place for at lease an hour every time I go to tokyo, no matter how packed my schedule is. Peaceful, refreshing, and helps clear up one's mind. Highly recommended!

Tranquil and a great walk around. The Meiji Shrine is one of the biggest and most famous in Tokyo and we had a brilliant time strolling through its tranquil gardens before arriving at the shrine itself. There are a few tours that go around and we briefly tagged on the back of one of them and learnt a bit about the shrine. There's not a great deal of signs about the history of the shrine otherwise. We found ourselves copying a lot of what the local people were doing including washing your hands before entering the shrine and how to bow before it.It's enclosed in a beautiful set of gardens and there's clear maps so they're easy to get around. It's a great way to spend a few hours.

Calmness amidst the hustle. Tokyo being so hustle and bustle...this temple afford some calmess...which is itself a therapeutic experience one must engage in while in Tokyo...the entrance leading towards the main temple deliver some beautiful walk in the park...while the temple's architecture itself is quite a sight to behold...Not many temple in Tokyo can afford such an experience unlike in Kyoto...Take a breather from busy Tokyo and you will be surprise...My opinion is to visit during the weekday...and give yourself more space for adventure....within this beautiful Japanese labyrinth..

Lovely stroll to a beautiful temple. It was hot in early September, and this shrine was the perfect spot to go next. The walk was peaceful and quiet, with lovely gardens all around. The signs on the way explained the (few) things on the path, and the temple itself was serene. As Tomo A said, this is located right at harajuku, and near shibuya and shinjuku so this is a perfect spot to visit between the other fast-paced neighborhoods. With respect to the other travelers who said the walk is long and hot, I would call this a flat, short walk (1/2 mile -ish) and all in the shade. Not to be missed.

Serene and peaceful. Enjoyed the serene long and straight pathway to the temple, a very zen like experience unlike in regular gardens. The gravel path makes it a little hard for those with kids and strollers. Overall a great place to visit in tokyo. I recommend visiting on a walking tour between shinjuku-harajuku-shibuya as this temple borders those areas.

A must see when you're in Tokyo. If you're in Tokyo and interested in more than just the big city life, you really should head over here. Hidden in amongst the high rise buildings is this enormous shrine dedicated to the country's favourite Emperor. Definitely lets you get to grips with the spiritual culture of Japan which is so different to that of the West.

Peace and Quiet. Visiting the shrine was quite the experience, as it provides you the peace and quiet that constantly avoids most people with their busy schedules. The amazing thing about the serenity was that the shrine is located in Shibuya, which is just full of life and vibrancy! The shrine was beautifully constructed and a popular spot for weddings, so keep an eye out for that (we happened to see three!) I recommend this spot to anyone visiting Tokyo and they will definitely appreciate the peace and quiet that Meiji Jingu exudes.
Nice and peaceful. Nice to walk into the park and there is a temple there which is visited by Emperor and Empress. U also learn how japanese people pray there.

Quintessentially Japan. We visited the temple on a cool spring afternoon. In fact it was our first of many temples in Japan. I remember vividly how beautiful it was, with its green roof, lining lantern against the gloomy sky. Some unforgettable experience can be had here. Come on the weekend like we did, you might find a traditional Japanese wedding in progress. They don't mind if you stand and watch or take photos as long as you keep respectful distance. Do get a wood piece from the temple office and write your hopes, dreams and wishes on it and hang it on the wishing board. It's also very interesting to see what people wish for. It's really touching to read some of the many hopes and dreams from people from all walks of life, circumstances and nationalities. You will never forget your visit here. I hope you enjoy it as much as we did. :)

Gorgeous Walk and so Peaceful.. I started my morning there early and it is located so close to great shopping. Such a peaceful and relaxing space dropped in the hustle and bustle in the city .Being A new Yorker, I truly appreciated this amazing park and space.a must see, and you can easily do this in two hours if pressed for time.

One of the better shrines in Tokyo. We were lucky when we visiting Meiji Jingu. We were able to witness a wedding ceremony (maybe it was an act?), where participants were dressed up with religious garments.It's a large area with several entrances. However, getting to the actual shrine itself isn't easy. It's in the center of a park or area with large trees. I think we got lost several times.
Place of tranquility in busy Tokyo. Beautiful park to walk though on the way to the Temple. Couldn't go inside the Temple itself but its still a great experience and a lovely place for some peace.

Go on a weekday!. This is my second time at Meiji Jingu! Last year i went, it was on a weekend. Ended up, there was a wedding. And there wasnt anyway i am able to get any omamori back or make any wishes.If you wish to have some time alone, take the trek alone. You will feel peaceful and the trees act as a very good shade from the sun too!Get your amulets and pray! But its a totally different area from the bustling Harajuku. Its peaceful and really, been in tokyo, the busy life and shopping, its time to take a break, relax and enjoy the serenity and calm.

Beautiful shrine in heart of Tokyo. This was on our to do list for sights in Tokyo and it did not disappoint. Its just a few mins walk from Meiji jingumae station on Chiyoda line. The walk to the shrine is very nice and the actual shrine itself is very serene. The shrine itself is probably a wedding venue since we saw a japanese couple getting married inside the shrine premises.

Tranquil. This temple was such a beautiful and relaxing place. There are areas around the centre of the temple were you can sit and take in your surroundings. The walk to the temple is very soothing and peaceful. It's very easy to forget you are in the heart of a city when walking through the tall trees.

A vast park right beside Harajuku. Just steps from the bustling Harajuku is the huge Meiji Jingu park, with beautiful huge trees making the stroll very scrnic and peaceful. Inside you'll find the Meiji temple which is also quite interesting.

A forest of tranquility in the middle of Tokyo. This was possibly my favorite place during my short stay in Tokyo. So much so I went back a few times. I found it brought peace to the chaos of the city, not only because it is effectively a forest in the middle of Tokyo (shade!) also the shrine and its rituals brought peace in my head. Just forget being a tourist and your photos, sit at the side and let the stillness come over you.It's a must visit. Go early and stay ahead of the crowds (although every time it was there it was never too crowded).

quite lovely place. The scenery is lovely, especially when you think that you are in a big megapolis. It nice that Japanese people are so close to the nature. We bough Japanese tea there which is not so unusual for not Asian people. There was an elderly lady who had a big sack of Meiji tea, she gave us a cup to try. it cost us 600 yen but the package was big.

Calm in bustling Tokyo. This is a large green area within West side of Tokyo, about 15 min walk from Shinjuku area (if you don't want to bother taking 2 stations to Harajuku). An important cultural and historical landmark of Tokyo. The shades from the tall trees keep us from the heat in middle of August.

A peaceful oasis in the heart of a city. Yoyogi is a beautiful and peaceful oasis at the heart of the city. I started my journey here to visit the Meiji Jingu Shrine which is located about 10 minute walk from the entrance of the park - in the centre. Depending how quick you walk. In any case, if you are a fan of photography this is a pretty place to take some nice shots of beautiful trees, lamps, japanese carpentry and of the sort. The temple itself (as always) is beautiful. You can pray (which i did) or just respect and appreciate the beliefs of the people who do. Its a tranquil place and you may even spot some monks passing by. There are little shops located on either side of the temple for souvenirs. i purchased a nice pair of beads for meditation and a small wooden model of part of the temple. Pricing is respectable. There are bathroom facilities located throughout the park and they are superbly clean!! There is also a bigger shop for souvenirs and a cafe with "ice cold" airconditioning if you want to get out of the sun. A good way to take a break :).id definitely recommend this place as a starter to your tour
Peaceful Place. Surrounded by trees. Quiet and peaceful. The weather is hot and humid. Advised bring water and umbrella with you. It is quite a long walk so walking shoes will be the best.

Pleasant walk to remember. Initially I was disappointed how far the shrine seems from the entrance but it was cool in Spring so the air was really fresh and the walk refreshing. I would encourage you to visit the park on weekends as you might witness traditional Japan wedding taking place. I bought a lot of Omamori as souvenirs but I think the ones in Meiji Shrine is relatively more expensive although not necessary the prettiest. Ask for the english "menu" where there is explanation what are the various omamori for. 90 minutes should be sufficient for this visit.

A jungle in the city.. Only thing missing is some wild animals here and there. I have to say that I didn't expect to enjoy this trip very much. Coming to Jaoan in August is not recommended at all by the way :) was the only opening time for me. Anyway, make sure to bring your water with you, they don't have any vending machines there. So, it's a very lovely place you get to walk through some very beautiful and quite scenery until you reach the actual shrine. It's a long walk so prepare yourself. I had my wife and 7 years old daughter with me and we all enjoyed it very much.

A world away from wild Harajuku. Meiji Jingu is such a totally different world than the hustle and bustle only a few meters away in Harajuku. I believe it is a remarkable testimonial to the city planners of Tokyo in the old days that they were able to construct such a peaceful haven and to the commitment of present-day administrators to maintain this oasis in the heart of one of the most famous and busy areas in the capital.You feel transported back in time once you go through the main wooden gate. The considerably long walk to the main shrine gives you the chance to enjoy the peaceful surroundings, green trees and reflect on your day. When I got to the shrine, there were several elderly Japanese gentlemen paying their respects, an image I thought to be most memorable. There were also a fair number of younger people similarly paying respects or admiring the centuries-old architecture. Don't go there expecting many shops like Sensoji or grand, towering structures. The shrine is a bit more subdued but elegant in its own way.Good walking shoes are recommended owing to the walking distance. Also allow a fair amount of time to appreciate this important site in its entirety.

Worth multiple visits. Worth multiple visits - in different seasons. I have been here several times over the years and my wife who is a native and I always find something new. Best early when there are fewer people.

Lots of Culture. It was a very hot day, so I recommend you bring an umbrella to shield yourself from the sun. We were part of a tour and our guide was very good at giving us the history behind this place. It is a sacred place to Buddhists and we were not allowed to take pictures once we reached the top of the steps. This was to show respect for the shrine. We enjoyed visiting this place.
serenity just next to the busy Harajuku area. You can feel here serenity in the woods in the center of the big city.Go before 8 a.m. if you want to avoid crowds.and appreciate here most.

Peaceful. Very quiet and peaceful compared to sensoji. No shopping stalls inside. Take the harajuku station. After seeing the shrine, you can walk around harajuku. Try not go August in Tokyo. It was so hot and humid.

Beauty and Serenity!. First of all the entrance to this shrine is located very near Harajuku train station and is easy to find from there.The shrine itself is located in Yoyogi Park and is extremely serene.It is a beautiful area made up of picturesque gardens and various temples and shrines.Expect to see alot of traditional Japanese weddings taking place there on the weekend which is a real treat.This place is also an area which is very much frequented on New Years eve as there is a 3 hour wait to walk through to the main temple and pray for good luck and fortune for the year to come.There is also a non-profit organization called: HIBIKI which runs free guided tours of the shrine by English speaking guides twice every month.This is an awesome facility that allows you to learn far more than you could otherwise on your own.Their website is: http://www.npohibiki.com and email address is: info@npohibiki.comNot only is this place worth a visit on it's own but in the surrounding area there is also Yoyogi Park and Harajuku to visit which are also magic.
Lovely Shrine. very pretty shrine, easy walk from harajuku station, lots of signs were in English which was very useful

Suprisingly calm. Finding this quiet spot in the heart of a bustling mega city like Tokyo was a major surprise. The park is peaceful and the shrine is very beautiful. After spending couple of days getting squished in fast paced life of Tokyo, finding this sanctuary was a major relief.Museums nearby are interesting places to visit too

just another shrine. this shrine is just another shrine and has nothing special to offer. The architecture is mediocre, the garden is uninspired and it's just a waste of time. If you want to see cultural relics than leve Tokyo and go to Kyoto

Peaceful in the middle of a metropolis, we loved it. We loved the walk through the park to the shrine and the tranquility we found upon arriving made the place seem even more magical.We went quite late (430pm), when some of the attractions around the shrine were already closing, as a result of which is was much more peaceful inside the shrine too. It really is an oasis of quiet and that makes the shrine more amazing.It is not very old but that doesn't make it less worthwhile visiting. We walked around, soaked up the atmosphere and took some great pictures. You can buy little wooden wish boards for 500 yen and write a message, which you can place on a large wall of such wooden boards as a prayer/wish - very nice!Overall, a must see when visiting Tokyo in my opinion!

Really beautiful Shrine in Yoyogi Park. Amazing park, screeches by the summer cicadas ringing through the park. Gives a good retreat from the bustling Tokyo metropolis, especially the Harajuku area around it. Very accessible via metro. Great quiet shade from the summer heat. Nice museum and resthouses along the way. Highly recommend anyone visiting Tokyo to take some time out to see the shrine.
great historic spot. beautiful construction and place, can't miss if you are in yoyogi park. wash your hands in the fountain to purify

Listen to the whispering of the nature. A place of refreshment in the heart of Tokyo. You don't need to be a shintoist, but just walk into the premises and you may have a moment of communion with the nature.

Truly fine oasis of Zen in Tokyo. Not so much just a shrine as a whole park and a large temple complex. Spend 15 minutes walking from the gate to the temple, and take in the spacious courtyard and watch the devout making their offerings and prayers by the sanctuary.A family attraction as well as a religious one: we were lucky enough to observe a Shinto wedding during our visit (not as rare as you might think - it's a popular venue) and see two families dressed in traditional costume braving the winter chill. Somehow made it very special, very much a part of the community fabric.

Time stands still at Meiji Jingu. Time stands still at Meiji Jingu. Once you are inside the compound, you experience the serenity of a wonderful shrine. You can imagine it to be 1713 (instead of 2013)....this is very close to how visiting a shrine experience would be, 300 years back. Recommend it to anyone interested in Japanese culture. Go in the morning and beat the crowd.

If you have been to other historic/religious places in Japan, skip this - If not, its a great shrine to check out. I have been to Kyoto several times so I have seen plenty of temples and shrines. I visited Meiji because it is so famous, but it was nothing spectacular given that I've seen so many. I would suggest spending your time somewhere else in Tokyo if you have experienced plenty of shrines - if you haven't, this is a great shrine to start with.
Beautiful and huge. This place is very beautiful and impressive, the main shrine located in the middle of a small forest. Was worth going there

Old Style Japan. This place is dedicated to the late 19th Century emperor who opened Japan the the west. Here you will find the most famous shrine. A great place for a casual stroll where you can breath in all the positive energy. Here also you can get a glimpse of a couples in traditional wedding attire ie kimono and hood for the women and groom in a black formal robe. Great place to appreciate Japanese history. Good place to get away from the hustle and bustle.

Prestine atmosphere. The reason I liked it so much because it presents the old, original japan that I was looking for. The park is real nice and you can feel the tradition in the shrine area eventhough it was rebuilt. You almost certainly will see a traditional wedding. Well worth the visit because it is free!
beautiful place!. This place was gigantic, a very nice place to stroll on a Sunday. We even witnessed a traditional Japanese wedding. A must-visit when in Tokyo!

Tranquil. I can just imagine how nice this place would be if you visited it when there's no one around. On the day I went, there were throngs of people pushing each other around for photo ops. Nevertheless, this is a scenic place and there was also a real wedding going on at the time I was there, so all in all it was a good visit. Ensure you walk all the way in! The temple and shrine is quite a walk inside.

Nice escape from the psychedelic amount of people. It's hard to believe you're still in tokyo here. Beautiful trees and gardens. Go take a picture of the fountain with your phone, brings you good luck.
Very scenic. Beautiful tree lined path leading to the shrine. We went on the weekend and it was packed, however it was still beautiful. We were also lucky to catch a glimpse of a traditional bride.

Look for a free tour guide!. Meiji Shrine is revered by Japanese. We went on a Sunday and was pleasantly surprised to find a group of volunteer guides who will walk with you from the gates to the main shrine, explaining to you the history and little-known facts about the place. Our guide Ken-San spoke good English and at the end of the tour refused to even accept some tips. "Tokyo is an expensive place to visit," he says.

Scenic location, nice walk.. Be prepared for a LONG walk, from the wooden gates to the shrine. A nice tranquil area, and once you have visited the shrine, there are great shops in the Meijijingu-mae railway station. The area is packed with teenage kids on weekends.

The best serenity place. No place is like this shrine, it does help me a lot when I felt stress, I do like this place very much.The best serenity place ever, where you can find your inner place and relaxing your mind and should. Definitely , recommend this place.

Relaxing Shrine. We have been to a number of different shrines before we got to the Meiji JinguWe just simply walked over after we finished visiting the Takeshita Dori. Though street performers were not allowed in front of the shrine, we saw one American street magician and a very talented Japanese independent singer. The Meiji Jingu is a big and leisure park, so it was perfect for us to wind down after the busy Takeshita Dori. We enjoyed the slow pace walking through the park. You should spare 1-2 hours for your visit.By the time we finished, the park was about to come to it's closing time (5 or 6 pm, i forgot)soothing.....

If you're in the area, check it out.. I wouldn't recommend traveling too far just to check this one out, but chances are that if you're visiting Tokyo, you'll be nearby. If you have the time, I do recommend taking a quick walk through. There's no fee, but if you've been to Kyoto and many other famous temples, it's not going to stun you or anything. It's right next to Yoyogi park, so head to a conbini, grab a beer (regular or non-alcoholic) and take a long walk through both. Sunday afternoon is the best time if you can make it.

Nice standard site to start your experience.. Large shrine in a wooded area right in Tokyo. Made for a former emperor and his wife, so a good basic start to your Japanese education. Nice restaurant/gift shop/WC area.

A beautiful, tranquil respite in the heart of Tokyo. This is one of my favorite places to go in Tokyo when I want to get out of the heat and the crowds. The quite lanes leading to the Meiji Jingu shrine are very peaceful and the scenery lovely. There is frequently something happening at the temple - this time it was a traditional wedding ceremony which was fascinating to observe.

favourite place in tokyo. the meiji shrine is the most popular shinto shrine in tokyo for good reason. it's large estate and 100 year old tree provides a state of calm and oneness with nature favoured in the shinto religion. the walk to the shrine through a wooded path in itself is a trip worth having. the shrine is mostly unpainted allowing the natural wood texture of the shrine to meld with surroundings. with its green roof it kinda looks like a big old tree itself. the omamori or good lucks have the nicest designs in my opinions are a great yet inexpensive gifts for family and friends. a stark contrast to the wild and artificial appearance of harajuku. also its right in front of the train station. i do recommend going to side routes and seeing the gardens especially during iris season

Interesting place. I quite enjoyed the Meiji Shrine myself, unlike anywhere else in Tokyo, it's quiet and there wasn't a throng of people in every direction one can see. It was also a rather refreshing walk to the shrine itself. There also seemed to be a wedding going on at the time I was. My friend said weddings there actually seem rather frequent as he witnessed one during all three visits he has been there.

Huge and Green. It's amazing found a place like in a big city. It's a really huge place, feels like entering the forest once you step in a gate. I didnt visit every spot, because I think the big shrine is enough. there, I saw the traditional wedding ceremony, so lucky

Fav place. It's a must see. You don't want to miss it. It's a gorgeous garden with an impressive temple. In the early morning is very peaceful. The details are amazing. So far it's one of my fav places in Tokyo.

Great get away from bustle. A wonderful and free attraction. You can walk the grounds, observe the shrine and then hang our in Harajuku. The trees are mature, the grounds are vast and the din of urban like is near silenced in the park. It doesn't take too long and it's on they way to so many things.

Wonderful walking attraction, deep in a quiet park. I'm not going to say this shrine is as atmospheric as Asakusa, but its completely different in the fact its set in the centre of a quiet park rather than in urban Tokyo. It is quite a walk to get to it from either of the stations, but its so worth it! You walk down a huge lined path in a dead straight line its just beautiful. When you arrive at the attraction there is a lot of wooden gates, and it is fairly spread out. One word of warning, they don't like you taking photos of the ceremonial area, I got told off! Its fairly quick to get around but there is some beautiful artwork/architecture to admire. On your way out there is a wonderful garden to explore (costs extra) with a fountain which is suppost to have unique water, I will write about this in a separate review as it was one of the most spiritual experiences I had ever had anywhere in the world, i still cant explain it! Overall put it on your list of to-do's in Tokyo!
Wonderful place to walk around. We really enjoyed it here - many things to look at. Make sure you take a coat as it gets quiet cold inside. Toliets around as well.

Where are the birds?. where are the birds. A forest full of ancient trees, with a beautiful temple, which is reached through huge portals made ​​of giant trunks, full of people and tourists, but empty of worshipers. Nor hear or see birds with the exception of crows. Rare in such forest

Quiet haven. We loved learning about the Shinto culture, the simplicity of nature, our guide was Shinto so we saw this lovely place through her eyes.We also saw two traditional weddings, comin from the temple and we were able to take many photos of the traditional headrest and clothes of bride and groom, we had them explained to us before, so understood the significance.

If you're looking for a peaceful stroll in Tokyo.... While it's turned into a tourist hotspot, the walk to the shrine is quite peaceful, and is quite a majestic sight in itself. If you're in the Harajuku area and want some quiet time away from the city crowds and noise, I recommend it.

If you are stuck in Tokyo you might as well go here. Its nice but not amazing. There is not really much to see in Tokyo so I guess go here. If you are stuck in Tokyo you might as well go here. Its a decent walk in a park

Really beautiful temple. We went here a little too late. It was 18.15 and the temple closed at 18.30. However - we were almost alone and could really feel the peace and the silence. I would suggest you get here at least one hour before they close.Much less crowded than the Asakusa temple and in my opinion - more beautiful since it's more of a hidden gem than an outstanding temple.

If you're in Tokyo, don't miss this. Very beautiful park like setting in the middle of Tokyo. The shrine itself is beautiful. If you go on a Sunday morning, you will also be treated to tiny little Japanese girls, 2 to 4 years old, dressed like little porcelain dolls. Completely charming.

The iris garden. I loved the iris garden, beautiful irises of various colours winding along a stream. It was a spectacular sight. I went on a Saturday so it was rather busy, and there were queues at some of the best vantage points. Still, I enjoyed it.The shrine itself is interesting enough, but doesn't compare with the shrines and temples in Kyoto. I was lucky enough to see one bridal couple in traditional dress, which I considered a bonus.

Beautiful respite in the middle of a big city. The grand tree-lined corridor of entry to the Shrine itself is a wonderful thing. A leisurely stroll in what feels like being out in the Japanese country is only interuppted by the occasional siren. Sure there are lots of tourists but it never feels crowded like the temples of Kyoto. This is truly a gem in the big city of Tokyo. The Shrine reflects the simple and natural purity of Shintoism with natural wood construction - none of the gaudy red and golds that adorn temples in Asakusa or Nikko. Just all a very serene experience.

A Spectacle During the Holidays. The grounds to this shrine are expansive and connected to Yoyogi Park. Both of these places are a great place to let the kids run around. Of course, in close proximity to the shrine, respect should be maintained. I was able to visit this shrine on shichi-go-san day (7-5-3) which celebrates children coming of a certain age. The kids were dressed in beautiful kimonos and yukatas while being paraded about before being blessed by a Shinto priest. A fascinating site with rich history. A time to avoid, or a time to go if you are adventurous, is the first week of the new year. This shrine will hose 3,000,000 people during the first five days fo the New Year, so expect extreme crowd and long lines. I have done it, it was very fun, but I won't do it again during that time of year. There are several shops and places to take a rest or enjoy additional entertainment that is often held at this shrine.

Such a beautiful park and the shrine the jewel within!. Located right in the middle of one of Tokyo`s most popular areas is an amazing urban oasis. Meiji Jingu is one of the most serene and peaceful places you can find in the busy city of Tokyo. The serenity comes from the location. The complex is located in middle of a huge forest, with some of the trees being 35 meters high – they thoroughly block out external sounds.

If you can not go to Kyoto .. this is fine. It is a beautiful garden (park) well kept with a large shrine and a museum inside. It is nice to give you a small sense of what is the great temples and castles of Kyoto. I went at around 7 am and at 9 am I saw many interesting priest's activities, including a Japanese drum solo and a blessing ceremony. For enter in the garden and the museum you may pay Y$500 for each.

Peaceful Park and Shrine. It was a peaceful park especially early in the morning. Make sure you arrive before 9 to avoid the crowds. I went there on a Sunday and visited the shrine. There was a traditional wedding there, and it was great to see the bride wearing traditional dress. The park also has a lot of huge trees. It will not take too long to walk around the park and the shrine. After visiting the park, you can go to Hirujuku and Shibuya. It will be a good route if you enjoy walking.

Sunday visit is fun. On sundays , there is a huge possibilty of you getting to watch a wedding procession ... very beautiful to stroll around and gorgeous tori gate too ... on sundays , english guides are available for free !!!!

One of the more peaceful tranquil shrines. We visited here from a Shibuya shopping trip. It's only a short walk to Harajuku. Right by the shrine is a very large park with beautiful water features which is well worth a stroll through on a sunny day. The shrine itself is very tranquil and if you get the timing right (late after noon, early evening before closing seems best) you can get the place almost to yourself. Compared to other Tokyo shrines which are all very touristy, this one is more pure. It's certainly not as elegant as some, but also not too overpowering.The shrine is dedicated to the emperor Meiji and his empress Shoken. The shrine was built in 1920. There are also two museums here, the 'Treasure' museum contains general items used at the time as well as a horse carriage. There is also an annex which contains various exhibitions depending on the time.Do pick up the free guide at the entrance. A great place outside all the hustle and bustle on a sunny afternoon.

a nice stroll to a relatively austere temple. the Emperor Meiji etc may well be very respected but do not get excited about the temple itself - there is little to see (and you are not supposed to take photos of the actual inner sanctum). It is likely much more interesting if you see a Shinto wedding procession which I did - on a Saturday - or couples done up in traditional gear for their photos.

Beautiful and Tranquil. A long, quiet path takes you up to the main shrine. Towering trees surround the area providing a tranquil atmosphere. Traditional Japanese architecture but built in the 20th century. The 40-foot high torii gate which marks the entrance to the shrine grounds is impressive.

Peaceful. Took a walk through the temple and unexpectedly ended up with several tour guides. There was a group of English majors that needed to practice their conversation skills and offered to show us around. The shrine is very peaceful and go break from the city.
Meiji Shrine. Beautifully preserved grounds and buildings. Peaceful and relaxing in the heart of Harajuku! Glad I made time to visit.

A tranquil temple in the heart of the city.. Take a break from the hustle and bustle of Omotensando and Harajuku with a nice leisurely walk to Meiji Jingu. The surrounding forest takes you to a serene and calm state of mind, just a few steps from the major tourist shopping area. When the season is right, there is a garden of irises and a "power spot/historic water well" before reaching the main temple. There is also a cafe at the entrance of the temple gate, if you would like to rest your legs and have a cup of tea or snack.
Nice to visit on a hot day. Nice place to visit on a hot day as it is situated within a leafy park. Don't know much about Japanese history but thought the shrine was a nice place to visit.

Peaceful Shrine, Post Your Prayers. Meiji Jingu was built starting in 1920 and commemorates Emperor Meiji who died in 1912 and his Empress. It's a very peaceful place, good for long walks. There are wonderful Torii gates and a large garden with trees from all over Japan. I saw a number of Shinto weddings taking place at the shrine, quite impressive with the costumes worn by the couple, Shinto priests, and procession. For 500 yen you can write your wishes on a wooden plaque, hang it around a holy tree, and have the priests bless it. A must do inTokyo. A bit of a walk down a tree lined path. Just make a right as you exit the Meiji-Jingumae station and cross the bridge over the railway. The nearby Omotesando-Dori road is the Champ Elysees of Tokyo with stores by every major designer.

Very beautiful, a wonderful place to see. If you like shrines, this is one of the best. If you're in Tokyo, but also want to do some cultural activities this is a perfect place to see. This was one of my favorite places on our recent Japan trip.There's a nice walk from the gate to the shrine with a rest stop for snacks and such. You can make a day out if it and also check out Yoyogi park and the Harajuku shopping scene.

Best on weekends. It's best to visit it on weekend. The premises are huge, even when crowdy you can' t reall feel it, it' s vast enough, nice shrines, well done park, nice ponds, neat walkways underneath shadows of old, tall trees, nice restaurant and gift shop, perfect place for weddings and family excursions. Historical side, take your children to see the Tokyo riding school as well. Visit treaure museum is optional, if you are nit a big fan you can easily skip that, main shrine building however it' s a must. Beautiful place for picknicks as well, bring your children, they will love it. Very nice.

A well balanced spot in the town. Located just opposite of hustle bustle Harajuku street, this shrine is definitely a break from all the chaos nearby. Went on Sunday, because we wanted to see those cos-players around Harajuku station. We were so lucky that two Japanese guys volunteered themselves because they wanted to practice their English language. One of the wood of the big gate in front of the park that leads to the shrine was actually replaced from Taiwan due to breakage few years back. Also note that you have to walk by the side of the path road, because based on the Japanese belief, the center pathway is solemnly for their Gods. The path itself offers a relaxing walk towards the shrine. The Japanese come here usually to make a prayer and wishes. They will normally pray in front of the opened space of the shrine. You can do that too, just observe how do they do it, and also a 5 Yen coin in your hand. Definitely worth a visit!

Relaxing cultural walk. Meiji Jingu offers good photo oportunity and a relaxing walking through the peacefull path in the middle of Tokyo.İt is a good experiance,very close to Harajuku station.I visited there at noon and had a chance to see a traditional wedding.İt was such a good cultural experiance.

Peace in the centre of Tokyo. I really enjoyed taking an hour out in the peace and sunshine, a beautiful walk through the woodland and a beautiful place to enjoy some time away from the Tokyo streets.....well worth it, easy to get to by metro, also saw a traditional wedding which added to the experience

beautiful park, nice place to walk. Hidden in a dense park just right next to the happening Harajuku. Interesting place to observe the religious practices and a Japanese wedding. A place worthwhile to visit while in Tokyo. The park is amazing and beautiful in an early winter morning. Start a day in Tokyo by getting some calm and serenity in the shrine/park before embarking on vibrant trips to some of Tokyo's liveliest areas such as the Shibuya crossing with the Hachiko statue. Visiting this shrine should be among the top list of a Tokyo experience.

An island of green in the middle of a metropolis. Good place to come to if you're looking for peace and quiet. Lovely grounds, nice places to wander, and a beautiful temple to visit. The "new green" leaves were particularly beautiful in the spring season.
A Must-See In Tokyo. Visiting the Meiji shrine is one must-see tourist site that inspires. It's amazing that such a peaceful park is right in the heart of Tokyo.

Meiji Shine -- Indulge in History. I’m not one to be dumbfounded by a religious venue and I certainly didn't know what to expect when visiting the Meiji Shrine. It was extremely beautiful and very captivating to see the locals come and do their prays. Tourist can even take part in the water washing at the entrance of the shrine and then write their prays to the Japanese Deities.My partner and I were pretty much in awe from our walk from the hotel all the way to the Meiji Shine -- keep in mind we couldn't figure out how to use the train yet so we walked the entire day. The Meiji Shine was absolutely beautiful. Seeing the locals do their prays was mesmerizing. Of course, we took part in it ourselves just for the experience and just mimicked everything this local elder gentleman did (i'm sure we freaked him out). Every time he sipped water, we sipped water. Great, great, great experience!

Respite from Tokyo. Engulfed by a park so dense it is almost forest like, Meiji shrine provides respite from the busyness of Tokyo. When you walk out of the park and back into Harajuku you'll remain amazed that this spot of tranquility exists so close to such vibrancy.

The best shrine in Tokyo in beautiful surroundings. The shrine is located in Yoyogi Park, just outside of the Harajuku train station (Yoyogi station-Odeo line). Once you enter the park you greeted by a huge Torii gate. It has to be at least 40 feet tall with very thick legs. A little further down are large, decorated barrels of sake for the New Year's celebration. The park is very peaceful even when busy and is very large. You can wander for hours here! The shrine is in the middle of the park and is quite large. It is an active shrine, and you will likely see traditional weddings taking place as we did. You are welcome to purchase offerings and post them as many visitors do. The most common offering is a small wooden plaque that you write prayers or wishes on, then hang on the structure with the others...you can't miss it. Respectful behavior is necessary, but you are welcome to wander around and take plenty of pictures. There are public toilets throughout the park, as well as food and museums (Meiji Treasure House/Annex-recommended). At the upper end of the park, near the museum, are some lakes with plenty of turtles, birds, and large koi meandering around.Do check ahead of time for the park/museum/shrine operating hours, as certain days/hours of the week they are closed. Many places in Japan are like that anyway, so it's a good idea to plan ahead!
Great Shrine in the Heart of Tokyo. This is one of the best shrines in Tokyo. If you go there on weekends/holidays, there is a good chance of witnessing a traditional Japanese wedding.

A Shinto Shrine in Tokyo. Probably it's Tokyo most important Shinto Shrine. You enter by a huge torii Gate and on the side of the gravel road there are hundreds of colorful sake barrels and wine casks as offerings to the Shrine. The Shrine itself it's very nice and we witnessed a Shinto wedding and a procession of Shinto monks and temple maidens.

Very peaceful. When we visited the shrine on Sunday, we were lucky to have witnessed two weddings taking place. What a wonderful sight!
The shrine itself was vast and beautiful. Many great trees and different plants everywhere.

Tranquil oasis in the city. The Meiji Jingu is located on 175 acres of landscaped ground, Yoyogi Park. The memorial Shinto temple is dedicated to the Emperor Meiji and his wife, Empress Shoken. Building began after their deaths. The first iteration was completed in 1921, but was destroyed in the air raids of WWII. The present iteration was finished in 1958.The temple walk begins through large torii gates built from single cypress trunks. Throughout the grounds and the temples, there are trees which have been gifted by the Japanese people and other countries. The large evergreen trees give a lot of shade, and provides relaxing sounds and smells throughout the walk. Large barrels of saki are placed near the entrance as well, representing saki from around Japan. The temple has several buildings and is in traditional Shinto style. There is a purification well and a wall of prayers left by visitors. Priests and nuns dress in traditional Shinto garb. Photographs of the staff are forbidden. The shrine is a popular place for weddings. We saw a wedding there in traditional Shinto costume, in blush pink and dark navy colors, beautiful and somber. Apparently there is a sports stadium in the outer temple. There is a small ice cream shop just outside the gates, selling interesting soft serve ice cream with flavors like wasabi, taro, sweet red bean.

Peaceful area in the middle of Tokyo. This temple was surrounded by Yoyogi Park, a large woodland-type area near Harajuku Station. While I felt the temple itself wasn't anything amazing, the overall peaceful ambiance is something worth checking out, especially to get away from the congestion of Tokyo and the subway stations. The torii gate at the entrance is quite impressive; reportedly the largest in Japan. It's quite a walk TO the temple, but the area is peaceful and beautiful; the gravel path is enshrouded with huge trees and lots of shade. The barrels of Sake at the beginning of the temple area also make for some nice, colorful photos. We were fortunate enough to witness a wedding party posing for pictures at the temple in traditional Japanese wedding clothes. Like most temples we saw, this one also included the purification fountain and wish/prayer board.

Serene and Well Kept. This is a great way to start a day in Japan. We got there early and the fresh air and large open walkways through the trees really woke us up. The gates and lanterns along the way to the shrine are large but simplistic in a beautiful way. The main shrine area is a beautiful display of classic architecture and we were lucky enough to catch a classical Japanese wedding coming through. There are informational pamphlets and maps for free that help you navigate the grounds as well.

Serene. A lovely walk to a Shinto shrine. Along the way, via the arches you'll see some sake and wine barrels, then the entrance to a garden (entrance fee). Keep walking to the Shrine. Take time to observe / honour the ritual of hand cleansing at the font; make a wish at the main shrine - paper / pens provided. A small brochure is available in English to explain how to do this.Don't rush, take your time to enjoy the peace and serenity. Most visitors are respectively quiet.You may see Weddings - couples in their national wedding dress, with their attendees and guests. Also couples with babes for a blessing.Other museums / attractions in the grounds if you have time or interest.

Worth a visit!. Great place to stroll and even though it was busy, it didn't seem like it because the property is pretty big. Very easy to get to (we walked from Shinjuku, didn't take too long - 20ish minutes). We also walked to Yoyogi Station as it was very busy at the nearest JR. It's free to wander around except for the garden. The garden was nice too.

unbelievable tranquility in the city. We were here during sakura season and it was beautiful. The peace is perfectly balanced to not be deafening but enough to transport you somewhere out of the city. Take your time walking further into the main shrine and next to the far end (I missed this both times I came because of lack of time). If you're lucky, you'll get to see an elaborate Japanese wedding or a ritualistic performance of the priests.This opens at dawn (depends on the month) and closes at dusk (also month-dependent) so it offered a lot of flexibility in our itinerary, as many attractions in Japan open around the late morning and close at around 5 - 6pm.Note: Quite a bit of walking with barely any seats! The elder folks in my group tried to rest their feet by sitting on the stone steps but got 'lectured' and chased away instead.

Quiet and Solemn. There are 3 large arches on the way to the actual shrine. I sneaked a peak of the arch that was at the outermost edge of the area and very near the metro exit and JR. I came back another day to walk into the grounds and visit the temple. There were many people visiting. And families were much quieter than when visiting other "touristy" areas. There were interesting tidbits posted as you walk along the path. There was a Japanese garden that required a 500yen fee for entrance. When I reached the temple, there was a ritual of washing and tourists were encouraged to participate. And inside, there was also a Japanese wedding being photographed.

The place to see weddings. We were lucky to be here during the sakura season and walked through the park to find this. I thought we might be able to enter, but it's just an open space you can look at, unless you are part of a wedding party. There weren't a lot of people here early in the morning, but we saw many kimono clad families attending weddings. As the day got later, it got very crowded. This is a good place on a Sunday to catch a glimpse of Japanese culture. We were very glad to see it and then headed to Yoyogi park just next store.

Very Peaceful. Lovely shrine in the heart of the park. It's a bit of a walk, but the atmosphere with all the huge green tree branches towering over the big path is an amazing feeling. The shrine itself is decent sized, quite busy with people and peaceful. Worth checking out.

Lovely peaceful Shinto Shrine. The Meiji Shrine is dedicated to the Emperor Meiji, the emperor who opened Japan to the rest of the world after the period of isolation under the Tokugawa Shoguns.It is a very peaceful place with lovely gardens. There is also a huge collection of French wine barrels and Sake barrels in memory of the emperor embracing trade with the rest of the world.

Large peaceful shrine in Yoyogi Park. Meiji Jingu Shrine is through a huge, wooden torii gate in Yoyogi park, accessed from just behind Harajuku station. The shrine is one of the most visited Shrines in the whole & Japan & it is easy to see why - it is much more peaceful & serene than a lot of the other shrines I visited in Japan. While in the shrine, we were lucky to see two wedding processions, which were really interesting to watch. As with other temples, there are stalls selling lovely small good luck charms.

A long walk but worth it. It is a long walk from the street to the entrance of Shrine but for me, it was worth it. Not too crowded and I think the people (even tourists) are more respectful and tried to be more quiet in this place compared to Senso-ji. We witness a wedding where the couple with their family walked on the grounds towards the "reception area." It was solemn, the couple tried not to be mindful of the people taking their pictures :) This is adjacent to Yoyogi park which is also a very good place to visit.
Simply Beautiful.. One of my most favourite places in the world, as my fiancé proposed to me here. It's a beautiful place, very serene - it's quite large, so we did lots of walking!

Beautiful shrine. In comparison to Senso-ji temple, this one is quiet, peaceful and serene. It's quite a lot of walking, but the walk is beautiful, outdoors amongst the trees. While at the temple we also saw a christening and several weddings - complete with traditional clothing (white hoods, red umbrellas...) - which was a neat cultural experience. Check online ahead of time to make sure you know what's happening the day you plan to go - sometimes there are markets and other ceremonies as well.
Very peaceful in the heart of the city. You walk into the grounds and feel relaxed into seconds. It seemed to take ages to walk there once you enter the grounds but well worth it. We loved the place
beautiful grounds and temple. Go on the weekend to catch some wedding processions, we were there on a Saturday and it was a great photo op! The walk through the grounds to the temple was beautiful.

Peaceful Retreat. Nice visit to a quiet area of Tokyo. Main shrine and walk in the woods is peaceful. Make a prayer at the shrine and leave a wish or thought on a placard or a letter. Good photo op. One-time visit though. Can be seen in an hour. Combine this with a visit to the Harajuku area as they share the same subway station. Guards and signs advise no pictures permitted of interior of main shrine.

Great photo ops. Always nice to visit this shrine. You'll get to see weddings. I was there on the Coming of Age day and not only get to take photos of the lovely girls in Kimonos and it also snowed in Tokyo that day. Makes for a different atmosphere to the photos

Awesome. Being able to go there and walk through the forest, to head towards the Meiji Shrine, is AWESOME to the MAX!!! So much history, so much nature, so calm and relaxing...
It is also one of the top places for weddings!!

The real McCoy. This is what I had been searching for in getting a feeling of Japan past. We went there on our last day in the rain. Absolutely freezing and beautiful. In total contrast to the nearby Takeshita Street for teenager shopping. Serene, colourful foliage and immaculately presneted large open spaces with good English captions. Free except for a small internal garden which was worth the $5 entry fee.So easy to acess. Adjacent to train station. Hint: we got confused on way back as we tried to catch metro but needed the Subway. A local man approached us and set us straight!
Highly recommended. Defniitely worth a quick trip to see. BEautiful forests in the middle of downtown Tokyo with a history lesson built in to boot. Check it out.

Calm in the bustle. I love the contrast of the busy shopping district on the doorstep of this wonderful sanctuary in the middle of such a metropolis. It is a must see part of Tokyo if you are visiting. We always take friends here and I never tire of seeing the grounds, beautiful temple buildings and courtyards. Walk in the main entrance and leave via the side gate near the tree with the wooden prayer boards surrounding it. The path joins back where the giant Tori gate is located. It makes a nice loop for an afternoon wander.

Wooded walk in dappled sunshine with history all around. The Meiji Shrine is an amazing tribute and speaks volumes for the honour and respect for this transforming emperor who brought Japan into the modern era. The walk to the shrine is meandering and allows you to enjoy the birds, trees, and get away from the surrounding hectic city. The shingle paths might challenge some, and the smallest of walking children will need a push chair. There is a side garden within the park to the Emperor and Empress' lodge, fishing lake and gardens - a lovely diversion and gives you a feel for their character and love for each other.A great diversion. Walking up Ometesando afterwards gives you a shocking contrast with its great shopping, and the side streets have superb little restaurants and cafes to catch a meal (try Harajuku Gyoza Lou)

A must see in Tokyo. The Meiji Jingu shrine is a beautiful oasis in the fast-paced city of Tokyo. If you only have a few days to catch the best of the city, be sure to add this to your itinerary. Great architecture, spiritual and serene. On most days, you will be able to witness a traditional Shinto wedding procession in front of the main shrine. Be sure to explore the grounds, including the inner garden (there is a 500yen fee for the gardens, the rest of the grounds are free). Give yourself 2+ hours to fully appreciate the sights.

Surprisingly quiet & beautiful shrine. The property was way bigger then I had enticipated & I made the terrible mistake of wearing heels.... All travellers should be warned in advance not to wear heels in Japan as they often get stuck with stone from the shrines or I between random metal stripes on the roads. The roads are uneven too..but I guess this is how the Japanese like it in its natural form.Ok back to the shrine, the entry was massive (& very long) we just kept walking & walking through the immaculately clean path which was really quite & peaceful (a stark contrary to Harajuku). It's a great place for a morning stroll & strategically located right beside Harajuku station. The shrine was very well maintained & a good place for us to buy some souvenirs. A must visit location for all tourist, it's good to visit the shrine before heading down to Harajuku.

Beautiful place to visit!. A memorable visit on 19th Feb as I admired the beauty of the shrine grounds while battling to stay warm in the freak snowfall that morning. You may be unlucky enough to bump into other noisy tour groups, but the main shrine area here is definitely grander looking and more quiet than the touristy Sensoji in Asakusa. The surrounding forest area is just really quiet, and I would have preferred the natural landscape at other parks like Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden.Do make it a point to visit the Treasure Museum at the other end of the Shrine grounds. The exhibits there provide a very detailed account of the early times of Japan under the reign of Emperor Meiji.

Beautiful. A must go if you're in Tokyo, considering its just a stones throw from the train station at Harajuku. We went for a late morning stroll there en route for shopping and lunch at the Harajuku area.The place is immaculately kept (like most of Japan is!), and I must say the public toilet here is sparkling clean. The gardens and surrounding gardens are isolated from the traffic noises - you almost forget you're in the middle of the city!Great place for a lazy stroll in the park and viewing the shrine itself, which was visited by tourists as well as families there to pray and pay their respects. On Sundays if you can even catch the cosplayers on the bridge (we only saw one, maybe cos it was too cold in the winter for cosplay!) :)The path is gravel and stones, so not wheelchair or stroller friendly FYI.

Relaxing walk. This is a lovely walk in the woods in the middle of Tokyo. Those gates are so high!The path is a little gravelly so I wouldn't recommend high heels (although there were some tottering around in them).Note you have to pay to enter the temple, and there is also a temple garden you have to pay to enter.Would recommend to get some peace and quiet in the middle of the city.

Meiji Shrine must not be missed. In the Yoyogi Park, walk through the enormous gate Ichi No Torii, then head for the Meiji Inner Garden, an utter treat and well worth an hour wandering around, then go to the famous Meiji shrine, in the most beautiful Shinto architecture, set amongst a densely forested park with over 100,000 trees. Calm, serene, and quite delightful. probably my favourite place in Tokyo. An oasis of calm away from the bustle of Harajuku which is on the east side of the park

Pleasant and Interesting. Just the walk in to the shrine was refreshing in itself. We took our time to notice little structures along the route, and soon the absence of traffic noise was noticeable. The attraction wasn't large by any means, but sufficient for a couple of hours visit to a peaceful location.

Japan Trip 2013. First shrine of the trip! Beautiful and scenic walkway within easy access of the train station. For an extra fee you can visit the empress' garden. Highly recommended if you are staying in the Tokyo area or have time to get to if you are elsewhere.

Good place to head to. I was stuck in Tokyo for a day as I couldn't get on the plane and so I decided to head to this shrine. It's located right next to the Harajuku station - when you exit, turn right (instead of beelining for the shopping paradise).The shrine is magnificent, albeit it's a long walk in. There is a cafe at the entrance, a restaurant halfway in and a place to get some souvenirs. The restaurant doesn't accept credit cards by the way. You get to write your wishes on a block, which you have to purchase.

Meiji Jingu amazing. This is an amazingly beautiful shrine. I have been lucky enough to witness two weddings on two of the occasions I have visited this shrine. It is amazing and very special to stand and watch a wedding procession at this temple. I felt like I had been transported back in time. The temple surrounds are very serene and during the summer the gardens are a welcome retreat from the madness of Harajuku. These two places are polar opposites. It is an amazing experience to be caught up in Harajuku on a Sunday when you can hardly move through the crowds and the noise and then to arrive at Meiji Jingu Temple to see the beauty of another era is a treat for the senses.

Great shrine, especially if there is a parade!. I was there for Foundation day and there was a huge parade! so much fun! tons of floats being carried by chanting people who carried them for 2 miles and then to certain head guy and then picked it up as high as possible. There was also a fantastic drum show.Can't actually comment too much on the shrine itself because of the parade taking up all the space.

Tranquil place in a busy city. The shrine and gardens are less than five minutes from the JR Harajuku station. The gardens and approach to the shrine are lovely and the city seems to melt inton the distance. The site might be helped with more introduction and history to the sit in languages other than Japanese as what information is there is limited. We saw a couple of weddings in progress which was a real privilege.

So much history. A large shrine that is a pleasant stroll after the tight and winding streets and alley ways of Harajuku and the surrounding area. The areas of calm within the bustling city of Tokyo make the city one of my favorite places to visit. No matter how busy the place may be, there is always a quiet spot to relax and reflect.

Tranquil escape in the heart of the city. The forest area is beautifully planted and has lovely walks through the trees and to the shrine at its centre. Its so peaceful you wouldn't know you were in the centre of the city.

Beautiful. Lovely place.... Nice walk... Beautiful
A love place to visit a must do if visiting the area,
Lush surroundings beautiful and green
worth visiting. Very nice atmosphere, a place worth visiting! Impressive space and architecture, very pleasant surrounding.

Shinto Weddings Galore!. We so loved our visit to this big park and Shinto temple. We managed to witness three weddings when we were there. A very peaceful place.
Shibuya is such a great place as well. Make sure you visit on the weekend if you can.

Peace & Tranquility. A large and beautiful shrine which is conveniently located near to the Harajuku train station. It is a little different from Sensoji Temple as you experience peace and tranquility at Meiji Shrine whereas Asakusa is more touristy and hustle bustle. There is quite a distance from the main entrance to the shrine thus it is best to wear shoes that has flat soles and to avoid wearing heels because there are plenty of stones around the pavements. Point to note: for those who intend to pay 100yen and draw lots at the shrine and could not understand japanese language, you can actually request for an english version of the lots. the forecast of the lot will also be given to you in english. Hope it helps!

Beautiful and peaceful place. This Shrine with surrounding parkland is a beautiful and peaceful place to wind down from the pace of Tokyo. The grounds are very beautiful and it is a lovely walk, mostly on gravel so avoid heels. A little pre reading on the shrine would be useful as there were queues of locals at various points around the shrine but it is not immediately obvious what it was about. We later found out after doing and organised walking tour in Tokyo that they were queuing to leave prayers, get their fortunes etc. Very interesting hour or so. The Shrine is a short walk from the Harajuku shopping district.

Grand & interesting indeed!. Must-visit the Temple and its surrounding area with beautiful trees. If one has enough time to visit the quiet garden, it is worthwhile but the entrance fee must be paid for. The souvenir shop has plenty of special green & black Meiji teas, and "noren" & "kakejike" or curtains. Just great.

Year of the Snake. Beautiful , peaceful, serene. This is a must see for anyone visiting the Shibuya area. We tour the shrine right before the New Year (avoiding the Millions who visit on New Years). Everything was decorated for the celebration of "The Year of the Snake". Really cool , "old world" Japan, right in the middle of Modern Day Tokyo.

A wonderful, relaxing day in bustling Tokyo. After a week in Kyoto then a week in Habuka playing on frozen fluffy water, Tokyo was to be a few days of hectic crazy city before heading home. But we had made no plans, so with a little research upon arriving, and having enjoyed the multiple shrines and temples of Kyoto, we decided to dedicate one day to the same in Tokyo. What first drew us to Meiji Temple was... Well, CHOCOLATE. Meiji Chocolate is a) delicious, b) ridiculously cheap and c) not on my diet... Anyway, it was at the Temple we learnt for the "love, respect and fondness in the warmest heart in all of glorious Japan that the memory of good Emperor Meiji is held". Well, and we thought he must have made the chocolate... The grounds are just wondrous, veritable forest in the heart of one of the worlds busiest cities, like Hyde or Central Park on other trips, was an absolute treat. Cheerio
Beautiful. Its lovely to sit on a bench there, theres always something going on, you'll have a good chance of seeing a wedding there, and last time I visited there was a bonsai festival^^

Very important place in Japanese culture. I was grown up in Japan when my parents worked there in 1970-s and each time I visit Tokyo now I go this Temple - if You want to feel Japanese Soul and have " a taste" of Japanese life and culture , it's one of the best placec!

Beautiful. This shrine is breathtaking, very quiet and calming. The gardens are very nice and the shrine itself is worth the trip to Tokyo. There is a bit of a trail, so bring good walking shoes, most of the trails are made of gravel. There are some donation boxes to help maintain the gardens.

Meiji Shrine - Great Traditional Site. We went in January, when the shrine had many special banners and other items for the New Year. Centered in a lovely evergreen forest. Enjoyed this oasis of beauty and calm in busy city.

Lots of walking but in a good way. What is there not to like. if you like culture and history, this is the place. it will be quite a walk from the tori gate ( having some physical fitness may help but im a big burly guy who lost his voice was able to endure it) but when you get to the temple its all worth it.

Big walk, free, interesting.. Great to see a bit of old style and nature in the middle of Tokyo. Exit out the Harajuku, Meiji jingu Mae subway station and follow the crowd, or there are maps. Greeted by a massive tori gate, it's quite a walk to the actual shrine.You can enjoy the shade of the trees for the next 10 minutes. Pass by the barrels of sake. There is a fun little ritual to cleanse yourself, with some water, instructions are in English at the place, then you can enter the actual shrine. It's free, it's interesting, it's a nice break from the skyscrapers and traffic. Worth a look if you have a spare hour in Tokyo. :-)

Green lungs in heart of Tokyo. This is a nice bit of wide open space in Tokyo city centre. You feel like you were in some big forest when you walk into the grounds of the Shrine. You will see many locals here with the possibility of seeing some young girls in traditional colourful dress.The shrine itself and the manicured trees is also interesting.

New Years Day Experience. Over 1 million people visit this shrine on New Years Day and this year I was one of them. The crowds are daunting at first but the peacefulness and order of a gathering this large is truly staggering to witness. I would like to return when it is not so crowded to spend time here because the Shrine seemed very interesting but I wouldn't have missed being part of this for anything. An unforgettable experience.

Serenity in the middle of Tokyo. Forget the ostensible temples of Thailand, Meiji is subtle, serene, calm...The garden complex of the temple site is worth a visit just as much as the temple itself - most tourists tend to skip it but it's an all-year-round-treat.Met a japanese photographer who handed me some bird seeds. It seems the birds of the garden are not afraid to eat out of your hand. The small well at the end of the walk is also a sweet site.The temple itself is a functioning one with wedding ceremonies, men and women in traditional japanese garb, people throwing coings, clapping their hands or washing them at the special pavilions at each entry point.Meiji Jingu is a magnificent place to spend a few hours away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. It's a rebirth of the senses.

Maybe this is what they call zen?. The place is calm. Only the sound of water and bird singing. Long walk from subway station, but it's not tiring...Once inside, there are wedding ceremonies. Ladies on traditional kimono. So many colors.

Beautiful shrine in Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is a beautiful, serene shrine right next to Harajuku station, and it was nice to have the juxtaposition of ancient and modern Japan right next to each other. It's worth visiting to see the rows of sake barrels and the beautifully kept shrine itself, which is airy and light. The charms sold here are more expensive than the other temples, but are very pretty. We were also lucky to spot a Japanese bride during our visit - apparently wedding ceremonies are commonly held here. The shrine is just a short walk away from Harajuku and Omotesando, and is definitely worth a visit.

Tranquility & Peace In The Heart of Tokyo. Love the tranquility and peaceful-ness that Meiji Jingu brings admist the bustle and business of Tokyo (Harajuku, Omoetanso) ... Depsite winter season, nice to see lush greenery (the park surrounding the shrine itself) ... Also had the opportunity to witness a Japanese wedding right midst in the compound. A must-visit for 1st timers coming into Tokyo!

Beautiful temple. Personally I find it very weird that there's such a huge temple that resides in the Shibuya and Harujuku area. And what makes me surprised was the air and the peacefulness in this temple. Despite the rest of the whole Tokyo that's busy and polluted but not Meiji Temple. It has that fresh scent from the trees. I saw traditional Japanese weddings on a Saturday and it's quite impressive to be honest.
The 'other Tokyo'. Always fun to visit the Meiji shrine - it's a nice change from the dynamic metropolis. The weekend is a little bit more crowded, but also more weddings to see...
Meiji Jingumae. Nice temple. beautiful setting, landscape. the gift shop sells nice things that you can buy and Yoyogi park is nice to walk around in
big shinto shrine. You can see Japanese traditional weddings on weekends and there are several weddings going on during each day. We went in the afternoon...

Japanese life. GO- whilst the shrine is a bit dull you get to see the Japanese at play and you may be lucky and see a Japanese wedding - I saw two in the space of 15 minutes - quite somber affairs although the second one the groom did wave and smile at the onlookers

Superb. This is one of the most beautiful spots in all of Tokyo. Every time I'm there, I happen to see a wedding (and sometimes several of them). They're very solemn and done in formal kimonos (for bride as well as groom). Just a wonderful place. This involves a good amount of walking and has a gravelly path, so it's not great for sandals!

Beautiful shrine. A visit to the Meiji Jingu shrine is "a must" especially if you like walking because the forest that surrounds it is ideal for walking. We felt the peace and the blessings of the place and we even wrote some wishes we had for our family in the prayer box. We were also very lucky to have witnessed one Japanese wedding and this was for us the highlight of our stay in Tokyo.

Peaceful break from Tokyo hustle. I went to Meiji Jingu in November and it was an absolute delight. There were a couple of wedding ceremonies that we got to witness, which was especially nice. And there is a prayer box if you want to write something for family/friends. The grounds are a great walk through to get to Harajuku as well, which is the opposite extreme (incredibly busy). Overall, I definitely recommend visiting if you're in Tokyo.

Tranquile. Very authentic shrine, you can feel something when walking around. Not so many tourist as in other places we went. Worth a visit especially if you walk by foot from Metropolitan building to Harayuku.

Impressive shrine with easy access to other sights. Guests usually like to see this shrine or the one in Asakusa. Both are great, but this shrine has the advantage of the established forest around it and close proximity to Harajuku and Omotesando. There's also a chance of seeing Japanese in full wedding regalia getting photos done.

Key shrine in Western Tokyo. Visit the Meiji shrine at a weekend when it's busiest to obtain a fascinating insight into how everyday Tokyo residents view religion. Young children are often taken there to be blessed, dressed up in their finest clothes - look out for the little girls in kimonos.
Breathtaking. The grounds were beautiful, I followed all of the rituals to cleanse yourself before going to pray, truly beautiful and very serene. Worth going to.

Quiet Oasis in an Urban Jungle. Situated in a small park next to the loud and youthful Shibuya district, the Meiji Jingu (Shrine) provides a quiet, contemplative retreat from the fashion boutiques nearby. Established in 1920 in honor of the late Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken, who the Japanese credit as leading their country into the modern era, the Meiji Jingu is both a shrine complex and a nature park with a circular walking path, ideal for a stroll before or after tackling the crowds in Shibuya. For 500 yen, you can also view the pleasant Gyoen gardens, whlie more historically minded visitors can visit the Homotsuden (Treasure Museum), also for 500 yen.
Tranquil. A beautiful shrine set in what feels like a lush forest in the middle of the city. It is very peaceful, and a lovely respite from the craziness that Tokyo can be.

Lots to see and do; but best go early. The shrine complex is huge, with a large garden and many additional buildings, outside of the main shrine complex. I was lucky enough to visit on Culture Day (November 3) so I saw a lot of additional events: martial arts displays, an archery competition, a farmers' market; plus, there was a big diplomatic reception at the shrine itself.The museum, and the museum annex, are definitely worth a visit. I suggest going early - the grounds, and the shrine itself, can be accessed right after sunrise. There is a hushed, reverent feeling to the area when there are only shrine attendants around; after the throngs of visitors and tourists arrive, it's a whole different experience.
Good park to find your zen. Liked the zen tranquility of it. Disliked that there are no trash cans. Definitely recommend writing your wishes onto the woodboard.

A touch of serenity in the centre of Tokyo.. Although not quite 100 years old, the Meiji Shrine is a small peak into yesterday of the Imperial Court when the nobility of Japan would use the grounds as a leisure spot and the shrine used to gain blessings from the spirits with the Shinto priests and monks that still live on these holy grounds. Dress respectfully and do not smoke. Enjoy the orchid gardens in the Spring time.

Beautiful, peaceful and totally worth the visit!. Maybe it is the most beautiful shrine in Tokyo. Peaceful even when it is crowded and conveniently located in the heart of the city. You have to walk for several minutes till the main gate but you won't feel tired at all. Had the luck to visit it during the Shichi-go-san festival so it was full of children and parents wearing their best clothes and visiting the Shrine. You may even catch a few weddings during weekends as it is a great site for this purpose too. You can write your wish in a wooden board, buy some expensive souvenirs and even have your lunch there if you like in the nearby restaurant. Highly recommended for photographers and those who seek a relaxing and peaceful break during the day.

Just GO!. Took my breath away. I loved it and I bought so many charms for those back home. I think the place speaks for itself. It is a magical place that is peaceful and calming. This is also in the center of a huge city but you can't tell while you enjoy the calm.

The Shrine of Shrines in Tokyo. Sat in the very heart of the picturesque Yoyogi Park is this beautiful historic shrine. I love the fact that you have to walk for several minutes through 2 or 3 Torri gates to get to the shrine which builds the anticipation. You will not be disappointed. As well as the shrine there are a number of features to the shrine such as a wish board and a fortune stall where you can leave a message or prayer on wood, or find out what your future holds. The shrine also hosts a number of weddings so you maybe lucky enough to experience the ceremony upon your visit. Not one to miss
Tranquility and beauty. A must while in Tokyo. Totally different than the coloured Asakusa but peaceful and impressive by its beauty.

Nice escape. This was a beautiful and nice escape from the city. We walked from Shibuya station (about 25 minutes). I would recommend this if you have extra time, but I don't necessarily think it is a 'must see'.
Visit on a Saturday. We visited on a Saturday and therefore had the added bonus of seeing several traditional Japanese wedding ceremonies

A must see in Tokyo. Contrary to my expectations, Tokyo is a fantastic city with many enjoyable areas for visiting. The Meiji shrine is perhaps the most remarkable of them. A 20-30 minutes walk fron Shibuya station, it can also be reached via subway, which will leave you just across its main entrance.
Great place to visit. Had a good walk along the forested road towards the shrine. Love the area around the shrine. Went on a Sunday and managed to see some weddings going on.

Well worth a visit. This is the place to come and see a Japanese wedding - the brides look beautiful, the guests are so smartly dressed, the children look adorable in their outfits.
The shrine itself is in such a perfect setting.
Great little walk. Beautiful gardens and shrine to visit while in Tokyo. Easy walk to Harajuku and Yoyogi park from there, so it is a nice calm from the business of that area.
