So romantic!. We visited here on our weekned breakaway. I was blown away, we came across a shinto wedding. It was truely magical. Lots of history to read while walking through when we were here. Wear runners as it is a long walk but truely magnificent! Would recommend!

A peaceful Temple hidden in a huge greenery Park in the big Tokyo City. The temple location is right in the middle of a busy City like Tokyo but once you entered into the park to get to the main temple, you will get a different feeling. The temple is hidden inside the park and you will need to walk approx. 10-15 minutes from the train station to reach the main temple site. But it's a nice walk as you will walk through the park, with lots of Trees, Plants and it will give you the feeling of walking in the forest. Lots of Green and nature..You will see many Japanese businessman in suits stop by at this temple to pray respect and leave. It's nice to see that even in a busy City like Tokyo, people still visit a temple no matter who they are and what they are doing.

Crowded but worth it. Tokyo's largest shrine is worth the visit if only for the pleasant walk through the tree laden pathway that takes you there. Hard to believe you are in one of the largest cities in the world once you get to the centre of the gardens and are at the main shrine. We were fortunate enough to see a series of different weddings taking place within the temple and outside which made for fascinating viewing. Well worth the effort ifyou can make it.

Love Lies Here. And I'm sure you know why, since all the guide books recommend this place. Really beautiful park surrounding a really beautiful shrine. Some tips.1. No entrance fees2. It's really a shrine, so people come to pray; no one will scold you but it's best to respect the worshippers and refrain from taking photos of certain areas3. It's a really long walk to get to the shrine from the gates4. There are restaurants and souvenir shops in the area5. Accessible from more than one train station, but I recommend Harajuku Station, since it has a lovely building

A brilliant free shrine - go on a Sunday if you can!. We visited here on a Sunday morning after reading that this was a good time to glimpse a traditional Japanese wedding, and we weren't disappointed as there were several wedding processions around the shrine.The shrine itself is located in Yoyogi park, a nice place for a stroll and was one of the most picturesque shrines we visited during our stay.

Still awesome and serene. After a lapse of so many years since my last visit, the place is still awesome. The aura is that of serenity and purity. We chanced upon three weddings ceremonies there. Great experience of Japanese Culture.

a great free attraction in the centre of Tokyo. There's trees and fresh air, there's history, and there's daily life. People go there for a walk or a jog or just to read a book on a bench, to pay their respect at the shrine or buy lucky charms or hang a personal prayer on a special tree... I've seen wedding parties come to take photos on the grounds and say a prayer at the shrine. I've seen a group of elderly people do tai-chi in a clearing. It's a wonderful "slice of life" experience and a relief from the relentless bustle of the ultramodern Tokyo around it. And it's free of charge...

Beautiful grounds. I roamed over to the Meiji-Jingu Shrine while waiting for the shops in Harajuku to open. It sits on the opposite side of the shopping area. It was a nice walk up to the shrine. There is a small museum with some nice artwork inside. It was very peaceful and beautiful.

Oasis in the middle of Tokyo. This is one of the most serene and atmospheric places I've ever been. Planted right in the center of Tokyo is a large swath of forest, inside of which is a beautiful shrine. I love the prayer tablets you can buy and hang, and all the different charms you can buy for different things - health, financial success, even one to ward off traffic accidents!
Nice walk but not much to see. This is a great little escape from the city life if you would like a walk in the woods, otherwise there is not much to see or do. I don't know why it is so popular.

Historical. Quite a walk into the shrine which is a jewel within. Bring your most comfy sneakers to tour the place as its quite a walk from the entrance. Historical markers pave the way into the shrine. souvenirs are quite pricey though. I got a metal wind chime for my home. Must try their Sencha (Japanese Tea) Try to sit down and breathe in the quiet ambiance. We were lucky to see someone getting married in the Shrine :)

Japanican Tour. We were taking a Tokyo city tour and this was offered as part of the tour. The guide wasnt really clear about the history of the place and I wasnt interested much about shrines so. It was so so nothing much to see
Tranquil change of scenery. Beautiful walk to the temple. Beware for bugs. I got bit a few times and they bugged me for the rest if the trip. Otherwise, very nice visit.

Best Shrine in Tokyo... maybe even Japan. It is one of the least commercial shrines there are in japan. (although I am sure they make a killing from wishboards/souvenirs. It is very simple, but pretty. The trees are huge and make it much cooler than surrounding areas, which is good because Tokyo can get very hot and humid.

Serene and amazing. The huge Toori gate is simply stunning, the gigantic gardens surrounding the shrine is great for photographer, and the shrine itself is beautifully remarkable. I spent quite some time enjoying myself at the temple as I enjoy a quiet walk among the gardens and making wishes at the shrine. Be sure to try the garden, and spend some time washing your hands and mouth and pray at the shrine. The serenity and the beauty there greatly amazed me.

Quiet and lovely in late afternoon. Avoid morning time as you will see tons of tourists but once you get inside, you would fall in love with the shrine. So serene and beautiful. Dress up in kimono and visit there would make your Tokyo trip even more fun :)

Amazingly beautiful and peaceful!. We took the train here from Ebisu station. The large Torii gate greeting you at the entrance is beautiful. The walking trail is really large and takes about 15 minutes to walk to the shrine itself. On the way to the shrine, there is a garden area that costs about 500 yen per person. Pay the money! The garden is beautiful and myself and the family had a great time walking around and even spotted some Japanese racoons. The shrine itself is rather beautiful...but if you have seen 20 Japanese shrines, you have seen them all. Overall, we had a great time and it is a great get-away from the madness of Tokyo.

Beautiful setting. Its a lovely stroll here, through yoyogi park and then all of a sudden you come across Meiji Jingu. Considering its one of the top ten things to do in many Tokyo guidebooks. I was surprised how quiet it was. Just us, a handful of other tourists and a similar number of locals. It was extremely peaceful.Entrance to the vast area is free and it's lovely to sit in the shade or the sun, on the numerous benches provided and watch people make their offerings of prayers or money.We went out of our way to visit here and I'm glad we did. It's a beautiful spot.

Beautiful shrine. We walked through giant trees on the way to this shrine. It was refreshing to feel the breeze on a warm September day. A religious ceremony was going on when we were there-- men and women in white kimonos walked across the entrance to the main shrine. It was interesting.

Amazing. If you have a couple hours of free time, you should really visit here. It is easily accessible from Harajuku station. The calm, serenity it brings in a bustling city is enjoyable. Take time to read and absorb the history. I see a Shinto wedding nearly every time I visit. Plus, when you are finished, you can people watch on Harajuku street.

A Peaceful Shrine in the Middle of a Bustling City. we accidently stumbled across this shrine when we were assessing the harajuku punk scene. this place is majcal - i cant believe how peacefull and tranquil it is. its a lush green misty tree lined walk with many artifacts and garden shows. its a must see for all

Tranquility. After visiting Tokyo's many tourist attractions take a moment to visit Meiji Jingu and relax. The Shrine is a beautiful park with the added attraction of listening to the insects and birds in the many beautiful trees that surround you. The sound is beautiful. We saw wedding photos being taken the day that we were there. The bride was beautiful.
A must see!. We really enjoyed visiting this area, it felt real and beautil and was well preserved! A true must see in Tokyo!

Peaceful. Meiji Jingu shrine is a favorite of mine because as you walk back into the woods to see the shrine, the noise of the city becomes quiet. You simply trek down the wide gravel paths on your way to the shrine in the center. I've never stopped to go through the gardens along the sides, but they seem interesting. Recently, because of an anniversary for the shrine (or the emperor?), they've had the history of the shrine up along the path. It's an amazing story...

Tranquility in Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is a gorgeous shrine with tree-lined pathways and beautiful gardens right in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Harajuku. You'll be amazed at just how quiet it is once you enter the grounds... the city just beyond the trees just completely disappears. Go on a Sunday and you will likely see the crazy fashion of the Harajuku kids on your way in and a wedding procession or two in progress inside the shrine. The walk takes a good twenty minutes or so to the inner part of the shrine so plan on at least a couple hours to see everything if you plan to see the gardens and all the grounds. Be sure to grab some street food and head to Yoyogi Park just next door after leaving the shrine to see how locals enjoy a Sunday afternoon. Dog lovers will enjoy the park as well, since this is where Tokyo's dog owners often bring their pets for a play date. Visitors to Tokyo should NOT miss Meiji Jingu.

Beautiful Natural Area in the Middle of a City. I thought it was such a surreal experience to walk into the woods and find a temple after leaving crazy Harajuku with the blaring K Pop. It was a beautiful, peaceful place and one of the amazing things about Japan.

A highlight of our visit to Tokyo. We've seen a number of shrines by now. This one was special. Even my teenager commented about how peaceful it was inside the shrine's main courtyard. Be careful to follow the rules on the English language brochure and map.

Worth a visit. This was a very quiet and tranquil place to visit. It was interesting to see the tree with all of the tablets and prayers in different languages hung up. It doesn't take long to see, and it's free, so it's worth a stop.

Nice area but not very impressive. The Meiji Jingu shrine was heavily endorsed by some friends. However after the Akusa area we found this shrine somewhat disappointing. The buildings were blank and hardly any special decoration. Overall not too impressive. If you like to go there do it before you visit one of the other museum/temple areas because this area will be most likely be of a lesser impact.
Beautiful Temple. Beautiful temple set in a beautiful park. Watch the crowds however as they can be heavy once the buses start arriving.

Lovely escape from the city. Calming park, with lovely views, historical stories around.Good place for tourists on a run especially if you can't travel for other cities.Great experience a must see place.
Incredible!. Wow, what a place! So peaceful and a nice break from the hectic streets of Shibuya. Yoyogi park is a beautiful place and well worth a look round. If you go to Tokyo you MUST come here!

An unexpected treat!. Although there's nothing flashy about this shrine, I actually enjoyed my visit. The shrine is located on a HUGE plot of land. While there is no fee to see the actual shrine, there is a fee to visit the small lake located on the grounds (I didn't do this, because I was short on time; but, it looked really nice!) So, the real highlight of my trip was seeing a real, Japanese wedding procession! Apparently, the shrine is used for weddings, and I was fortunate to see an elaborate procession during my visit. I'd CERTAINLY recommend visiting this site and taking some time to explore the grounds. However, if you're short on time (like I was), it's still worth a quick visit.

Nice shrine in a quiet park - good break from the city. Set in a large park in Tokyo, the shrine is a bit of a walk from the metro. It's a very nice break from the intense crowds and lights of Tokyo. Actual building is re-built, but still gives a feel for a traditional Japanese shrine. Must see for any visit to Tokyo.

Must see, very interesting. Meiji Shrine is a short walk from the Harajuku Station (and Yoyogi Park). The shrine begins with a large gate and a wide paved path into the woods. It's about a mile total walk and very flat so it's easy for kids, wheelchairs, etc. Along the way there are various murals depicting scenes from the rule of Emperor Meiji, barrels of sake, barrels of French wine, a fountain, a couple of restaurants and souvenir stands, and finally the shrine complex. You can only go so far into the shrine area. There is a tradition of throwing in a few yen and then doing a series of claps and bows at the interior shrine, if you watch people you'll get what you're supposed to do. You can also write prayers or intentions to be read by monks if you're into that. All in all it's a nice walk, interesting artwork, and a cool look at Japanese culture.

Another shrine. This ranks as one of the top sites in Tokyo. The setting is pleasant, in a dense forest, and the huge tori arches are worth taking a picture of, but the shrine itself is post WWII, and somewhat baffling if you aren't of this culture. Candidly, it seemed very similar to any shrine in Japan, and many in China. If you're going to see one of the Shinto Shrines, I'd recommend Yakusuni Jinga, where there is at least some contemporary controversy to make it more interesting.The map of the surrounding park notes a "treasure" exhibit on the northern end, but a walk there revealed nothing but closed buildings, that looked somewhat unkempt.It was extremely hot when I went (early in the morning), and even making every effort to stay in the shade, I was soaked through by the time I left.

be ready for some serious walking. we went there on a hot day but it wasn't that hot once when we got to the park where there were lots of big big trees and you can't believe you were just in Harajuku, one of the busiest area of tokyo. Elders might have trouble walking all the way to the shrine. it was a 15 minutes walk from the entrance and the path which leads to the shrine were gravel roads so it was very difficult for strollers and wheelchair to maneuver through. the shrine was a nice japanese architecture. don't forget to properly wash your hands at the fountain before you get into the shrine. the water is cool and refreshing after a long walk on a sunny day. when we went (at 2PM) there was a ritual ceremony at the shrine. you can;t take photos at the shrine though.

Pleasant Break from bustle of Tokyo. This is one of the few attractions of Tokyo that offers natural beauty (the gardens) and interesting architecture (the shrine itself) without having to travel very far from the centre. Best to go early morning (I arrived at 8.30 am) to avoid the crowds and enjoy the solitude. If you are extraordinarily lucky, as I was at 9.30 am on a Thursday morning in August, you might catch Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko paying their respects. The Emperor looks rather frail but the Empress appears to be in excellent health

An oasis of calm in the middle of a concrete jungle. When you are inside the temple complex, you can easily make yourself believe that you are elsewhere and not in the middle of a big metropolis. That's how quite and peaceful the place is. Though not much to look around otherwise, if you are lucky you may be able to catch a wedding procession in progress.

A quiete retreat from the city.. This temple was very a nice break from our day of shopping and eating. The walk to the temple was very nice because of all the mature trees, we were there on one of the hottest days, but it was cool and shaded along the path. There was history along the way to read as well. When I got to the temple it was worth the walk.

Good escape from the rush and the crowd. The place is a nice place to visit if you wish to have an easy relaxing stroll in the woods. The shrine itself would be appreciated more if you know it's history. I went there on a Sunday and was able to watch a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony. Overall nice but nothing more
Beautiful & Peaceful. Don't miss Meiji Jingu if you're in Tokyo or in the Harajuku area. Beautiful and peaceful grounds. Easy walking distance from the train station.

Relaxing spot. This shrine is a very interesting visit for the history it represents. But added to the history and significance of the shrine is the fact that the grounds are a very pleasant place to stroll. It is worth taking a half day or so out of your schedule in Tokyo to pay a visit. if you are only going to visit one shrine, this is the one to see.

Great escape from Shibuya. My hotel was in Shibuya for convenience of traveling to various parts of Tokyo to make sales calls. Meiji Jingu was a great escape in the middle of Tokyo for trees, peace and quiet and time to reflect. It was recommended by one of my Japanese co-workers as he knew that I was looking for a quite escape from noisy Shibuya.
Nice Experience. Nice to visit on your trip, i would go as far as to say its a must see. The beauty and historical significance make it this.

You can forget you're in Tokyo!. A nice break from the hussle and bussle, located near to harijuku. When we went there was aflower festival so the walk to the shrine was lined with stunning flowers. Its a huge complex, and quite a walk to the shrine, but the huge trees that line it make it feel very peaceful. LOved it, and plan to go again
Worth a visit.. I really enjoyed walking through the woods from the north and happening upon the shrine. Once there, it was interesting and pretty cool.

Very nice Shrine and easy to get to.. Due to it's proximity to crowded areas like Shinjuku/Shibuya/Harajuku this place will always be crowded. You might even forget you're in Japan when you see hordes of caucasions running around. Plenty of english signage makes it easy to understand what is going on.There are even english speaking locals (college age i think) that offer their explanation services for free which is a nice touch. Meiji Jingu is definitely one of those must see things but the crowding might be a little off putting, don't expect a calm and quiet atmosphere. After this you can easily enjoy the Harajuku area which is merely across the street.

One word, ZEN!. Tranquility among the crowd is what this shrine is all about. From the entrance gate to the temple itself, everything was laid out perpetually. Not one corner is a mess. Clean, plain, simple, peaceful, with plenty of fresh air. Who would have thought there's a place like this just off harajuku(which was a complete opposite). There are no dress code here, but I would say wear and behave properly as the shrine are very well respected among Japanese.

A Pleasant Walk. We stayed at the wonderful Dormy Inn hotel which was within easy walking distance to the Meiji Temple. We arrived at the temple after an early morning rain which made the surrounding woods and forest so refreshingly cool and even more peaceful and serene. It was the kind of perfect day where I could have walked under the shade of the trees and just feel nature around me forever.

Beautiful shrine and relaxing forest in the heart of Tokyo madness!. This is the first Shinto Shrine that I have visited and I was blown away by how beautiful it was and how relaxing and tranquil it was. The Meiji shrine was established in 1920 and is dedicated to the Emperor Meiji and his Empress who died in the early 20th century. The shrine is surrounded by a forest which was made in honour of the Emperor and Empress by importing 100,000 trees from all over Japan and from overseas.The walk from Harajuku to the entrance to the shrine is about a 10-20 minute walk depending on how fast you walk and whether you stop to look at the beautiful forest, sake/wine barrels/gift shop etc. The path is a gravel path so I would definitely recommend wearing good walking shoes. However, the walk was really very pleasant and as I am living in Tokyo I will definitely go back just to walk around the grounds again.There is a gift shop in the grounds (about halfway between the main entrance at Harajuku and the main shrine) which is worth a look around as they have some great Japanese souvenirs and potential gifts to take home for friends and family. The prices also seemed quite reasonable in Tokyo terms!I was worried that I would not understand the signs and would therefore not be able to show the appropriate level of respect at the shrine (as after all this is a sacred place for many people). However, all of the important signs were also in English and there was a very good explanation of how to wash your hands and mouth at the font before entering the shrine. There were also free english leaflets at the font explaining some of the history of the font, together with the appropriate ettiquette for visiting a shrine which were very handy.Inside the shrine, you can purchase charms for certain things e.g. success in entrance examinations, good health etc. For 500 yen you can also write a prayer out and leave it at the shrine.I would recommend a visit to this shrine to any visitors to Tokyo!

beautiful place. this is the 100th year of the emperor's passing and there was a special exhibition to tell the story of the emperor's life. we found it extremely interesting and informational just reading the exhibition. unfortuantely it was drizzling when we went so we didnt get to see much of yogogi park, but still, it was a very beautiful shrine.
beautiful. be sure to visit jinjiavery inspiring and funny shows do they do it still?

Must see. Not only is this shrine beautiful, but Yogogi Park (the park where the shrine is in) is equally lovely. Walking through the park to the shrine, you don't even realize you're in a huge metropolis anymore. As you walk to the shrine, there are lots of billboards with fun facts about the history of Japan, the park and the shrine itself. The location is also quite excellent. If you're planning on coming here, you can easily take a walk to Harajuku, and to Shibuya crossing.

Very beautiful ~. Getting to the main shrine required a fair bit of walking, however, it was a walk well worth it. Being surrounded by all the greenery and the tranquility was a welcome escape from all the hype and excitement at the nearby Harajuku. I would definitely go again on my next trip to japan.

Friend's wedding. I went to Meiji Jingu to attend my dearest friend's wedding. Yes, it's a very famous place to held wedding and reservation is hard. It is so peaceful yet charming.I rented the kimono from their wedding department and had vast choices. I highly recommend anyone to walk around here.

Very tranquil, requires a bit of walk. This is a huge shrine. Emphasis on the huge. And what huge is actually the forest area surrounding the shrine, it would take 15 minutes walk to reach the shrine from the main entrance.If you take different exit you'll end up to different train station.With all of its simplicity, it's simply the best shrine in Japan, in my humble opinion.

Most beautiful Shrine. Meiji Shrine is definitely a place to visit. May was our second time in Japan and we went to the shrine again because we remembered how wonderful it was. We took my sister and her husband and we were all lucky enough to be at the shrine while 4 wedding parties were taking pictures. They were all so beautiful and didn't mind us taking pictures! The shrine and it's gardens are a wonderful way to spend your morning/afternoon

Beautiful park & shrine. The Meiji Jingu is located in a beautiful sprawling park. The grounds were immaculate and the park was quite peaceful. The actual shrine was definitely worth the visit. The is an exhibition about the Meiji Emperor and neat bits of history to read & see all throughout the shrine. Highly recommended.

Meiji Jingu, heart of Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is a massive green park in the centre of Tokyo, bordered by Shibuya, Yoyogi and Shinjuku areas..... extraordinary to walk through. One immediately senses the mysterious past of Japan. The deep "quiet" is overwhelming while the rustle of fast trains in the distance, and occasional freeway traffic noises can still be heard. Tokyo is a mass of steel and concrete, bitumen and glass, trucks and cars and trains, and so much more. And so a nature reserve of this size, in the middle of the metropolis, is a powerful "symbol" as well as a practical retreat from city life, for the urban walker.

Nice Shinto Shrine. I was at the Meiji Jingu Shrine and this was quite a walk from the nearby sub-station. The shrine was generally peaceful and not very crowded which was great. There is also an exhibition about the emperor and his contributions to global peace and Japan's development.

Cultural experience & peaceful spiritual place in the heart of Tokyo. Beautiful & peaceful place in Tokyo. Historical exhibit along the way from entrance to the shrine. Lots of trees!! You might get to see a wedding there.

Lovely walkways and informative posters. We happened by accident on this Shinto Shrine dedicated to the Emperor Meiji (1852-1912) and Empress Shoken (1850-1914). The shrine is located in the Shibuya area of central Tokyo, about 50 meters from the Harajuku Station on the JR Yamanote line. This year (2012) is the centennial of Emperor Meiji's death so a lot of events are planned for the time period June 30 through July 30. The shrine's grounds are extensive and forested, and contain a huge tori, a museum with personal items of the Emperor and Empress, a lunchroom, and a souvenir shop. The museum was closed the Thursday we visited. The souvenir shop contained more tasteful items than many such shops. We enjoyed walking on the broad carriage paths in this shrine area as a respite from the commotion of Tokyo streets. Posters set up for the centennial celebration contained pictures and prints plus extensive text in Japanese and English about the significance of this emperor. See www.meijijingu.or.jp/english/index.html for more information about this interesting but less well known site.

Nice spot to take a quiet stroll. This shrine dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken is a really nice place to take a stroll in the middle of the afternoon. Surrounded by a forest full of huge trees it is the perfect place to take a break and relax. Good option when traveling with small children. If you are lucky you may catch a wedding ceremony.
Popular Shrine in Tokyo. Beautiful place to walk, lots of trees and wide paths. There are large murals lining the way to the shrine, illustrating Emperor Meiji's life.
Exquisitely simple and peaceful. Love the trees, love the air, the atmosphere, the sound of wind and birds, it is just beautiful

Instant Calm. The tori gates at the park entrances are magnificent. Other than racing to Meji Shrine, enjoy the walk which would bring calm to anyone overwhelmed by the incredible sights and sounds of Tokyo. It's like a museum with a range of interest points, displays, a pay to enter garden and information. The sight of a tori gate, the trees overhead and a sky scraper in the back drop hit home that traditional and modern Japan coexisting side by side is reality in Tokyo. The japanese notion of balance is evident in the asymetrical design of Meji Jingu, and the grounds are immaculate. Summer means the iris flowers are in full bloom and there were displays by the shrine entrance. Although i saw someone spraying them with water, they were so perfect that i'm still convincing myself they were real!
Awesome. go on a sunday and you might be lucky to see a traditional Japanese wedding or two. . .I did!!!

Go on a Sunday to see weddings. We rally enjoyed visiting Meiji Jingu. The walk to the shrine itself through the park is lovely. We went on a Sunday and were very fortunate to see a couple of weddings with the bride and groom in traditional dress which was a highlight. The buildings are lovely and well worth the trip. As with everything in Japan, the grounds were spotless. There is a restaurant and shop which was good to buy gifts in. To get the full benefit, I recommend walking in through the forest from the Yoyogi side and leave through the Hairjuku gate filling the afternoon up in Harijuku which is fun on a Sunday.

Serenity with lots of greens. There is a sense of peace as you enter the Torii gate main entrance to the Meiji Shrine. I love the greens surrounding the shrine. The barrels of sake and wines in Meiji Jingu is definitely one of the attractions for photo-taking. There are so many encouraging words or prayers written on little wooden blocks hanging on some wooden stands surrounding a tree at the mainyard.We were also lucky to witness the wedding ceremony of a Japanese bride and her foreign bridegroom at the mainyard. There were just the couple and a lady beside them, apart from two photographers accompanying them for some wedding shoots.

Attending Wedding Ceremonies. I was lucky to get invited for a Japanese weddding ceremony at Meiji Jingu! It was fabulous but quiet wedding. Ceremony was organized with minute-to-minute schedules and rules. I was still more lucky to get inside the alter, where, traditionally family member's area. The wedding was conducted by two priests and two female assistants. The ceremony was carried out in copy-book style. The environment was fantastic, traditional shinto style wedding. I was even more happy that I could visit Meiji Jingu almost 20 years later. The first time, I was like a visitor (Tourist), this time, I was with a wedding party!!!
Tokyo must-see. By far the best shrine to see in Tokyo. Spend some time in Yoyogi Park, or walk north up to the lovely Shinjuku Park.
Lovely stroll. Very enjoyable walk from the Harajuku station and through the wooded grove. And the view of the shrine is worth the walk.

Interesting Shrine Near Harajuku & Shibuya. I would recommend visiting Meiji Jingu especially if you're not able to make it outside of Tokyo to see other shrines. There are more interesting shrines to visit outside of the city, but the location of this one is convenient and it's a good place to start. They provide a lot of background historical information on the shrine in English and we saw a traditional wedding taking place, which was really very beautiful. I think I enjoyed walking along the trails leading to and from the Meiji Jingu and through Yoyogi Park as much as I enjoyed the shrine itself. The grounds are beautiful and it's hard to believe you're still so close to the city. I would recommend stopping here on a Sunday morning if you're staying in Shibuya - it's an easy and beautiful walk.

Long Walk to a Pretty Shrine. This is a Shinto Shrine that was opened in 1920 in honor Emperor and Empress Meiji. It is about a 10 minute walk to the shrine after you go through the Torii gate, but it is very pretty.
Meiji jingu. Very Japan, loved the wish wall where people have posted their wishes and prayers. Saw a couple of families dressed up in kimono to visit, so beautiful, a very nice sight.

Beautiful Walk. It is such a beautiful park with a shrine in the middle of it. One of the main gates is located right behind Harajuku station. It is free of charge to get to the shrine. There is also a garden but there is a 500yen charge for the up keep of the garden. But on a nice sunny day it is a great break from all the tall buildings and busy streets.

Nice to learn history of Japan. Emperor Meiji is considered a deity and is quite interesting to visit his sanctuary, surrounded by a forest of camphor trees. Many wedding ceremonies were taking place while I visited it. Budist monks and priest added interest fo the colorful ceremonies.
A nice walk.. I always love to walk by the shrine and watch the traditional wedding processions. Very beautiful.

Peace and quiet in the midst of bustling Tokyo. I must admit, I saw this shrine my second day in Tokyo, so I was still a bit jet lagged. I hadn't quite mastered the subway system so I ended up walking waaaay too far- take the JR train to Harajuku Station and you will be right there. The walk into the temple, as others have said, is pretty long- if you have young children, are elderly, or otherwise don't like long walks you may wish to see some of the more accessible shrines in Tokyo. The walk to the shrine is interesting though- huge caskets of sake given as offerings and boards with the story of the Meiji period and the building of the shrine make the long walk more bearable. There is a great gift shop (not crazily overpriced compared to others and has some unique trinkets) and decent restaurant. The grounds of the shrine are peaceful and quiet (not a lot of tourists the day I went). Like other shrines, you can purchase a wooden board to write a message or prayer, as well as purchase other souvenirs. This was not the most impressive shrine I saw in terms of colors, design, and accessibility, but the history and grandeur of the site are definitely worth seeing! For a visually stunning shrine that's a bit more out of the way, look up Nezu Shrine near the Yanaka.

Lucky to be here. When we visited this shrine, there were two wedding ceremonies. They were very traditional with the kimonos and the whole thing. Feel very to visit in such a great occasion. I also write some wishes in an altar.

Beautiful Place. We were waiting for the cosplay teens in Harajuku, so while waiting we went to this Shrine. The big torii marker at the gate already sets the tone for this beautiful shrine. We were also very fortunate to witness 2 wedding processions! One of the favorite photographic highlights of my Tokyo trip.Blogged about it here:http://www.tagofabic.com/2012/05/meiji-shrine-and-wedding-procession.html

quiet simple famous. Probably one of the most famous shrines in the city though it is not as pretty as those in Kyoto. It is a good place to roam if you are in the area (Omotesando and Harajuku) but there are other much prettier shrines in the country.
Weddings on Sunday. On Sunday they had many traditional Japanese weddings occurring; very interesting.

A Quiet Interesting Place To Visit. This was my 5th visit to Japan with my wife to visit her relatives there, and on this trip her cousin took us to the Meiji Jingu Shrine. My wife and I enjoyed it very much, especially the informative billboard size photos and history of Emperor Meiji's life and times. If you are in Tokyo for several days like we were it's great to get away to a quiet wooded area for a bit. There is a lovely pond full of Koi and turtles just a five minute walk from the middle of the shrine area. We didn't go to the museum just past the pond, but hope to on our next trip to Tokyo. Plan on spending an hour or two and take a picinic if the weather allows, as the park by the pond and museum would be a good place for a picinic lunch. We agree with others in the forum that it's fun to be there on a weekend to see a wedding party or two. One of the best things about the visiting shrine is it's free!

Beautiful haven in busy Tokyo. Head to Meiji Jingu early to avoid the crowds and its especially pretty. I went on my first day in Tokyo when I woke early with jet lag and got there just as it opened with mist shrouding the trees in the surrounding forest. I saw two Shinto weddings taking place whilst I was there which were special to see as its so different from a Western wedding. A definite must see for me in Tokyo and in my top five.
A VERY NICE walk in the park. A bit of a scenic hike. Don't be overwhelmed by it, thought.

go on the weekend. we went on the weekend and saw like 5 weddings it was cool to see there outfits. the temple is beautiful, the washing of the hands and mouth at the entry is fun to be a part of the culture. there are some western toilets through out the park and these are clean enough suggest hand soap or hand sanitiser. there is a shop which seemed popular, also a restaurant and small food hall.

Inspiring place. I had a chance to visit this shrine on a work day morning and it was very quiet and peaceful place. The shrine itself looks nice and the place has inspiring atmosphere. If you have enough time you can stroll around the large surrounding park.

I'm sure it is very peaceful without the chainsaws.. This is really easy to reach from Harajuku station. The surrounding forest is really pleasant to walk through. I went at about 11am on a week day and it was pretty quiet, apart from the constant chainsaw noise because the trees beside the shrine were being maintained. I guess we got unlucky with that. Otherwise it would have been a serene place.

High end weddings on weekends - a treat to witness!. On a beautiful Sunday day in April, while the sakura was blooming, we were fortunate to witness and photograph a Japanese high-society wedding. It was a major treat! Police escorts and protection, tons of media, etc. I understand that on the weekends weddings are not that rare. Try to see one. During the week this place is very peaceful. This is a very large island of tranquility.

Serene and beautiful shrine. We visited on a Sunday when lots of local people had also decided to see the park and shrine. Approached through a torii gate which takes you from the bustle around Harajuku station you walk beneath trees along a gravel path. On the right is a cafeteria and small exhibitions hall before you pass two 'walls' of wine - on the left barrels of Burgundy and of the right barrels of sake, offerings to the shrine.At the end is the shrine itself, a simple Shinto building where the Emperor Meiji is venerated. If you do visit, be sure to follow the instructions given in the leaflets available which tell you how to show the proper respect to the emperor and empress.There is a serene and respectful feel to the place; it is peaceful and quiet out of respect to the honour due to the emperor. Well worth a visit and in a place as fast and hectic as Tokyo it's a welcome escape to the peace of a quiet parkland.

Beautiful - and such a contrast to neigbouring Harajuku!. This shrine, and the approach to it through a nice park, are so beautiful and serene, it's a great place to visit after a day out in crazy (but fun) Harajuku. I happened to see what I assume was a photo shoot at a Japanese wedding, a great thing to stumble upon.Approaching from Harajuku Station, you'll pass a little tourist centre in the park, the soba there is great (and really cheap).

worth doing once. Having lived in Tokyo I always recommend seeing the Meiji Shrine. It is worth doing once. A relatively modern Shrine built around 1900 it is a major cultural icon. If you have seen it once it is probably not necessary to do it again
Lucky to have witnessed a Japanese wedding. We went on a beautiful day to see this Shinto shrine and we were lucky to see a Japanese wedding.

Tokyo's most important shrine. The grounds of this enormous shrine are beautiful, and one thing I noticed is that they are absolutely spotless. It's very quiet, and being so near Shinjuku and Harajuku (which are NOT quiet!), it's amazing. This was the first big "sight" I saw in Tokyo, aside from the observatory at the Metropolitan Government Office Bldg., and I immediately decided that Tokyo was terrific--a view I have never changed.
Not the best. That wasnt my favorite temple. There wasnt a lot of people. I think we maybe just went there on the wrong day !

Loved It. Not much of a museum or temple fan but this was great. Walking into the shrine area is like putting on a pair of ear muffs. The noise of Tokyo simply goes away. We saw a traditional wedding party - very special.

peace and quiet steps away from the Harajuku crown. Surprisingly large shrine in very central and fashionable part of Tokyo. You can always spend some time to be away from the noise and crowd. You can visit the more "shrine-like" part, or just enjoy this huge patch of green like a public park.

A must-see in Tokyo. This is an excellent example of a temple that's easily accessible and great for tourists and those unfamiliar with Japanese customs and traditions.It's actively used by the people of Tokyo, yet isn't so intimate that foreigners/tourists feel out of place. Plus, it has some of the largest torii gates in Japan.

Nice way to learn a bit of Japanese history. In a lovely park, we were lucky because the weather was starting to show signs of spring which made the walk very pleasant, and with informative displays outside the shrine to explain the background to the shrine. Very interesting.
Peaceful in the middle.. Historical,but bland.Nice to eat lunch but all too soon the surrounding city is to be seen.

Tranquil Oasis in a busy city. This is a tranquil place set among well kept parkland in Tokyo. From Mejii-jingumae subway station its a 1 minute walk to the park entrance. There are signs inside directing you to the temple which is about a 10 minute walk from the entrance. The temple itself has a couple of stands selling gifts as well as wooden prayer boards and an area where you can write a prayer and offer it to the temple to be included in their daily prayers. This is a peaceful, calm place and definitely worth a visit.

tranquil, fascinating and if you're lucky you'll see a wedding. I am not a big viewer of shrines and temples however I manage to spend about 30 or 40 minutes here just soaking it up. Luckily for me a wedding party (i presume) arrived and that was seriously special.In the background a big booking drum was sounding off and then the wedding party arrived, serene and stunning. I was gob smacked. It was very special.the whole area itself is set with in the wider park of Yoyogi and it is a very enjoyable walk through the woods. its not really the done thing to take photos of some parts of the temple and that was fine by me. If you are in Shibuya/HJ area I think this is worth a pop in.
Good place. I visited this temple on the new year day of 2010.......i love this place

Filled with fossils. The fossils, of course, are of the living variety. This place is filled with senior citizens with nothing else to fill their time. They appear to be bussed in, and they all walk along with a bored look on their faces.Meiji Jingu is a relic of a culture that has long since died. If you are truly interested in this piece of history, read about it. Do not spend your precious vacation minutes here thinking you are soaking up true Japanese culture.Instead, take a walk down Omotesando Dori, about five minutes away by foot. Stroll down as many of the side streets as possible. They are filled with boutiques, galleries, bistros and cool little spaces where the youth of Japan are creating a fashion culture that radiates out to the rest of the world. This is where you can truly soak up an ambience that is quintessentially Japanese.And really, if you've seen one rebuilt Japanese temple, you've seen them all.
Always Good. Even with many people a peaceful feel. Weekends great to catch a glimpse of a wedding

Meiji shrine. Great adjunct to shopping at Harajuku. Its only downside is you might already be tired from walking...and its a long walk in, and then long walk back. But its very quiet, and has decent information to help an uninformed westerner...

Grand temple in pristine parkland. A stroll from Harajuku station, the Meiji Jingu is a Shinto shrine dedicated to the 122nd Emperor of Japan (Meiji), the great-grandfather of the current Emperor. There are several historical monuments throughout the park on the way to the shrine and the pathways and gardens are immaculately kept.
Great space. Visisted on a Festival Day, was just great. Will visit again so I can just walk around and enjoy the surroundings.

Stunning. One of Tokyo's biggest landmarks, this is a place I go constantly to relax! To get out of the hustle and bustle of Tokyo and find yourself in a beautiful garden then in a quiet shrine is amazing. A must see!

A must see if visiting Tokyo. I was amazed by how large the grounds covered. You have to walk a bit to get into the actual shrine itself. The walkway leading to the shrine itself is wide so you don't feel congested. It is also very well landscaped, very peaceful feeling.Towards the end of the walkway, along the side there was displays with information about Meiji Emperor's life and contribution to modern Japan.We went on New Year's Day. There was a huge crowd of Japanese because it is there tradition to go to a shrine on New Year's Day and pray for a good new year. Even though there was a large crowd, the Japanese are very respectful and you still feel you have sufficient personal space. Love the experience!! If you are in Tokyo on New Year Day, I strongly recommend going.
Quiet Oasis. just down the road from Teeny Bopper Cosplay Anime Crazy Capital of Harajuku, Takeshita Street. If you're lucky, you'll get to see a wedding.

Zen atmospere !. It is very close to the Harajuku Station and also
famouse fashion street 'Takeshita dori' and 'Omotesando'.
The atmosphere of the Meiji Jungu is excellent. a lot of green, very calming and Zen atmosphere! You can often see the Japanese style wedding inseide Meiji Jingu.

Peaceful and serene. Meiji Jingu is such a contrast to the "Cosplay" on the main street - it is simple, traditional, serene and GORGEOUS!
The walk to the temple is beautiful, with a small bridge and a tiny (blkin and you will miss it) streamlet. A must-visit on your trip to Tokyo. The walk and the temple were less crowded than Sensoji.
beautiful and peaceful. beautiful walk to the shrine through the woods. impressive shrine.

Lovely shrine. Meji Shrine is an oasis from the busy streets of harajuku. Surrounded by a huge park the shine is a great place to visit any time of the year. They offer English guides and translations of information about the shine and of the charms and fortunes.

Nice escape from intense Harajuku. Easily accessible from Harajuku or Meijijingumae Stations. The walk there is peaceful compared to the rest of Tokyo. The shrine building is pretty cool and it's usually not too busy. If there's a special occasion then it will be very busy but it's still worth going to see people dressed in kimono, feel the atmosphere and possibly see special displays.
old shrine in japan. this is the culture of japan that shows the great and full of history that creat by a genaration ..........
Beautiful. I loved this temple. The walkway in was really refreshing as it passed through all the trees amoung the city. The temple was really nice too, with great design.

Very peaceful place. In the heart of the city, this shinto shrine is located in a quiet and peaceful park, and is well worth a visit.It is easy to get to from Harajaku station, though we walked a long way from Shibuya station. There is a long walk through the park before you reach the actual shrine.We visited, and then decided to go again on New Years Eve as we thought something would happen for the new year. Little did we now that it was the place to be. We found ourselves at the beginning of the queue for the inner shrine. Having no idea what was happening we decided to wait. Pretty soon there were loads of people behind us. We were waiting 2 hours before they opened the gates. It was unplanned, but a once in a lifetime opportunity to be the first in and to actually be at the shrine when the drums banged in the new year. When we left we saw that the queue to get in must have had many thousands of people. The police were there in force doing crowd control and the trains ran constantly through the night to cope with the volume of people who were visiting that night.Our previous visit, during the day a few days earlier, was a much calmer affair with no queues at all.

Atmospheric. Right in the heart of Tokyo there is this quiet walk lined with mature trees leading up to one of the most significant shrines in Japan. This is where the Emperor and Empress Meiji, who oversaw the modernisation of Japan are deified. Nearby are some lovely gardens, esp. famous for irises. This place is esp. crowded at New Year as THE place to visit to pray for luck for the coming year.

A serene patch of niceness in Tokyo. Meiji Jingu Shrine is a famous Shinto shrine built in the 1920s in dedication to the souls of Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken, whose physical tombs are in Kyoto. I must say the setting is most peaceful and dignified. I purified at the temizuya and proceeded to reflect at the shrine. People of all faiths -- or no faith at all -- are welcome but it's important to remember this is a holy place and proper etiquette should be observed during one's visit. Photography is permitted only outside.This is a very popular site to visit for Japanese and foreigners alike. There were several traditional Shinto weddings taking place during my visit. And many people from all walks of life came to pay their respects. It was a very positive experience and I felt quite refreshed afterwards. One word of caution: you may not want to visit on or just after New-Year's Day. This is possibly the most popular time for people to visit and you will have to wait in line for a very long time.

An Oasis of Serenity in the Downtown Chaos of Tokyo. Meiji Shrine is a forest right in the heart of Tokyo. Going inside one almost forgets there is a bustling city outside. A lot of people visit the shrines especially on holidays but if you go during the week one might get a bit more peace and quiet.The shrine is relatively recent have been built to commemorate Emperor Meiji who died in the early 20th Century. It is an excellent example though of Shinto architecture. It is definitely a must-see on any Tokyo itinerary. Within the park there is a small garden, treasure house, and art museum with a small admittance fee. They are worth a look as well.If you are lucky you might catch a traditional Shinto wedding and see the bride and groom in their kimono. On Sundays near the entrance you can see the goth kids in their photogenic outfits.The best time to go to Meiji Shrine is when they have events there:On Jan 6, the Sumo Champion(s) come to Meiji Shrine to perform a ring-entering ceremony around 3pm.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aX09ujLk8QcOn the second Monday of January is Seijin-no-Hi which is coming of age day for all those turning 20. You can see many girls clad in long-sleeve kimono called furisode:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kFQuzN5__aQAlso on that day, an archery ritual is performed in honor of the new adults:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nik5nrC-aXIOn November 3rd, they do a number of martial arts demonstrations including Yabusame - Japanese mounted archery:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ywRP725u11k
Good healing atmosphere. It's nice for mind relaxing after a day's walk in busy Tokyo. Truly worth visiting!

Beautiful and historic.. A must see while in Japan. You get a real sense of Emperor Meiji and how loved he was by seeing the temples built, which were dedicated to him. The garden was ok - you have to contribute 500 yen - did not think it was worth it.

Beautiful park and temple courtyard - worth a visit. If you're traveling around Tokyo, Meiji-Jingu deserves to be a part of your itinerary (I recommend doing Shibuya, Harajuku, Yoyogi park, and Meiji-Jingu in one day).Its a wonderful wooded park with the temple at the center. The temple itself isn't as impressive as some of the Kyoto area temples, but it has a beautiful tiled courtyard where you can soak up the history.Meiji-Jingu, like Senso-ji, is free to enter (the Meiji garden costs 500 Yen when we were there), so again it is very much worth a visit. the only thing that I wish for the park was a walk way connecting Meiji park to Yoyogi.

Weekends are the best time.. This is the place to get married and there is a wedding parade walking through every 15 minutes. Each one is dressed in the most traditional way. We, the tourists look like paparazzi trying to snap photos of the bride and groom as they walk through this timeless shrine.
Serene and traditional. On the weekends you are bound to see some traditional Japanese weddings going on. Most famous place to get wed. It is a nice visit anytime, though

Brisk afternoon stroll. Walked from Harajuku Station after spending the morning in Shibuya. It was my wife and I, 15 yr old daughter and 13/11 year old sons. We got there around 1300 and had a lovely 20-30 minute walk up to the shrine. There are two fantastic Tori Gates and the Shrine itself was large, but mostly open area. It was a bit cold and not as many people as we expected. We didn't go up to the treasure house, but did pay the 500 yen to walk around the inner garden which was lovely. We stopped at the fishing lake to relax after a busy day and the kids ran around looking at the colorful carp and taking pictures of each other with the lake and Fallish colors as a background.

Serenity in a bustling city. Meiji Jingu, in Yoyogi park is an island of quiet serenity in a loud and bustling city. Walking into this park will provide the break you need from the craziness that is Tokyo.

A nice stroll through the shrine. It was a Sunday morning, people were there for specific occasions, and personal events. Take a walk through the park during the fall, the colors are capturing, Sunday is where it seems to be the place where groups of choirs practice. Easily can be done within an hour or less.

Beautiful. If you go to one Shinto shrine in Tokyo, go to this one. Walk the expansive grounds, admire the trees, the sake casks, and the beautiful elaborate shrine buildings. The best part about it is all the locals dressed up in their best (especially on weekends) attending weddings and taking photos of their kids all dressed up in the traditional ceremonial outfits. If you're a budding photographer, I guarantee you will take some magnificent shots here. Usually, Japanese people don't like having their picture taken by strangers. But here, you are more than welcome to take their photo and just join in on family photo shoots! It's even convenient to get to, just over the famous bridge near Harajuku station. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Lively. Albeit a place for the way of the Kami, Meiji-jingu has a lively and wonderful atmosphere with a profusion of newly married couples, families, small children and babies and a totally upbeat crowd of Tokyo people. Tourists are treated with respect and kindness.

easy access, great for walk in the green in Tokyo city. the temple itself do not need admission fees but the garden charges a JY500, do not recommend a visit if u r on budget unless it's autumn o spring

Yoyogi Park and the Meiji Jingu Temple. We went to Yoyogi Park on a Sunday morning. After jumnping of the subway we went straight over to the entrance and began our walk. The start is the Torii at the entrance. Its not the only one but is quite beautiful nonetheless. The gardens are huge in their size, so take your time. Being a Sunday morning the gardens were actually already quite busy at 9.00 am. When we got to the Meiji Jungu temple we saw why. There were weddings in progress. We had the opportunity to be there for three Shinto weddings. This included wedding processions and guests all dressed in traditional attire. Take your time and soak it all up.Feel free to take many pictures, just stay out of the official photographers way. By the way this is all free, no admission fees required.

A big, serene place in the heart of Tokyo. The visit to this shrine has to be one of the highlights of our stay in Tokyo. Its huge, its calm, its serene. The long walk to the actual shrine is beautiful. The architecture is very Japanese, and its magnificent. Easily accessed from JR Harajuku station of the Tokyo Metro.

Well-maintenace Temple, a sacred place for Japanese. The Meiji Jingu Shrine is very convenient to go. You just take JR Line Railway and get off at Shibuya Station then you follow "Meiji Jingu Shrine Sign", Once you are out of the station, walk straight for about 10 meters and turn right, the Meiji Jingu Shrine is just around the corner.From the Entrance, you have to walk about 2 kilometers to reach the Shrine. The path is very well-paved with small stone and there will be someone who will sweep the dried leaves along the way to make sure that the path looks neat. Both sides there are flowers greenhouse which nursing bonzai and colorful chrysanthemum. Moreover, there will be barrels of wine for Consecration at Meiji Jingu exhibit along the way to the shrine.This Meiji Jingu Shrine is famous for the Japanese to perform a traditional wedding here. Also when you reach the shrine, you will see "Ema" - a votive tablet for personal prayer hang around the tree, you can buy an ema and make your own wish at the rate of 400 Yen per ema. Also there will be lucky charms for sale in which the Japanese believe that these will bring good luck for the holder, there are many different kinds of lucky charms for example, lucky charm for scholarship, winning competition, good healthy, etc. I bought the pink one which will help opening our luck.This place limits the area where we can eat, drink or go to toilet. There will be a spot where they have a small shop that sell beverage, snacks, and ice-cream and you are not allowed to eat or drink beyond that area.
Beautiful - especially the walk there. Walk down from Shinjuku Stn, throuhg Meiji park and finish at Harajuku station. The perfect mix of what Tokyo has to offer in half a day.
Great Temple. This temple is within walking distance of the hotel. It's not a quick walk, but it's doable, or take Tokyo Metro right there. It's also close to Harajuku. It's a wonderful experience.
go on a weekend to see the wedding processions!. Saturday morning seems to be a popular time to get married - lots of wedding processions, adding quite the charm to the shrine!

Beautiful park setting; largest torii (shrine gates) in Japan. If you are feeling overwhelmed with the city, the lovely grounds of this shrine make for a nice break. Also, the torii (shrine gates) are the tallest you will find in Japan. We enjoyed seeing them. Easy to get to from subway. Park closes shortly before dusk. If you go close to that time, make sure to bring bug spray!

Fine little shrine in a serene area. I had spent a week in Kyoto prior to getting to Tokyo so felt very templed out, but I did enjoy the Meiji Shrine. It's quite the trek from Harajuku station, but along a quiet stone path, and it was reasonably early when I got there, so I think I enjoyed the journey more than the destination.The standout point with this shrine was that there were a couple of weddings going on at the time. One was processing through the main square and getting pictures taken at the main shrine, and one was posing for pictures behind one of the outer buildings. It all looked very nice, but I felt so sorry for the one doing the procession as a buncha tourists got up close and started snapping like ‘gee, honey look at these natives; she’s a geee-sha and he’s a samur-hey.’ I assume the other wedding would do the same but later and at a time where there would be even more tourists. I guess it’s a done thing, so I’m surprised that they couldn’t cordon off an area for the happy couple or something, but what do I know – perhaps the geee-sha and her samur-hey enjoy the attention.

Serene temple amidst Yoyogikoen. This shinto temple Is surrounded by the beautiful evergreen trees of Yoyogi park, Shibuya. First you pass trough large Torii-gates. The path up to the temple lined by tall trees. The gravel path perfectly svept. Such a great contrast to the hectic tempo of the city outside of the park. I feel relaxed and find inner peace as I arrive at the temple itself. The temple is beautiful and surrounded by a serene atmosphere, especially early In the morning. It is a very popular temple for weddings, so you have an opportunity to vitness a traditional japanese wedding ceremony. Of course observe courtesy and keep your distance to the happy couple at their very special day. This shrine and park is well worth a visit.

Perfect place for Japanese traditional wedding. Perfect place to see Japanese traditional wedding. Here is one of the most popular place for the wedding among Japanese people and you can see wedding ceremony every weekend. You can see the bride in a white Japanese traditional kimono dress.

Peaceful shrine with two shinto wedding processions. We loved this shrine. The pathway to get to the shrine is lined with huge trees and is so peaceful. The highlight was the ability to watch two traditional shinto wedding processions walk through the courtyard. The bride and groom wore absolutely stunning, traditional outfits. It was a real treat.

Nicest place in Tokyo. We went here in sept 2009, the gardens are really nice and all staff really friendly. There was an aircaft exibition on : http://aviation-art.homestead.com/ the day we were there so it was a real bonus. I would recomment you try visiting here in the afternoon as mornings can be too quiet and can feel eerie I have been told.Please enjoyAustin

Go on a Sunday. We recently came back from a six day trip to Tokyo, and made it a priority to check out the Meiji Jingu shrine on Sunday. There were no less than four wedding ceremonies performed while we were walking around the shrine grounds. It's a wonderful experience to see the wedding rituals performed and the wedding party dressed in traditional kimono. Be sure to maintain a repectable distance, as it is an intimate procedure, but I was surprised we were allowed to get so close and take photos. The shrine itself is incredibly beautiful, and the torii that mark the entrance to the shrine are enormous and 1500 years old. We had a relaxing walk through Yoyogi Park.

Inner Garden: Birdwatcher's Paradise. Inner Garden of the Meiji Shrine is peaceful, quiet place detached from bustling Tokyo streets. 500 yen admission will be well-rewarded. Until Meiji Restoration this area had been the Daimyo Lord's residence and Kiyomasa's Well may be the only remainder of the Edo era garden. Like other gardens such as Koraku-en and Rikugien it is a typical stroll garden. Lots of wild birds find their home in this garden so if you are a birdwatcher this garden is a perfect place for you.

A nice retreat in the city. If there is a place that can make you forget you are in a huge bustling city like Tokyo, walking towards this shrine is the place. You start walking into an area that is nicely wooded and gives you the impression that you are walking through some wilderness towards the shrine. The shrine itself was nice and is definitely worth a stop if you have sometime in Tokyo. There were a couple of wedding processions going on, so that was pretty neat to soak in during my time there. It is a nice escape from the busy-ness of this cool city.

Serene and peaceful. I went to the shrine twice during my visit as it was the most serene and pleasant place that i have been too. The place gives you a different feeling all together. Before u reach the entrance, there will be a tori entrance whereby the wood smells like sandalwood. the whole wood comes from one piece of wood. its amazing how the entrance is made.the temple has some special enegry which keeps you rejuvenated. I must visit.... when you are in tokyo

Visit on a Sunday morning and you may be in for a treat.. If you can visit the Meiji Shrine on a Sunday morning you might get a chance to see a wonderful part of Japanese culture. I went on a Sunday in mid-May and it was alive with activity. There was a tea master’s ceremony going on, along with several traditional Japanese Shinto weddings. With all the excitement going on it is easy to forget you and in downtown Tokyo and not a rural, tree covered village. Even if you can't make it on a Sunday see the shrine that is the most important and beautiful in the City.

Stunning. What a fantastic place - quite the highlight of Tokyo, for me. The wooden temple itself is lovely - very impressive, and a remarkably peaceful place. The surrounding woods are very pleasant too, and the empress's stunning garden is a must-see.

Meiji Shrine in Autumn. I visited the Meiji Shrine last week (around Nov. 18th) and was struck by the size & beauty of the grounds. Many meticulously groomed plants & trees line the winding walkway to the shrine itself & approaching the building was the most diverse display of chrysanthemums I've seen. I was lucky enough to witness a marriage ceremony & there were children running about in kimonos, contributing to a nearly intoxicating cultural & spiritual experience. The highlight of my visit was seeing the fruit & vegetable offerings from all of the different areas of Japan. My wife was able to locate what I believe were persimmons from her home prefecture of Yamanashi. One tip- when passing through the entry-way of the gate, make sure to step OVER the wooden step in the door frame. Apparently it's bad luck to step ON it.
